context: Patient: Pharmacists maintain that doctors should not be permitted to sell the medicine that they prescribe because doctors would then be tempted to prescribe unnecessary medicines in order to earn extra income. But pharmacists have a financial interest in having a monopoly on the sale of prescription medicines, so their objection to the sale of medicines by doctors cannot be taken seriously.
question: What is the rationale for the patient's argument attempting to discredit a position by questioning the motives of the proponents of that position?
answers: Lack of pharmacists' knowledge was not highlighted in the argument against putting them in charge of prescriptions
The patient does not invoke public opinion in their argument but instead highlights the incentive structure which introduces conflicts for pharmacists and doctors.
The patient correctly highlights that the pharmacists position also has a potential conflict of interest just like those of the doctors
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: The patient's argument proceeds by
main_answers: attempting to discredit a position by questioning the motives of the proponents of that position
rejecting a questionable position on the grounds that the general public does not support that position
pointing out an unstated assumption on which the pharmacists' argument relies and then refuting it
asserting that pharmacists lack the appropriate knowledge to have informed opinions on the subject under discussion
others.target_option: attempting to discredit a position by questioning the motives of the proponents of that position

context: Biologist: A careful study of the behavior of six individual chameleons concluded that lizards such as chameleons bask in the sun not only for warmth but also to regulate their production of vitamin D. Critics of the study -- although correct in observing that its sample size was very small -- are wrong to doubt its results. After all, the study' s author is well regarded professionally and has been doing excellent work for years.
question: Why is the biologist's argument considered vulnerable to criticism for focusing its attention on the study's author rather than on the study itself?
answers: The writer refers here to focusing on who wrote the conclusion, the study's writer, rather than the biologist's work and study, which may be redirection.
Here, the author points towards conclusions of a sub set of chameleon, correlating with the entire set of lizard family, as a whole.
comparatively holds the researcher of biology in question, to a differing standard than the critics of said study.
ignores the educated and well received expert perspective, of the critics of the biologist researcher, in question.
label: A

others.main_question: The reasoning in the biologist's argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the argument
main_answers: focuses its attention on the study's author rather than on the study itself
takes the behavior of chameleons to be generalizable to lizards as a whole
fails to demonstrate that the study's critics have relevant expertise
holds the study's author to a higher standard than it holds the study's critics
others.target_option: focuses its attention on the study's author rather than on the study itself

context: Detective: Laser-printer drums are easily damaged, and any nick in a drum will produce a blemish of similar dimensions on each page produced by that printer. So in matching a blemish on a page with a nick on a drum, we can reliably trace a suspicious laser-printed document to the precise printer on which it was produced.
question: Explain why the fact that most suspicious documents are not produced on laser printers does not weaken the detective's argument.
answers: This weakens the argument because it tells the reader that perhaps an identical or very similar blemish could be coming from more than one printer which would make tracing the document back to the exact printer very difficult if not impossible.

This does not weaken the detective’s argument because his argument does not include that most suspicious documents are or are not produced on laser printers. He is only saying that a blemish on a laser printer produced document can be traced back to the printer.
The argument does not bring up anything about the expertise or skill level needed to accurately determine the size and shape of the drum nick, only that it can be traced back.

Again, this does not weaken the argument because the detective is not saying criminals do or not use their own laser printers and is merely stating that the document with a blemish can be traced back to the printer that was used regardless of who owns or does not own it.
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the detective's argument?
main_answers: Most suspicious documents are not produced on laser printers.
Criminals are unlikely to use their own laser printers to produce suspicious documents.
Drum nicks are usually so small that it requires skill to accurately determine their size and shape.
The manufacturing process often produces the same nick on several drums.
others.target_option: Most suspicious documents are not produced on laser printers.

context: Department store manager: There is absolutely no reason to offer our customers free gift wrapping again this holiday season. If most customers take the offer, it will be expensive and time-consuming for us. On the other hand, if only a few customers want it, there is no advantage in offering it.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the department store manager's argument does not require the assumption that anything that slows down shoppers during the holiday season costs the store money?
answers: The manager does not list the outcome if a moderate amount of customer wanted gift wrapping.
The manager does not mention rising costs or the need to charge for gift wrapping.
The manager claims it is only expensive if the customer takes the offer and not if the customer rejects the offer.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the department store manager's argument?
main_answers: It would be expensive to inform customers about the free gift wrapping service.
Gift wrapping would cost the store more during this holiday season than in previous holiday seasons.
Either few customers would want free gift wrapping or most customers would want it.
Anything that slows down shoppers during the holiday season costs the store money.
others.target_option: Anything that slows down shoppers during the holiday season costs the store money.

context: The use of space-based satellites to study environmental conditions on Earth is an important development in the conservation movement' s history. Environmental problems may now be observed long before they otherwise would be noticed, allowing for intervention before they reach the crisis stage. It is no wonder that environmentalists fail to consider both that spacecraft may damage the ozone layer and that this damage could be serious enough to warrant discontinuing spaceflight.
question: How does the reasoning above closely conform to the principle that people tend to ignore possible objectionable consequences of actions that support their activities?
answers: Despite the negative impacts of satellite use being mentioned, there is no mention of negative impacts of technology as a whole.
In support of satellites showing environmental concerns earlier than able to be shown before, environmentalists overlook the environmental problems caused by the use of the satellites.
The problem proposed is with ignoring negative impacts all together rather than not weighing them against positive impacts.
The damages related to the satellites are not being associated with being unforeseen but more so ignored.
label: B

others.main_question: The reasoning above most closely conforms to which one of the following principles?
main_answers: People tend to ignore possible objectionable consequences of actions that support their activities.
Attempts to employ technology often have unforeseen consequences that may be negative.
Technology usually has at least some negative impact on the environment, even if it is largely beneficial.
A negative consequence of an activity may be outweighed by its great positive consequences.
others.target_option: People tend to ignore possible objectionable consequences of actions that support their activities.

context: Life on Earth depends on water. Unfortunately, water is the world' s most threatened natural resource as a result of unrelenting pollution. In the near future, wars will be fought over clean drinking water, as climate change reduces the amount of potable water and pollution taints the drinking water. However, this trend can be broken. Citizens around the globe can aggressively lobby their governments to invest in sustainable energy sources, cleanup polluted waterways, and implement regulations to prevent commercial dumping. Citizens can also have a lasting impact by recycling and taking other steps to reduce their household' s biological footprint. As long as citizens actively respond, then the crisis can be mitigated.
question: Explain why the argument's primary purpose is not to criticize the status quo in government.
answers: The benefits of recycling are only one of several actions that the author suggests.
The author doesn't imply that citizens are unaware of the consequences of pollution, and instead gives suggestions of how to act.
The author does not criticize the government, but instead calls on citizens to act.
The author encourages citizens to act, and suggests several actions that they can take.
label: C

others.main_question: What is the argument's primary purpose?
main_answers: To criticize the status quo in government.
To spur activism amongst citizens.
To inform citizens about the consequences of continued pollution.
To promote the benefits of recycling.
others.target_option: To criticize the status quo in government.

context: Opponents of peat harvesting in this country argue that it would alter the ecological balance of our peatrich wetlands and that, as a direct consequence of this, much of the country' s water supply would be threatened with contamination. But this cannot be true, for in Ireland, where peat has been harvested for centuries, the water supply is not contaminated. We can safely proceed with the harvesting of peat.
question: Why does the fact that the peat-harvesting industry of Ireland has been able to supply most of that country's fuel for generations not strengthen the argument?
answers: The success of past peat-harvesting in supplying fuel does not mean that there were no unintended consequences such as damage to the environment and contamination of the water supply, or that there would be no such consequences in the future.
Change in ecological balance caused by industry can be much more abrupt than more gradual natural change, and even natural change is not always beneficial.
The fact that other industries threaten the water supply does not mean that peat-harvesting will not harm it, and the existence of other threats makes it even more important to avoid further harms.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?
main_answers: The peat-harvesting industry of Ireland has been able to supply most of that country's fuel for generations.
The original ecology of the peat-harvesting areas of Ireland was virtually identical to that of the undisturbed wetlands of this country.
Over hundreds of years, the ecological balance of all areas changes slowly but significantly, sometimes to the advantage of certain flora and fauna.
The activities of other industries in coming years are likely to have adverse effects on the water supply of this country.
others.target_option: The peat-harvesting industry of Ireland has been able to supply most of that country's fuel for generations.

context: In a study, pairs of trained dogs were placed side by side and given a command such as "sit. " After both obeyed the command, one dog was given a treat while its partner was given no reward at all. Over time, the dogs who went unrewarded began to disobey the command. This shows that dogs have an aversion to being treated unfairly.
question: Why is it not necessary to know whether dogs who were accustomed to receiving regular rewards prior to the study were more inclined to obey the command in order to evaluate the argument?
answers: A dog that is accustomed to receiving rewards would respond to the reward, not to the fairness of the trial.
A dog receiving treats in one trial and not in the other does not address whether the dog is responding to the fairness of the trial, or the treat itself.
The number of repetitions that occurred before disobedience does not change the outcome.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following would be most useful to know in order to evaluate the argument?
main_answers: Were dogs who were accustomed to receiving regular rewards prior to the study more inclined to obey the command?
How many repetitions were required before the unrewarded dogs began to disobey the command?
Is there a decline in obedience if rewards are withheld from both dogs in the pair?
Were dogs who received treats in one trial ever used as dogs that did not receive treats in other trials?
others.target_option: Were dogs who were accustomed to receiving regular rewards prior to the study more inclined to obey the command?

context: Traveler: Southern Airways has a far worse safety record than Air Dacentaria over the past few years, in terms of both the frequency of accidents and the severity of accidents. Ttherefore, although Air Dacentaria is slightly more expensive, I will choose it over Southern Airways for my flight from Pederton to Dacenta, since it is worth paying extra to have a safer flight.
question: How does the fact that most Southern Airways flights, but not its flight from Pederton to Dacenta, use Sarmouth airport, which because of its mountainous location is one of the world's most dangerous, cast serious doubt on the traveler's argument?
answers: If both have small amounts of accidents it would lead you to believe that there can be safety issue regardless of what you fly.
Because Southern Airways flyies through an airport that has dangerous mountains the cause of it having a poor safety rating good be attributed to this.
There is not enough evidence to suggest that stopping in Gorinda makes Southern Airways less safe.

context: The advanced technology of ski boots and bindings has brought a dramatic drop in the incidence of injuries that occur on the slopes of ski resorts: from 9 injuries per 1, 000 skiers in 1950 to 3 in 1980. As a result, the remainder of ski-related injuries, which includes all injuries occurring on the premises of a ski resort but not on the slopes, rose from 10 percent of all ski-related injuries in 1950 to 25 percent in 1980. The incidence of these injuries, including accidents such as falling down steps, increases with the amount of alcohol consumed per skier.
question: What is the basis for inferring that injuries that occurred on the slopes of ski resorts made up a smaller percentage of ski-related injuries in 1980 than in 1950 from the passage?
answers: It just says the percentage increases not the total amount.
This cannot be assumed because there will be a point in which this relationship will peak.

This was stated as the first statement that ski injuries have dropped in percentage over that time.

context: Tony: Few anarchists have ever performed violent actions. These few are vastly outnumbered by the violent adherents of other political ideologies. Ttherefore, the special association in the public mind between anarchism and political violence is unwarranted. Keisha: Anarchists have always been few in number, whereas other ideologies have often spawned mass movements. Ttherefore, the proportion of anarchists who are violent is possibly greater than the proportion of adherents of other ideologies who are violent.
question: Why does Keisha's response not involve presenting evidence that the two groups Tony has compared have no significant qualities in common?
answers: She brings up two pieces of evidence, that Anarchists are few in number, and that other ideologies often spawn mass movements, which are compatible with Tony's evidence that few anarchists have ever been violent and they are vastly outnumbered by other ideologies.
It is more likely that association in the public mind is due to a proportional basis rather than absolute numbers.
Anarchists having been few in numbers compared to other ideologies is not equivalent to having nothing in common.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Keisha responds to Tony's argument in which one of the following ways?
main_answers: She attempts to undermine Tony's conclusion by introducing plausible evidence that is incompatible with the evidence Tony offers in support of that conclusion.
She presents evidence that the two groups Tony has compared have no significant qualities in common.
She shows that Tony's conclusion is questionable because Tony bases it on a comparison that inappropriately involves absolute numbers rather than proportions.
She questions the accuracy of the claims on which Tony bases his conclusion.
others.target_option: She presents evidence that the two groups Tony has compared have no significant qualities in common.

context: A certain cultivated herb is one of a group of closely related plants that thrive in soil with high concentrations of metals that are toxic to most other plants. Agronomists studying the growth of this herb have discovered that it produces large amounts of histidine, an amino acid that, in test-tube solutions, renders these metals chemically inert. Hence, the herb's high histidine production must be the key feature that allows it to grow in metal-rich soils.
question: Why is it not necessary to determine whether the herb can thrive in soil that does not have high concentrations of the toxic metals in order to evaluate the argument?
answers: What growing the herb in soil over time does to the concentration in the soil has no bearing on the premise of the argument and histidine production rendering the metals inert.
Thriving in soil that does not contain toxic metals would not support or disprove whether histidine production helps in metal rich soils.
Unless the low level production of another amino acid could render the metals present inert and reduce their toxification, it would not matter in evaluating the argument.
If other pllants produce histidine in large quantities but do not grow well in metal rich soils, then histidine production could not be the key feature that allows for such growth.
label: B

others.main_question: In evaluating the argument, it would be most important to determine which of the following?
main_answers: Whether the herb can thrive in soil that does not have high concentrations of the toxic metals
Whether growing the herb in soil with high concentrations of the metals will, over time, reduce their concentrations in the soil
Whether the herb's high level of histidine production is associated with an unusually low level of production of some other amino acid
Whether others of the closely related group of plants also produce histidine in large quantities
others.target_option: Whether the herb can thrive in soil that does not have high concentrations of the toxic metals

context: Environmentalist: An increased number of oil spills and the consequent damage to the environment indicate the need for stricter safety standards for the oil industry. Since the industry refuses to take action, it is the national government that must regulate industry safety standards. In particular, the government has to at least require oil companies to put double hulls on their tankers and to assume financial responsibility for accidents. Industry representative: The industry alone should be responsible for devising safety standards because of its expertise in handling oil and its understanding of the cost entailed. Implementing the double-hull proposal is not currently feasible because it creates new safety issues. Furthermore, the cost would be burdensome to the industry and consumers.
question: Why does the argument of the environmentalist not depend on the assumption that government safety regulations are developed in a process of negotiation with industry leaders and independent experts?
answers: Environmentalists are not calling for the outright ban of the oil industry, but rather accepting financial responsibility for potential negative environmental consequences or preventing negative outcomes.
Not enough information is provided on the cost of double hull tankers and the cost savings from reduction of potential spills.

Environmentalists believe that because the oil  industry is not willing to adopt costly solutions to prevent environmental damage or incorporate the negative externalities into the true social cost of their industry from potential spills, then government is needed to establish the needed safety standards.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument of the environmentalist depends?
main_answers: Government safety regulations are developed in a process of negotiation with industry leaders and independent experts.
Environmental concerns outweigh all financial considerations when developing safety standards.
The requirement of two hulls on oil tankers, although initially costly, will save money over time by reducing cleanup costs.
The only effective sources of increased stringency in safety standards for oil tankers are action by the industry itself or national government regulation.
others.target_option: Government safety regulations are developed in a process of negotiation with industry leaders and independent experts.

context: The conventional process for tanning leather uses large amounts of calcium oxide and sodium sulfide. Tanning leather using biological catalysts costs about the same as using these conventional chemicals if the cost of waste disposal is left out of the comparison. However, nearly 20 percent less waste is produced with biological catalysts, and waste disposal is a substantial part of the overall cost of tanning. It is ttherefore less costly to tan leather if biological catalysts are used instead.
question: What is the reasoning that the argument does not require the assumption that leather tanned using the conventional process is not lower in quality than is leather tanned using biological catalysts?
answers: The argument does not rely on any assumptions in the quality of the leather.

The argument states that the only significant difference in costs between the biological catalyst process and the conventional process comes from the cost of waste disposal, so it does not rely on any assumption that the biological catalysts themselves are cheaper than the chemicals used in the conventional process.

The argument states that the only significant difference in costs between the biological catalyst process and the conventional process comes from the cost of waste disposal, so it does not rely on any assumption around labor costs.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument?
main_answers: Leather tanned using the conventional process is not lower in quality than is leather tanned using biological catalysts.
Disposal of tanning waste produced with biological catalysts does not cost significantly more than disposal of the same amount of waste produced with the conventional process.
The biological catalysts that can be used in the tanning process are less costly by weight than are calcium oxide and sodium sulfide.
The labor costs associated with tanning leather using biological catalysts are not any greater than the labor costs associated with the conventional tanning process.
others.target_option: Leather tanned using the conventional process is not lower in quality than is leather tanned using biological catalysts.

context: A luxury apartment condo recently opened up along the Biltmore's waterfront. Within the first two months, 80% of the standard units in the first ten of the condo's twelve stories were sold. Nonetheless, only two of the eight penthouses, all of which are located in the top two stories of the building, have sold. In order to sell the remaining six penthouses, the corporation that owns the property, should drop the rate of the penthouses by 20%.
question: Explain why the fact that Biltmore has recently suffered a recession and economists do not predict an imminent recovery does not argue against the proposal?
answers: There is no evidence that any specific reduction in price would result in penthouses being sold as compared to regular units.
A recession that does not have an end in sight would not suggest a simple reduction in price would cause high end properties to sell.
Even if a standard units sell first, with eighty percent sold, it would be likely a higher percentage of penthouses would have started to sell after the first one.
If there are stricter standards to buy certain units, it would be more likely that those units would sell slower as there would be a smaller pool of potential buyers that would meet those standards.
label: B

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, would argue against the proposal above?

After the proposed discount each penthouse will only be 15% more costly than a standard unit.
Typically, the very first unit to sell in a luxury condo is a standard unit.
There have been so many buyers ready to purchase the penthouses that apartment management has been carefully selecting those applicants with the best credit histories.
others.target_option: Biltmore has recently suffered a recession and economists do not predict an imminent recovery.

In the passage if not not overlook the fact that there may be a high dropout rate.

context: Dario: The government should continue to grant patents for all new drug compounds. Patents promote innovation by rewarding pharmaceutical companies for undertaking the costly research needed to develop new drugs. Cynthia: Promoting innovation is certainly important. For this reason, patents should be granted only for truly innovative drugs, not for minor variants of previously existing drugs. Since it is much less expensive to tweak an existing drug than to develop a wholly new one, pharmaceutical companies tend to focus primarily on the cheaper alternative.
question: What is the source of the disagreement between Dario and Cynthia regarding whether patents should be granted for all drug compounds?
answers: Dario does not refute Cynthia's argument that pharmaceutical companies are incentivized to create minor variants.
Cynthia agrees with Dario that drug patents can promote innovation if truly innovative drugs are patented.
Cynthia agrees with Dario that developing new innovative drugs is costly.
Dario believes that patents should be granted for all new drugs, while Cynthia believes they should not be granted for drugs that are minor variants of existing drugs.
label: D

others.main_question: Dario and Cynthia disagree over whether
main_answers: patents should be granted for all drug compounds
developing truly innovative drugs is costly
drug patents can promote innovation
pharmaceutical companies have an incentive to create minor variants of existing drugs
others.target_option: patents should be granted for all drug compounds

context: On the first day of the course, a philosophy professor told the class that no student has ever earned an A without reading all of the mandatory books. Jorge read all of the mandatory books and suggested course materials for his philosophy course. Ttherefore, Jorge will earn an A in his philosophy course.
question: What evidence is there that the argument does not commit the mistake of confusing probability and certainty?
answers: There is no mention of probability related to reading of coursework in the passage, rather it is a requirement to have a chance at getting an A.
Correlation and causation is not applicable here, as it does not state that all students that read the course work get an A.
There is no relative or absolute condition in the passage.
It is necessary to read all the course material to get an A, but it is not sufficient enough of a condition to guarantee an A.

main_answers: It confuses probability and certainty.

context: Sponges attach to the ocean floor, continually filtering seawater for food and ejecting water they have just filtered to avoid reingesting it. Tubular and vase-shaped sponges can eject filtered water without assistance from surrounding ocean currents and thus are adapted to slow-moving, quiet waters. Because of their shape, however, these sponges cannot live in strong currents, since strong currents would dislodge them. Both of these varieties of sponge were widespread during the late Jurassic period.
question: Why does the evidence not strongly support the claim that no types of sponge live in large colonies, since sponges do not flourish in areas where much of the water has been filtered by other sponges?
answers: The passage indicates that specific types of sponge prefer weaker currents and also were widespread in the late Jurassic, supporting this conclusion.
The passage mentions the current strength tolerances of only tubular and vase-shaped sponges, not of any other sponges.
The passage mentions sponges in the context of only one time period, the late Jurassic.
The passage does not address the ability of sponges to tolerate the presence of other sponges in close proximity.
label: D

others.main_question: The statements above, if true, most strongly support which one of the following claims?
main_answers: No types of sponge live in large colonies, since sponges do not flourish in areas where much of the water has been filtered by other sponges.
Few tubular or vase-shaped sponges lived before the late Jurassic period.
During the late Jurassic period there were many areas of the ocean floor where currents were weak.
All sponges that are neither tubular nor vase-shaped inhabit areas of the ocean floor where there are extremely strong currents.
others.target_option: No types of sponge live in large colonies, since sponges do not flourish in areas where much of the water has been filtered by other sponges.

context: H. G Wells' s great dramatic novel The Time Machine is classified as science fiction simply because it takes place in the future. But this classification is inappropriate because Wells' s book possesses something that great dramatic novels have and science fiction generally lacks -- compelling characters that enable the reader to become absorbed in their plight and not just in the author' s representation of the future of technology.
question: Why does the argument's conclusion follow logically if it is assumed that a dramatic novel cannot both be great and belong to the genre of science fiction?
answers: The author concludes that every novel book being classified, always cleanly fits into a specific genre of book, tidily.

The author concludes that a specific object/book can only qualify for a level of quality (i.e. greatness) if and only if a particular subjective trait, "compelling characters" - are present in the specific object/book.

The author states that because a particular genre of book category, generally does not have a subjective trait of compelling characters, that a book classified in said category, cannot be a member of said category, science fiction, because this book does indeed have compelling characters.
The author states comparatively that a particular book which,  has the trait of compelling characters, automatically qualifies, to be a member of a particular book category.
label: C

others.main_question: The argument's conclusion follows logically if which one of the following is assumed?
main_answers: All novels that contain compelling characters are great dramatic novels.
Novels can always be clearly classified into distinct genres.
A dramatic novel cannot both be great and belong to the genre of science fiction.
A work of science fiction cannot achieve greatness unless it contains compelling characters.
others.target_option: A dramatic novel cannot both be great and belong to the genre of science fiction.

context: Archaeologist: After the last ice age, groups of paleohumans left Siberia and crossed the Bering land bridge, which no longer exists, into North America. Archaeologists have discovered in Siberia a cache of Clovis points -- the distinctive stone spear points made by paleohumans. This shows that, contrary to previous belief, the Clovis point was not invented in North America.
question: How does the fact that archaeologists have discovered in Siberia artifacts that date from after the time paleohumans left Siberia not strengthen the archaeologist's argument?
answers: Artifacts found after the paleohumans left Siberia weakens the argument as it goes against the main argument and the importance of finding stuff before the paleohumans left.
Finding older Clovis points in Siberia means that Clovis points cannot be invented in North America, since invented means first created.
Knowing if migrants returned or not doesn't really matter as it does not relate to the invention of the Clovis point.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, would most strengthen the archaeologist's argument?
main_answers: Archaeologists have discovered in Siberia artifacts that date from after the time paleohumans left Siberia.
The Clovis points found in Siberia are older than any of those that have been found in North America.
Clovis points were more effective hunting weapons than earlier spear points had been.
Some paleohuman groups that migrated from Siberia to North America via the Bering land bridge eventually returned to Siberia.

question: How does the fact that the Clovis points found in Siberia are older than any of those that have been found in North America strengthen the archaeologist's argument?
answers: Knowing if migrants returned or not doesn't really matter as it does not relate to the invention of the Clovis point.
Artifacts found after the paleohumans left Siberia weakens the argument as it goes against the main argument and the importance of finding stuff before the paleohumans left.
Finding older Clovis points in Siberia means that Clovis points cannot be invented in North America, since invented means first created.
None of the above choices

context: A recent study involved feeding a high-salt diet to a rat colony. A few months after the experiment began, standard tests of the rats' blood pressure revealed that about 25 percent of the colony had normal, healthy blood pressure, about 70 percent of the colony had high blood pressure, and 5 percent of the colony had extremely high blood pressure. The conclusion from these results is that high-salt diets are linked to high blood pressure in rats.
question: Why is it necessary to answer the question of how many rats in the colony studied had abnormally high blood pressure before the study began in order to evaluate the conclusion drawn above?
answers: A baseline is needed in order to conclude that the blood pressure levels increased during the study period.
The aim of the study was not to determine how much salt caused high blood pressure.
The existence of other rat colonies that feed on high salt diets does not change the fact that it leads to high blood pressure.
Another species of rodent having increased blood pressure from a high salt diet cannot be used to conclude the same results in rats.
label: A

others.main_question: The answer to which one of the following questions is most relevant to evaluating the conclusion drawn above?
main_answers: How many rats in the colony studied had abnormally high blood pressure before the study began?
How much more salt than is contained in a rat's normal diet was there in the high-salt diet?
What percentage of naturally occurring rat colonies feed on high-salt diets?
Have other species of rodents been used in experiments of the same kind?
others.target_option: How many rats in the colony studied had abnormally high blood pressure before the study began?

context: Carl: Researchers who perform operations on animals for experimental purposes are legally required to complete detailed pain protocols indicating whether the animals will be at risk of pain and, if so, what steps will be taken to minimize or alleviate it. Yet when human beings undergo operations, such protocols are never required. If lawmakers were as concerned about human beings as they seem to be about animals, there would be pain protocols for human beings too. Debbie: But consider this: a person for whom a doctor wants to schedule surgery can simply be told what pain to expect and can then decide whether or not to undergo the operation. So you see, pain protocols are unnecessary for human beings.
question: What is the reason for why Debbie's attempt to counter Carl's argument by drawing an analogy that illustrates a major flaw in it is not successful?
answers: Debbie argument is that Carl's overlooks an important factor, and does not comment on its provability.
Debbie's argument contains an example, not an analogy.
Debbie's argument is that humans and animals differ in their ability to give informed consent, which is clearly relevant to Carl's conclusion.
Debbie does not suggest that humans and animals have differing moral worth, and so her argument cannot be characterised as an appeal to sentiment.
label: B

main_answers: drawing an analogy that illustrates a major flaw in Carl's argument
claiming that Carl's argument should be rejected because it is based on an appeal to sentimentality rather than on reasoned principles
pointing out a relevant difference to undermine an analogy on which Carl bases his conclusion
offering a specific example to demonstrate that Carl's argument is based on a claim that can be neither confirmed nor disproved
others.target_option: drawing an analogy that illustrates a major flaw in Carl's argument

context: Engine noise from boats travelling through killer whales' habitats ranges in frequency from 100 hertz to 3, 000 hertz, an acoustical range that overlaps that in which the whales communicate through screams and squeals. Though killer whales do not seem to behave differently around running boat engines, engine noise from boats can be loud enough to damage their hearing over time. Ttherefore, __.
question: What is the basis for not concluding that the statement that younger killer whales are better able to tolerate engine noise from boats than older whales are logically completes the argument?
answers: The noise of the engines are in the same frequency range as the whales' communication noises, so the boats might drown out the whale noises or confuse them.
Since the engine noises affect their ability to communicate, even light boat traffic would be disruptive to their lifestyle.
The whales only hear the noises, they don't know exactly what is causing the noise. They might even try to communicate more with each other because they feel threatened by the noises.
A younger killer whale would have better hearing, and would be more bothered by the noise of the boats than an older whale who might not even hear the boat due to damaged hearing.

killer whales are most likely to prefer areas where boat traffic is present, but light
noise from boat engines may impair killer whales' ability to communicate
killer whales are less likely to attempt to communicate with one another when boat engines are operating nearby

context: Politician: We should impose a tariff on imported fruit to make it cost consumers more than domestic fruit. Otherwise, growers from other countries who can grow better fruit more cheaply will put domestic fruit growers out of business. This will result in farmland' s being converted to more lucrative industrial uses and the consequent vanishing of a unique way of life.
question: Why does the politician's recommendation not closely conform to the principle that government intervention sometimes creates more economic efficiency than free markets?
answers: The politician's recommendation does focus on the interests of its own citizens at the expense of foreign citizens, but it does not necessarily mean that this prioritization always applies.
The politician acknowledges that the recommended government intervention actually prevents creation of economic efficiency compared to allowing fully free markets.

The politician acknowledges that domestic fruit growers going out of business would result in more lucrative and efficient industrial opportunities, but frames this as an undesirable outcome because of the social problems that would result in the form of damage to traditional ways of life.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The politician's recommendation most closely conforms to which one of the following principles?
main_answers: A country should put the interests of its own citizens ahead of those of citizens of other countries.
Government intervention sometimes creates more economic efficiency than free markets.
A country should put its own economic interest over that of other countries.
Social concerns should sometimes take precedence over economic efficiency.
others.target_option: Government intervention sometimes creates more economic efficiency than free markets.

context: Some theorists argue that literary critics should strive to be value-neutral in their literary criticism. These theorists maintain that by exposing the meaning of literary works without evaluating them, critics will enable readers to make their own judgments about the works' merits. But literary criticism cannot be completely value-neutral. Thus, some theorists are mistaken about what is an appropriate goal for literary criticism.
question: Why does the argument's conclusion follow logically if it is assumed that if it is impossible to produce completely value-neutral literary criticism, then critics should not even try to be value-neutral?
answers: The passage never mentions this phenomena , this would not lead to value neutral criticism.
This passage is saying that readers should make their own judgements, not be influenced by a critic.
The line in the passage says it right out that literary criticism cannot be value neutral, so by this logic there should be no criticism.
This does not relate to the claim made because readers are not supposed to be evaluating the work.
label: C

others.main_question: The argument's conclusion follows logically if which one of the following is assumed?
main_answers: Any critic who is able to help readers make their own judgments about literary works' merits should strive to produce value-neutral criticism.
If it is impossible to produce completely value- neutral literary criticism, then critics should not even try to be value-neutral.
The less readers understand the meaning of a literary work, the less capable they will be of evaluating that work's merits.
Critics are more likely to provide criticisms of the works they like than to provide criticisms of the works they dislike.
others.target_option: If it is impossible to produce completely value- neutral literary criticism, then critics should not even try to be value-neutral.

context: Almost all of the books published in the past 150 years were printed on acidic paper. Unfortunately, every kind of acidic paper gradually destroys itself due to its very acidity. This process of deterioration can be slowed if the books are stored in a cool, dry environment. Techniques, which are now being developed, to deacidify books will probably be applied only to books with historical significance.
question: Why is it not necessary to conclude that books published on acidic paper in 1900 should now all be at about the same state of deterioration in order for the statement to be true?
answers: This is false since the deacidification process is only now being developed.
Deacidifying books is just under development so only historically significant books will be prioritized
This is false because the rate of deterioration can be slowed by the environment in which they are stored.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: If all of the statements in the passage above are true, which one of the following must also be true?

Almost all of the books published in the past 150 years will gradually destroy themselves.
Books published on acidic paper in 1900 should now all be at about the same state of deterioration.
If a book is of historical significance and was printed before 150 years ago, it will be deacidified.
others.target_option: Books published on acidic paper in 1900 should now all be at about the same state of deterioration.

context: When politicians describe their opponents' positions, they typically make those positions seem implausible and unattractive. In contrast, scholars try to make opposing positions seem as plausible and attractive as possible. Doing so makes their arguments against those positions more persuasive to their professional colleagues. Politicians should take note: they could persuade more voters with their arguments if they simply followed the scholars in charitably formulating their opponents' positions.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument considered vulnerable to criticism for failing to address the possibility that an approach that works with one kind of audience will not work with another?
answers: The does not address the possibility that professional scholars may react differently to the suggested approach than will the general public.
The audiences for the two styles are clearly different in this case, and so suitability to similar audiences is not relevant.
Any such difficulty in producing charitable formulations would apply equally to both scholars and politicians, and so it's absence is not a weakness in reasoning.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The reasoning in the argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that it
main_answers: fails to address the possibility that an approach that works with one kind of audience will not work with another
takes for granted that both scholars and politicians have persuasion as their aim
fails to account for the difficulty of coming up with charitable formulations of positions to which one is opposed
focuses on the differences between two styles of argumentation even though those styles might be suited to similar audiences
others.target_option: fails to address the possibility that an approach that works with one kind of audience will not work with another

context: Doctors in Britain have long suspected that patients who wear tinted eyeglasses are abnormally prone to depression and hypochondria. Psychological tests given there to hospital patients admitted for physical complaints like heart pain and digestive distress confirmed such a relationship. Perhaps people whose relationship to the world is psychologically painful choose such glasses to reduce visual stimulation, which is perceived as irritating. At any rate, it can be concluded that when such glasses are worn, it is because the wearer has a tendency to be depressed or hypochondriacal.
question: What is the reason for why the argument does not assume that for hypochondriacs wearing tinted glasses, the glasses serve as a visual signal to others that the wearer's health is delicate?

context: Crops can be traded on the futures market before they are harvested. If a poor corn harvest is predicted, prices of corn futures rise; if a bountiful corn harvest is predicted, prices of corn futures fall. This morning meteorologists are predicting much-needed rain for the corn-growing region starting tomorrow. Ttherefore, since adequate moisture is essential for the current crop' s survival, prices of corn futures will fall sharply today.
question: Explain why the fact that futures prices for corn have been fluctuating more dramatically this season than last season does not weaken the argument.
answers: Higher fluctuations could cause the corn futures to drop more dramatically, but does not alter the essential argument that more corn leads to lower prices.
Corn futures are based on the perceived future availability of corn, not on whether any one person takes possession or not.
The argument states that the rain is much needed, which implies that this is either the pollination stage or is an earlier stage necessary for the corn to survive to the pollination stage.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most weakens the argument above?
main_answers: Most people who trade in corn futures rarely take physical possession of the corn they trade.
Futures prices for corn have been fluctuating more dramatically this season than last season.
Agriculture experts announced today that a disease that has devastated some of the corn crop will spread widely before the end of the growing season.
Corn that does not receive adequate moisture during its critical pollination stage will not produce a bountiful harvest.
others.target_option: Futures prices for corn have been fluctuating more dramatically this season than last season.

context: The Interstate Bridge over the Apache River, built in the 1950s, shows a substantial amount of rust: as much as 45% of its surface is coated in rust. Community activists have argued that the bridge presents a hazard: it is likely to collapse in places where it has rusted through. Professors of mechanical engineering at the local university did an extensive analysis of the bridge. These professors and their graduate students determined that 98% of the rust on the bridge exists on the surface only, and actually seals the underlying steel from the corrosive influence of the elements. The results of this academic study suggest that the bridge is safe for continued use.
question: What is the basis for concluding that the first portion in boldface is a position that the argument opposes and the second is the conclusion of the argument?
answers: The argument is opposite of the first. The second is not evidence.
The argument is that the bridge is safe (the second bolded statement), while the first bolded statement assumes the bridge presents a hazard and is likely to collapse.
The first is an assumption, not an interpretation. The second is a conclusion.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: In the argument given, the two portions in boldface play which of the following roles?
main_answers: The first is a position that the argument opposes; the second is the conclusion of the argument.
The first is evidence taken to support one conclusion; the second provides evidence that calls this conclusion into question.
The first is the main conclusion of the argument; the second provides evidence that calls this conclusion into question.
The first is an interpretation of evidence; the second calls that evidence into question.
others.target_option: The first is a position that the argument opposes; the second is the conclusion of the argument.

context: The television show Henry was not widely watched until it was scheduled for Tuesday evenings immediately after That' s Life, the most popular show on television. During the year after the move, Henry was consistently one of the ten most-watched shows on television. Since Henry' s recent move to Wednesday evenings, however, it has been watched by far fewer people. We must conclude that Henry was widely watched before the move to Wednesday evenings because it followed That' s Life and not because people especially liked it.
question: How does the fact that the show that now follows That's Life on Tuesdays has double the number of viewers it had before being moved strengthen the argument?
answers: Henry was not popular before the move to following That’s Life, so time on the air is not really meaningful to the passage.

If this were true it doesn’t have a great deal of bearing to the passage as it is now the most popular show on television and was the most popular show on television at the time Henry was moved on the schedule to follow it.
This reiterates and lends credence to the fact that  show following the most popular show on television will also be very widely watched simply because viewers have the television on that channel.

This may help explain why Henry is no longer as successful as it was when following That’s Life due to a created challenge of going up against televisions second most popular show, but if it were really popular it would still be receiving very high ratings.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?
main_answers: The show that now follows That's Life on Tuesdays has double the number of viewers it had before being moved.
Henry has been on the air for three years, but That's Life has been on the air for only two years.
After its recent move to Wednesday, Henry was aired at the same time as the second most popular show on television.
That's Life was not widely watched during the first year it was aired.
others.target_option: The show that now follows That's Life on Tuesdays has double the number of viewers it had before being moved.

context: Numismatist: In medieval Spain, most gold coins were minted from gold mined in West Africa, in the area that is now Senegal. The gold mined in this region was the purest known. Its gold content of 92 percent allowed coins to be minted without refining the gold, and indeed coins minted from this source of gold can be recognized because they have that gold content. The mints could refine gold and produced other kinds of coins that had much purer gold content, but the Senegalese gold was never refined. As a preliminary to negotiating prices, merchants selling goods often specified that payment should be in the coins minted from Senegalese gold.
question: What is the reason for the preference not being explained by the fact that since gold coins' monetary value rested on the gold they contained, payments were frequently made using coins minted in several different countries?
answers: Using Senegalese gold coins provided a standard so that merchants could be relatively sure they were getting the proper value for their goods, whereas the value of other gold coins would be less certain due to their more variable gold content.
The preference in different situations for silver versus gold coins does not explain a preference for a specific type of gold coin in situations where gold coins were used.

The location of where gold coins were minted is not necessarily related to the source of their gold, so the mint location does not explain a preference for coins specifically minted from Senegalese gold.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to explain this preference?
main_answers: During this period most day-to-day trading was conducted using silver coins, though gold coins were used for costly transactions and long-distance commerce.
Since gold coins' monetary value rested on the gold they contained, payments were frequently made using coins minted in several different countries.
The mints were able to determine the purity, and hence the value, of gold coins by measuring their density.
Because refined gold varied considerably in purity, specifying a price as a number of refined-gold coins did not fix the quantity of gold received in payment.
others.target_option: Since gold coins' monetary value rested on the gold they contained, payments were frequently made using coins minted in several different countries.

context: Advertisement: Attention homeowners! All the pests in your yard will die within minutes of being treated by JTE pesticide. What' s better, JTE pesticide is not harmful to the birds or small animals that make your yard their home. By using JTE, you can eliminate the pests in your yard and keep the rabbits and birds.
question: What is the basis for the argument not depending on the assumption that JTE pesticide will not harm the underground water supply?
answers: The argument does not focus on what the application procedures are only discussing that it will kill pests and help you keep other animals.
The argument does not make an assumption or depend on whether or not the pesticide is approved by state or federal standards.
This is true because if it is saying it will kill all of the pests but you will still be able to keep the birds and rabbits than they do not need to pests in order to be in your yard.
The argument is in no way suggesting or making an assumption regarding the water supply.  The argument does not depend on the status of the water.
label: D

The rabbits, birds, or other small animals are not in your yard because of the pests.
The effectiveness of JTE pesticide does not depend on the strict adherence to specific application procedures.

context: Film historians have made two major criticisms of Depression-era filmmakers: first, that they were too uncritical of the economic status quo; and second, that they self-indulgently created films reflecting their own dreams and desires. However, these filmmakers made their movies with an eye to profit, and so they provided what their audiences most wanted in a film: a chance to imagine being wealthy enough not to have a care in the world. Thus, the second criticism cannot be accurate.
question: Why does the conclusion of the argument not follow logically even if it is assumed that to avoid self-indulgence, filmmakers should take a critical stance toward the existing economic system and should allow audiences to form their own personal aspirations?
answers: It may, in fact, be self-indulgent for a filmmaker to take a critical stance, depending on their desires.
Movie goers may or may not have been satisfied, we only know they went to films that were satisfied with the status quo.
The opposite is true, that filmmakers uninterested in profit are more likely to make a radical film.
A filmmaker may want to make a film critical of the economic status quo, but denies this desire to satisfy an audience.
label: A

others.main_question: The conclusion of the argument follows logically if which one of the following is assumed?
main_answers: To avoid self-indulgence, filmmakers should take a critical stance toward the existing economic system and should allow audiences to form their own personal aspirations.
It cannot be self-indulgent for a filmmaker to give an audience what it most wants.
The people who regularly went to movies during the Depression were those likely to have been most satisfied with the economic status quo.
Depression-era filmmakers who did not make films for profit could not take radical critical stances toward then-current economic and political issues.
others.target_option: To avoid self-indulgence, filmmakers should take a critical stance toward the existing economic system and should allow audiences to form their own personal aspirations.

context: Film historians have made two major criticisms of Depression-era filmmakers: first, that they were too uncritical of the economic status quo; and second, that they self-indulgently created films reflecting their own dreams and desires. Thus, the second criticism cannot be accurate.

context: It is pointless to debate the truth of the law of noncontradiction, a fundamental logical principle according to which two statements that contradict each other cannot both be true. For a debate to be productive, participants must hold some basic principles in common. But the principles held in common in a debate over the law of noncontradiction would be much less certain than that law, so it matters little whether the law of noncontradiction can be defended on the basis of those principles.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the overall conclusion of the argument is that statements that contradict each other cannot both be true?
answers: The conclusion relates to the productivity of debating whether this statement is true, not whether or not it actually is true.

The difference in certainty regarding the law of noncontradiction and the principles that could defend it are accepted as a truth in the argument, acting as a component justifying the actual conclusion being made.

The conclusion and whole argument are centered around the question of how productive and meaningful a debate on the law of noncontradiction is, with all the statements making arguments as it relates to this point.
None of the above choices
label: A

Statements that contradict each other cannot both be true.
Any principles that could be used to defend the law of noncontradiction are less certain than it is.
It is pointless to debate the truth of the law of noncontradiction.
others.target_option: Statements that contradict each other cannot both be true.

context: Government department head: We already have a code of ethics that companies doing business with the department are urged to abide by. The fact that virtually all of the companies have agreed to abide by it indicates that it is successful. Ttherefore, neither stronger ethics regulations nor enforcement mechanisms are necessary to ensure ethical behavior by companies doing business with the department.
question: Explain why the fact that the code of ethics was instituted only after it was discovered that several companies had committed serious violations of ethics in their business with the department does not cast doubt on the department head's conclusion.
answers: The companies that do business with you can still do unethical behavior with other companies.
Everyone not just the top executives need to be on board to make the agreement successful

The code of ethics was instituted only after it was discovered that several companies had committed serious violations of ethics in their business with the department.
The code of ethics applies only to companies that do business with the department.

others.target_option: The code of ethics was instituted only after it was discovered that several companies had committed serious violations of ethics in their business with the department.

context: Researcher: Every year approximately the same number of people die of iatrogenic "disease" -- that is, as a direct result of medical treatments or hospitalization -- as die of all other causes combined. Ttherefore, if medicine could find ways of preventing all iatrogenic disease, the number of deaths per year would decrease by half.
question: What is the rationale for why the researcher's argument is considered flawed for not taking into account that people who do not die of one cause may soon die of another cause?
answers: The researcher is not looking to change the rate of noniatrogenic disease.
The researcher assumes that preventing iatrogenic disease would cure the patients entirely, which is untrue.
The researcher is not looking for a single way to prevent iatrogenic disease.
The passage does not state whether iatrogenic disease is a result of invasive or damaging medical treatments
label: B

others.main_question: The reasoning in the researcher's argument is flawed because the argument fails to consider that
main_answers: people who do not die of one cause may soon die of another cause
prevention of noniatrogenic disease will have an effect on the occurrence of iatrogenic disease
some medical treatments can be replaced by less invasive or damaging alternatives
there is no one way to prevent all cases of death from iatrogenic disease
others.target_option: people who do not die of one cause may soon die of another cause

context: Insurance Company X is considering issuing a new policy to cover services required by elderly people who suffer from diseases that afflict the elderly. Premiums for the policy must be low enough to attract customers. Ttherefore, Company X is concerned that the income from the policies would not be sufficient to pay for the claims that would be made.
question: What is the rationale for not using the strategy of insuring only those individuals who are wealthy enough to pay for the medical services to minimize Company X's losses on the policies?
answers: If someone was rejected by another company than they are probably for likely to have serious health issues which would make them less profitable to insure.
Attracting middle aged customers who are healthier and less likely to file claims would be cheaper and more profitable for the company.
A wealthy individual may be more likely to shop around for a better policy and therefore would not give you the income that you are looking for.
Most children do not need insurance policies.  Therefore you will not make much of a profit selling to children.
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following strategies would be most likely to minimize Company X's losses on the policies?
main_answers: Insuring only those individuals who did not suffer any serious diseases as children
Insuring only those individuals who are wealthy enough to pay for the medical services
Insuring only those individuals who were rejected by other companies for similar policies
Attracting middle-aged customers unlikely to submit claims for benefits for many years

context: Several companies will soon offer personalized electronic news services, delivered via cable or telephone lines and displayed on a television. People using these services can view continually updated stories on those topics for which they subscribe. Since these services will provide people with the information they are looking for more quickly and efficiently than printed newspapers can, newspaper sales will decline drastically if these services become widely available.
question: Explain why the fact that approximately 30 percent of people have never relied on newspapers for information but instead have always relied on news programs broadcast on television and radio does not significantly weaken the argument.
answers: Despite the cost this does not mean that the sales of the newspaper will decline.

People also seek out and look at other information that they may not have subscribe or been looking for.  You are liking to find information that you did not know you were interested in when you look at multiple resources.
This just tells you that companies will have competing prices for the service.  It does not prove that newspaper sales will suffer.
That means there are still 70 percent who rely on newspapers which would still promote sales.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
main_answers: Approximately 30 percent of people have never relied on newspapers for information but instead have always relied on news programs broadcast on television and radio.
In reading newspapers, most people not only look for stories on specific topics but also like to idly browse through headlines or pictures for amusing stories on unfamiliar or unusual topics.
Companies offering personalized electronic news services will differ greatly in what they charge for access to their services, depending on how wide a range of topics they cover.
The average monthly cost of subscribing to several channels on a personalized electronic news service will approximately equal the cost of a month's subscription to a newspaper.
others.target_option: Approximately 30 percent of people have never relied on newspapers for information but instead have always relied on news programs broadcast on television and radio.

context: Hospitals, universities, labor unions, and other institutions may well have public purposes and be quite successful at achieving them even though each of their individual staff members does what he or she does only for selfish reasons.
question: Why does the passage not clearly illustrate the generalization that what is true of some social organizations is not necessarily true of all such organizations?
answers: The listed organizations are stated as being successful towards what they are working for and this would go along with what founders intended them to do. The passage is not discussing social consequences.

The passage was not discussing an instrument being created for one purpose but serving a different purpose entirely. The passage focused on the organizations being successful overall while employees may be working and doing things for their own selfish reasons.

The passage focuses only upon the organizations as being similar in the topic of achieving success even though the workers do things only for selfish reasons and was not comparing differences between different organizations.
The mentioned organizations often work toward the greater good and benefit of humanity even though it’s members are exhibiting selfish traits and may not possess the same overall goal of helping.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following generalizations is most clearly illustrated by the passage?
main_answers: What is true of some social organizations is not necessarily true of all such organizations.
Often an instrument created for one purpose will be found to serve another purpose just as effectively.
Many social institutions have social consequences unintended by those who founded them.
An organization can have a property that not all of its members possess.
others.target_option: What is true of some social organizations is not necessarily true of all such organizations.

context: Only an expert in some branch of psychology could understand why Patrick is behaving irrationally. But no expert is certain of being able to solve someone else' s problem. Patrick wants to devise a solution to his own behavioral problem.
question: Explain why it is not valid to conclude that, unless Charles is an expert in some branch of psychology, Charles should not offer a solution to Patrick's behavioral problem based on the passage?
answers: Even an expert can not be certain of solving a problem, so there is no reason for Patrick to be certain of solving his own problem, and that uncertainty does not mean that he can't devise a solution.

No expert is certain of being able to solve someone else's problem, and only an expert can understand Patrick's behavior; Charles is certain of being able to solve Patrick's problem, therefore Charles is not an expert and does not understand Patrick's behavior.

Patrick may or may not be an expert in psychology, because we do not know if he understands why he is behaving irrationally, and we do know that he will be solving his own problem rather than someone else's.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following conclusions can be validly drawn from the passage?
main_answers: Patrick is not certain of being able to devise a solution to his own behavioral problem.
Unless Charles is an expert in some branch of psychology, Charles should not offer a solution to Patrick's behavioral problem.
If Charles is certain of being able to solve Patrick's behavioral problem, then Charles does not understand why Patrick is behaving in this way.
Patrick is not an expert in psychology.
others.target_option: Unless Charles is an expert in some branch of psychology, Charles should not offer a solution to Patrick's behavioral problem.

context: Teachers should not do anything to cause their students to lose respect for them. And students can sense when someone is trying to hide his or her ignorance. Ttherefore, a teacher who does not know the answer to a question a student has asked should not pretend to know the answer.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the conclusion is properly drawn if it is assumed that students respect honesty above all else?
answers: The conclusion is that teachers shouldn't pretend to know the answer to a question that they don't know, so the assumption is that student's respect for a teacher is interlinked to the student's perceived knowledge of the teacher.
The conclusion does not have anything to do with a teacher being effective.
The ranking of students' respect for honesty is not relevant to the conclusion of a teacher shouldn't pretend to know an answer to question they don't know the answer to.
The assumption is that students' respect for the teacher is based on how much knowledge the teacher has.
label: C

others.main_question: The conclusion is properly drawn if which one of the following is assumed?
main_answers: Students respect honesty above all else.
Students lose respect for teachers whenever they sense that the teachers are trying to hide their ignorance.
Students' respect for a teacher is independent of the amount of knowledge they attribute to that teacher.
A teacher cannot be effective unless he or she retains the respect of students.
others.target_option: Students respect honesty above all else.

context: When storing Renaissance oil paintings, museums conform to standards that call for careful control of the surrounding temperature and humidity, with variations confined within narrow margins. Maintaining this environment is very costly, and recent research shows that even old oil paint is unaffected by wide fluctuations in temperature and humidity. Ttherefore, museums could relax their standards and save money without endangering their Renaissance oil paintings.
question: Why does the argument not depend on the assumption that most Renaissance oil paintings are stored in museums located in regions near the regions where the paintings were created?
answers: The author assumes wood frames, for example, respond to temperature like the paintings themselves.
This confuses to location of creation with the location of storage, which may have nothing to do with each other.
This may or may not be true, and we don't know if in fact temperature fluctuations did cause some damage to some paintings.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
main_answers: Renaissance paintings were created in conditions involving far greater fluctuations in temperature and humidity than those permitted by current standards.
None of the materials in Renaissance oil paintings other than the paint are vulnerable enough to relatively wide fluctuations in temperature and humidity to cause damage to the paintings.
Most Renaissance oil paintings are stored in museums located in regions near the regions where the paintings were created.
Under the current standards that museums use when storing Renaissance oil paintings, those paintings do not deteriorate at all.
others.target_option: Most Renaissance oil paintings are stored in museums located in regions near the regions where the paintings were created.

context: Rhizobium bacteria living in the roots of bean plants or other legumes produce fixed nitrogen, which is one of the essential plant nutrients and which for nonlegume crops, such as wheat, normally must be supplied by applications of nitrogen-based fertilizer. So if biotechnology succeeds in producing wheat strains whose roots will play host to Rhizobium bacteria, the need for artificial fertilizers will be reduced.
question: Explain why the argument does not make the assumption that fixed nitrogen is currently the only soil nutrient that must be supplied by artificial fertilizer for growing wheat crops.

context: Unprecedented industrial growth in the country of Remo has created serious environmental problems because factories there lack adequate pollution-control systems. Remo is developing a clean growth plan that includes environmental regulations that will require the installation of such systems. Since no companies in Remo currently produce pollution-control systems, the plan, if implemented, will create significant opportunities for foreign exporters to market pollution-control systems.
question: How does the fact that the clean growth plan will provide tax incentives for local businesses to develop and manufacture pollution-control devices weaken the argument?
answers: Stricter regulations handicap the countries that impose them on businesses so lax regulations in Remo will give a competitive advantage to local businesses which weakens the argument.
Yes such tax incentives will give local businesses a competitive advantage over imported devices which weakens the argument that the clean growth plan is an opportunity for foreign exporters.
If the lobbyists succeed and the environmental regulations are not implemented then the conclusion is entirely negated.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
main_answers: Foreign exporters would provide factory-trained technicians to maintain the pollution-control systems sold to Remo.
The clean growth plan will provide tax incentives for local businesses to develop and manufacture pollution-control devices.
The regulations that Remo plans to implement are much less strict than those in neighboring nations.
Industrial lobbyists sponsored by local businesses in Remo are trying to prevent the implementation of the government regulations.
others.target_option: The clean growth plan will provide tax incentives for local businesses to develop and manufacture pollution-control devices.

context: A recent survey showed that 50 percent of people polled believe that elected officials should resign if indicted for a crime, whereas 35 percent believe that elected officials should resign only if they are convicted of a crime. Ttherefore, more people believe that elected officials should resign if indicted than believe that they should resign if convicted.
question: Why is the reasoning not considered to be invalid due to its attempt to draw a conclusion about a specific belief based on responses to queries about two different specific beliefs?
answers: Ambiguity is asserted in an unspecified term without supporting evidence for it being present in either passage or answer.
Only one premise is advanced by the passage, namely that more people believe that elected officials should resign on being indicted than on being convicted.
The reasoning actually draws a conclusion about the relationship between TWO beliefs.

Elected officials must be first indicted in order to be convicted, thus convicted officials are also indicted officials and should be recognised as such when making numerical comparisons between the two cases.
label: C

others.main_question: The reasoning above is flawed because it
main_answers: draws a conclusion about a specific belief based on responses to queries about two different specific beliefs
contains premises that cannot all be true
confuses a sufficient condition with a required condition
is based on an ambiguity of one of its terms
others.target_option: draws a conclusion about a specific belief based on responses to queries about two different specific beliefs
