context: MetroBank made loans to ten small companies, in amounts ranging from $1, 000 to $100, 000. These ten loans all had graduated payment plans, i. e. , the scheduled monthly loan payment increased slightly each month over the five-year term of the loan. Nonetheless, the average payment received by MetroBank for these ten loans had decreased by the end of the five-year term.
question: How does the fact that of the ten small companies, the three that had borrowed the largest amounts paid off their loans within three years help to resolve the apparent discrepancy in the statements above?
answers: The amount of the loan does not matter here. If the amount of the payments increased with the life of the loan then the average payment should have also  increased and not decreased.

The test states that all the loans were graduated payment plans. By default, the payments on graduated payment plans increases with the life of the loan. None of the loans given could have had payments that decreased.

If, on a graduated payment plan, then the payments increase over the life of the loan. As payments increase, the average received would increase. The only way it would decrease is if the number of loans decreased. Since the largest amounts would have the largest payments, they would affect the average more than a small amount.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to resolve the apparent discrepancy in the statements above?
main_answers: Of the ten small companies, the three that had borrowed the largest amounts paid off their loans within three years.
For some loans made by MetroBank, the monthly payment decreases slightly over the term of the loan.
The number of small companies receiving new loans from MetroBank increased over the five-year term.
Most banks offer a greater number of loans for under $100, 000 than for over $100, 000.
others.target_option: Of the ten small companies, the three that had borrowed the largest amounts paid off their loans within three years.

context: The first publicly available fantasy football league was launched in 1997, and within three years, every major football media website had launched their own sites. From 2000 until 2015, viewership for the National Football League rose by 27 percent, and it is currently the most popular televised sport in the United States. Fantasy football heavily contributed to the increased viewership since fantasy players had a vested interest in nearly every game.
question: Why is it valid to conclude that the author's argument relies on the assumption that some fantasy players watch National Football League games?
answers: NFL revenue from television is irrelevant to fantasy players and was not mentioned by the author.
The author does not discuss the popularity of football relative to other sports, simply that the viewership increased.
The author relied on this because fantasy players have a vested interest in nearly every NFL game.
The author did not assume this, because they did not state how well the fantasy players performed.
label: C

others.main_question: Upon which one of the following assumptions does the author's argument rely?
main_answers: Some fantasy players watch National Football League games.
Fantasy football increased the play ers' knowledge of the National Football League.
Football was the least popular sport in the United States before 2000.
The National Football League earns a large portion of its revenue from high television ratings.
others.target_option: Some fantasy players watch National Football League games.

context: Restaurant critic: Most people agree that the food at Marva' s Diner is exceptional, while the food at the more popular Traintrack Inn is fairly ordinary. This discrepancy should come as no surprise, since the Traintrack Inn' s more convenient location is by itself almost enough to guarantee a steady flow of customers .
question: Explain why the principle that there is no relationship between the quality of a restaurant's food and the popularity of that restaurant does not help to justify the restaurant critic's reasoning.
answers: If you have people coming in to your restaurant based on location alone and you are profitable, there is no reason to change your products.
This passage says that the location is the most important factor for popularity.
This article does not say this is the case, it just mentions that location is a bigger factor.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following is a principle that, if valid, most helps to justify the restaurant critic's reasoning?
main_answers: The best way for a business to attract a steady flow of customers is to improve its products .
The quality of the food at a restaurant is the most important factor in its popularity.
There is no relationship between the quality of a restaurant's food and the popularity of that restaurant.
A business will improve its products only when it is necessary to do so in order to attract customers .
others.target_option: There is no relationship between the quality of a restaurant's food and the popularity of that restaurant.

context: Guitar strings often go "dead"-become less responsive and bright in tone-after a few weeks of intense use. A researcher whose son is a classical guitarist hypothesized that dirt and oil, rather than changes in the material properties of the string, were responsible.
question: What is the reason for why determining whether a metal alloy is used to make the strings used by classical guitarists is not likely to yield significant information that would help evaluate the researcher's hypothesis?
answers: Playing different styles of music on a guitar would only be relevant if the method of playing the guitar is different between styles.
It is already known as a fact that dead strings produce inferior sound quality.
Smearing new guitar strings with various substances would eliminate the passing of time as a variable which causes guitar strings to go dead.
Knowing the type of metal used in guitar strings would not explain why the string goes dead with intense use.
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following investigations is most likely to yield significant information that would help evaluate the researcher's hypothesis?
main_answers: Determining whether a metal alloy is used to make the strings used by classical guitarists
Determining whether classical guitarists make their strings go dead faster than do folk guitarists
Determining whether smearing various substances on new guitar strings causes them to go dead
Determining whether a dead string and a new string produce different qualities of sound
others.target_option: Determining whether a metal alloy is used to make the strings used by classical guitarists

context: As advances in medical research and technology have improved the ability of the medical profession to diagnose and treat a wide variety of illnesses and injuries, life spans have increased and overall health has improved. Yet, over the past few decades there has been a steady and significant increase in the rate of serious infections.
question: Explain why the fact that doctors sometimes prescribe ineffective medications due to misdiagnosis does not help to resolve the apparent discrepancy in the information above.
answers: While overall health has improved, there are individual areas that need improvement, such as eliminating infections.
A medication being ineffective wouldn't necessarily cause a person to become more susceptible to infections.
If a population has a healthy immune system, they shouldn't become vulnerable to serious infections, even if there are more people.
One of the side effects of many medical interventions for fatal illnesses, is a temporary dip in the ability of the immune system to fight off infections.
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to resolve the apparent discrepancy in the information above?
main_answers: Modern treatments for many otherwise fatal illnesses increase the patient's susceptibility to infection.
It remains true that doctors sometimes prescribe ineffective medications due to misdiagnosis.
Life spans have increased precisely because overall health has improved.
As a population increases in size, there is a directly proportional increase in the number of serious infections.
others.target_option: It remains true that doctors sometimes prescribe ineffective medications due to misdiagnosis.

question: Explain why the fact that as a population increases in size, there is a directly proportional increase in the number of serious infections does not help to resolve the apparent discrepancy in the information above.
answers: One of the side effects of many medical interventions for fatal illnesses, is a temporary dip in the ability of the immune system to fight off infections.
If a population has a healthy immune system, they shouldn't become vulnerable to serious infections, even if there are more people.
While overall health has improved, there are individual areas that need improvement, such as eliminating infections.
A medication being ineffective wouldn't necessarily cause a person to become more susceptible to infections.
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to resolve the apparent discrepancy in the information above?
main_answers: Modern treatments for many otherwise fatal illnesses increase the patient's susceptibility to infection.
It remains true that doctors sometimes prescribe ineffective medications due to misdiagnosis.
Life spans have increased precisely because overall health has improved.
As a population increases in size, there is a directly proportional increase in the number of serious infections.
others.target_option: As a population increases in size, there is a directly proportional increase in the number of serious infections.

context: In Yasukawa' s month-long study of blackbirds, the percentage of smaller birds that survived the duration of the study exceeded the percentage of larger birds that survived. However, Yasukawa' s conclusion that size is a determinant of a blackbird' s chances of survival over a month-long period is probably mistaken, since smaller blackbirds are generally younger than larger ones.
question: Why is it not valid to infer that larger blackbirds of a given age are actually more likely to survive over a one-month period than are smaller blackbirds of the same age based on the statements above?
answers: There was nothing showing larger blackbirds having a higher survival rate than smaller blackbirds of the same age.
The study attempted to link survival based on size but it could very well be due to age differences instead.
Smaller blackbirds are usually younger than bigger blackbirds.
Smaller blackbirds have a higher survival percentage regardless of sample size.
label: A

others.main_question: The statements above, if true, support which one of the following inferences?
main_answers: Among the blackbirds that survived the month-long study, there was no relation between size and age.
Among blackbirds of the same age, a difference in size may not indicate a difference in chances of survival over a month-long period.
With a larger sample of blackbirds, the percentage of smaller birds that survive a one-month period would be the same as the percentage of larger birds that survive.
Larger blackbirds of a given age are actually more likely to survive over a one-month period than are smaller blackbirds of the same age.
others.target_option: Larger blackbirds of a given age are actually more likely to survive over a one-month period than are smaller blackbirds of the same age.

context: Ethicist: Utilitarianism argues that it is good and right to act in the best interests of all entities involved, and says the best action is that which serves the maximum number of those entities. For example, making vaccination of children a requirement is considered utilitarianism because __.
question: Why does the conclusion that the policy of mandatory vaccinations does more harm than good for the receivers of the vaccinations not logically complete the argument?
answers: This follows the view of utilarianism because the idea acts in the best interest of the maximum number of people.
The point is that it is serving the most people possible regardless of whether or not there are more children than adults.  That is not relevant.
The point is not whether it does more harm than good it is looking at serving the most people possible.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following most logically completes the argument?
main_answers: it is seen as an act of serving the majority of public good.
it does more harm than good for the receivers of the vaccinations.
is considered utilitarianism because there are more children than adults in the world.
it is seen as giving the parents complete control over the decisions they make for their children.
others.target_option: it does more harm than good for the receivers of the vaccinations.

context: Kim: Some people claim that the battery-powered electric car represents a potential solution to the problem of air pollution. But they forget that it takes electricity to recharge batteries and that most of our electricity is generated by burning polluting fossil fuels. Increasing the number of electric cars on the road would require building more generating facilities since current facilities are operating at maximum capacity. So even if all of the gasoline-powered cars on the roads today were replaced by electric cars, it would at best be an exchange of one source of fossil-fuel pollution for another.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that Kim's argument does not focus on the claim that gasoline-powered cars will probably remain a common means of transportation for the foreseeable future?
answers: Kim's argument makes no prediction as to the relative popularities of gasoline  and gasoline-powered cars.
This assertion that more energy generation will be required is made, but is not the main point of Kim's argument.
Kim argues that electric cars will indeed not reduce overall emissions compared to gasoline-powered cars, due their need for emission-producing electricity generation.
Kim's argument assesses only one cause of air pollution, and cannot be generalised to include all possible causes.
label: A

others.main_question: The main point made in Kim's argument is that
main_answers: gasoline-powered cars will probably remain a common means of transportation for the foreseeable future
a significant reduction in air pollution cannot be achieved unless people drive less
replacing gasoline-powered cars with battery- powered electric cars will require building more generating facilities
battery-powered electric cars are not a viable solution to the air-pollution problem
others.target_option: gasoline-powered cars will probably remain a common means of transportation for the foreseeable future

context: Miguel has four family members who plan to come to his graduation on Sunday afternoon, but it is likely that only three of them will be allowed to attend. Normally graduation is held in the football stadium, where there is no limit on the number of family members who can attend. However, the ceremony is relocated to the gymnasium if it rains, and each graduate receives just three admission tickets for use by family members.
question: Why does the conclusion of the argument not strongly depend on the assumption that Miguel has several friends who have fewer than three family members coming to graduation?
answers: No mention is made of whether un-needed spaces can be transferred between students, and so this cannot be assumed to impact the number of spaces available to Miguel's family.
Rain would preclude the use of the stadium which has no limit of the number of family members attending and force the use of the gymnasium, which limits the number attending to three.
A family member who cannot attend the graduation has no relevance to how many may be allowed to attend.
Abnormally large class size may not preclude Miguel from having more than three family members attend, as the football stadium is a possible venue and has no limitation on the number who may attend.
label: A

others.main_question: The conclusion of the argument is most strongly supported if which one of the following is assumed?
main_answers: Miguel has several friends who have fewer than three family members coming to graduation.
Miguel's graduating class is much larger than usual.
Miguel has a fifth family member who is unable to come to his graduation.
The weather service has indicated that there is a very high likelihood of rain on Sunday afternoon.
others.target_option: Miguel has several friends who have fewer than three family members coming to graduation.

context: Our tomato soup provides good nutrition: for instance, a warm bowl of it contains more units of vitamin C than does a serving of apricots or fresh carrots!
question: Explain why the advertisement is not considered to be misleading if it is true that a liquid can lose vitamins if it stands in contact with the air for a protracted period of time.
answers: Because the soup is higher than these chosen fruits and vegetables is convenient since they are not known for being high in these values.
The passage is assuming that the people eat the soup before it loses nutrients.
Strawberries are never mentioned in the passage, making it irrelevant.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The advertisement is misleading if which one of the following is true?
main_answers: Few people depend exclusively on apricots and carrots to supply vitamin C to their diets.
A liquid can lose vitamins if it stands in contact with the air for a protracted period of time.
The amount of vitamin C provided by a serving of the advertised soup is less than the amount furnished by a serving of fresh strawberries.
Apricots and fresh carrots are widely known to be nutritious, but their contribution consists primarily in providing a large amount of vitamin A, not a large amount of vitamin C.
others.target_option: A liquid can lose vitamins if it stands in contact with the air for a protracted period of time.

context: One should apologize only to a person one has wronged, and only for having wronged that person. To apologize sincerely is to acknowledge that one has acted wrongfully. One cannot apologize sincerely unless one intends not to repeat that wrongful act. To accept an apology sincerely is to acknowledge a wrong, but also to vow not to hold a grudge against the wrongdoer.
question: Why does the evidence not strongly support the claim that if one commits a wrongful act, then one should sincerely apologize for that act?
answers: The author of this passage says an apology is not sincere unless the two parties are both able to acknowledging the wrongful act.
The apology can still be sincere in intention even if the outcome leads to future failure.
To receive an apology sincerely requires the person to not hold a grudge and not for the person offering to be sincere.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The statements above, if true, most strongly support which one of the following?
main_answers: An apology cannot be both sincerely offered and sincerely accepted unless each person acknowledges that a wrongful act has occurred.
One cannot sincerely accept an apology that was not sincerely offered.
If one commits a wrongful act, then one should sincerely apologize for that act.
If one apologizes and subsequently repeats the wrongful act for which one has apologized, then one has not apologized sincerely.
others.target_option: If one commits a wrongful act, then one should sincerely apologize for that act.

context: In some countries, national planners have attempted to address the problems resulting from increasing urbanization by reducing migration from rural areas. But some economists have suggested an alternative approach. These economists assert that planners could solve these problems effectively by trading goods or services produced by a predominantly urban population in order to obtain the agricultural products that were previously produced domestically.
question: Why does the fact that problems associated with migration to cities from rural areas are primarily due to trade imbalances between countries not provide support for the economists' assertion?
answers: The main point of the passage is that urban areas are getting too populated for food production.
The passage does not mention government subsidies.
This passage does not mention trade imbalances.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, would provide the most support for the economists' assertion?
main_answers: Government subsidies to urban manufacturers can ease the problems caused by the migration of people from rural to urban areas.
Problems associated with migration to cities from rural areas are primarily due to trade imbalances between countries.
A scarcity of agricultural products is a central element of many problems created by urbanization.
All problems that have economic causes must have economic solutions.
others.target_option: Problems associated with migration to cities from rural areas are primarily due to trade imbalances between countries.

context: Art critic: Nowadays, museum visitors seldom pause to look at a work of art for even a full minute. They look, perhaps take a snapshot, and move on. This tells us something about how our relationship to art has changed over time. People have become less willing to engage with works of art than they once were.
question: What evidence is there to suggest that the art critic's argument does not rely on the assumption that visitors would enjoy their museum experiences more if they took more time with individual works of art?
answers: The art critic does not make any claim about how many pieces of art people look at per museum visit, nor do they draw a direct logical connection between looking at how many pieces of art are looked at and engagement with the art.

The art critic does not make any claim about how often people look at the pictures after taking snapshots of works of art, nor do they draw a direct logical connection between looking at snapshots of art and engagement with the art.
The art critic does assert that people take less time to engage with art than they did in the past, but does not claim that taking more time would increase their enjoyment.
The only evidence that the art critic uses to support their conclusion about engagement with works of art is how short the time is that museum visitors spend looking at a work of art.
label: C

others.main_question: The art critic's argument depends on the assumption that
main_answers: visitors would enjoy their museum experiences more if they took more time with individual works of art
the amount of time spent looking at a work of art is a reliable measure of engagement with that work
museum visitors who take snapshots of works of art rarely look at the pictures afterward
museum visitors today generally look at more pieces of art during each museum visit than museum visitors looked at in the past
others.target_option: visitors would enjoy their museum experiences more if they took more time with individual works of art

context: Buying elaborate screensavers -- programs that put moving images on a computer monitor to prevent damage -- can cost a company far more in employee time than it saves in electricity and monitor protection. Employees cannot resist spending time playing with screensavers that flash interesting graphics across their screens.
question: Why does the fact that an electronic keyboard may be cheaper to buy than a piano but more expensive to repair not closely conform to the principle illustrated above?
answers: The expenses relating to potential repairs are not comparable to the expenses related to trade-offs that are certain like the author is referring to.

A complicated security system reduces the burden of one problem while increasing the burden of another problem, which is directly comparable to the reducing the burden of energy consumption while increasing the burden of unproductive employees that the author suggests is the result of screensavers.

The author is making an argument specifically about trade-offs in two distinct aspects of a particular system, which is unlike merely looking at how a particular system will be beneficial or not over a period of time.

The author argues about the productivity of workers being traded for energy consumption, while the duration of cooking dinner versus receiving delivered pizza merely points to how long something may take or how convenient it is.
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following most closely conforms to the principle illustrated above?
main_answers: An electronic keyboard may be cheaper to buy than a piano but more expensive to repair.
An energy-efficient insulation system may cost more up front but will ultimately save money over the life of the house.
The time that it takes to have a pizza delivered may be longer than it takes to cook a complete dinner.
A complicated hotel security system may cost more in customer goodwill than it saves in losses by theft.
others.target_option: An electronic keyboard may be cheaper to buy than a piano but more expensive to repair.

context: Ethanol is a derivative of corn and other grains. When burned as fuel, it emits significantly lower levels of carbon monoxide, a major atmospheric pollutant, than does gasoline. For that reason, environmentalists claim that ethanol is a better source of energy than gasoline.
question: Explain why the fact that ethanol is comparable in price to gasoline does not strongly support the environmentalists' claim.
answers: The claim talks about benefits, but does not mention price. Comparable prices would not make one better than the other, also.
The supply of gasoline relative to the supply of corn is unknown, so it does not factor into their claims.
Releasing less pollutants would be better in the eyes of environmentalists, which aligns with them claiming that it is a better fuel source.
Both ethanol and gasoline can be used as heating fuel, so neither is significantly better at this.
label: A

main_answers: Ethanol is comparable in price to gasoline.

Ethanol can be used as heating fuel.

context: If we are to expand the exploration of our solar system, our next manned flight should be to Phobos, one of Mars' s moons, rather than to Mars itself. The flight times to each are the same, but the Phobos expedition would require less than half the fuel load of a Mars expedition and would, ttherefore, be much less costly. So, it is clear that Phobos should be our next step in space exploration.
question: Why does the fact that smaller spaceships require less fuel than larger spaceships not help to explain the difference in fuel requirements?
answers: If Phobos has a weaker gravitational pull, it would require less force to escape from its orbit to return to earth, which would allow them to use less fuel.
The motorized exploration vehicles would be the same for both trips so there would be no big difference in equipment.
The distance between Phobos and Mars is irrelevant because the trip would be between Earth and either Mars or Phobos.
The space exploration team would be using the same space ship to make either trip.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, would most help to explain the difference in fuel requirements?
main_answers: Smaller spaceships require less fuel than larger spaceships.
The shortest distance between Phobos and Mars is less than half the shortest distance between Earth and Mars.
More equipment would be required to explore Phobos than to explore Mars.
Lift-off for the return trip from Phobos requires much less fuel than that from Mars because of Phobos' weaker gravitational pull.
others.target_option: Smaller spaceships require less fuel than larger spaceships.

context: It is often said that beauty is subjective. But this judgment has to be false. If one tries to glean the standard of beauty of earlier cultures from the artistic works they considered most beautiful, one cannot but be impressed by its similarity to our own standard. In many fundamental ways, what was considered beautiful in those cultures is still considered beautiful in our own time.
question: Explain why the fact that in most cultures art is owned by a small social elite does not weaken the argument.
answers: The passage is not stating that artists were or were not influenced by being exposed to the work of earlier artists. If they had not been exposed to earlier art the argument would not be weakened and may in fact even strengthen the argument.
If this is true it still does not weaken the argument that what people found to be beautiful has not changed much over the years as importance and beauty are two very different categories.

Who owns art in cultures has no bearing as to whether or not people or the culture altogether find it to be beautiful. Many times art cannot be owned by everyone due to its high prices but we can still appreciate the art and its beauty.
This weakens the argument because it would assume that people are basing their beliefs about beauty in art on what they saw in older works of art and applying them to todays works of art.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following statements, if true, most weakens the argument?
main_answers: In most cultures art is owned by a small social elite.
Our own standard of beauty was strongly influenced by our exposure to works that were considered beautiful in earlier cultures.
Few contemporary artists have been significantly exposed to the art of earlier cultures.
The arts held a much more important place in earlier cultures than they do in our culture.
others.target_option: In most cultures art is owned by a small social elite.

context: Anselm of Canterbury (1033 -- 1109) was a medieval theologian. According to Anselm' s ontological argument for the existence of God, "accidental beings" are all those things -- essentially all sense objects -- whose non-existence could be imagined without inherent contradiction, and "necessary beings" are those things whose existence is guaranteed precisely by what they are. Because accidental beings could not have guaranteed that they ever would come into existence, there must be a necessary being upon whom all the accidental beings depends to bring them into existence; and this necessary being Anselm identifies with God, who ttherefore clearly must exist.
question: What is the basis for the eleventh century argument being considered vulnerable to the criticism that it makes a distinction that presupposes the truth of the conclusions that is to be established?
answers: The opposite is true. The accidental can not exist before its cause.
The conclusion is that God therefore exists and the fact provided is the unnecessary nature of creation. The latter fact neither contradicts nor confirms the former.
Yes the distinction made is between accidental and necessary beings but there is no rationale provided for why the necessary being is God, it could be matter-energy.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: In our modern analysis, this eleventh century argument is most vulnerable to what criticism?
main_answers: It presents as evidence in support of a claim information that is inconsistent with other evidence presented in support of the same claim.
It establishes an effect that must exist well before its cause.
It makes a distinction that presupposes the truth of the conclusions that is to be established.
The conclusion supports facts that directly contradict the evidence given to support it.
others.target_option: It makes a distinction that presupposes the truth of the conclusions that is to be established.

context: Harry: Airlines have made it possible for anyone to travel around the world in much less time than was formerly possible. Judith: That is not true. Many nights are too expensive for all but the rich.
question: What evidence does Judith's response provide to suggest that she interprets Harry's statement to imply that anyone can afford to travel long distances by air?
answers: Judith only discusses flights only and not other modes of transportation. If she thought Harry meant all travel was not affordable, she would have mentioned them.
Judith specifically mentions flights. Harry stated people could travel faster than before, which means they could still travel before, therefore there are other modes of travel around the world.

When Judith lets Harry know that flights are only affordable to the rich, she categorizes travel into rich and not rich. The blanket statement that anyone "can" travel implies that anyone can afford to travel.
None of the above choices
label: C

the majority of people are rich

context: The difference between manners and morals is that the former are necessarily social in nature whereas the latter are not necessarily social in nature. So the rules of etiquette do not apply when one is alone.
question: What is the basis for inferring that one could be immoral without ever having caused any other person any harm based on the statements above?
answers: Many moral topics deal with how one treats other human beings.
One can commit an action which goes against once abstract values of right and wrong, without there being any obvious negative consequences to another person.
Sometimes the prevailing manners of a society also overlap with one's own established beliefs of what is right and wrong.
None of the above choices
label: B

The rules of morality apply only when one is alone.

context: Herpetologist: Some psychologists attribute complex reasoning to reptiles, claiming that simple stimulus-response explanations of some reptiles' behaviors, such as food gathering, cannot account for the complexity of such behavior. But since experiments show that reptiles are incapable of making major alterations in their behavior, for example, when faced with significant changes in their environment, these animals must be incapable of complex reasoning.
question: What is the reasoning that justifies the herpetologist's argument not requiring the assumption that reptile behavior appears more complex in the field than laboratory experiments reveal it to be?
answers: Whether reptile behavior is more complex in the field than in the laboratory does not indicate whether or not they can change their behavior in response to changes in their environment, or are capable of complex reasoning.
It may be possible for animals to make major changes in their behavior even without the capability of complex reasoning.
Even if stimulus-response explanations can in principle account for all reptile behavior, that does not necessarily rule out the possibility of complex reasoning.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the herpetologist's argument?
main_answers: Reptile behavior appears more complex in the field than laboratory experiments reveal it to be.
If reptiles were capable of complex reasoning, they would sometimes be able to make major changes in their behavior.
Simple stimulus-response explanations can in principle account for all reptile behaviors.
Animals could make major changes in their behavior only if they were capable of complex reasoning.
others.target_option: Reptile behavior appears more complex in the field than laboratory experiments reveal it to be.

context: Several ancient Greek texts provide accounts of people being poisoned by honey that texts suggest was made from the nectar of rhododendron or oleander plants. Honey made from such nectar can cause the effects the texts describe, but only if eaten fresh, since the honey loses its toxicity within a few weeks of being made. In Greece, rhododendrons and oleander bloom only in springtime, when they are the predominant sources of nectar.
question: Why does the fact that whether the honey in a beehive is toxic depends solely on which plants were the source of that was used to make the honey not strongly support the accounts of Greek texts?
answers: This statement does not strongly support the Greek accounts because it contains not-very-relevant information. There is nothing in the original account that necessarily depends on the volume of nectar produced; simply that some toxic honey is at some point consumed by humans. It doesn't necessarily matter how much nectar is produced by different types of plants.

This statement would strongly support the accounts found in the Greek texts, because if the honey is only toxic when it is fresh, and it is only fresh in the springtime, it makes sense that the people who consumed it would die in the springtime (when it is toxic to consume).

This would not necessarily strongly support the Greek accounts because it essentially just restates the idea already expounded upon in the passage. The reader has already been informed that rhododendron and oleander nectar will produce toxic honey, so it doesn't really matter whether or not those specific plans are the ONLY reason the honey is toxic. The key point is that it IS toxic, and could potentially kill people.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most strongly support the accounts of Greek texts?

context: Several ancient Greek texts provide accounts of people being poisoned by honey that texts suggest was made from the nectar of rhododendron or oleander plants. Honey made from such nectar can cause the effects the texts describe, but only if eaten fresh, since the honey loses its toxicity within a few weeks of being made. In Greece, rhododendrons and oleander bloom only in springtime, when they are the predominant sources of nectar.
question: Why does the fact that there are no plants that Greece in ancient times that produce more nectar than rhododendrons or oleanders does not strongly support the accounts of Greek texts?
answers: This statement would strongly support the accounts found in the Greek texts, because if the honey is only toxic when it is fresh, and it is only fresh in the springtime, it makes sense that the people who consumed it would die in the springtime (when it is toxic to consume).

This would not necessarily strongly support the Greek accounts because it essentially just restates the idea already expounded upon in the passage. The reader has already been informed that rhododendron and oleander nectar will produce toxic honey, so it doesn't really matter whether or not those specific plans are the ONLY reason the honey is toxic. The key point is that it IS toxic, and could potentially kill people.

This statement does not strongly support the Greek accounts because it contains not-very-relevant information. There is nothing in the original account that necessarily depends on the volume of nectar produced; simply that some toxic honey is at some point consumed by humans. It doesn't necessarily matter how much nectar is produced by different types of plants.
None of the above choices
label: C

The incidents of honey poisoning that are related in the ancient texts occurred in the springtime or in the early summer
Whether the honey in a beehive is toxic depends solely on which plants were the source of that was used to make the honey.
There are no plants that Greece in ancient times that produce more nectar than rhododendrons or oleanders does.
others.target_option: There are no plants that Greece in ancient times that produce more nectar than rhododendrons or oleanders does.

context: Even though she thought the informant was untrustworthy, the journalist promised not to reveal his identity so long as the information he provided did not tum out to be false. However, she will publicly reveal the informant' s identity if she is ordered to do so by a judge or her editor. After all, the information concerns safety violations at the power plant. Thus, the journalist will surely reveal the informant' s identity even if the information is accurate.
question: Why does the conclusion of the argument not follow logically even if it is assumed that the informant understood, at the time the journalist promised him confidentiality, that she would break this promise if ordered to do so by a judge?
answers: Whether an informant understood that confidentiality would be broken if ordered so by a judge is not relevant to how sure it would be that confidentiality would be broken.

The author states that if information is accurate, the only way the informant's identity would be revealed is by order of a judge or editor, and then suggests that because safety concerns are involved, they are certain the identity will be revealed, so a court order is a reasonable explanation.
The author's conclusion sets the condition that the information is accurate, not false.

The condition that the editor will not reveal the informant's identity unless the information is inaccurate is contradictory to the author's statement that the informant's identity will be revealed even if the information is accurate.
label: A

The information that the informant provided is known to be false.
If the information concerns safety at the power plant, a judge will order the journalist to reveal her informant's identity.

context: Food company engineer: I stand by my decision to order the dumping of small amounts of chemicals into the local river even though there is some evidence that this material may pose health problems. 1 fish in the river myself and will continue to do so. Furthermore, I will have no problem if other food manufacturers do what our company does.
question: What is the basis for concluding that the engineer's reasoning closely conforms to the principle that one is justified in performing an act if one is willing to submit oneself to the consequences of that action performed by oneself or others?
answers: the greatest number of people would be benefited by no dumping in the river
The engineer made the decision to dump in the river prior to others and states they don't mind if others do as well.
The engineer says they themselves fish in the river and will continue to do so despite his dumping.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: The engineer's reasoning most closely conforms to which one of the following principles?
main_answers: One is justified in performing an act if one is willing to submit oneself to the consequences of that action performed by oneself or others.
One should always choose to act in a way that will benefit the greatest number of people.
One is justified in performing an act if other people are also planning to perform that kind of act.
One should never perform an act until one has fully analyzed all the ways in which that act could impact others.
others.target_option: One is justified in performing an act if one is willing to submit oneself to the consequences of that action performed by oneself or others.

context: When a married couple has frequent emotionally satisfying conversations, they tend in overwhelming percentages to remain married throughout their lives. Queen Melinda and Prince Jonathan, Duke of Westphalia, have been married for over sixty years, so clearly they must have emotionally satisfying conversations all the time.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the argument is vulnerable to the criticism that it presents as evidence in support of a claim information that is inconsistent with other evidence presented in support of the same claim?
answers: The Melinda and Jonathan marriage could definitely have more factors causing it to last long than simply emotionally satisfying conversations. For example, they are public figures with obligations that they have to keep.
No such distinction was made.
It is not necessarily true that the long lasting marriage happened after the emotionally satisfying conversations.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: This argument is most vulnerable to what criticism?
main_answers: It takes a condition to be the effect of something that has happened only after the condition already existed.
It takes one possible cause of a condition to be the actual cause of that condition without considering any other possible causes.
It makes a distinction that presupposes the truth of the conclusions that is to be established.
It presents as evidence in support of a claim information that is inconsistent with other evidence presented in support of the same claim.
others.target_option: It presents as evidence in support of a claim information that is inconsistent with other evidence presented in support of the same claim.

context: Scientists are discussing ways to remove excess carbon dioxide from the atmosphere by increasing the amount that is absorbed by plant life. One plan to accomplish this is to establish giant floating seaweed farms in the oceans. When the seaweed plants die, they will be disposed of by being burned for fuel.
question: Explain why the fact that some people may be reluctant to switch to the new fuel even if seaweed farms prove effective does not indicate a serious weakness in the plan.
answers: The seaweed farms do not necessarily have to be located in the Southern Hemisphere.

People's willingness to use seaweed as a fuel source is not directly related to its effectiveness in removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, since the seaweed plants can be burned as fuel without people actually using the fuel's energy.
While these figures may be accurate, they are subject to change, and more plants like seaweed can be grown to increase the amount of carbon dioxide absorbed by plants.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, would indicate the most serious weakness in the plan above?
main_answers: Even if seaweed farms prove effective, some people will be reluctant to switch to this new fuel.
Some areas of ocean in the Southern Hemisphere do not contain sufficient nutrients to support large seaweed farms.
Each year about seven billion tons of carbon dioxide are released into the atmosphere but only about five billion tons are absorbed by plant life.
When a seaweed plant is burned, it releases an amount of carbon dioxide comparable to the amount it has absorbed in its lifetime.
others.target_option: Even if seaweed farms prove effective, some people will be reluctant to switch to this new fuel.

context: Many scientific studies have suggested that taking melatonin tablets can induce sleep. But this does not mean that melatonin is helpful in treating insomnia. Most of the studies examined only people without insomnia, and in many of the studies, only a few of the subjects given melatonin appeared to be significantly affected by it.
question: Explain why the fact that none of the studies that suggested that taking melatonin tablets can induce sleep examined a fully representative sample of the human population does not strengthen the argument.
answers: The text implies that melatonin is not helpful to people with insomnia. If all people who took melatonin were effected then that would weaken the argument presented in the text.
This would not strengthen the argument in the text since people given the placebo were able to sleep. This would imply that is was not the melatonin inducing sleep but something else.
This would not strengthen the argument in the text. Since a good sample was not taken, you can not generalize the results to the population.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?
main_answers: None of the studies that suggested that taking melatonin tablets can induce sleep examined a fully representative sample of the human population.
Several people who were in control groups and only given placebos claimed that the tablets induced sleep.
If melatonin were helpful in treating insomnia, then every person with insomnia who took doses of melatonin would appear to be significantly affected by it.
In the studies that included subjects with insomnia, only subjects without insomnia were significantly affected by doses of melatonin.
others.target_option: None of the studies that suggested that taking melatonin tablets can induce sleep examined a fully representative sample of the human population.

context: Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease: white blood cells attack the myelin sheath that protects nerve fibers in the spinal cord and brain. Medical science now has a drug that can be used to successfully treat multiple sclerosis, but the path that led medical researchers to this drug was hardly straightforward. Initially, some scientists believed attacks characteristic of multiple sclerosis might be triggered by chronic viral infections. So in 1984 they began testing gamma interferon, one of the body' s own antiviral weapons. To their horror, all the multiple sclerosis patients tested became dramatically worse. The false step proved to be instructive however.
question: Explain why the fact that gamma interferon stops white blood cells from producing myelin-destroying compounds is not compatible with the results of the gamma interferon experiment.
answers: If gamma interferon stops white blood cells from producing myelin-destroying compounds, the multiple sclerosis patients that were tested with gamma interferon should have improved rather than becoming worse.

If gamma interferon spikes before and during multiple sclerosis attacks, then it is likely that a treatment which increases gamma interferon would be associated with a worsening of multiple sclerosis symptoms.
If gamma interferon causes a worsening of symptoms in those with multiple sclerosis, then a drug that inhibits the activity of gamma interferon should help to improve symptoms of multiple sclerosis.

If gamma interferon causes an increase in the number of white blood cells in those without multiple sclerosis, it may do the same in those with multiple sclerosis, and that increase in white blood cells would cause an increase in attacks on the myelin sheath of the nerve fibers for those with multiple sclerosis.
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following is LEAST compatible with the results of the gamma interferon experiment?
main_answers: Gamma interferon stops white blood cells from producing myelin-destroying compounds.
Administering gamma interferon to those without multiple sclerosis causes an increase in the number of white blood cells.
The drug now used to treat multiple sclerosis is known to inhibit the activity of gamma interferon.
Medical researchers have discovered that the gamma interferon level in the cerebrospinal fluid skyrockets just before and during multiple sclerosis attacks.
others.target_option: Gamma interferon stops white blood cells from producing myelin-destroying compounds.

context: The population of songbirds throughout England has decreased in recent years. Many people explain this decrease as the result of an increase during the same period in the population of magpies, which eat the eggs and chicks of songbirds.
question: Why does the fact that the number of eggs laid yearly by a female songbird varies widely according to the songbird's species not argue strongly against the explanation reported in the passage?
answers: If areas with decreased songbird populations are not among those where magpies increased, it suggests that the larger data set is misleading and contains irrelevant information.
The number of eggs typically laid by different species of songbirds has no bearing on what a magpie's effect would be on their overall population.
This only adds an explanation for why the population of magpies increased, which is unneeded and provides nothing in determining an explanation that applies to songbird populations.
The fact that magpies' diets include foods other than eggs and chicks of songbirds tells nothing about their influence on songbird populations.
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, argues most strongly against the explanation reported in the passage?
main_answers: The number of eggs laid yearly by a female songbird varies widely according to the songbird's species.
Although magpies eat the eggs and chicks of songbirds, magpies' diets consist of a wide variety of other foods as well.
The population of magpies has increased because farmers no longer shoot or trap magpies to any great extent, though farmers still consider magpies to be pests.
Although the overall population of magpies has increased, in most areas of England in which the songbird population has decreased, the number of magpies has remained stable.
others.target_option: The number of eggs laid yearly by a female songbird varies widely according to the songbird's species.

context: Ph. D. programs are valuable only if they inculcate good scholarship and expedite the student' s full participation in the field. Hence, doctoral dissertations should not be required in the humanities. Undertaking a quality book-length dissertation demands an accumulation of knowledge virtually impossible for those relatively new to their disciplines. The student consequently either seeks to compensate for poor quality with quantity or ends up spending years producing a work of quality. Either way, the dissertation is counterproductive and frustrates the appropriate goals of the doctoral program.
question: Why does the claim that doctoral dissertations should not be required in the humanities not provide evidence for the assumption that requirements for degrees in the humanities differ from requirements for degrees in other disciplines?
answers: The article is attempting to persuade readers that the dissertation process is harmful to the humanities.
The article is not a descriptive one attempting to record observations of the dissertation process, but rather arguing to abolish it.
The article is not attempting to compare and contrast degree requirements across fields, but rather argues that the humanities will benefit from eliminating the dissertation requirement.
None of the above choices
label: C

It confirms the observation that the requirement for a dissertation can frustrate the goals of a doctoral program.
It is what the argument is attempting to establish.
It provides essential support for the conclusion.

context: Eighteenth-century European aesthetics was reasonably successful in providing an understanding of all art, including early abstract art, until the 1960s, when artists self-consciously rebelled against earlier notions of art. Since the work of these rebellious artists is quite beautiful but outside the bounds of the aesthetic theory then current, there can be no complete theory of aesthetics.
question: Why is the reasoning not considered to be flawed for assuming that it is more important for a complete aesthetic theory to account for the beauty of traditional art than for it to account for the beauty of self-consciously rebellious art?
answers: The passage is assuming that European aesthetics is encompassing, this option raises the flaw in that.
The passage has nothing to do with other parts of the world, only European aesthetics.
The passage states that they were rebelling against earlier notions of art. This option goes against that by saying they were not guided, in some way, by it.
This does not apply. The passage has nothing to do with it being more important.
label: D

main_answers: takes for granted that it is more important for a complete aesthetic theory to account for the beauty of traditional art than for it to account for the beauty of self-consciously rebellious art

presumes, without providing justification, that an aesthetic theory developed in one part of the world cannot be applied in another

context: Scientist: My research indicates that children who engage in impulsive behavior similar to adult thrill-seeking behavior are twice as likely as other children to have a gene variant that increases sensitivity to dopamine. From this, I conclude that there is a causal relationship between this gene variant and an inclination toward thrill-seeking behavior.
question: Why does the fact that children are often described by adults as engaging in thrill-seeking behavior simply because they act impulsively not call into question the scientist's argument?
answers: Thrill seeking behavior is associated with a gene that would not change from childhood to adulthood.
Whether or not adults are sensitive to dopamine as it is children's sensitivity to dopamine that is referenced in connection with their behavior.
Impulsive behavior is defined differently depending on a wide variety of circumstances and situations.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most calls into question the scientist's argument?
main_answers: Children are often described by adults as engaging in thrill-seeking behavior simply because they act impulsively.
Many impulsive adults are not unusually sensitive to dopamine.
Many people exhibit behavioral tendencies as adults that they did not exhibit as children.
It is not possible to reliably distinguish impulsive behavior from other behavior.
others.target_option: Children are often described by adults as engaging in thrill-seeking behavior simply because they act impulsively.

context: Editorialist: In a large corporation, one of the functions of the corporation' s president is to promote the key interests of the shareholders. Ttherefore, the president has a duty to keep the corporation' s profits high.
question: How does the fact that shareholders sometimes will be satisfied even if dividends paid to them from company profits are not high not strengthen the editorialist's argument?
answers: The passage only mentions the president is trying to increase profit l, it mentions nothing else.
This passage does not mention a board of directors.
This comment hits on both points that are made in the article and ties them together perfectly.
This passage explicitly states that the president is trying to increase profits for the shareholders, it does not mention that they would be okay with less profit.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, would most strengthen the editorialist's argument?
main_answers: In considering where to invest, most potential shareholders are interested in more than just the profitability of a corporation.
Shareholders sometimes will be satisfied even if dividends paid to them from company profits are not high.
The president and the board of directors of a corporation are jointly responsible for advancing the key interests of the shareholders.
Keeping a corporation's profits high is likely to advance the important interests of the corporation's shareholders.
others.target_option: Shareholders sometimes will be satisfied even if dividends paid to them from company profits are not high.

context: Columnist: Over the last 20 years the demand in North America for Japanese-made automobiles has increased, whereas the Japanese demand for North American-made automobiles has been stagnant. Until recently, this imbalance could plausibly be attributed to Japanese models' superior fuel efficiency and reliability, but now cars made in North America are by these standards the equal of any Japanese model. What North American exporters continue to ignore is that the Japanese drive on the left side of the road. Ttherefore, one obstacle to reducing the automotive trade imbalance will be removed if North American manufacturers simply produce more cars with right-side steering wheels.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the columnist's argument requires the assumption that if the Japanese drive on the left side of the road, then they are not inclined to buy cars with left-side steering wheels?
answers: Sales of American cars to Japan have not increased even as fuel efficiency and reliability have become more similar among different manufacturers, so there is no evidence that most Japanese would choose the North American model among all cars with right-side steering wheels.

The columnist's argument is that American auto sales to Japan would be increased by manufacturing more cars with right-side steering wheels, so it is necessary to assume that the Japanese would not want to buy cars with left-side steering wheels.
There may be ways to correct the automotive trade imbalance other than specifically meeting the needs Japanese buyers.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the columnist's argument?
main_answers: If the Japanese drive on the left side of the road, then they are not inclined to buy cars with left-side steering wheels.
Given a choice between similar Japanese and North American models, all with right-side steering wheels, most Japanese would choose the North American model.
Japanese automotive safety standards require that all new domestic automobiles have rightside steering wheels.
The automotive trade imbalance can be lessened only if North American manufacturers produce automobiles that more effectively meet the needs of Japanese buyers.
others.target_option: If the Japanese drive on the left side of the road, then they are not inclined to buy cars with left-side steering wheels.

context: Research has shown that shoppers who purchase garments in a "luxury" material, such as cashmere or angora, are likely to purchase garments in more than one other luxury materials, as well. A recent livestock disease has significantly reduced the amount of cashmere available on the market. This, in turn, has driven up the prices of the cashmere products still available for purchase. We can ttherefore conclude that more people will be buying angora items of clothing this year than they did in previous years.
question: What evidence is there to suggest that the claim that people will be buying angora clothing this year is not supported by the fact that the number of customers purchasing angora has increased every year for the past decade in steady increments?
answers: The number of customers purchasing angora was not stated to have been increasing each year.

There is a shortage of cashmere, and customers that purchase cashmere are also likely to purchase angora, which, due to the rising prices of cashmere, will be a more affordable option for them and thus more likely to be purchased.
The disease that affected the cashmere-producing livestock was not noted to have also affected the angora-producing livestock.
Cashmere and angora's similarities were not mentioned.
label: A

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, best supports the claim that more people will be buying angora clothing this year?
main_answers: The number of customers purchasing angora has increased every year for the past decade in steady increments.
In a recent study, shoppers who had recently purchased a garment in a luxury material cited similar reasons for buying angora as buying cashmere.
Most consumers cannot tell the difference between cashmere and angora, which are both expensive and similar in texture.
The same disease that affected the livestock producing cashmere has also affected the farms that produce angora.
others.target_option: The number of customers purchasing angora has increased every year for the past decade in steady increments.

context: The United States government generally tries to protect valuable natural resources. But one resource has been ignored for too long. In the United States, each bushel of corn produced might result in the loss of as much as two bushels of topsoil. Moreover, in the last 100 years, the topsoil in many states, which once was about fourteen inches thick, has been eroded to only six or eight inches. Nonetheless, federal expenditures for nationwide soil conservation programs have remained at ridiculously low levels. Total federal expenditures for nationwide soil conservation programs have been less than the allocations of some individual states.
question: Why does the fact that the federal government's expenditures for soil conservation in the various states have been inequitable not express the main point of the argument?
answers: There was o comparison in the cost effectiveness of corn. There was only a comparison of amount of topsoil used per bushel of corn.

Stating that the total federal spending is below what some individual states spends serves to highlight how little they have spent. The text states that soil conservation has been ignored. This implies that the government needs to spend more to converse the soil.
Soil conservation from both the state and federal government was mentioned in the text, with no preference for who is responsible.
The text does not mention how much money is spend in each state by the government. It only mentions the total spending to be less that what some of the states spend themselves.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following best expresses the main point of the argument?
main_answers: The federal government's expenditures for soil conservation in the various states have been inequitable.
Corn is not a cost-effective product and substitutes should be found where possible.
Soil conservation is a responsibility of the federal government, not the states.
The federal government should spend much more on soil conservation than it has been spending.
others.target_option: The federal government's expenditures for soil conservation in the various states have been inequitable.

context: Ten years ago, the Salisbury City Council passed the Culinary Bill, new legislation to protect the interests of local non-franchise restaurants. Of the 120 local non-franchise restaurants in Salisbury today, 85 opened during the last ten years. Clearly the Culinary Bill has caused a surge in the number of local non-franchise restaurants operating in Salisbury over the past ten years.
question: What is the reasoning for why the argument does not depend on the assumption that all economic indicators suggest that household incomes in Salisbury have risen substantially over the past ten years?
answers: The passage makes no mention of household incomes in Salisbury and only focuses upon the Culinary Bill and the amount of restaurants that remain open today.
The passage tells us that there are 120 non-franchise restaurants in Salisbury and that of those 120 restaurants 85 opened in the last ten years.
The bills is stated to have been created to protect the interests of non-franchise restaurants as well as being stated to have caused a surge in the number of non-franchise restaurants in the city.
We have no knowledge from the passage as to whether or not patrons are aware of the Bill and its intentions or not. Assuming the patrons are or are not informed would be erroneous.
label: A

others.main_question: Which of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
main_answers: All economic indicators suggest that household incomes in Salisbury have risen substantially over the past ten years.
The Culinary Bill provides no benefit to restaurants that are members of national franchise chains
Most of the consumers in Salisbury who patronize these local restaurants are aware of the provisions of the Culinary Bill and approve of them.
Of the local non-franchise restaurants in Salisbury ten years ago, fewer than 85 have closed.
others.target_option: All economic indicators suggest that household incomes in Salisbury have risen substantially over the past ten years.

context: Microbiologist: A lethal strain of salmonella recently showed up in a European country, causing an outbreak of illness that killed two people and infected twenty-seven others. Investigators blame the severity of the outbreak on the overuse of antibiotics, since the salmonella bacteria tested were shown to be drug-resistant. But this is unlikely because patients in the country where the outbreak occurred cannot obtain antibiotics to treat illness without a prescription, and the country's doctors prescribe antibiotics less readily than do doctors in any other European country.
question: Explain why the fact that Salmonella has been shown to spread easily along the distribution chains of certain vegetables, such as raw tomatoes, does not weaken the microbiologist's reasoning.
answers: The text did not mention how the bacteria was spread. How the bacteria spreads will not effect if the bacteria is antibiotic resistance.

The text does not mention how much antibiotic use has increased or decreased in any country. And even if the use had increased in neighboring countries, it has no effect on the amount of antibiotics prescribed in the country with the outbreak and no bearing on whether the bacteria in the country with the outbreak are antibiotic resistant.

The text states that these doctors prescribe less antibiotics than other countries, but does not give a reason for this. But whatever the reason for not prescribing the antibiotics would still mean the bacteria would not be antibiotic resistant.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, would most weaken the microbiologist's reasoning?
main_answers: Salmonella has been shown to spread easily along the distribution chains of certain vegetables, such as raw tomatoes.
Use of antibiotics in two countries that neighbor the country where the outbreak occurred has risen over the past decade.
Physicians in the country where the outbreak occurred have become hesitant to prescribe antibiotics since they are frequently in short supply.
People in the country where the outbreak occurred often consume foods produced from animals that eat antibiotics-laden livestock feed.
others.target_option: Salmonella has been shown to spread easily along the distribution chains of certain vegetables, such as raw tomatoes.

context: The striking similarities between Greek temples and subsequent Roman villas testify to the fact that great architects typically draw inspiration from the work of other architects. Such drawing of inspiration does not mean, however, a slavish lack of originality; building according to formulas does not make good buildings. When formulas are used, the results are either bland or disastrous. By contrast, a great architect creates fresh architectural compositions out of familiar forms and synthesizes past and present into a new, richer whole.
question: Explain why it is not valid to infer from the passage that some Greek temples were not themselves inspired by older models.
answers: The opposite is true, in fact it is basic or formulaic design that leads to bland or disastrous architecture.
It is stated the Greek temples did in fact draw inspiration from the past works of other architects.
Good Roman architects put a fresh spin on past architectural ideas, so they were not lacking in originality or thought.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following can be inferred from the passage?
main_answers: Some Greek temples were not themselves inspired by older models.
Some Roman architecture exemplifies the creation of fresh architectural compositions out of familiar forms.
Buildings with unfamiliar forms are likely to be either bland or architectural disasters.
Roman architects designed many buildings with little or no originality of thought.
others.target_option: Some Greek temples were not themselves inspired by older models.

context: Pundit: Grenier will almost certainly not be elected as mayor. Although she says she believes in raising city employees' wages, it was only a few years ago that she was arguing that their wages should not be increased. Her claim that she has learned more about the issue since then -- though sincere -- will not matter to most voters, who will see her as insincere.
question: Explain why the principle that voters are unlikely to be influenced by what a politician's views were in the past if the voters agree with the politician's current positions does not help to justify the pundit's reasoning.
answers: Voters questioning a politician's sincerity does not mean that the voters are unwilling or unlikely to vote for the politician.

It is unclear how many voters would or would not vote for Grenier based on her current view of wanting to raising city employees' wages, so it cannot be concluded that her current position would cause her to lose the election for mayor.

The pundit thinks that Grenier's change in stance on city employees' wages will be viewed by voters as insincere, so they would therefore be unlikely to vote for Grenier, supporting the pundit's conclusion that Grenier will most likely not be elected mayor.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following principles, if valid, most helps to justify the pundit's reasoning?
main_answers: Voters are unlikely to be influenced by what a politician's views were in the past if the voters agree with the politician's current positions.
Voters are likely to elect a politician who they believe understands their financial concerns.
Voters are likely to question the sincerity of a politician who does not hold the same beliefs they do.
Voters are unlikely to vote for a politician whom they perceive to be insincere.
others.target_option: Voters are unlikely to be influenced by what a politician's views were in the past if the voters agree with the politician's current positions.

context: The solidity of bridge piers built on pilings depends largely on how deep the pilings are driven. Prior to 1700, pilings were driven to "refusal, " that is, to the point at which they refused to go any deeper. In a 1588 inquiry into the solidity of piers for Venice' s Rialto Bridge, it was determined that the bridge' s builder, Antonio Da Ponte, had met the contemporary standard for refusal: he had caused the pilings to be driven until additional penetration into the ground was no greater than two inches after twenty-four hammer blows.
question: Explain why it is not valid to infer from the passage that Da Ponte's standard of refusal was less strict than that of other bridge builders of his day.
answers: There is no indication that the pilings were unsafe.

The mention of the standard being the "contemporary" standard implies that the standard may be different now and the explanation of how "refusal" is determined also leaves room for the explanation that the pilings could have been driven deeper.
There is no mention of any other standard during Da Ponte's day.
There is no mention of the standard for driving pilings after 1588.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following can properly be inferred from the passage?
main_answers: After 1588, no bridges were built on pilings that were driven to the point of refusal.
Da Ponte's standard of refusal was less strict than that of other bridge builders of his day.
The Rialto Bridge was built on unsafe pilings.
It is possible that the pilings of the Rialto Bridge could have been driven deeper even after the standard of refusal had been met.
others.target_option: Da Ponte's standard of refusal was less strict than that of other bridge builders of his day.
