question: Why is it not valid to infer from the passage that the Rialto Bridge was built on unsafe pilings?
answers: There is no mention of the standard for driving pilings after 1588.

The mention of the standard being the "contemporary" standard implies that the standard may be different now and the explanation of how "refusal" is determined also leaves room for the explanation that the pilings could have been driven deeper.
There is no mention of any other standard during Da Ponte's day.
There is no indication that the pilings were unsafe.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following can properly be inferred from the passage?
main_answers: After 1588, no bridges were built on pilings that were driven to the point of refusal.
Da Ponte's standard of refusal was less strict than that of other bridge builders of his day.
The Rialto Bridge was built on unsafe pilings.
It is possible that the pilings of the Rialto Bridge could have been driven deeper even after the standard of refusal had been met.
others.target_option: The Rialto Bridge was built on unsafe pilings.

context: The solidity of bridge piers built on pilings depends largely on how deep the pilings are driven. Prior to 1700, pilings were driven to "refusal, " that is, to the point at which they refused to go any deeper. In a 1588 inquiry into the solidity of piers for Venice' s Rialto Bridge, it was determined that the bridge' s builder, Antonio Da Ponte, had met the contemporary standard for refusal: he had caused the pilings to be driven until additional penetration into the ground was no greater than two inches after twenty-four hammer blows.
question: What is the basis for inferring that it is possible that the pilings of the Rialto Bridge could have been driven deeper even after the standard of refusal had been met from the passage?
answers: There is no mention of the standard for driving pilings after 1588.

The mention of the standard being the "contemporary" standard implies that the standard may be different now and the explanation of how "refusal" is determined also leaves room for the explanation that the pilings could have been driven deeper.
There is no mention of any other standard during Da Ponte's day.
There is no indication that the pilings were unsafe.
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following can properly be inferred from the passage?
main_answers: After 1588, no bridges were built on pilings that were driven to the point of refusal.
Da Ponte's standard of refusal was less strict than that of other bridge builders of his day.
The Rialto Bridge was built on unsafe pilings.
It is possible that the pilings of the Rialto Bridge could have been driven deeper even after the standard of refusal had been met.
others.target_option: It is possible that the pilings of the Rialto Bridge could have been driven deeper even after the standard of refusal had been met.

context: To perform an act that is morally wrong is to offend against humanity, and all offenses against humanity are equally bad. Because murder is morally wrong, it is just as bad to have murdered one person by setting off a bomb as it would have been to have murdered a hundred people by setting off that bond.
question: What is the basis for concluding that, if lying is morally wrong, telling a lie is as bad as murdering someone in accordance with the principles invoked above?
answers: If all offenses against humanity are equally bad, it only means that they are morally equal and does not mean the harm to society will be equal in every case.
If all offenses against humanity are equally bad, and both lying and murder are offenses against humanity, then both lying and murder are equally bad.
If all offenses against humanity are equally bad, it does not mean that all good actions toward humanity are equally good.
Murder is an intentional act but an accident is not, so it does not necessarily mean that an accident would be an offense against humanity or morally wrong.
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following judgments conforms to the principles invoked above?
main_answers: If lying is morally wrong, telling a lie is as bad as murdering someone.
Risking one's life to save the lives of a hundred people is morally no better than risking one's life to save one person.
If stealing is morally wrong, it is equally important to society to prevent people from stealing as it is to prevent them from committing murder.
Accidentally causing the death of a person is just as bad as murdering that person.
others.target_option: If lying is morally wrong, telling a lie is as bad as murdering someone.

context: After 1950, in response to record growth in worldwide food demand, farmers worldwide sharply increased fertilizer use. As a result, the productivity of farmland more than doubled by 1985. Since 1985, farmers have sought to increase farmland productivity even further. Nevertheless, worldwide fertilizer use has declined by 6 percent between 1985 and the present.
question: How does the fact that several varieties of crop plants that have become popular recently, such as soybeans, are as responsive to fertilizer as are traditional grain crops not help to resolve the apparent discrepancy in the information above?
answers: If recently popular crops responded similarly to fertilizer as traditional crops, farmers would not decrease fertilizer use.
While farmers likely did increase crop yields prior to 1985, they would not reduce fertilizer use since they wished to continue increasing yields.
Trade disputes occurring between 1975 and 1980 would likely not still affect the availability of fertilizer in the present.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to resolve the apparent discrepancy in the information above?
main_answers: After fertilizer has been added to soil for several years, adding fertilizer to the soil in subsequent years does not significantly improve crop production.
Several varieties of crop plants that have become popular recently, such as soybeans, are as responsive to fertilizer as are traditional grain crops.
Between 1950 and 1985 farmers were able to increase the yield of many varieties of crop plants.
Between 1975 and 1980 fertilizer prices temporarily increased because of labor disputes in several fertilizer-exporting nations, and these disputes disrupted worldwide fertilizer production.
others.target_option: Several varieties of crop plants that have become popular recently, such as soybeans, are as responsive to fertilizer as are traditional grain crops.

context: In the past, combining children of different ages in one classroom was usually a failure; it resulted in confused younger children, who were given inadequate attention and instruction, and bored older ones, who had to sit through previously learned lessons. Recently, however, the practice has been revived with excellent results. Mixed-age classrooms today are stimulating to older children and enable younger children to learn much more efficiently than in standard classrooms.
question: How does the fact that today's mixed-age classrooms, unlike those of the past, emphasize group projects that are engaging to students of different ages help to resolve the apparent discrepancy in the passage?
answers: This is the most plausible explanation because it directly addresses the main problems in mixed-aged classrooms in the past.
Class size does not address the instruction content problem that plagued mixed-aged classrooms in the past.
Classroom equipment was not noted as a cause for the poor performance of past mixed-age classrooms.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to resolve the apparent discrepancy in the passage?
main_answers: Today's mixed-age classrooms, unlike those of the past, emphasize group projects that are engaging to students of different ages.
On average, mixed-age classrooms today are somewhat larger in enrollment than were the ones of the past.
Few of the teachers who are reviving mixed- age classrooms today were students in mixed-age classrooms when they were young.
Mixed-age classrooms of the past were better equipped than are those of today.
others.target_option: Today's mixed-age classrooms, unlike those of the past, emphasize group projects that are engaging to students of different ages.

context: A recent study showed that people who address problems quickly and directly are significantly less likely to have gum disease than are people who react to problems by refusing to think about them. Since stress can have a negative effect on the immune system, the study' s results clearly indicate that some forms of gum disease are caused or aggravated by suppression of the immune system.
question: What evidence is needed to support the claim that the argument does not depend on the assumption that painful conditions will interfere with a person's ability to address problems quickly and directly?
answers: Seeking dental care as a first option cannot be assumed as there are other avenues for addressing dental problems quickly.
The author mentions stress leading to worse dental outcomes but does not say or reference how people with stressful lives react to problems.
Some forms of dental disease are caused by lowered immune system and one factor that causes this is stress.
Pain is not an indicator that problems will or will not be tackled quickly or directly.
label: D

others.main_question: The argument requires the assumption that
main_answers: people who tend to address problems quickly and directly will invariably seek dental care at the first sign of problems
painful conditions will interfere with a person's ability to address problems quickly and directly
people who have highly stressful lives tend to address problems quickly and directly
refusing to think about something troubling contributes to a person's level of stress
others.target_option: painful conditions will interfere with a person's ability to address problems quickly and directly

context: Chronic fatigue syndrome is characterized by prolonged fatigue, muscular pain, and neurological problems. It is not known whether these symptoms are all caused by a single virus or whether each symptom is the result of a separate viral infection. A newly synthesized drug has been tested on those who suffer from chronic fatigue syndrome. Although the specific antiviral effects of this drug are unknown, it has lessened the severity of all of the symptoms of chronic fatigue syndrome. Thus there is evidence that chronic fatigue syndrome is, in fact, caused by one virus.
question: Why does the argument not assume that an antiviral medication that eliminates the most severe symptoms of chronic fatigue syndrome thereby cures chronic fatigue syndrome?
answers: Whether or not all those who suffer from prolonged fatigue also suffer from neurological problems is not important to the argument of how the drug works to treat it.
The author concludes that the syndrome is caused by one virus therefore they must believe that the drug targets that one specific virus.
The severe symptoms could be relieved without the syndrome being cured entirely.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: The argument assumes which one of the following?
main_answers: An antiviral medication that eliminates the most severe symptoms of chronic fatigue syndrome thereby cures chronic fatigue syndrome.
It is more likely that the new drug counteracts one virus than that it counteracts several viruses.
Most syndromes that are characterized by related symptoms are each caused by a single viral infection.
All those who suffer from prolonged fatigue also suffer from neurological problems.
others.target_option: An antiviral medication that eliminates the most severe symptoms of chronic fatigue syndrome thereby cures chronic fatigue syndrome.

context: One of the most important events for modern astronomy was the series of collisions, during a single week in 1994, of more than a dozen large objects with Jupiter. The collision of these objects, which once formed most of the comet Shoemaker-Levy 9, resulted in formations that showed no signs of water. There was thus no water involved in the collisions, so we know that none of the comet' s fragments penetrated to Jupiter' s lower atmosphere and that the comet was composed of rock rather than ice.
question: Why does the argument not depend on the assumption that the post-collision analysis of Jupiter showed that the formations all had exactly the same composition?
answers: This is exactly what the passage is alluding to when it mentions that the comet would need to go lower in the atmosphere to see water.
The passage says the opposite to this that this comet had no water in it.
The passage is not saying this, it is saying that if the comet fragment went deeper into jupiters atmosphere that maybe there would be signs of water.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
main_answers: Comets tend to be composed largely of ice while asteroids are composed mainly of rock.
The post-collision analysis of Jupiter showed that the formations all had exactly the same composition.
The deeper the explosion occurred in Jupiter's atmosphere, the more difficult it would be to detect from Earth.
If Jupiter's lower atmosphere had been penetrated by the comet's fragments, the resulting formations would show signs of water.
others.target_option: The post-collision analysis of Jupiter showed that the formations all had exactly the same composition.

context: Stylistic evidence and laboratory evidence strongly support the claim that the magnificent painting Garden of Eden is a work of the Flemish master van Eyck. Nevertheless, the painting must have been the work of someone else, as any one with a little historical and zoological knowledge can tell merely by looking at the painting. The animals in the painting are all vivid representations of actual animals, including armadillos. Yet armadillos are native only to the Americas, and van Eyck died decades before Europeans reached the Americas.
question: Explain why the two highlighted portions of the argument do not serve the roles of the first being a judgment that serves as the basis for the main conclusion of the argument and the second stating that main conclusion.
answers: Yes the whole point of the passage is the conclusion in the first portion; and the second gives the irrefutable evidence for that conclusion.
The first is not an intermediate conclusion, it is final and contradicts the evidence of the previous sentence; and the second gives the proof for the final conclusion.
The first is the main conclusion itself; and the second proves it.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: In the argument given, the two highlighted portions play which of the following roles?
main_answers: The first is a position that the argument seeks to reject; the second is evidence that the argument uses against that position.
The first is a judgment that serves as the basis for the main conclusion of the argument; the second states that main conclusion.
The first is an intermediate conclusion drawn in order to support a further conclusion stated in the argument; the second provides evidence in support of that intermediate conclusion.
The first presents the main conclusion of the argument; the second provides evidence in support of that conclusion.
others.target_option: The first is a judgment that serves as the basis for the main conclusion of the argument; the second states that main conclusion.

context: Rita: No matter how you look at them, your survey results are misleading. Since people generally lie on such surveys, the numbers you collected are serious underestimates. Hiro: I have no doubt that people lie on surveys of this type. The question is whether some people lie more than others. While the raw numbers surely underestimate what I' m trying to measure, the relative rates those numbers represent are probably close to being accurate.
question: What is the basis of Rita and Hiro's disagreement over whether the survey results are misleading regardless of how they are interpreted?
answers: In the text, Rita says people lie in general leading to misleading results and Hiro questions if some people lie more than others which leads to the relative rates being close to accurate.
Both Rita and Hiro say that people lie on the types of surveys they are discussing.
Both Rita and Hiro both state in the text that the "raw" numbers collected are seriously underestimated.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Rita and Hiro disagree over whether
main_answers: the survey results are misleading regardless of how they are interpreted
people tend to lie on certain kinds of surveys
the raw numbers collected are serious underestimates
a different type of measure than a survey would produce results that are less misleading
others.target_option: the survey results are misleading regardless of how they are interpreted

context: Critic: Photographers, by deciding which subjects to depict and how to depict them, express their own worldviews in their photographs, however realistically those photographs may represent reality. Thus, photographs are interpretations of reality.
question: Why is it valid to conclude that the argument's conclusion is properly drawn if it is assumed that to express a worldview is to interpret reality?
answers: It is specifically photography being discussed. A painting or sculpture may not necessarily be representative of the artist's worldview.
A person's worldview is their interpretation of the reality which they are experiencing and is unique to each individual.
Nonrealistic photographs would not necessarily convey how the artist views the world/their reality and so would not help form the same conclusion
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The argument's conclusion is properly drawn if which one of the following is assumed?
main_answers: To express a worldview is to interpret reality.
All visual art expresses the artist's worldview.
Any interpretation of reality involves the expression of a worldview.
Nonrealistic photographs, like realistic photographs, express the worldviews of the photographers who take them.
others.target_option: To express a worldview is to interpret reality.

context: In polluted industrial English cities during the Industrial Revolution, two plant diseases -- black spot, which infects roses, and tar spot, which infects sycamore trees -- disappeared. It is likely that air pollution eradicated these diseases.
question: What is the reason for why the fact that scientists theorize that some plants can develop a resistance to air pollution does not strengthen the reasoning?
answers: Plants building up a resistance to air pollution would not impact air pollution's effect on diseases.
The effects of air pollution on plants wasn't being discussed, it was the effects of air pollution on diseases.
The author stated that it is likely that air pollution eradicated these diseases, so a lack of air pollution would bring the diseases back.
The author stated that these two diseases disappeared, but attributed it specifically to the increased air pollution.
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the reasoning above?
main_answers: Scientists theorize that some plants can develop a resistance to air pollution.
Black spot and tar spot returned when the air in the cities became less polluted.
For many plant species, scientists have not determined the effects of air pollution.

context: It is wrong to waste our natural resources, and it is an incredible waste of resources to burn huge amounts of trash in incinerators. When trash is recycled, fewer resources are wasted. Because less trash will be recycled if an incinerator is built, the city should not build an incinerator.
question: Why is it not valid to infer that by recycling more trash, the city can stop wasting resources entirely based on the statements above?
answers: According to the passage recycling more trash will help cut back on the amount of resources being wasted, but nowhere does it tell us that it will put a stop to resources being wasted entirely.
Recycling trash does conserve resources according to the passage, but nowhere in the passage does it tell the reader that it is the most effective method in which to conserve.
This can be inferred because the passage states that when large amounts of trash is burned in an incinerator it wastes resources because items are not being recycled.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following can be properly inferred from the statements above?
main_answers: If the city does not burn trash, it will not waste resources.
By recycling more trash, the city can stop wasting resources entirely.
If the city is to avoid wasting resources, huge amounts of trash cannot be burned in any city incinerator.
The most effective way to conserve resources is to recycle trash.
others.target_option: By recycling more trash, the city can stop wasting resources entirely.

context: If a civilization as technologically advanced as human civilization existed on another planet and that planet were within 50 light years of Earth, that civilization would have found evidence of intelligent life on Earth and could have easily contacted us. Scientists can thus rule out the possibility of finding a civilization as technologically advanced as our own within 50 light years of Earth.
question: What is the basis for the argument not requiring the assumption that there is no reason to doubt the possibility that there are technologically advanced civilizations on planets more than 50 light years from Earth?
answers: This assumption is required for the argument that if a civilization is within 50 light years of us, it would have by definition contacted us.  This presupposes that it would want to contact us, and not avoid us for some reason.

There is a difference in what this response proposes, scientists actively seeking life forms, which could be technologically advanced or not, and what the statement above proposes, which is that we would be passive recipients, receiving contact from another civilization.
A civilization, whether it is  within 50 light years or farther away, could have many reasons to contact us, or not contact us.  Making this an absolute statement can't be supported.

There is no way to confirm that an intelligent species can recognize other intelligent species.  For many years, people thought humans of different races were inferior, so why would a totally different species not view us as a non-intelligent species?
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument?
main_answers: There is no reason to doubt the possibility that there are technologically advanced civilizations on planets more than 50 light years from Earth.
A technologically advanced civilization on another planet would want to communicate with intelligent life that it detected on Earth.
Intelligent life forms on other planets would be able to recognize all signs of intelligent life on Earth.
Scientists who are searching for evidence of extraterrestrial life forms generally focus their search on evidence of technologically advanced life forms.
others.target_option: There is no reason to doubt the possibility that there are technologically advanced civilizations on planets more than 50 light years from Earth.

context: Trainer: I recently developed an exercise routine that can get anybody to meet his or her goals. The routine combines cardio and bodybuilding during each session for the purpose of losing weight. Every person I' ve trained has lost weight on the program.
question: How does the fact that every client the trainer has worked with has weight loss as a goal affect the strength of the argument?
answers: There was no mention of diet here. The trainer said they could meet their goals with cardio and bodybuilding. We can not know if they worked out more to counteract a bad diet, or had a good diet. We only know that the trainer used cardio and bodybuilding and all the clients lost weight.
The text does not mention the health of the clients either before or after losing weight. It only mentions losing weight. So we can not know if they got healthy after losing weight.
There is no mention of how mush exercise experience any one has had prior to seeing the trainer.

The text states that the trainer can get anyone to meet their goals and every person they have trained have lost weight. There is no mention of achieving any other goal, therefore all their clients must have wanted to lose weight.
label: D

others.main_question: The strength of the argument depends on which one of the following?
main_answers: Every client the trainer has worked with has weight loss as a goal.
Every client the trainer has worked with has prior experience lifting weights.
Every client the trainer has worked with has also adopted a healthy diet.
Losing weight is always a healthy outcome.
others.target_option: Every client the trainer has worked with has weight loss as a goal.

context: Many important types of medicine have been developed from substances discovered in plants that grow only in tropical rain forests. There are thousands of plant species in these rain forests that have not yet been studied by scientists, and it is very likely that many such plants also contain substances of medicinal value. Thus, if the tropical rain forests are not preserved, important types of medicine will never be developed.
question: What is the basis for the argument not requiring the assumption that most of the tropical rain forest plants that contain substances of medicinal value can also be found growing in other types of environment?
answers: It is not necessary for any and all substances of medicinal value to be discovered, the discovery of a limited number could still be valuable.

That tropical rain forests should be preserved to make it possible for important medicines to be developed from plant species that have not yet been studied is explicit to the argument, it is not an assumption.

If substances of medicinal value can also be found growing in other types of environment then the argument that it is necessary to preserve rain forests in order to obtain these substances is weakened, not strengthened.
If the substances that have not yet been discovered are no different from those that have been discovered then it would weaken the author's argument that it is important to be able to discover them.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument?
main_answers: Most of the tropical rain forest plants that contain substances of medicinal value can also be found growing in other types of environment.
The tropical rain forests should be preserved to make it possible for important medicines to be developed from plant species that have not yet been studied by scientists.
Any substance of medicinal value contained in plant species indigenous to tropical rain forests will eventually be discovered if those species are studied by scientists.
There are substances of medicinal value contained in tropical rain forest plants not yet studied by scientists that differ from those substances already discovered in tropical rain forest plants.
others.target_option: Most of the tropical rain forest plants that contain substances of medicinal value can also be found growing in other types of environment.

context: Ancient humans in eastern North America hunted mammoths until the mammoth disappeared from the area around 13, 000 years ago. Recently, a fossil bone with an engraving that depicts a mammoth was found in an ancient settlement in eastern North America. This shows that the settlement was occupied at a time when mammoths lived in this area.
question: What evidence is needed to demonstrate that the argument does not depend on the assumption that the fossil on which the engraving was made was not a mammoth bone?
answers: The passage does not give us information regarding where all mammoths were thought to have lived in this time 13,000 years ago.
This can be assumed from the passage because a person had to have seen mammoths before in order to be able to engrave the likeness of a mammoth on the fossil.
The assumption that the bone found with the engraving was any specific bone cannot be made from the passage as it does not inform the reader as to what kind of bone it was other than being a fossil.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: The argument requires the assumption that
main_answers: the fossil on which the engraving was made was not a mammoth bone
when mammoths disappeared from eastern North America, there were no mammoths left anywhere in North America
there is no scientific way of dating when the engraving of the mammoth was made
the engraving was made during the time when the settlement was occupied
others.target_option: the fossil on which the engraving was made was not a mammoth bone

context: Blogger: Traditionally, newspapers have taken objectivity to be an essential of good journalism . However, today' s newer media are more inclined to try to create a stir with openly partisan reporting. This contrast in journalistic standards is best understood in terms of differing business strategies. The newer media outlets need to differentiate themselves in a crowded marketplace. The standard of objectivity developed primarily among newspapers with no serious rivals, so the most important objective was to avoid offending potential readers.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the blogger's argument does not require the assumption that journalists at traditional newspapers are just as partisan as journalists who work for newer media outlets?
answers: It's implied in the passage that the old media are well established, and the newer media are having to put in extra effort to stand out of the crowd.
While the passage stated the newspapers were trying to avoid readers by being objective, it gives no information on whether or not people actually prefer one or the other.
Since objectivism is seen as good journalism, people by far would be more likely to consume objective media.
The old journalists came to be with no major competitors, so they never had to become partisan to attract consumers like some new media journalists may have had to.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the blogger's argument?
main_answers: People prefer objective reporting to partisan reporting that merely reinforces their own partisan leanings.
Journalists at traditional newspapers are just as partisan as journalists who work for newer media outlets.
Newspapers have regarded objective reporting as less likely to offend people than openly partisan reporting.
The newer media outlets are increasing in popularity at the expense of traditional newspapers.
others.target_option: Journalists at traditional newspapers are just as partisan as journalists who work for newer media outlets.

context: The difference in average annual income in favor of employees who have college degrees, compared with those who do not have such degrees, doubled between 1980 and 1990. Some analysts have hypothesized that increased competition between employers for employees with college degrees drove up income for such employees.
question: Explain why the fact that during the 1980s there were some employees with no college degree who earned incomes comparable to the top incomes earned by employees with a college degree does not seriously undermine the explanation described above.
answers: The average age of all employees overall does not tell us anything about the increase in income among those with college degrees during the same period of time.

If college graduates are required to take unskilled jobs because they cannot find one requiring a college degree, then the increase in wages among college graduates is not the result of employer competition for college graduates because there are more graduates than employers.

The fact that some employees with no college degree earned an income comparable to some employees with a college degree does not tell us anything about the overall increase in the incomes of all employees with college degrees.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most seriously undermines the explanation described above?
main_answers: The unemployment rate changed very little throughout the 1980s
During the 1980s there were some employees with no college degree who earned incomes comparable to the top incomes earned by employees with a college degree.
During the 1980s a growing percentage of college graduates, unable to find jobs requiring a college degree, took unskilled jobs.
The average age of all employees increased slightly during the 1980s.
others.target_option: During the 1980s there were some employees with no college degree who earned incomes comparable to the top incomes earned by employees with a college degree.

context: The difference in average annual income in favor of employees who have college degrees, compared with those who do not have such degrees, doubled between 1980 and 1990. The average age of all employees overall does not tell us anything about the increase in income among those with college degrees during the same period of time.

context: Editorial: It is clear that if this country' s universities were living up to both their moral and their intellectual responsibilities, the best-selling publications in most university bookstores would not be frivolous ones like TV Today and Gossip Review. However, in most university bookstores the only publication that sells better than Gossip Review is TV Today.
question: What is the reasoning for concluding that, on the basis of the statements, at least some of this country's universities are not meeting their moral responsibilities or their intellectual responsibilities or both?
answers: The editorial suggests that it is morally and/or intellectually irresponsible for universities to have created a moral and intellectual environment where frivolous publications are the most popular, but it does not make any claims about whether merely carrying such publications is irresponsible.

The editorial makes a claim about the moral and intellectual responsibilities of universities, but says nothing about the moral and intellectual responsibilities of individuals who attend these universities.

The best-selling publications in university bookstores are frivolous ones like TV Today and Gossip Review, so based on the editorial, this country's universities cannot be living up to both their moral and intellectual responsibilities.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: If the statements in the editorial are true, which one of the following must also be true on the basis of them?
main_answers: At least some of this country's universities are not meeting their moral responsibilities or their intellectual responsibilities or both.
People who purchase publications that are devoted primarily to gossip or to television programming are intellectually irresponsible.
Many people who attend this country's universities fail to live up to both their moral and their intellectual responsibilities.
It is irresponsible for university bookstores to carry publications such as Gossip Review and TV Today.
others.target_option: At least some of this country's universities are not meeting their moral responsibilities or their intellectual responsibilities or both.

context: One good clue as to which geographical regions an ancient relic was moved through in the past involves the analysis of pollen that clings to the surface of the relic. A relic is linked to a geographical area by the identification of pollen from plants that are known to have been unique to that area.
question: How does the fact that pollens are often transported from one region to another by wind or human movement cast doubt on the reliability of the method described above?
answers: The difficulty and expense associated with a method does not imply it is not a useful or accurate method.

If pollen is not specific to an area and can be moved, then it would be an unreliable measure to determine if something was from a specific area based on pollen content since it could change over time and be in places it did not originate.
While the same kind of pollen being found in more than one area would make it a less specific measure for an items place of origin, it would still narrow the area down to some degree.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, casts the most doubt on the reliability of the method described above?
main_answers: Data are scarce as to the geographical distribution of the pollens of many ancient plants.
Pollens are often transported from one region to another by wind or human movement.
Many types of pollen were common to several geographical regions in the ancient world.
Pollen analysis is a painstaking process that is also expensive to conduct.
others.target_option: Pollens are often transported from one region to another by wind or human movement.

context: The tendency toward overspecialization in the study of artifacts is unfortunate. Scholars can enhance their understanding of a certain artistic period by studying art from earlier periods that had a significant influence on it. For instance, because of its influence on Spanish artisans, a proper understanding of Arabic porcelain is indispensable for a proper understanding of Spanish porcelain.
question: Why does the principle that the passage as a whole illustrates not closely conform to the claim that to appreciate fully the French language, one must understand the other languages that share its linguistic ancestry?
answers: The passage maintains that a full understanding of a historical topic requires an understanding of earlier historical influences, and Plato's philosophy was a direct historical influence on Aristotle's philosophy.

The passage emphasizes that full understanding of something requires understanding of its historical influences, so it would maintain that to fully appreciate the French language, one must understand its linguistic ancestry, not specifically other languages that share its linguistic ancestry.

The passage emphasizes that full understanding of something requires understanding of its historical influences, but similar events in earlier centuries do not necessarily influence events of this century.

The passage emphasizes that full understanding of something requires understanding of its historical influences, but the practices of the wider academic community are not necessarily historical influences on an academic discipline.
label: B

others.main_question: Of the following, which one most closely conforms to the principle that the passage as a whole illustrates?
main_answers: To appreciate fully the French language, one must understand the other languages that share its linguistic ancestry.
To understand properly any academic discipline, one must have at least a superficial acquaintance with the practices of the wider academic community.
To understand fully the historical events of this century, a historian must have an understanding of similar events in earlier centuries.
To understand completely Aristotle's philosophy, one must be well acquainted with the philosophy of his intellectual mentor, Plato.
others.target_option: To appreciate fully the French language, one must understand the other languages that share its linguistic ancestry.

context: Studies suggest that, for the vast majority of people who have normal blood pressure, any amount of sodium greater than that required by the body is simply excreted and does not significantly raise blood pressure. So only persons who have high blood pressure and whose bodies are incapable of safely processing excess sodium need to restrict their sodium intake.
question: Explain why the fact that every human being has a physiological need for at least some sodium does not weaken the argument.
answers: According to the test there is a required amount of sodium for people. This strengthens the argument for decreasing sodium intake since we all need a minimum amount. Going over that minimum amount is harmful for some people.
It would not matter how harmful high blood pressure is, the recommendation is to help people with blood pressure, no matter how harmful it is.

This would weaken the argument that only people who can not process the excess sodium should decrease their consumption. If excess sodium will eventually destroy the body's ability to secrete it, then that is true for all people. According to that, all people should decrease sodium intake.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, would most seriously weaken the argument?
main_answers: Every human being has a physiological need for at least some sodium.
Any sodium not used by the body will increase blood pressure unless it is excreted.
Excess sodium intake over time often destroys the body's ability to process excess sodium.
High blood pressure is more harmful than was previously believed.
others.target_option: Every human being has a physiological need for at least some sodium.

context: In a few recent cases, some teenagers with advanced programming abilities used a new programming language, FANTOD, to hack into ETS and change their own SAT scores. All of the teenagers convicted of this crime were highly skilled in programming FANTOD. In light of these cases, some colleges have discounted the official SAT scores of applicants with a knowledge of FANTOD, and have required them to take special admission tests in supervised conditions on their own campuses.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that students who learn FANTOD tend to have much lower SAT scores than do their peers based on the information given?
answers: The passage just states that some colleges are requiring additional tests it does not suggest that colleges should completely rely on their own tests.
Students who learn FANTOD have advanced programming abilities but this does not show or prove that they have lower SAT scores.
It is not correct to assume that all who learn to program FANTOD are doing so to commit a crime.  The passage stated that that some used this.  it does not reference all.

Students who have knowledge of FANTOD are at a disadvantage as they are being subjected to extra scrutiny and may even have to  take special tests to prove they are capable of the scores that they are getting.
label: B

others.main_question: Which of following conclusions can most properly be drawn from the information above?
main_answers: Students who learn FANTOD tend to have much lower SAT scores than do their peers.
Most people who learn to program in FANTOD do so to commit some kind of hacking.
The college admissions process possibly places some students with a knowledge of FANTOD at a disadvantage.
Colleges should rely on their own admissions tests instead of the SATs
others.target_option: Students who learn FANTOD tend to have much lower SAT scores than do their peers.

context: Dr. Theresa Pagano, a biologist, has found that the checkerspot butterfly is becoming more prevalent in regions farther north than before and less prevalent in regions farther south. The northward shift of the butterflies is almost perfectly correlated with the northward shift of the warm zones in the global climate, and Dr. Pagano has ttherefore concluded that the changing climate is responsible for the northward movement of the butterflies.
question: Why does the experimental evidence suggesting that the checkerspot butterfly can adapt easily to a wide range of temperatures and geographic conditions not support Dr. Pagano's reasoning?
answers: If the warm zones are shifting northward due to climate change, the plants the butterfly relies on would also gradually shift northward, leaving fewer to none of these plants in the southern regions for the butterflies to depend on.
Those same small temperature changes that critically affect the checkerspot butterfly in the lab would also affect the butterfly as climate zones shift northward.
If the checkerspot butterfly can easily adapt to a wide range of temperatures, it would make more sense for the butterfly to both shift northward as well as remain in place.
One would expect that if species very similar to the checkerspot butterfly only survive in warm climates, the same would be true of the checkerspot butterfly as well.
label: C

others.main_question: Each of the following, if true, supports Dr. Pagano's reasoning EXCEPT:
main_answers: Experimental evidence suggests that the checkerspot butterfly can adapt easily to a wide range of temperatures and geographic conditions.
Climate does not affect checkerspot butterflies themselves directly, but the plants they depend on thrive best in warm climates.
Several studies have shown that several other species of butterfly closely related to the checkerspot butterfly survive only in warm climates.
Checkerspot butterfly colonies observed under laboratory conditions are critically affected by small temperature changes.
others.target_option: Experimental evidence suggests that the checkerspot butterfly can adapt easily to a wide range of temperatures and geographic conditions.

context: Sociologist: Marriage is one of the most important societal institutions. Marital relationship provides numerous structural benefits for married couples and their offspring. question: Why is it valid to conclude that the argument depends on assuming that the task cannot be assigned to anyone other than a supervisor in the shipping department?
answers: The claim that Larson has the assertiveness the task requires is not important to the argument that the ask must be assigned to a supervisor in the shipping department.

The argument states that the task must be given to the only supervisor left who can do it but if the task could be assigned to a person who is not a supervisor there could be more options for who to assign it to.
A person is excluded because of an unavoidable scheduling conflict, it's possible that the task could be assigned to people with other kinds of scheduling conflicts.
None of the above choices
label: B

main_answers: Franks would be assigned the task if Franks had the assertiveness the task requires.

context: Every week, the programming office at an FM radio station reviewed unsolicited letters from listeners who were expressing comments on the station' s programs. One week, the station received 50 letters with favorable comments about the station' s news reporting and music selection and 10 letters with unfavorable comments on the station' s new movie review segment of the evening program. Faced with this information, the programming director assumed that if some listeners did not like the movie review segment, then there must be other listeners who did like it. Ttherefore, he decided to continue the movie review segment of the evening program.
question: What is the basis for identifying a problem with the programming director's decision process due to his inability to properly infer from the fact that some listeners did not like the movie review segment that some others did?
answers: The programming director's argument relies on the notion that people are more likely to criticize than to praise, because there was no praise of the movie review segment.
No one wrote a positive comment on the movie review segment, not even the people who praised other segments, which could mean that no one liked it.
The director's argument relies on comments not written, so would apply no matter how many or few unfavorable comments the station received.
Assuming there is a relationship between the news and movie review segments would actually bolster the director's arguments, since all the news comments were positive.
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following identifies a problem with the programming director's decision process?
main_answers: He could not properly infer from the fact that some listeners did not like the movie review segment that some others did.
He did not wait until he received at least 50 letters with unfavorable comments about the movie review segment before making his decision.
He failed to take into account the relation existing between the movie review segment and the news.
He failed to recognize that people are more likely to write letters of criticism than of praise.
others.target_option: He could not properly infer from the fact that some listeners did not like the movie review segment that some others did.

context: After a nuclear power plant accident, researchers found radioactive isotopes of iodine, tellurium, and cesium-but no heavy isotopes-in the atmosphere downwind. This material came either from spent fuel rods or from the plant' s core. Spent fuel rods never contain significant quantities of tellurium isotopes. Radioactive material ejected into the atmosphere directly from the core would include heavy isotopes. After the accident, steam, which may have been in contact with the core, was released from the plant. The core contains iodine, tellurium, and cesium isotopes, which are easily dissolved by steam.
question: What is the evidence that suggests that the statement that the nuclear power plant's spent fuel rods were not damaged is not strongly supported by the information above?
answers: There were no heavy isotopes which would have been present if ejected from the core.

Because tellurium never occurs from spent fuel rods, the assertion that radioactive material was carried by steam is supported since they are dissolved in steam which is still left as a possible explanation for their presence after an accident.
Fuel rods are mentioned being spent.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Of the following statements, which one is most strongly supported by the information above?
main_answers: The nuclear power plant's spent fuel rods were not damaged.
Spent fuel rods do not contain heavy isotopes in significant quantities.
The researchers found some radioactive material from spent fuel rods as well as some material that was ejected into the atmosphere directly from the plant's core.
The radioactive material detected by the researchers was carried into the atmosphere by the steam that was released from the plant.
others.target_option: The nuclear power plant's spent fuel rods were not damaged.

context: Science writer: The deterioration of cognitive faculties associated with Alzheimer' s disease is evidently caused by the activities of microglia -- the brain' s own immune cells. For one thing, this deterioration can be slowed by some anti-inflammatory drugs, such as acetylsalicylic acid. Furthermore, patients with Alzheimer' s are unable to eliminate the protein BA from the brain, where it accumulates and forms deposits. The microglia attack these protein deposits by releasing poisons that destroy surrounding healthy brain cells, thereby impairing the brain' s cognitive functions.
question: How does the fact that acetylsalicylic acid reduces the production of immune cells in the brain support the science writer's argument?
answers: Reactions of microglia in other diseases is not necessarily relevant to their involvement in Alzheimer's.

Immune cells are produced in the brain in Alzheimer's patients as a result of protein deposits so reducing the inflammation from these deposits could lead to less immune response and therefore, less tissue damage since the immune response destroys surrounding tissue, leading to a decline in cognitive function.
While problems with eliminating BA is a deficiency in Alzheimer's patients, reducing the immune response to the BA is what would be addressed with Acetylsalicylic acid.

While this is the reason it is important to address the immune system that results from the buildup of BA, it is the response that affects cognitive function by destroying the surrounding tissue in response.
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to support the science writer's argument?
main_answers: Acetylsalicylic acid reduces the production of immune cells in the brain.
Immune reactions by microglia occur in certain diseases of the brain other than Alzheimer's.
The inability of Alzheimer's patients to eliminate the protein BA from the brain is due to a deficiency in the brain's immune system.
The protein BA directly interferes with the cognitive functions of the brain.
others.target_option: Acetylsalicylic acid reduces the production of immune cells in the brain.

context: Lack of exercise produces the same or similar bodily effects as aging. In fact, the physical changes that accompany aging can often be slowed down by appropriate exercise. No drug, however, holds any promise for slowing down the changes associated with aging. Ttherefore, __.
question: Why does the fact that people who do not exercise when they are young will gain few benefits from beginning to exercise at a later age not provide a logical completion to the passage?
answers: Since drugs do not slow the physical changes associated with aging and exercise does do this, this option is true and a natural conclusion to the passage, which makes both points.

Since the passage points out that drugs do NOT slow the physical changes associated with aging, adding drugs to exercise will not help and so this option is false and not a natural conclusion to the passage.
Aging can be slowed down by exercise no matter when in life you start exercising, so this option is false and thus not a natural conclusion to the passage.
Appropriate exercise can't prevent the physical changes associated with aging; it can only slow them down, so this option is false and thus not a natural conclusion to the passage.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following provides a logical completion to the passage above?
main_answers: people who do not exercise when they are young will gain few benefits from beginning to exercise at a later age
appropriate exercise can prevent the physical changes associated with aging
if the physical changes of aging are to be slowed, it is more practical to rely on exercise than on drugs
people who do not exercise are likely to need drugs to sustain their health
others.target_option: people who do not exercise when they are young will gain few benefits from beginning to exercise at a later age

context: Economist: A country' s trade deficit may indicate weakness in its economy, but it does not in itself weaken that economy. So restricting imports to reduce a trade deficit would be like sticking a thermometer into a glass of cold water in the hope of bringing down a patient' s feverish temperature.
question: Why does the economist's argument not employ the technique of demonstrating that an analogy explicitly used to establish a certain conclusion is faulty?
answers: The passage compares the sign of a weakened economy to that of a glass of water. It is showing why this will not work through comparison.
The passage does not suggest that any bad consequences will happen.
This passage does not use an analogy to prove a conclusion is faulty, it uses it to make a point.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: The economist's argument employs which one of the following techniques?
main_answers: showing that a recommended course of action would have disastrous consequences
demonstrating that an analogy explicitly used to establish a certain conclusion is faulty
calling into question the authority on the basis of which a claim is made
appealing to an analogy in order to indicate the futility of a course of action
others.target_option: demonstrating that an analogy explicitly used to establish a certain conclusion is faulty

context: Huang: Most people who commit violent crimes do not carefully consider whether or how they will be punished for these crimes. And those who don' t commit violent crimes have no inclination to do so. Rather than impose harsh mandatory sentences, we should attend to the root causes of violence to reduce the rate of violent crime. Suarez: Would you say the same about nonviolent crimes, such as tax evasion? Surely mandatory penalties are a useful deterrent in these cases. At any rate, I am confident that mandatory sentences prevent most people who would otherwise physically harm others from doing so.

answers: While Huang states that the best way to reduce violent crime is to address the root causes of violence, Suarez does not take a stance on addressing the root causes of violence; the issue both Huang and Suarez address directly is mandatory sentencing.
Only Suarez mentions penalties for nonviolent crimes such as tax evasion; the main conversation and issue that both Suarez and Huang address is sentencing for violent crime.

Huang states that they believe that people who commit violent crimes do not carefully consider the consequences, but Suarez does not address this directly and so it is not the focus of their conversation.

Suarez states that they are confident that mandatory sentences prevent physical harm in most cases, while Huang states that they believe people who commit violent crimes do not consider the consequences.

context: Public health will improve more quickly in the wake of new medical discoveries if medical researchers abandon their practice of waiting until their findings are published in peer-reviewed journals before informing the press of important research results. This is because the public release of new medical information allows people to use that information in order to improve their health, but the peer-review process is unavoidably very slow.
question: Why is it valid to conclude that the argument depends on the assumption that people would use new medical information even if it were not first published in peer-reviewed journals?
answers: The passage is not focused on speeding up the peer-review process, rather upon releasing findings to the public immediately in an effort to allow people to use new information to better their health. Even if this statement were true, the passage is not focused upon speeding up this process.

This statement reiterates the point of the passage by stating that the public would use findings immediately in an effort to better their health even if the findings had not been published in peer-reviewed journals.

This goes against the passage because right now the information and findings that is published in the journals does receive public attention, but the goal is to speed this process up by eliminating the public having to wait until such information becomes published.

The passage does not delve into whether or not medical journal reviewers are also medical researchers or not and this information has no bearing upon the argument of the importance of releasing research findings to the public immediately.

context: Ninety percent of recent car buyers say safety was an important factor in their purchase. Yet of these car buyers, only half consulted objective sources of vehicle safety information before making their purchase; the others relied on advertisements and promotional materials. Thus, these other buyers were mistaken in saying that safety was important to them.
question: Why does the argument's conclusion not logically follow even if it is assumed that most consumers are aware that advertisements and promotional materials are not objective sources of vehicle safety information?
answers: If consumers were aware of how lacking in vehicle safety information the promotional materials were, they would make more of an effort to do independent research if they were genuine.
If someone is really obsessed with purchasing the most safe vehicle for his or her family, they would take the extra step in doing more than surface research on the safety of the vehicle.
Even if the safety information in the promotional materials is incomplete, that would have no bearing on whether or not the person was sincere in their concern about vehicle safety.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The argument's conclusion follows logically if which one of the following is assumed?
main_answers: Someone who claims that safety was an important factor in a buying decision does not necessarily mean that safety was the most important factor.
Advertisements and promotional materials sometimes provide incomplete vehicle safety information.
Most consumers are aware that advertisements and promotional materials are not objective sources of vehicle safety information.
Anyone to whom safety is an important factor in purchasing a car will consult an objective source of vehicle safety information before buying.
others.target_option: Most consumers are aware that advertisements and promotional materials are not objective sources of vehicle safety information.

context: The caterpillar of the monarch butterfly feeds on milkweed plants, whose toxins make the adult monarch poisonous to many predators. The viceroy butterfly, whose caterpillars do not feed on milkweed plants, is very similar in appearance to the monarch. Ttherefore, it can be concluded that the viceroy is so seldom preyed on because of its visual resemblance to the monarch.
question: Explain why the fact that some of the predators of the monarch butterfly also prey on viceroys does not seriously undermine the argument.
answers: If the viceroy is toxic to most predators then looking like a less toxic butterfly, such as the monarch, would not decrease the likelihood of it not being preyed on so much as it would likely be decreased by its own association with toxicity.
If there was no reaction to the toxin there would be no reason for a predator to avoid a food source with the toxin in it.
Monarch and viceroy butterflies would have to have common predators if the assumption is that those predators are deterred due the appearance of the butterflies being similar.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if it were discovered to be true, would most seriously undermine the argument?
main_answers: Some of the predators of the monarch butterfly also prey on viceroys.
The viceroy butterfly is toxic to most predators.
Some predators do not have a toxic reaction to insects that feed on milkweed plants.
Toxicity to predators is the principal means of protection for only a few butterfly species.
others.target_option: Some of the predators of the monarch butterfly also prey on viceroys.

context: Sociologists study folktales because they provide a means of understanding the distinctive values of a culture. However, the folktales in almost all cultures are adaptations of the same ancient narratives to the local milieu.
question: How does the fact that the ancient narratives persist largely because they speak to basic themes and features of the human condition help to resolve the apparent discrepancy in the information above?
answers: The absence of a single author does not necessarily mean that a folktale will reflect the values of a specific culture, because it could be reflecting values that are common to all cultures.

Although most folktales have their origins in the same ancient sources, the different ways in which they have evolved over time provides information about what different cultures have found to be most important and worth remembering.
Whether a folktale is written or survives from oral traditions does not tell us anything about why it might reflect the values of a specific culture.
The fact that folktales speak to basic themes of the human condition does not explain why sociologists would study them to understand the distinct values of a culture.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to resolve the apparent discrepancy in the information above?
main_answers: The ancient narratives persist largely because they speak to basic themes and features of the human condition.
Because no single person is the author of a folktale, folktales must reflect the values of a culture rather than those of an individual.
Folktales are often oral traditions that persist from times when few people left written materials.
The manner in which a culture adapts its narratives reveals information about the values of that culture.
others.target_option: The ancient narratives persist largely because they speak to basic themes and features of the human condition.

context: If cold fusion worked, it would provide almost limitless power from very inexpensive raw materials, materials far cheaper than coal or oil. But replacing all the traditional electric generators that use these fuels with cold-fusion power plants would result in a reduction of no more than 25 percent in the average residential electric bill.
question: Why would the fact that personnel costs for the distribution of power to consumers are unrelated to the type of raw materials an electric company uses help to resolve the apparent discrepancy between the predictions above?
answers: Even though the cost of raw materials for cold fusion would be very inexpensive the limited savings for consumers could relate to personnel costs.
The higher costs of building and maintaining cold-fusion power plants would offset other savings.
If companies were willing to use cold-fusion it would be expected that there would be a more significant reduction in costs for users due to the inexpensive materials used in cold fusion.
Although the fuel for cold-fusion would be cheaper this only represents a small portion of residential electric bills.
label: A

others.main_question: Each of the following, if true, would help to resolve the apparent discrepancy between the predictions above EXCEPT:
main_answers: Personnel costs for the distribution of power to consumers are unrelated to the type of raw materials an electric company uses.
Most electric companies would be willing to incorporate cold-fusion technology into their power plants.
Cold-fusion power plants would be more expensive to build and maintain than traditional electric generators are.
Only a relatively small portion of any residential electric bill is determined by the electric company's expenses for fuel.
others.target_option: Personnel costs for the distribution of power to consumers are unrelated to the type of raw materials an electric company uses.

context: A university study reported that between 1975 and 1983 the length of the average workweek in a certain country increased significantly. A governmental study, on the other hand, shows a significant decline in the length of the average workweek for the same period. Examination of the studies shows, however, that they used different methods of investigation; thus there is no need to look further for an explanation of the difference in the studies' results.
question: Why is the argument's reasoning not considered to be invalid due to its failure to acknowledge that varying economic conditions result in the average workweek changing in length?
answers: It does not fail to distinguish the different studies, it blatantly says that one study was a university and one was by the government.
This passage does not mention anything about vetting economic conditions.
Just because in this circumstance the results were different and the methodology was different does not ensure that will always be the case.
The purpose is not important here, it is the difference between two studies that is the topic at hand.
label: B

others.main_question: The argument's reasoning is flawed because the argument fails to
main_answers: recognize that varying economic conditions result in the average workweek changing in length
recognize that two different methods of investigation can yield identical results
distinguish between a study produced for the purposes of the operation of government and a study produced as part of university research
distinguish between a method of investigation and the purpose of an investigation
others.target_option: recognize that varying economic conditions result in the average workweek changing in length

context: Boreal owls range over a much larger area than do other owls of similar size. The reason for this behavior is probably that the small mammals on which owls feed are especially scarce in the forests where boreal owls live, and the relative scarcity of prey requires the owls to range more extensively to find sufficient food.
question: Why does the fact that the boreal owl requires less food, relative to its weight, than is required by members of other owl species not help to confirm the explanation above?
answers: If the size of ranges for this particular species of owl varies depending on the scarcity or abundance of prey, it stands to reason that this rationale would apply to the differences between this species and others as well.
The difference in size between the size of different owls' ranges would not confirm whether a lack of prey is the cause of the disparity.
If anything, this would contradict the explanation given that requiring less food would suggest that these owls would not need to range as extensively to get adequate sustenance.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most helps to confirm the explanation above?
main_answers: Boreal owls range over larger areas in regions where food of the sort eaten by small mammals is sparse than they do in regions where such food is abundant.
The boreal owl requires less food, relative to its weight, than is required by members of other owl species.
Some boreal owls range over an area eight times larger than the area over which any other owl of similar size ranges.
After their young hatch, boreal owls must hunt more often than before in order to feed both themselves and their newly hatched young.

context: In 1955, legislation in a certain country gave the government increased control over industrial workplace safety conditions. Among the high-risk industries in that country, the likelihood that a worker will suffer a serious injury has decreased since 1955. The legislation, ttherefore, has increased overall worker safety within high-risk industries.
question: Why does the fact that most of the work-related injuries that occurred before 1955 were the result of worker carelessness not weaken the argument?
answers: The decreased likelihood of serious worker industry could be attributed to the reduction in unprotected interaction between workers and heavy machinery driven by technological innovation, rather than to the legislation from 1955.

The improvement in workplace safety conditions in all industries could be driven by the legislation from 1955, which would support the claim that the legislation increased worker safety specifically in high-risk industries.

The specific cause of work-related injuries does not impact the argument that the 1955 legislation increased worker safety in high-risk industries, without further knowledge of the details of the legislation.
None of the above choices
label: C

context: John: There have been complaints about the lack of parks in our city. Some people favor turning the old airport land into biking and hiking trails, but there may be more productive ways of using that land. Pablo: But the old airport land is ideal for biking and hiking trails. Our citizens have gone too long with an inadequate number of parks; we should not dismiss this proposal for biking and hiking trails without further consideration.
question: What is the evidence that Pablo did not interpret John to be claiming that it may not be possible to convert the old airport land into adequate biking and hiking results?
answers: Pablo is arguing with John that the land is best used to make the trails while John argues it may not be the best, neither are arguing that it is not possible to make the land into trails.

John makes no alternative park ideas, only stating the land may be used for something else than biking and hiking trails, so Pablo sees it as John being against the latter, not for any other park ideas.

Pablo argues with John that the idea of biking and hiking trails on the land is ideal and should not dismiss the idea, this shows that he believes John doesn't want to continue with the idea of using the land made for biking and hiking trails.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Pablo's criticism suggests that he interpreted John to be
main_answers: maintaining that converting the old airport land into biking and hiking trails would be entirely unproductive use of that land
asserting that it may not be possible to convert the old airport land into adequate biking and hiking results
recommending that the proposal for converting the old airport land into biking and hiking trails should be promptly dismissed
favoring the development of parks other than biking and hiking trails
others.target_option: asserting that it may not be possible to convert the old airport land into adequate biking and hiking results

context: Psychologist: Identical twins are virtually the same genetically. Moreover, according to some studies, identical twins separated at birth and brought up in vastly different environments show a strong tendency to report similar ethical beliefs, dress in the same way, and have similar careers. Thus, many of our inclinations must be genetic in origin, and not subject to environmental influences.
question: Explain why the fact that scientists are far from being able to link any specific genes to specific inclinations does not weaken the psychologist's argument.
answers: The author offers observation that science practitioners have yet to connect specific gene types to specific choices or preferences, overall.
The author compares contextual difference in Nature versus Nurture, here stating that reveal that identically genetic people, are similar in some traits, and different in others.

The author compares "Nature versus Nurture" and extends or flips the initial comparison - difference in belief categories, can occur in same genetic people, identical people physically. By comparison, identical people in identical environments are different also.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, would most weaken the psychologist's argument?
main_answers: Scientists are far from being able to link any specific genes to specific inclinations.
Many people, including identical twins, undergo radical changes in their lifestyles at some point in their lives.
While some studies of identical twins separated at birth reveal a high percentage of similar personality traits, they also show a few differences.
Identical twins who grow up together tend to develop different beliefs, tastes, and careers in order to differentiate themselves from each other.
others.target_option: Scientists are far from being able to link any specific genes to specific inclinations.

context: Magazine article: Punishment for crimes is justified if it actually deters people from committing them. But a great deal of carefully assembled and analyzed empirical data show clearly that punishment is not a deterrent. So punishment is never justified.
question: Why is the reasoning in the magazine article's argument not considered to be invalid due to its attempt to be more precise than its subject matter properly allows?
answers: The article does not shift the meaning of "punishment".
The reasoning in the article is not precise at all; it is very generalized.
It does not ignore the problem of mistakenly punishing the innocent because it says no punishment is ever justified.
None of the above choices
label: B

mistakes being sufficient to justify punishment for being required to justify it

context: Soft Drinks Manufacturer: Despite attractive offers, our company has rejected any plans to expand our market into the Czech Republic at this time. We simply have no data on how well received our products would be in the Czech Republic. Industry Analyst: Your position is inconsistent. Last year, you expanded into Bolivia, even after taste tests had definitely found that approximately 40% of the Bolivian population did not care for any of your products. Ttherefore, concerns about how well received your product will be cannot be motivating this position.
question: Why is the industry analyst's argument considered flawed for failing to consider that known risks can be assessed, but unknown risks cannot?
answers: The popularity of coffee in these countries has little or nothing to do with the popularity of soft drinks in these countries.
We are not concerned with which soft drink is most popular in these countries.
The relative value of these currencies is not the question at hand.
None of the above choices
label: D

known risks can be assessed, but unknown risks cannot.
coffee is more popular than most soft drinks in both Bolivia and in the Czech Republic
the Czech currency is much stronger than the Boliviano, the national currency of Bolivia.
others.target_option: known risks can be assessed, but unknown risks cannot.

context: Frobisher, a sixteenth-century English explorer, had soil samples from Canada' s Kodlunarn Island examined for gold content. Because high gold content was reported, Elizabeth I funded two mining expeditions. Neither expedition found any gold there. Modern analysis of the island' s soil indicates a very low gold content. Thus the methods used to determine the gold content of Frobisher' s samples must have been inaccurate.
question: Explain why the argument does not depend on the assumption that the two mining expeditions funded by Elizabeth I did not mine the same part of Kodlunarn Island?
answers: Whether the two expeditions mined the same part of Kodlunarn Island for gold is not relevant to whether or not the soil-testing methods were accurate.
The gold content of the soil today on Kodlunarn Island does not necessarily reflect its gold content in the sixteenth century.
If Frobisher had added gold to the soil samples before they were examined, then the tests would be accurate but the results falsified.
There is no evidence that the accuracy of the soil-testing method depends on having samples from other Canadian islands to examine for gold content.
label: A

others.main_question: Which of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
main_answers: The two mining expeditions funded by Elizabeth I did not mine the same part of Kodlunarn Island.
Frobisher did not have soil samples from any other Canadian island examined for gold content.
Gold was not added to the soil samples collected by Frobisher before the samples were examined.
The gold content of the soil on Kodlunarn Island is much lower today than it was in the sixteenth century.
others.target_option: The two mining expeditions funded by Elizabeth I did not mine the same part of Kodlunarn Island.
