context: Announcement for a television program: Are female physicians more sensitive than male physicians to the needs of women patients? To get the answer, we' ll ask physicians of both sexes this question. Tune in tomorrow.
question: Explain why the fact that there still are fewer women than men who are physicians does not identify a flaw in the plan for the program?
answers: Questioning the physicians about whether they are more helpful to female patients does not actually answer the question of whether they are helpful to the female patients; you have to question the patients to get an accurate answer to this question. So this option does point out this flaw in the reasoning of the passage.

That physicians don't discuss the treatment style of other physicians has nothing to do with their discussing their helpfulness to women patients, so this option is irrelevant to the passage and therefore does not point out a flaw in it.

That women are beginning to take a more active role in their healthcare is irrelevant to whether their female physicians serve them better than their male physicians and so this has nothing to do with the passage and does not identify a flaw in it.

Even if there are fewer female physicians than male physicians, those female physicians with female patients are the ones who are going to be questioned.  It is irrelevant that some female patients have male physicians, so this option is irrelevant to the passage.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, identifies a flaw in the plan for the program?
main_answers: There still are fewer women than men who are physicians, so a patient might not have the opportunity to choose a woman as a physician.

context: Many people change their wills on their own every few years, in response to significant changes in their personal or financial circumstances. This practice can create a problem for the executor when these people are careless and do not date their wills: the executor will then often know neither which one of several undated wills is the most recent, nor whether the will drawn up last has ever been found. Ttherefore, people should not only date their wills but also state in any new will which will it supersedes, for then there would not be a problem to begin with.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument considered flawed for treating a partial solution to the stated problem as though it were a complete solution?
answers: The proposed solution of will dating does in fact solve one aspect of the problem (relative recency of wills), and makes no mention of any other parties being involved.
Dating the will would solve the problem of determining it's relative recency, but would not establish whether or not the most recent will had been found, contrary to the claim made by the argument.
The argument makes no mention of containing adverse effects, merely enumerating two of them.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The reasoning in the argument is flawed because the argument
main_answers: fails to distinguish between prevention of a problem and successful containment of the adverse effects that the problem might cause
treats a partial solution to the stated problem as though it were a complete solution
proposes a solution to the stated problem that does not actually solve the problem but merely makes someone else responsible for solving the problem
claims that a certain action would be a change for the better without explicitly considering what negative consequences the action might have
others.target_option: treats a partial solution to the stated problem as though it were a complete solution

context: When a polygraph test is judged inconclusive, this is no reflection on the examinee. Rather, such a judgment means that the test has failed to show whether the examinee was truthful or untruthful. Nevertheless, employers will sometimes refuse to hire a job applicant because of an inconclusive polygraph test result.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that most examinees with inconclusive polygraph test results are in fact untruthful based on the information given?
answers: Employers may refuse to hire job applicants due to inconclusive polygraph test results, but there is no indication that employers have refused to use polygraph test results for hiring purposes.
An inconclusive polygraph test result does not indicate anything about the examinee, so refusing to hire such an examinee on the basis of their polygraph test result is unfair.
Inclusive polygraph test results do not indicate anything about the examinees, including how truthful they are as a whole.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following conclusions can most properly be drawn from the information above?
main_answers: Most examinees with inconclusive polygraph test results are in fact untruthful.
An inconclusive polygraph test result is sometimes unfairly held against the examinee.
A polygraph test indicating that an examinee is untruthful can sometimes be mistaken.
Some employers have refused to consider the results of polygraph tests when evaluating job applicants.
others.target_option: Most examinees with inconclusive polygraph test results are in fact untruthful.

context: City council member: Despite the city' s desperate need to exploit any available source of revenue, the mayor has repeatedly blocked council members' attempts to pass legislation imposing real estate development fees. It is clear that in doing so the mayor is sacrificing the city' s interests to personal interests. The mayor cites figures to show that, in the current market, fees of the size proposed would significantly reduce the number of building starts and thus, on balance, result in a revenue loss to the city. But the important point is that the mayor' s family is heavily involved in real estate development and thus has a strong financial interest in the matter.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the main conclusion of the city council member's argument is that imposing real estate development fees is the best way for the city to exploit the available sources of revenue?
answers: The argument mentions no other methods of exploiting sources of revenue and so does not address the relative importance of development fees.
The argument does not directly address whether the mayor's advancement of the contrary argument regarding the effect of reduced building starts is correct or not.
Financial interests by the mayor's family are asserted, but they are not the argument's main conclusion.
The argument concludes that the mayor's reluctance to impose development fees is due to his and his family's personal financial interest in the matter, due to them being impacted by such fees.
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following most accurately and completely expresses the main conclusion of the city council member's argument?
main_answers: Significantly reducing the number of building starts would not, on balance, result in revenue loss to the city.
Imposing real estate development fees is the best way for the city to exploit the available sources of revenue.
The mayor's family has a strong financial interest in preventing the passage of legislation that would impose real estate development fees.
In blocking council members' attempts to impose real estate development fees, the mayor is sacrificing the city's interests to personal interests.
others.target_option: Imposing real estate development fees is the best way for the city to exploit the available sources of revenue.

context: Physician: In itself, exercise does not cause heart attacks; rather, a sudden increase in an exercise regimen can be a cause. When people of any physical condition suddenly increase their amount of exercise, they also increase their risk of heart attack. As a result, there will be an increased risk of heart attack among employees of this company due to the new health program.
question: Why does the conclusion not logically follow even if it is assumed that all employees, no matter what their physical condition, will participate in the new health program?
answers: Even if all the employees participated, the increased risk of heart attack would only happen if they suddenly increase their activity level. If everyone exercised at their current level then participating in the program will not lead to an increased risk of hear attack.

The text does not state if this is a sudden change by the company or if they are just changing health programs. Even if it is sudden, the suddenness of the program does not increase risk of heart attack- it is the sudden increase in actual exercise.

If an abrupt increase in exercise will increase the risk of heart attack, then an increase in heart attacks would happen with this new program because people suddenly increases their activity when they joined the program.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The conclusion drawn by the physician follows logically if which one of the following is assumed?
main_answers: Employees will abruptly increase their amount of exercise as a result of the new health program.
The new health program will force employees of all levels of health to exercise regularly.
The new health program constitutes a sudden change in the company's policy.
All employees, no matter what their physical condition, will participate in the new health program.
others.target_option: All employees, no matter what their physical condition, will participate in the new health program.

context: Correctly measuring the productivity of service workers is complex. Consider, for example, postal workers: they are often said to be more productive if more letters are delivered per postal worker. But is this really true? What if more letters are lost or delayed per worker at the same time that more are delivered?
question: What is the reason for the objection not being based on doubts about the truth of the statement that postal workers are representative of service workers in general?
answers: This is doubted to be true since the text determines instances when quality of services is ignored in determining productivity, but those quality is just as important as the other things counted in productivity.
This would not be in doubt since the argument uses postal workers as an example of how measuring productivity of service workers is not clear cut.
This is not called into doubt because the text offers the question about the letters that are delayed or not delivered. This implies that these pieces also relate to measuring productivity.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The objection implied above to the productivity measure described is based on doubts about the truth of which of the following statements?
main_answers: The delivery of letters is the primary activity of the postal service.
Postal workers are representative of service workers in general.
The quality of services rendered can appropriately be ignored in computing productivity.
The number of letters delivered is relevant to measuring the productivity of postal workers.
others.target_option: Postal workers are representative of service workers in general.

context: Studies in restaurants show that the tips left by customers who pay their bill in cash tend to be larger when the bill is presented on a tray that bears a credit card logo. Consumer psychologists hypothesize that simply seeing a credit-card logo makes many creditcard holders willing to spend more because it reminds them that their spending power exceeds the cash they have immediately available.
question: How does the fact that patrons who are under financial pressure from their credit-card obligations tend to tip less when presented with a restaurant bill on a tray with a credit-card logo than when the tray has no logo support the psychologists' interpretation of the studies?
answers: This clearly indicates that an association exists between credit availability via credit card and the propensity (or otherwise) to spend cash on tips, strengthening the suggestion of such a relationship in the passage.
This indicates that credit availability via a credit card cannot be the sole motivating factor for increased spending on tips, as argued in the passage.
This strongly indicates that the patrons studied cannot have been motivated to spend more cash due to the availability of  credit via a credit card.
This indicates that use of a credit card in fact motivates patrons to leave smaller tips, contradicting the argument made in the passage.
label: A

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most strongly supports the psychologists' interpretation of the studies?
main_answers: Patrons who are under financial pressure from their credit-card obligations tend to tip less when presented with a restaurant bill on a tray with a credit-card logo than when the tray has no logo.
The effect noted in the studies is not limited to patrons who have credit cards.
In virtually all of the cases in the studies, the patrons who paid bills in cash did not possess credit cards.
In general, restaurant patrons who pay their bills in cash leave larger tips than do those who pay by credit card.
others.target_option: Patrons who are under financial pressure from their credit-card obligations tend to tip less when presented with a restaurant bill on a tray with a credit-card logo than when the tray has no logo.

context: Gamba: Munoz claims that the Southwest Hopeville Neighbors Association overwhelmingly opposes the new water system, citing this as evidence of citywide opposition. The association did pass a resolution opposing the new water system, but only 25 of 350 members voted, with 10 in favor of the system. Furthermore, the 15 opposing votes represent far less than 1 percent of Hopeville' s population. One should not assume that so few votes represent the view of the majority of Hopeville' s residents.
question: What evidence supports the claim that Gamba's strategy of argumentation is attempting to cast doubt on a conclusion by claiming that the statistical sample on which the conclusion is based is too small to be dependable?
answers: Gamba makes no mention of likelihood to vote in relation to any group within the city.
Gamba asserts that Munoz's views have the declared support of less than 1% of one district of the city, and should not be generalised to a majority of the entire population of the city.
Gamba in fact questions both Munoz's assertion regarding the view of the Southwest Hopeville Neighbors Association AND his generalisation of this assertion to encompass the entire city.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Of the following, which one most accurately describes Gamba's strategy of argumentation?
main_answers: criticizing a view on the grounds that the view is based on evidence that is in principle impossible to disconfirm
attempting to cast doubt on a conclusion by claiming that the statistical sample on which the conclusion is based is too small to be dependable
attempting to refute an argument by showing that, contrary to what has been claimed, the truth of the premises does not guarantee the truth of the conclusion
questioning a conclusion based on the results of a vote, on the grounds that people with certain views are more likely to vote
others.target_option: attempting to cast doubt on a conclusion by claiming that the statistical sample on which the conclusion is based is too small to be dependable

context: Archaeologist: The allegation that members of the excavation team recovered artifacts outside the authorized site is unfounded. Archaeologists, unlike most treasure hunters, excavate artifacts to publish the results of their findings. But material recovered illegally could not be used in a publication without the illegal act being discovered. So it would be of no use to an archaeologist.
question: Why is the archaeologist's reasoning not considered to be flawed for presuming without evidence that most treasure hunters excavate artifacts to sell them?
answers: The archaeologist's reasoning only provides a reason for why an archaeologist specifically would not recover artifacts illegally, and does not provide any rationale for why non-archaeologist members of the excavation team would not recover artifacts illegally.
The archaeologist does not fail to consider that not all treasure hunters act illegally, as they consider archaeologists to be treasure hunters and claim that archaeologists would not act illegally.
The archaeologist does not presume that most treasure hunters excavate artifacts to sell them.
The archaeologist does not assume that any use of illegally recovered material is itself illegal.
label: C

main_answers: presumes without providing adequate justification that most treasure hunters excavate artifacts to sell them

fails to consider that not all treasure hunters act illegally

context: In the paintings by seventeenth-century Dutch artist Vermeer, we find several recurrent items: a satin jacket, a certain Turkish carpet, and wooden chairs with lion' s head finials. These reappearing objects might seem to evince a dearth of props. Yet we know that many of the props Vermeer used were expensive. Thus, while we might speculate about exactly why Vermeer worked with a small number of familiar objects, it was clearly not for lack of props that the recurrent items were used.
question: Why does the conclusion follow logically if it is assumed that if a dearth of props accounted for the recurrent objects in Vermeer's paintings, we would not see expensive props in any of them?
answers: If the satin jacket and wooden chairs in Vermeer's paintings were owned by his sister, then perhaps he couldn't afford to purchase props and had to borrow them.
Any props that were in Vermeer's studio would have been available for him to use, not just the ones seen in his paintings.
If Vermeer could afford to purchase the expensive items that are seen as props in his works, then he could certainly afford to purchase many inexpensive props as well.
If Vermeer was constantly including sentimental items in his paintings, then one could not assume that he didn't also own a lot of props that were not as important to him.
label: C

others.main_question: The conclusion follows logically if which one of the following is assumed?
main_answers: If a dearth of props accounted for the recurrent objects in Vermeer's paintings, we would not see expensive props in any of them.
The props that recur in Vermeer's paintings were always available to him.
The satin jacket and wooden chairs that recur in the paintings were owned by Vermeer's sister.
The several recurrent items that appeared in Vermeer's paintings had special sentimental importance for him.
others.target_option: If a dearth of props accounted for the recurrent objects in Vermeer's paintings, we would not see expensive props in any of them.

context: Bunty: The primary job of police officers is keeping the peace. Since their subsidiary jobs, such as controlling traffic, hinder their performance of the primary one, people other than police officers should be hired to perform the subsidiary jobs. Naina: To perform their primary job well, police officers must have the trust of citizens. They gain that trust by performing their subsidiary jobs, which are the only functions most citizens see them fulfill.
question: What is the reason for Bunty and Naina's disagreement about whether the subsidiary jobs police officers perform enable them to perform their primary job effectively?
answers: Bunty states that the primary job of police officers is keeping peace, and Naina's argument implies agrement with this.
The disagreement is whether subsidiary jobs help officers gain the trust of citizens, not whether it is possible altogether.

Bunty believes that the subsidiary jobs hinder the performance of their primary job, while Naina believes that they gain trust, and thus are helped in the performance of primary duties, through subsidiary jobs.
While Naina argues that police officers need to win the trust of citizens to keep the peace, Bunty's argument does not imply any disagreement with this.
label: C

whether police officers can effectively gain the trust of citizens
whether police officers need to win the trust of law-abiding citizens in order to keep the peace effectively

context: Ethicist: Studies have documented the capacity of placebos to reduce pain in patients who believe that they are receiving beneficial drugs. Some doctors say that they administer placebos because medically effective treatment reinforced by the placebo effect sometimes helps patients recover faster than good treatment alone. But administering placebos is nonetheless ethically questionable, for even if a placebo benefits a patient, a doctor might, for example, have prescribed it just to give the patient satisfaction that something was being done.
question: Why does the ethicist's argument not depend on the assumption that a patient's psychological satisfaction is not a consideration in administering medical treatment?
answers: The ethicist specifically cites that sometimes, a patient's psychological satisfaction is a consideration in administering medical treatment, so the argument does not rely on an assumption that it is not a consideration.
The ethicist's conclusion is that administering placebos is ethically questionable, which is not supported by a claim that administering placebos is justified.

The ethicist states that the ethical questionability of placebo administration arises from the reason that the doctor had for prescribing a placebo, such as wanting to assure the patient that something was being done.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The ethicist's argument depends on which one of the following assumptions?
main_answers: The pain relief produced by the placebo effect justifies the deception involved in administering a placebo.
Medical treatment that relies on the placebo effect alone is ethically indefensible.
The motivation for administering a placebo can be relevant to the ethical justification for doing so.
A patient's psychological satisfaction is not a consideration in administering medical treatment.
others.target_option: A patient's psychological satisfaction is not a consideration in administering medical treatment.

context: Infants younger than six months who have normal hearing can readily distinguish between acoustically similar sounds that are used as part of any language -- not only those used in the language spoken by the people who raise them. Young adults can readily distinguish between such sounds only in languages that they regularly use. It is known that the physiological capacity to hear begins to deteriorate after infancy. So the observed difference in the abilities of infants and young adults to distinguish between acoustically similar speech sounds must be the result of the physiological deterioration of hearing.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument considered flawed for taking a factor that might contribute to an explanation of the observed difference as a sufficient explanation for that difference?
answers: As the argument clearly ignores the possibility of neurological changes in the  brains of the participants with age contributing to the observed differences in perception, this characterisation of the reasoning is valid.
No references to any individuals within either group are made at any stage of the argument.
The cutoff point may have been arbitrary, but this does not invalidate any comparisons drawn between the two populations thus created.
This asserts a difference in data quality between measured populations without providing evidence for it, and as such is not relevant to the argument.
label: A

context: The formation of hurricanes that threaten the United States mainland is triggered by high atmospheric winds off the western coast of Africa. answers: The author states that a driving area with long city blocks, correlates with cars driving faster. Faster driving is assumed to be more dangerous for pedestrians, at least that is implied by author, more dangerous than shorter block areas.

The author states that a particular plant behaves one way in full sun exposure, and therefore must behave a polar or opposite way in night or no sun exposure. The assumption being that the flower must be open during a particular state of sun or no sun exposure.

context: According to a prediction of the not-so-distant future published in 1940, electricity would revolutionize agriculture. Electrodes would be inserted into the soil, and the current between them would kill bugs and weeds and make crop plants stronger.
question: Why does the fact that in order for farmers to avoid electric shock while working in the fields, the current could be turned off at such times without diminishing the intended effects not strongly indicate that the logic of the prediction is flawed?
answers: This shows a great flaw in the prediction and logo because weeds and crops are both types of plants and no explanation as to how the machine would know the difference between types of plants is given in the prediction.
This would support the prediction because it would take potential farmer or human injury or death out of the equation and make the prediction safer and easier to come true.

This also supports the prediction because it answers the question or concern as to how the planting machine and the electrodes would be able to safely interact and come into contact with one another. New parts would be designed to make this possible and safe.
None of the above choices
label: B

Because a planting machine would need to avoid coming into contact with the electrodes, new parts for planting machines would need to be designed.
It cannot be taken for granted that the use of electricity is always beneficial.
Since weeds are plants, electricity would affect weeds in the same way as it would affect crop plants.

context: Lactose, a sugar found in milk, aids in the absorption of calcium, which in turn is required for bone repair. In addition to there being shortages of milk in tropical areas, inhabitants of these areas lose the ability to absorb lactose, unlike people from nontropical areas. Yet inhabitants of tropical areas have no more problems with bone repair than do people who inhabit nontropical areas.
question: Explain why the fact that people living in tropical areas periodically take tablets containing lactose when there are shortages of milk does not help to resolve the apparent paradox described above.
answers: The passage does not mention anything about taking lactose tablets.
Genetics are not mentioned to have an effect on lactose.
The passage does not mention anything about the amount of milk consumption.
This shows that something else in the body can aid in calcium absorption other than lactose.
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to resolve the apparent paradox described above?
main_answers: People living in tropical areas periodically take tablets containing lactose when there are shortages of milk.
Milk consumption has fallen in both tropical and nontropical areas.
The extent to which people living in tropical areas lose the ability to absorb lactose depends on a genetic predisposition.
The abundant sunlight in tropical areas causes the human body to produce vitamin D naturally, which aids in the absorption of calcium.
others.target_option: People living in tropical areas periodically take tablets containing lactose when there are shortages of milk.

context: Even if many more people in the world excluded meat from their diet, world hunger would not thereby be significantly reduced.
question: Explain why the fact that often people go hungry because they live in remote barren areas where there is no efficient distribution for emergency food relief does not call into question the claim above.
answers: This is showing that both meat and crops have issues.  The argument was just focused on what would happend if meat was solely removed.
If you replace growing grain on land where animals are you would be able to feed more people with the grain than with the meat.  This could end hunger.
This does not show a connection to not eating meat.  This is focusing on scarity of food based on an emergency.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most calls into question the claim above?
main_answers: Often people go hungry because they live in remote barren areas where there is no efficient distribution for emergency food relief.
Hunger often results from natural disasters like typhoons or hurricanes, which sweep away everything in their path.
Both herds and crops are susceptible to devastating viral and other diseases.
The amount of land needed to produce enough meat to feed one person for a week can grow enough grain to feed more than ten people for a week.
others.target_option: Often people go hungry because they live in remote barren areas where there is no efficient distribution for emergency food relief.

context: In a recent poll of chief executive officers (CEOs) of 125 large corporations, the overwhelming majority claimed that employee training and welfare is of the same high priority as customer satisfaction. So the popular belief that the top management of large corporations behaves indifferently to the needs and aspirations of employees is unfounded.
question: What is the rationale for why the argument is considered vulnerable to criticism for presuming, without giving justification, that the CEOs' claims are reflected in actual practice?
answers: The argument does not depend on the correctness of the CEOs' priorities, only on their relative perceived importance.
The CEOs may perceive that employee training and welfare are as important as customer satisfaction, but does not give examples of how CEOs actually implement these priorities.
The argument is based on a poll of 125 large-company CEOs, which is a pretty large sample.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that it
main_answers: fails to define adequately the term "top management"
presumes, without giving justification, that the CEOs' priorities tend to be misplaced
presumes, without giving justification, that the CEOs' claims are reflected in actual practice
makes a generalization based on an unrepresentative sample
others.target_option: presumes, without giving justification, that the CEOs' claims are reflected in actual practice

context: A very popular ice-cream shop recently raised the price of an ice-cream soda by $0. 20, from $1. 80 to $2. 00. Within a week of the price increase, all of the waiters-and waitresses had quit.
question: What is the reason for why the fact that the price increase allowed the shop to retain its popular generous portions of ice cream does not help to explain the resignations of the waiters and waitresses?
answers: If regular customers still came into the shop, the demand stayed the same. If demand is the same, then the wait staff would have the same work expectations and same pay and would not need to quit.
If tips decreased then the overall pay of the wait staff decreased. That would lead to them leaving to find a better paying job.
Retaining the same generous portions would not affect the wait staffs job. And if their job was not effected, they would not quit.
If the wage rate were the same and the staff were making the same amount of money then they would not need to look for another job.
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, would most help to explain the resignations of the waiters and waitresses?
main_answers: The price increase allowed the shop to retain its popular generous portions of ice cream.
The waiters and waitresses received fewer tips than before because the increased price deprived customers of change that many had left as tips.
The increased price of ice-cream sodas did not affect the wage rate at which the waiters and waitresses were paid.
Regular customers continued to frequent the shop, despite the increase in the price of ice cream sodas.
others.target_option: The price increase allowed the shop to retain its popular generous portions of ice cream.

context: Editorial: Contrary to popular belief, teaching preschoolers is not especially difficult, for they develop strict systems (e. g. , for sorting toys by shape), which help them to learn, and they are always intensely curious about something new in their world.
question: How does the fact that children intensely curious about new things have very short attention spans weaken the editorial's argument?
answers: Stating that children have very short attention spans would weaken the argument that teaching preschoolers is not difficult because it would take a lot of time, effort, and energy in order to keep them on task and continually redirect their attention.
Lower levels of stress typically have a correlation with the ease or difficulty of jobs. Low levels of stress strengthens the argument that teaching preschoolers is not difficult.

Preschoolers imitating adults would result in the majority of preschoolers acting mature and following routines and directions easily which would strengthen the argument that teaching preschoolers is not difficult.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the editorial's argument?
main_answers: Children intensely curious about new things have very short attention spans.
Preschool teachers generally report lower levels of stress than do other teachers.
Preschoolers have a tendency to imitate adults, and most adults follow strict routines.
Some older children also develop strict systems that help them learn.
others.target_option: Children intensely curious about new things have very short attention spans.

context: Trent is a member of the SWAT Team, the most elite tactical unit at the city police department. SWAT apprehends more suspected criminals than all other police units combined. Taken as a whole, the police department solves a higher percentage of crime than ever before in its history. Within the SWAT team, Trent' s four-man unit is the most successful. However, the number of unsolved crime increases every year.
question: Why does the statement that Trent's SWAT team is the city's best police unit not logically resolve the apparent paradox?
answers: SWAT does not respond to property damage and this is more focused on Trent's SWAT unit and their performance and correlation to increased unsolved crime rate per year.
If the total number of crimes increases every year, it would make sense that the number of unsolved crimes would also increase no matter how well-performing Trent's unit is.
If they are the best police unit in the city, one would think they would solve even more crime and so it does not explain the number of unsolved crimes increasing every year
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following statements, if true, most logically resolves the apparent paradox?
main_answers: Trent's SWAT team is the city's best police unit.
The total number of crimes increases every year.
Violent crime has decreased dramatically, while petty drug offenses have increased substantially.
The police department focuses more on crimes involving serious injury or significant property damage.
others.target_option: Trent's SWAT team is the city's best police unit.

The total number of crimes increases every year.
Violent crime has decreased dramatically, while petty drug offenses have increased substantially.
The police department focuses more on crimes involving serious injury or significant property damage.
others.target_option: Violent crime has decreased dramatically, while petty drug offenses have increased substantially.

context: Trent is a member of the SWAT Team, the most elite tactical unit at the city police department. SWAT apprehends more suspected criminals than all other police units combined. Taken as a whole, the police department solves a higher percentage of crime than ever before in its history. Within the SWAT team, Trent' s four-man unit is the most successful. However, the number of unsolved crime increases every year.
question: Why does the fact that the police department focuses more on crimes involving serious injury or significant property damage not logically resolve the apparent paradox?
answers: If the total number of crimes increases every year, it would make sense that the number of unsolved crimes would also increase no matter how well-performing Trent's unit is.
SWAT does not respond to property damage and this is more focused on Trent's SWAT unit and their performance and correlation to increased unsolved crime rate per year.
If they are the best police unit in the city, one would think they would solve even more crime and so it does not explain the number of unsolved crimes increasing every year
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which of the following statements, if true, most logically resolves the apparent paradox?
main_answers: Trent's SWAT team is the city's best police unit.
The total number of crimes increases every year.
Violent crime has decreased dramatically, while petty drug offenses have increased substantially.
The police department focuses more on crimes involving serious injury or significant property damage.
others.target_option: The police department focuses more on crimes involving serious injury or significant property damage.

context: In a town containing a tourist attraction, hotel and restaurant revenues each increased more rapidly over the past year than did revenue from the sale of passes to the attraction, which are valid for a full year. This led those in charge of the attraction to hypothesize that visitors were illicitly selling or sharing the passes.
question: Why does the fact that during the past year other tourist attractions have opened up in the area help to undermine the hypothesis of those in charge of the tourist attraction?
answers: This answer does help to undermine the attraction owners' argument. If other attractions have opened up over the past year, it could simply be that the attraction is experiencing more competition. It doesn't have to be true that people are selling or sharing their passes; it could just be that people are choosing to patronize attractions other than this attraction.

This answer does help to undermine the attraction owners' argument because if this statement is true, then it's probably the higher prices of hotels and meals that have caused the hotel and restaurant industries' profits to increase. If the cost of the attraction passes has NOT increased, it makes sense that they would see less revenue growth than the restaurant/hotel industries.

This does help to undermine the attraction owners' argument because if the passes are a one-time expense, and then people can visit for a whole year, the repeat visitors are essentially getting in for "Free." They pay the cost upfront, and then the attraction makes no more revenue off them for a whole year. So if people possessing passes are making frequent trips to the attraction throughout the year, it makes sense that the attraction's revenues would stagnate.

If this was true, it would not undermine the hypothesis of those in charge of the tourist attraction, because it would mean that the increased revenues of the hotel and restaurant industries are NOT due to tourists taking longer vacations (thus paying more for lodging, meals, etc.). Therefore, there must still be some other reason that hotel/restaurant revenues are increasingly more rapidly than the revenue of the tourist attraction, leaving the illegal selling/sharing of passes as a possibility.
label: A

others.main_question: Each of the following, if true, helps to undermine the hypothesis of those in charge of the tourist attraction EXCEPT:
main_answers: During the past year other tourist attractions have opened up in the area.
While the cost of passes is unchanged since last year, hotel and meal prices have risen.
The local board of tourism reports that the average length of stay for tourists remained unchanged over the past year.
Those possessing passes made more frequent trips to the attraction last year than in previous years.
others.target_option: During the past year other tourist attractions have opened up in the area.

context: Many people limit the intake of calories and cholesterol in their diet in order to lose weight and reduce the level of cholesterol in their blood. When a person loses weight, the fat cells in that person' s body decrease in size but not in number. As they decrease in size, fat cells spill the cholesterol they contain into the bloodstream. Ttherefore, a person who goes on a low-calorie, low cholesterol diet __ .
question: What is the reasoning behind the conclusion that someone who begins a high-fat diet might at first have an increased level of cholesterol in his or her blood?
answers: Increased calorie consumption would not help one lose weight.
The person on such a diet would lose weight and when losing weight, the fat cells decrease in size.
The person will initially have their cholesterol dumped into their blood stream contained within their fat cells.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following most logically completes the argument?
main_answers: will both decrease the level of cholesterol in his or her blood and gain weight
might at first have an increased level of cholesterol in his or her blood
will not lose weight any faster than will a person whose diet is high in calories
will not decrease the size of his or her fat cells
others.target_option: might at first have an increased level of cholesterol in his or her blood

context: For a trade embargo against a particular country to succeed, a high degree of both international accord and ability to prevent goods from entering or leaving that country must be sustained. A total blockade of Patria's ports is necessary to an embargo, but such an action would be likely to cause international discord over the embargo.
question: What evidence is there to suggest that the claims do not strongly support the conclusion that the balance of opinion is likely to favor Patria in the event of a blockade?
answers: Explanation is given that a blockade would only be successful if complete and it is not implied that a simple blockade would give way to a successful embargo.
Explanation for a successful embargo does not necessarily require a certain international opinion as much as it requires a complete stop of imports and exports.
There is no indication that Patria is preferred or not.
The mention of how thorough an embargo would have to be to be successful supports the idea that an embargo would be likely to fail.
label: C

others.main_question: The claims above, if true, most strongly support which of the following conclusions?
main_answers: The balance of opinion is likely to favor Patria in the event of a blockade.
Any trade embargo against Patria would be likely to fail at some time.
A naval blockade of Patria's ports would ensure that no goods enter or leave Patria.
For a blockade of Patria's ports to be successful, international opinion must be unanimous.
others.target_option: The balance of opinion is likely to favor Patria in the event of a blockade.

context: DataCom, a company that filed many patents last year, was financially more successful last year than were its competitors, none of which filed many patents. It is ttherefore likely that DataCom owed its greater financial success to the fact that it filed many patents last year.
question: Why is the argument not considered to be flawed for applying a generalization to an exceptional case?
answers: The author assumes that patent filings is the only reason why DataCom performed better than its competitors, without providing for the possibility of other factors or explaining why patents are the main factor.
There is no evidence provided in the article that DataCom's outperformance is an exceptional or out of the ordinary case of patent filings driving financial success.

The article does not provide specifics of how DataCom's patents drove financial out performance versus its competitors or consider that other relevant factors like marketing or operating efficiency could be giving DataCom a competitive advantage.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that it
main_answers: gives no reason to exclude the possibility that other differences between DataCom and its competitors accounted for its comparative financial success
applies a generalization to an exceptional case
presupposes what it sets out to demonstrate about the relationship between the financial success of DataCom's competitors and the number of patents they filed
confuses a company's financial success with its technological innovativeness
others.target_option: applies a generalization to an exceptional case

context: An analysis of the XO Candy Corporation divided its products into two categories: chocolate-based candies and non-chocolate-based candies. The analysis shows that, unlike the non-chocolate candies, few chocolate candies sold enough units to be profitable. Nevertheless, stopping production of the unprofitable chocolate candies will not necessarily make the entire company more profitable, because__ .
question: What is the logical basis for concluding that a large proportion of XO's customers are those who initially bought XO's chocolate candies and eventually went on to buy other candies made by XO?
answers: No part of the argument suggests that the date that certain product categories were developed is of relevance to the sensibility of what categories to continue producing.

Customers being attracted to a certain overall unprofitable product category before moving on to be more regular and loyal consumers of the more profitable product category explains why as the statement says, the former category is worthwhile to keep around for overall company profitability.
If a product category is not especially profitable, merely changing the particular products in that category doesn't mean that the category will necessarily become profitable.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which of the following most logically completes the passage?
main_answers: the recipes of the chocolate candies date from the 19th century, while the non-chocolate candies were all developed more recently.
a large proportion of XO's customers are those who initially bought XO's chocolate candies and eventually went on to buy other candies made by XO.
XO has recently removed its two lowest-selling chocolate candies from their product line and replaced them with different types of chocolate candies.
the chocolate candies are distributed differently than the non-chocolate candies, as chocolates are more popular on the coasts.
others.target_option: a large proportion of XO's customers are those who initially bought XO's chocolate candies and eventually went on to buy other candies made by XO.

context: A new gardening rake with an S-shaped handle reduces compression stress on the spine during the pull stroke to about one-fifth of what it is with a straight-handled rake. During the push stroke, however, compression stress is five times more with the new rake than with a straight-handled rake. Neither the push stroke nor the pull stroke with a straight-handled rake produces enough compression stress to cause injury, but compression stress during the push stroke with the new rake is above the danger level. Ttherefore, straight-handled rakes are better than the new rakes for minimizing risk of spinal injury.
question: Why is it valid to conclude that the conclusion is properly drawn from the premises given if it is true that compression stress resulting from pushing is the only cause of injuries to the spine that occur as a result of raking?
answers: If compression stress resulting from pushing is the only cause of spine injuries from raking, then a straight-handled rake is better than an s-handled rake because a straight-handled rake puts less pressure stress on the spine during the push stroke.
The comparison is only between s-handled and straight-handled rakes, so other handle designs or the possibility of other designs is not relevant to the argument.
It would not be necessary for all strokes to be push strokes, only that the s-handle creates more pressure on the spine with any push stroke.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The conclusion above is properly drawn from the premises given if which one of the following is true?
main_answers: Compression stress resulting from pushing is the only cause of injuries to the spine that occur as a result of raking.
A garden rake can never be used in such a way that all the strokes with that rake are push strokes.
It is not possible to design a garden rake with a handle that is other than straight or S-shaped.
Raking is a frequent cause of spinal injury among gardeners.
others.target_option: Compression stress resulting from pushing is the only cause of injuries to the spine that occur as a result of raking.

context: Most people are indignant at the suggestion that they are not reliable authorities about their real wants. Such self-knowledge, however, is not the easiest kind of knowledge to acquire. Indeed, acquiring it often requires hard and even potentially risky work. To avoid such effort, people unconsciously convince themselves that they want what society says they should want.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the argument's main point is that knowledge of what one really wants is as desirable as it is usually thought to be?
answers: The argument does not make any claims about what people should want, only that people unconsciously align their wants with what society believes they should want.
The argument claims that knowledge of what one really wants is difficult to achieve, but it does not make any judgment on how desirable this knowledge is.
The argument discusses people's avoidance of putting in effort to understand their real wants, but not avoidance of making difficult decisions.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The main point of the argument is that
main_answers: people cannot really want what they should want
knowledge of what one really wants is not as desirable as it is usually thought to be
people are not necessarily reliable authorities about what they really want
people usually avoid making difficult decisions
others.target_option: knowledge of what one really wants is not as desirable as it is usually thought to be

context: In the last election, 89 percent of reporters voted for the incumbent. The content of news programs reveals that reporters allowed the personal biases reflected in this voting pattern to affect their news coverage: 54 percent of coverage concerning the challenger was negative, compared with only 30 percent of that concerning the incumbent.
question: Why is the argument not logically flawed for disregarding the possibility that reporters generally fear losing access to incumbents more than they fear losing access to challengers?
answers: The electorate's voting behavior does not affect the arguments logic.
There could be actual news that supports the reporters views regardless of their biases.
It actually supports the probability that they fear losing access to incumbents more.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: The argument is logically most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that it
main_answers: ignores the possibility that there was more negative news worthy of reporting concerning the challenger than there was concerning the incumbent
ignores the possibility that reporters generally fear losing access to incumbents more than they fear losing access to challengers
ignores the possibility that the electorate's voting behavior is not significantly affected by the content of coverage of candidates
presumes, without providing justification, that both candidates received equal amounts of coverage overall
others.target_option: ignores the possibility that reporters generally fear losing access to incumbents more than they fear losing access to challengers

context: Footwear designer John de los Santos last year released several limited editions of his best-known model of sneaker in exotic colors and prints. Although the new releases were priced substantially higher than their counterparts in more traditional colors, they sold out within a week of their release, and have since been selling on the resale market for up to four times the original price. The cost of producing the sneakers in exotic prints is no greater than that of producing them in more traditional colors, so de los Santos could earn a higher profit per unit by producing a greater percentage of his sneakers in such prints.
question: What is the reasoning behind the assumption that consumers' willingness to pay higher prices for the exotic sneakers was not influenced by the relative scarcity of those sneakers in drawing the conclusion?
answers: The passage does not go into any detail concerning counterfeit products and how easy or difficult it would be to reproduce the sneakers. As no mention of counterfeit products were made it would be difficult to make an assumption regarding the ability to do so.
The passage focuses only on De los Santo’s designs and not about the competition of other designers and no mention is made as to the price differences between Santo and his competitors.

The passage states that consumers will continue to pay higher prices for the exotic colored shoes even if more are produced which reasons that consumers are not paying higher prices for the product because of scarcity or limited production.
No information is given concerning Santos competitors and what they have produced in the past or will be producing in the near future.
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following is an assumption made in drawing the conclusion above?
main_answers: Consumers' willingness to pay higher prices for the exotic sneakers was not influenced by the relative scarcity of those sneakers.
The workmanship of de los Santos's sneakers is of such high quality that it is impossible for lower-budget shoemakers to produce counterfeit versions of them.
De los Santos's sneakers are not priced substantially higher than those of the designers who compete most directly with him.
The designers who compete most directly with de los Santos will not produce similar lines of limited-edition sneakers in the near future.
others.target_option: Consumers' willingness to pay higher prices for the exotic sneakers was not influenced by the relative scarcity of those sneakers.

context: The primary task of a university is to educate. But to teach well, professors must be informed about new developments in their disciplines, and that requires research. Yet many universities cannot afford to support faculty research adequately. So a lack of funds for research adversely affects the degree to which a university can fulfill its central mission.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that, in order to be able to teach well, university professors must conduct research based on the argument?
answers: The text states that lack of research by the educators will have a varying degree of adverse effects. Since that will effect some of the ability to teach effectively, the quality of education is reduced.
The text states that the primary task is to educate. It does not state it has to be effective. It implies that is should be effective, but does not state that it has to.

The text states that research is needed to stay informed about developments in their field. That research does not have to be their own research and they can still teach well if they use outside research in their field.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the conclusion of the argument?
main_answers: Lack of financial support for faculty research is the root of ineffective teaching at universities.
In order to be able to teach well, university professors must conduct research.
Effective teaching is the primary mission of a university.
Lack of funds for research reduces the quality of education a university provides.
others.target_option: In order to be able to teach well, university professors must conduct research.

context: Every adult male woolly monkey is larger than even the largest female woolly monkey. In colonies of woolly monkeys, any adult male will dominate any female.

context: The average cable television company offers its customers 50 channels, but new fiber-optic lines will enable telephone companies to provide 100 to 150 television channels to their customers for the same price as cable companies charge for 50. Ttherefore, cable companies will be displaced by the new television services offered by telephone companies within a few years.
question: How does the fact that some telephone companies own cable companies in areas other than those in which they provide telephone services not strengthen the argument?
answers: Customers will not have to give up any of their preferred shows, when they switch over, so there is no down side for them.
If many of the cable companies are owned by the telephone companies that offer fiber optic lines, then these companies will not be displaced, but continue to exist.
If the out of pocket expenses for installing the service is too great, many households will not be able to take advantage of the fiber optic service.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to strengthen the argument?
main_answers: Some telephone companies own cable companies in areas other than those in which they provide telephone services.
The most popular movies and programs on channels carried by cable companies will also be offered on channels carried by the fiberoptic lines owned by the telephone companies.
Cable television companies will respond to competition from the telephone companies by increasing the number of channels they offer.
The initial cost per household of installing new fiber-optic television service will exceed the current cost of installing cable television service.
others.target_option: Some telephone companies own cable companies in areas other than those in which they provide telephone services.

context: The corpus callosum -- the thick band of nerve fibers connecting the brain' s two hemispheres -- of a musician is on average larger than that of a nonmusician. The differences in the size of corpora callosa are particularly striking when adult musicians who began training around the age of seven are compared to adult nonmusicians. Ttherefore, musical training, particularly when it begins at a young age, causes certain anatomic brain changes.
question: Why does the argument not depend on the assumption that musical training late in life does not cause anatomic changes to the brain?
answers: This may or may not be true, but the argument rests on comparing their corpora callosa to nonmusicians, not to each other.
We don't know if there are other activities which grow the corpus callosum, so there may be adult nonmusicians with a larger corpus callosum, but we don't know either way.
The changes are just not as striking, which mean they still occur.
If musical training grows the corpora callosa, it is necessarily true that a beginner with no training will be average.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
main_answers: Musical training late in life does not cause anatomic changes to the brain.
Adult nonmusicians did not participate in activities when they were children that would have stimulated any growth of the corpus callosum.
For any two musicians whose training began around the age of seven, their corpora callosa are approximately the same size.
The corpora callosa of musicians, before they started training, do not tend to be larger than those of nonmusicians of the same age.
others.target_option: Musical training late in life does not cause anatomic changes to the brain.

context: Child-rearing Expert: Parents should never discipline their children in public. Some children who are disciplined in public suffer from attention deficit disorder. This shows that these children do not need discipline, but rather need assistance from their parents or firm instructions to help the children pay attention to their surroundings.
question: Why is the child-rearing expert's reasoning flawed for not considering the possibility that the children who are disciplined in public, but do not suffer from attention deficit disorder, might benefit from being disciplined in public?
answers: The expert made no mention of children disciplined in private nor does anything in the passage implicate the idea that they also suffer from the disorder.
Firm instructions would be preferable to other means of discipline such as spanking, etc.
The expert explicitly states that assistance is the preferred method of handling children with the disorder.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Each of the following describes a flaw in the child-rearing expert's reasoning EXCEPT:
main_answers: It assumes that children with attention deficit disorder can pay attention to their surroundings without discipline.
It presumes, with justification, that children who are disciplined in private also suffer from attention deficit disorder.
It overlooks the possibility that the children who are disciplined in public, but do not suffer from attention deficit disorder, might benefit from being disciplined in public.
It neglects the possibility that providing firm instructions could be a form of disciplining children in public.
others.target_option: It overlooks the possibility that the children who are disciplined in public, but do not suffer from attention deficit disorder, might benefit from being disciplined in public.

context: Political scientist: Some analysts point to the government' s acceptance of the recent protest rally as proof that the government supports freedom of popular expression. But the government supports no such thing. Supporting freedom of popular expression means accepting the expression of ideas that the government opposes as well as the expression of ideas that the government supports. The message of the protest rally was one that the government entirely supports.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the political scientist's argument requires the assumption that the government would not have accepted a protest rally whose message it opposed?
answers: This text did not mention any particular groups who wanted to stage a protest and did not. It also did not give the name of the group that did protest. Since there was no reference to any group, you can not know if a group did not protest or the reason why they did not.

The text here states that the protest here was one the government supports. Freedom of expression applies to those the government do and do not support. The text implies that the government does not support views opposed to theirs.
There was no mention of what the protesters were protesting here, only that there was a protest.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption that is required by the political scientist's argument?
main_answers: The government would not have accepted a protest rally whose message it opposed.
The message of the recent protest rally did not concern any function of the government.
The government feared a backlash if it did not show acceptance of the recent protest rally.
There are groups that are inhibited from staging a protest rally out of a fear of government response.
others.target_option: The government would not have accepted a protest rally whose message it opposed.

context: Some students attending a small university with a well-known choir live off campus. From the fact that all music majors are members of the choir, a professor in the music department concluded that none of the students who live off campus is a music major.
question: Why does the professor's conclusion not properly follow even if it is assumed that all students who are members of the choir are music majors?
answers: While all music majors may be members of the choir, there could be students with other majors that are also members.

context: The top prize in architecture, the Pritzker Prize, is awarded for individual achievement, like Nobel Prizes for science. But architects are judged by their buildings, and buildings are the result of teamwork. As achievements, buildings are not like scientific discoveries, but like movies, which compete for awards for best picture. Thus, it would be better if the top prize in architecture were awarded to the best building rather than the best architect.
question: Why does the argument not succeed in concluding that one type of object has more inherent value than the other by making a distinction between two different types of objects?
answers: The argument does not make any value judgments about the different types of objects or achievements discussed.

The argument concludes that awards in architecture should be given for buildings rather than individuals due to the achievements being the result of teamwork, comparing to how awards are given for movies, which are another type of achievement done through teamwork.

The argument does compare between awards for architecture and awards for movies and scientific discoveries, but it does not make any claim about the applicability of criticisms from one type of award to any others.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The argument proceeds by
main_answers: making a distinction between two different types of objects in order to conclude that one has more inherent value than the other
contending that an action is inappropriate by presenting an argument that a corresponding action in an analogous case is inappropriate
reaching a conclusion about the way something should be done in one field on the basis of comparisons with corresponding practices in other fields
pointing to similarities between two practices as a basis for concluding that criticisms of one practice can rightly be applied to the other
others.target_option: making a distinction between two different types of objects in order to conclude that one has more inherent value than the other

context: When a group of people starts a company, the founders usually serve as sources both of funding and of skills in marketing, management, and technical matters. It is unlikely that a single individual can both provide adequate funding and be skilled in marketing, management, and technical matters. Ttherefore, companies founded by groups are more likely to succeed than companies founded by individuals.
question: What is the basis for the argument not requiring the assumption that some founding members of successful companies can provide both funding and skills in marketing, management, or technical matters?
answers: The argument states that these skills are important when starting a new company.
The argument is concerned with the overall skills and contributions of the company not how these skills are provided.
The argument is not concerned with who can more easily acquire these abilities.
None of the above choices

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument?
main_answers: Some founding members of successful companies can provide both funding and skills in marketing, management, or technical matters.

New companies are more likely to succeed when their founders can provide adequate funding and skills in marketing, management, and technical abilities than if they must secure funding or skills from nonfounders.
A new company is more likely to succeed if every founding member contributes equally to the company's initial funding than if some members contribute more funds than others.
others.target_option: Some founding members of successful companies can provide both funding and skills in marketing, management, or technical matters.

context: The Minoan civilization flourished on the island of Crete around 2000 B. (C) The discovery on Crete of large numbers of bronze implements and the furnaces used in their manufacture shows that the Minoans had a thriving bronze industry. Moreover, many bronze artifacts from this period that are similar in style to those produced on Crete have been found in southern Greece. Hence it is probable that, besides making bronzeware for domestic use, the Minoans exported bronzeware to southern Greece.
question: Explain why the fact that copper and tin, the main ingredients of bronze, were present in Southern Greece does not strengthen the argument given.
answers: It would be possible for the Minoans to export pottery and not export their bronze items.
The presence of the bronze artifacts in southern Greece, without any furnaces or other means that could be used to produce them, makes it more likely that they were indeed imported from Crete.
Even if they had access to copper and tin in Southern Greece, if they had no way to forge them into bronze, then they had to have gotten the bronze artifacts from another civilization.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument given?
main_answers: No furnaces dating from the Minoan era and suitable for the manufacture of bronze implements have been found in southern Greece.
Copper and tin, the main ingredients of bronze, were present in Southern Greece.
The Minoans exported a great deal of pottery, which was highly valued by other ancient civilizations.
Some of the pieces of bronzeware found on Crete were non-Minoan in origin.
others.target_option: Copper and tin, the main ingredients of bronze, were present in Southern Greece.

context: Journalists agree universally that lying is absolutely taboo. Yet, while many reporters claim that spoken words ought to be quoted verbatim, many others believe that tightening a quote from a person who is interviewed is legitimate on grounds that the speaker' s remarks would have been more concise if the speaker had written them instead. Also, many reporters believe that, to expose wrongdoing, failing to identify oneself as a reporter is permissible, while others condemn such behavior as a type of lying.
question: Explain why the information does not support the claim that omission of the truth is the same thing as lying.
answers: Some reporters disagree on the morality of tightening a quote versus using it verbatim, as well as whether or not it is permissible to hide one's identity as a reporter.
The article points out areas of disagreement, but doesn't speak to the correctness of the differing opinions.
The article mentions the alteration of quotes and the hiding of one's identity as a reporter, but does not mention omission of truth.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following is most supported by the information above?
main_answers: Since lying is permissible in some situations, reporters are mistaken to think that it is absolutely taboo.
Reporters disagree on what sort of behavior qualifies as lying.
There is no correct answer to the question of whether lying in a given situation is right or wrong.
Omission of the truth is the same thing as lying.
others.target_option: Omission of the truth is the same thing as lying.

context: Trustee: The recent exhibit at the art museum was extensively covered by the local media, and this coverage seems to have contributed to the record-breaking attendance it drew. If the attendance at the exhibit had been low, the museum would have gone bankrupt and closed permanently, so the museum could not have remained open had it not been for the coverage from the local media.
question: Why is the reasoning in the trustee's argument not considered to be flawed for assuming that most people who read articles about the exhibit also attended the exhibit?
answers: It does not matter what another exhibit has done in the past.
The media covered it does not necessarily have an impact in all situations so the conclusion could not have been presupposed.
This is perfect causation without correlation. There is no way to know whether there would have been many attendees, there is no control group.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: The reasoning in the trustee's argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the argument
main_answers: presupposes the very conclusion that it is trying to prove
takes for granted that most people who read articles about the exhibit also attended the exhibit
fails to address the possibility that the exhibit would have drawn enough visitors to prevent bankruptcy even without media coverage
takes for granted that no previous exhibit at the museum had received such extensive media coverage
others.target_option: takes for granted that most people who read articles about the exhibit also attended the exhibit

context: Pacifist: It is immoral to do anything that causes harm to another person. But, since using force causes harm to another person, it is also immoral to threaten to use force, even when such a threat is made in self-defense.
question: Why does the fact that the line between use of force in self-defense and the aggressive use of force is always vague not help to justify the pacifist's reasoning?
answers: The use of force even for self defense is harmful and immoral.  The reasoning to the pacifist is that this is clear and not vague.
To a pacifist the circumstances do not matter if you are making a threat it is wrong.
This is very close to what a pacifist believes but the simple act of the threat is even enough just not the carrying out of the threat.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following principles, if valid, would most help to justify the pacifist's reasoning?
main_answers: Given the potential harm caused by the use of force, the line between use of force in self-defense and the aggressive use of force is always vague.
Whether a threat made in self-defense is immoral depends on the circumstances.
It is immoral to threaten to do what it is immoral to do.
It is immoral to carry out a threat if making the threat is itself immoral.
others.target_option: Given the potential harm caused by the use of force, the line between use of force in self-defense and the aggressive use of force is always vague.

context: To suit the needs of corporate clients, advertising agencies have successfully modified a strategy originally developed for political campaigns. This strategy aims to provide clients with free publicity and air time by designing an advertising campaign that is controversial, thus drawing prime-time media coverage and evoking public comment by officials.
question: Explain why the statements do not seriously undermine the assertion that campaign managers have transformed political campaigns by making increasing use of strategies borrowed from corporate advertising campaigns.
answers: The statements above do not describe any borrowing of strategies by political campaigns from corporate advertising campaigns, but rather only the reverse.
The statements above do not make any claim about the effectiveness of the described strategy in influencing voters in their voting decisions.

The described strategy focuses on publicity and controversy rather than persuasion, so if these strategies are effective, that means the usefulness of an advertising campaign also depends on how much publicity the campaign's advertisements generate.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The statements above, if true, most seriously undermine which one of the following assertions?
main_answers: Campaign managers have transformed political campaigns by making increasing use of strategies borrowed from corporate advertising campaigns.
Only a small percentage of eligible voters admit to being influenced by advertising campaigns in deciding how to vote.
Advertising agencies that specialize in campaigns for corporate clients are not usually chosen for political campaigns.
The usefulness of an advertising campaign is based solely on the degree to which the campaign's advertisements persuade their audiences.

context: Most road repairs require more time and money than is budgeted, but last summer' s nighttime repairs of Highway 93 and similar roads required no more time or money than had been budgeted. Ttherefore, making summer repairs to major roads at night would save both time and money.
question: Why does the fact that asphalt used in road repair tends to expand in warmer temperatures and contract in cooler temperatures not strongly support the conclusion drawn above?
answers: The lights and orange cones are not relevant enough to the time or money spent on the repairs to make a significant difference.
This argument only focuses on the budget and not the time.
The expansion and contraction of the asphalt is not relevant to the time and money spent on road repairs.
Since workers can work more comfortably at night, they are able to complete projects faster which saves time and money.

context: News item: The result of a recent public survey has been called into question because one of the pollsters admitted to falsifying data. question: Why is the news item's argument not considered to be flawed for not taking into account the possibility that people's opinions about investing in information technologies can change as new technologies are developed?

the conclusion of the survey would be verified if the falsified data were excluded

context: Montgomery, a biologist who is also well read in archaeology, has recently written a book on the origin and purpose of ancient monumental architecture. This book has received much positive attention in the popular press but has been severely criticized by many professional archaeologists for being too extreme. Montgomery' s views do not deserve a negative appraisal, however, since those views are no more extreme than the views of some professional archaeologists.
question: What is the basis for the argument being considered vulnerable to the criticism that it fails to establish that professional archaeologists' views that are at least as extreme as Montgomery's views do not deserve negative appraisal for that reason?
answers: The argument is not questioning the motives of others.
Just because there are other extreme views of professional archeologists, it doesn't mean that those views shouldn't be criticized as well or that Montgomery's views shouldn't get negative appraisal.
This argument is not made anywhere in the passage. There is no mention of biologists at all. This fact is irrelevant.
