others.main_question: The argument is most vulnerable to which one of the following criticisms?
main_answers: It fails to establish that professional archaeologists' views that are at least as extreme as Montgomery's views do not deserve negative appraisal for that reason.
It provides no independent evidence to show that the majority of professional archaeologists do not support Montgomery's views.
It attempts to support its position by calling into question the motives of anyone who supports an opposing position.
It assumes without warrant that many professional archaeologists consider biologists unqualified to discuss ancient architecture.
others.target_option: It fails to establish that professional archaeologists' views that are at least as extreme as Montgomery's views do not deserve negative appraisal for that reason.

context: The following exchange occurred after the Baseball Coach' s team suffered a heartbreaking loss in the final inning. Reporter: The team clearly did not rise to the challenge. I' m sure that getting zero hits in twenty at-bats with runners in scoring position hurt the team' s chances at winning the game. What are your thoughts on this devastating loss? Baseball Coach: Hitting with runners in scoring position was not the reason we lost this game. We made numerous errors in the field, and our pitchers gave out too many free passes. Also, we did not even need a hit with runners in scoring position. Many of those at-bats could have driven in the run by simply making contact. Our team did not deserve to win the game.
question: Explain why the main point of dispute between the reporter and baseball coach does not concern whether the loss was heartbreaking.
answers: The coach directly refutes the reporter's assertion that the lack of hitting with runners in scoring position was the primary reason for the loss by pointing out that hits weren't needed to score those runs and by pointing out problems with the pitching and fielding.

The coach does not refute the reporter's statement that the loss was heartbreaking.
The coach agrees with the reporter that the team did not rise to the challenge, just not why.
label: C

context: In recent years, many cabinetmakers have been winning acclaim as artists. But since furniture must be useful, cabinetmakers must exercise their craft with an eye to the practical utility of their product. For this reason, cabinetmaking is not art.
question: Why does the fact that some furniture is made to be placed in museums, where it will not be used by anyone, not support drawing the conclusion from the reason given for that conclusion?
answers: Furniture must be useful and practical. For this reason the passage tells us that cabinetworking is not art.

Making a generalization about what groups of people should or should not be concerned with is difficult and dangerous and is up to each individual. The passage does not make these inferences or generalizations and is focused solely upon stating that furniture is not art.
The passage does not go into this subject and is focused on whether or not furniture can be considered art and not how concerned artists are about the value of the products they create.
Placing furniture in a museum not to be used but to be viewed would make it art, which contradicts the passage’s conclusion that furniture is not art.
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following is an assumption that supports drawing the conclusion above from the reason given for that conclusion?
main_answers: Some furniture is made to be placed in museums, where it will not be used by anyone.
Artists are not concerned with the monetary value of their products.
Cabinetmakers should be more concerned with the practical utility of their products than they currently are.
An object is not an art object if its maker pays attention to the object's practical utility.
others.target_option: Some furniture is made to be placed in museums, where it will not be used by anyone.

context: In a study of the relationship between aggression and television viewing in nursery school children, many interesting interactions among family styles, aggression, and television viewing were found. High aggression occurred in both high-viewing and low-viewing children and this seemed to be related to parental lifestyle. High-achieving, competitive, middle-class parents, whose children did not watch much television, had more aggressive children than parents who planned their lives in an organized, child-centered way, which included larger amounts of television viewing.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that low levels of television viewing often lead to high levels of aggression among children based on the passage?
answers: The passage lists at least two different factors other than TV viewing which might influence the observed aggression levels, suggesting that no factor alone is responsible.
The passage indicates a correlation between aggression and parenting style but does not establish sole causation, as alternative factors such as inherited traits or TV viewing are also mentioned.
The passage does not establish the relative importance of any of the factors compared to the others which might also be contributing to differing levels of aggression.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following conclusions is best supported by the passage?
main_answers: If high-achieving, competitive, parents were more child-centered, their children would be less aggressive.
Low levels of television viewing often lead to high levels of aggression among children.
The level of aggression of a child cannot be predicted from levels of television viewing alone.
Parental lifestyle is less important than the amount of television viewing in determining the aggressiveness of children.
others.target_option: Low levels of television viewing often lead to high levels of aggression among children.

context: Undoubtedly, one' s freedom is always worth the risk of losing one' s life. Consider a person who is locked in a bare cement room with no hope of escape. This person is not really living and has nothing to lose.
question: What is the rationale for why the argument's reasoning is flawed for inappropriately generalizing from a single extreme case to a universal claim?
answers: It isn't taking into account more realistic events that one faces.  It is presenting you with a solely life or death situation.
It is focusing more on the freedom of oneself versus the freedom of others.
It is telling you that the opportunity is there whether or not it is attainable.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: A flaw in the argument's reasoning is that the argument
main_answers: generalizes inappropriately from a single extreme case to a universal claim
presumes, without providing justification, that nothing can have greater value than one's own freedom
fails to consider that it is not always possible to rebel physically against an encroachment on one's freedom
fails to establish that the freedom of others is worth taking risks for
others.target_option: generalizes inappropriately from a single extreme case to a universal claim

context: Chemical fertilizers not only create potential health hazards, they also destroy earthworms, which are highly beneficial to soil. For this reason alone the use of chemical fertilizers should be avoided. The castings earthworms leave behind are much richer than the soil they ingest, thus making a garden rich in earthworms much more fertile than a garden without them.
question: Why does the conclusion that the castings that earthworms leave behind are much richer than the soil they ingest not accurately express the main conclusion of the argument?
answers: This statement fails to mention chemical fertilizers, which are the main subject of the passage.
This statement is merely a side note about the benefits of earthworms and does not state anything about fertilizers.
While fertilizers are harmful to earthworms, this statement does not explain why this is a bad thing.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the main conclusion of the argument?
main_answers: The castings that earthworms leave behind are much richer than the soil they ingest.
Chemical fertilizers destroy earthworms.
The use of chemical fertilizers should be avoided.
Earthworms are highly beneficial to soil.
others.target_option: The castings that earthworms leave behind are much richer than the soil they ingest.

context: Humans' emotional tendencies are essentially unchanged from those of the earliest members of our species. Accordingly, although technology makes possible a wider range of individual and societal choices than in centuries past, humans are generally unable to choose more wisely.
question: Why does the argument not depend on assuming that regardless of the range of choices available to humans, they choose on the basis of their emotions alone?
answers: The article makes no linkage between emotional control and decision making, but rather an unchanging set of emotional tendencies to make decisions about an ever growing set of environments.
The argument states that humans' emotional tendencies are unchanged, but states nothing about exclusively relying on them to make decisions
The article assumes that we are using the same emotional tendencies to a whole new set of different circumstances and that those tendencies are ill equipped to deal with these changes.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The argument depends on assuming which one of the following?
main_answers: Regardless of the range of choices available to humans, they choose on the basis of their emotions alone.
Humans have undergone no significant changes since the origin of the species.
Humans would now be able to make wiser choices than in centuries past only if an essential change had taken place in humans' emotional dispositions.
Humans who make wise choices are generally in control of their emotions.
others.target_option: Regardless of the range of choices available to humans, they choose on the basis of their emotions alone.

context: Business ethicist: Managers of corporations have an obligation to serve shareholders as the shareholders would want to be served. Ttherefore, corporate managers have an obligation to act in the shareholders' best interest.
question: Why does the business ethicist's conclusion follow logically if it is assumed that shareholders would want to be served only in ways that are in their own best interest?
answers: Assuming all shareholders want to be served in identical ways does not mean that it would be in the best interest of all shareholders.

The obligation to serve shareholders as they would want to be served and therefore being obligated to serve them in their best interest assumes that shareholders want to be served in their own best interest.
Assuming that managers are always able to discern what is in the best inerest of shareholders does not mean that they will act in accordance with that interest.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The business ethicist's conclusion follows logically if which one of the following is assumed?
main_answers: Shareholders would want to be served only in ways that are in their own best interest.
Corporate managers are always able to discern what is in the best interest of shareholders.
All shareholders want to be served in identical ways.
The shareholders have interests that can best be served by corporate managers.
others.target_option: Shareholders would want to be served only in ways that are in their own best interest.

context: Criminologist: The main purpose of most criminal organizations is to generate profits. The ongoing revolutions in biotechnology and information technology promise to generate enormous profits. Ttherefore, criminal organizations will undoubtedly try to become increasingly involved in these areas.
question: Explain why the conclusion of the criminologist's argument is not properly inferred even if it is assumed that criminal organizations are already heavily involved in every activity that promises to generate enormous profits.
answers: The writer states seems to suggest that a category of criminal, will do illegal and also legal business activity, if they are both obviously profitable.
The author implies that a successful criminal organization that is profitable, will adapt and adjust into newer industry options, because they are focused on large profit.
The author assumes that because a category of criminal,  focuses on profit, they must be in all areas that produce profit, which may or may not be accurate.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: The conclusion of the criminologist's argument is properly inferred if which one of the following is assumed?
main_answers: Criminal organizations are already heavily involved in every activity that promises to generate enormous profits.
At least some criminal organizations are or will at some point become aware that the ongoing revolutions in biotechnology and information technology promise to generate enormous profits.
Any organization whose main purpose is to generate profits will try to become increasingly involved in any technological revolution that promises to generate enormous profits.
Most criminal organizations are willing to become involved in legal activities if those activities are sufficiently profitable.
others.target_option: Criminal organizations are already heavily involved in every activity that promises to generate enormous profits.

context: The chances that tropical storms will develop in a given area increase whenever the temperature of a large body of water in that area exceeds 26 degrees Celsius to a depth of about 60 meters. If the amount of carbon dioxide in the Earth' s atmosphere continues to increase, the temperatures of all of the Earth' s waters will rise, with the result that the number of large bodies of water whose temperatures exceed 26 degrees Celsius to a depth of about 60 meters will eventually be greater than it is today.
question: What is the basis for concluding that the statements above strongly support the conclusion that there are likely to be more tropical storms if the amount of carbon dioxide in the Earth's atmosphere continues to increase?
answers: Increased carbon leads to increased temperatures which leads to more storm activity, so this is necessarily true.
The opposite is stated, that increased carbon leads to increased temperatures which leads to stronger storms.
This cause and effect should be reversed, since increased carbon leads to increased temperatures.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The statements above, if true, most strongly support which one of the following conclusions?
main_answers: The number of large bodies of water whose temperatures exceed 26 degrees Celsius to a depth of about 60 meters is greater today than it ever was.
The ferocity of tropical storms does not depend on the amount of carbon dioxide in the Earth's atmosphere.
There are likely to be more tropical storms if the amount of carbon dioxide in the Earth's atmosphere continues to increase.
Any increase in the temperatures of the Earth's oceans would cause the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere to increase as well.
others.target_option: There are likely to be more tropical storms if the amount of carbon dioxide in the Earth's atmosphere continues to increase.

context: Kernland imposes a high tariff on the export of unprocessed cashew nuts in order to ensure that the nuts are sold to domestic processing plants. If the tariff were lifted and unprocessed cashews were sold at world market prices, more farmers could profit by growing cashews. However, since all the processing plants are in urban areas, removing the tariff would seriously hamper the government' s effort to reduce urban unemployment over the next five years.
question: How does the fact that a lack of profitable crops is driving an increasing number of small farmers in Kernland off their land and into the cities weaken the argument?
answers: Regardless what price processors pay for the unprocessed cashews, they will sell them abroad at higher world market prices if allowed to do so.
If true then removing the tariff could actually improve employment, particularly in rural farming areas, create more raw products which in turn could reduce unemployment in urban areas as well.
Other cashew producing countries subsidizing their processing plants is irrelevant because the farmers would still sell the unprocessed cashews abroad at world prices.
What by-products are made from cashews does not affect the outcome of the tariff decision.
label: B

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
main_answers: Buying unprocessed cashews at lower than world market prices enables cashew processors in Kernland to sell processed nuts at competitive prices.
A lack of profitable crops is driving an increasing number of small farmers in Kernland off their land and into the cities.
Other countries in which cashews are processed subsidize their processing plants.
Some of the by-products of processing cashews are used for manufacturing paints and plastics.
others.target_option: A lack of profitable crops is driving an increasing number of small farmers in Kernland off their land and into the cities.

context: More pedestrian injuries occur at crosswalks marked by both striping on the roadway and flashing lights than occur at crosswalks not so marked. Obviously these so-called safety features are a waste of taxpayer money.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument not considered to be flawed for assuming that crosswalks with both striping and flashing lights have no other safety features?
answers: The passage did not state anything about using less expensive features.
Nothing is being taken granted in the passage regarding failure to reduce the number of injuries.
The passage is discussing it being a waste of taxpayer money, not that it has no other safety features.
The passage assumes that the crosswalks are all equal in safety, when, in fact, the most dangerous ones are marked in such a way. This points out that flaw.
label: C

others.main_question: The reasoning in the argument is most vulnerable to criticism because the argument
main_answers: takes for granted that crosswalks with both striping and flashing lights have no other safety features
fails to consider that crosswalks marked by both striping and flashing lights are marked in this way precisely because they are the most dangerous ones
presumes that there are less expensive features that will reduce the number of pedestrian injuries just as effectively as striping and flashing lights
takes for granted that safety features that fail to reduce the number of injuries are a waste of taxpayer money
others.target_option: takes for granted that crosswalks with both striping and flashing lights have no other safety features

context: Historian: During the Industrial Revolution, for the first time in history, the productivity of the economy grew at a faster rate than the population and thus dramatically improved living standards. An economist theorizes that this growth was made possible by the spread of values such as hard work and thrift. But successful explanations need to be based on facts, so no one should accept this explanation until historical evidence demonstrates that a change in values occurred prior to the Industrial Revolution.
question: What evidence does the historian's overall conclusion require in order to accept the economist's explanation that a change in values occurred prior to the Industrial Revolution?
answers: It may have grown at a faster rate but the question is why did it.
The explanation needs to be based on facts.  More information needs to be gathered to provide evidence that this is indeed tru.
The growth was made possible by hard work but this does not fully demostrate why the change occurred.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The overall conclusion of the historian's argument is that
main_answers: no one should accept the economist's explanation until historical evidence demonstrates that a change in values occurred prior to the Industrial Revolution
during the Industrial Revolution the productivity of the economy grew at a faster rate than the population
the improvement in living standards that occurred during the Industrial Revolution was not due to the spread of a change in values
values such as hard work and thrift did not become widespread prior to the Industrial Revolution
others.target_option: no one should accept the economist's explanation until historical evidence demonstrates that a change in values occurred prior to the Industrial Revolution

context: Certain bacteria that produce hydrogen sulfide as a waste product would die if directly exposed to oxygen. The hydrogen sulfide reacts with oxygen, removing it and so preventing it from harming the bacteria. Furthermore, the hydrogen sulfide tends to kill other organisms in the area, thereby providing the bacteria with a source of food. As a result, a dense colony of these bacteria produces for itself an environment in which it can continue to thrive indefinitely.
question: What evidence is there to suggest that the hydrogen sulfide produced by the bacteria does not strongly support the claim that it kills other organisms in the area by reacting with and removing oxygen?
answers: The passage does not specify the fraction of the organisms killed by the hydrogen sulfide that can be food for the bacteria, it could be all of them or less than half of them.
The passage does not mention that the hydrogen sulfide kills other organisms indirectly like that, instead it implies that the hydrogen sulfide kills them directly.
Yes the passage clearly says that it takes a high density of the bacteria to create an environment in which it can survive indefinitely.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the information above?
main_answers: The bacteria can continue to thrive indefinitely only in an environment in which the hydrogen sulfide they produce has removed all oxygen and killed other organisms in the area.
Most organisms, if killed by the hydrogen sulfide produced by the bacteria, can provide a source of food for the bacteria.
The hydrogen sulfide produced by the bacteria kills other organisms in the area by reacting with and removing oxygen.
A dense colony of the bacteria can indefinitely continue to produce enough hydrogen sulfide to kill other organisms in the area and to prevent oxygen from harming the bacteria.
others.target_option: The hydrogen sulfide produced by the bacteria kills other organisms in the area by reacting with and removing oxygen.

context: Consumers planning to buy recreational equipment tend to buy higher quality, more expensive equipment when the economy is strong than when it is weak. Hill and Dale is a business that sells high-quality, expensive camping and hiking equipment in Boravia. Although all the signs are that Boravia' s economy is now entering a period of sustained strength, the managers of the business do not expect a substantial increase in sales.
question: What is the basis for why the fact that the economic upturn is likely to allow Boravia's national parks, where most of the camping and hiking is done, to receive extra funding to improve their visitor facilities does not provide the strongest justification for the managers' judgment?
answers: Improvements to hiking and camping equipment would have a positive impact on sales, as these products would become more attractive to people.
Improvements to Boravia's national parks would have a positive impact on sales, as more people would be motivated to go to the national parks and use camping and hiking equipment there.

High interest in spending time in wilderness areas means that a lot of people need hiking and camping equipment in order to be prepared when spending time in wilderness areas, which would mean relatively high sales for Hill and Dale.

Since Boravia's economy is entering a period of strength, people will be more likely to vacation overseas instead of going camping, which reduces the demand for camping and hiking equipment and therefore makes a substantial increase in sales of such equipment unlikely.
label: B

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, would provide the strongest justification for the managers' judgment?
main_answers: The economic upturn is likely to allow Boravia's national parks, where most of the camping and hiking is done, to receive extra funding to improve their visitor facilities.
Advances in materials technology have led to the development of hiking and camping equipment that is more comfortable and lightweight than before.
In Boravia when the economy is strong, those who might otherwise go camping tend to take vacations overseas.
Many people in Boravia not only are committed to preserving the country's wilderness areas but also are interested in spending some time in them.
others.target_option: The economic upturn is likely to allow Boravia's national parks, where most of the camping and hiking is done, to receive extra funding to improve their visitor facilities.

context: Modern physicians often employ laboratory tests, in addition to physical examinations, in order to diagnose diseases accurately. Insurance company regulations that deny coverage for certain laboratory tests ttherefore decrease the quality of medical care provided to patients.
question: What is the reasoning behind the assumption that physical examinations and the uncovered laboratory tests together provide a more accurate diagnosis of many diseases than do physical examinations alone serving to justify the conclusion?
answers: The passage mentions that physicians use both methods, there is no way to know if only one way can be used to solve issues.
The passage references that modern physicians use both methods to treat patients, this would lead one to believe that they are both required for good care.
The passage does not mention if the physicians oppose insurance companies.
The passage does not mention whether people are uninsured or not.
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption that would serve to justify the conclusion above?
main_answers: Physical examinations and the uncovered laboratory tests together provide a more accurate diagnosis of many diseases than do physical examinations alone.
Many physicians generally oppose insurance company regulations that, in order to reduce costs, limit the use of laboratory tests.
There are some illnesses that experienced physicians can diagnose accurately from physical examination alone.
Many patients who might benefit from the uncovered laboratory tests do not have any form of health insurance.
others.target_option: Physical examinations and the uncovered laboratory tests together provide a more accurate diagnosis of many diseases than do physical examinations alone.

context: In response to high mortality in area hospitals, surgery was restricted to emergency procedures during a five-week period. Mortality in these hospitals was found to have fallen by nearly one-third during the period. The number of deaths rose again when elective surgery (surgery that can be postponed) was resumed. It can be concluded that, before the five-week period, the risks of elective surgery had been incurred unnecessarily often in the area.
question: Explain why the fact that the physicians planning elective surgery performed before the five-week period had fully informed the patients who would undergo it of the possible risks of the procedures does not seriously undermine the conclusion.
answers: A patient dying of an infection after surgery strengthens the argument that the surgery is too risky.
Even if the physicians informed the patients of the risks the risks might still have been unnecessary.
Even if elective surgery is less risky than emergency surgery in general the risks for the elective surgeries in this case could have been unnecessary.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously undermines the conclusion above?
main_answers: The physicians planning elective surgery performed before the five-week period had fully informed the patients who would undergo it of the possible risks of the procedures.
Even if a surgical procedure is successful, the patient can die of a hospital-contracted infection with a bacterium that is resistant to antibiotic treatment.
The conditions for which elective surgery was performed would in the long run have been life-threatening, and surgery for them would have become riskier with time.
Elective surgery is, in general, less risky than is emergency surgery because the conditions requiring or indicating surgery are often less severe.
others.target_option: The physicians planning elective surgery performed before the five-week period had fully informed the patients who would undergo it of the possible risks of the procedures.

context: Professor Riley characterized the university president' s speech as inflammatory and argued that it was ttherefore inappropriate. However, Riley has had a long-standing feud with the president, and so we should not conclude that her speech was inflammatory solely on the basis of Riley' s testimony. Ttherefore, unless there are independent reasons to deem the president' s speech inflammatory, it is not true that her speech was inappropriate.
question: Why is the argument not considered to be invalid due to its failure to sufficiently consider the possibility that Riley's animosity toward the university president is well founded?
answers: The author shows that Riley may be biased against the president but they do not state the Riley has anything in particular to gain in this situation.
The author argues that Riley's animosity toward the university may cause bias and this would be the case whether the animosity was well founded or not.
The author argues that unless the speech can be proven to be inflammatory it can not be inappropriate but the speech could not be inflammatory yet still be inappropriate in some other way.
The author argues for the stance that the speech was likely appropriate, therefore the speech being appropriate for some audiences is in line with their argument.
label: B

others.main_question: The argument is flawed in that it
main_answers: fails to adequately address the possibility that inflammatory speeches may be appropriate for some audiences
fails to adequately address the possibility that Riley's animosity toward the university president is well founded
concludes that Riley's claim is false merely on the grounds that Riley has something to gain if the claim is accepted as true
takes for granted that the speech could not be inappropriate if it was not inflammatory
others.target_option: fails to adequately address the possibility that Riley's animosity toward the university president is well founded

context: The traditional view of the Roman emperor Caligula as a cruel and insane tyrant has been challenged by some modern historians. They point out that little documentation of Caligula' s alleged cruelty or outrageous behavior survives from the time of his reign and that the histories that have come down to us were written by his enemies.
question: Why does the fact that people who have lived under someone regarded as a cruel tyrant are more likely to view that person unfavorably than favorably not add support for the challenge from the modem historians?
answers: The passage does not mention if modern tyrants are more cruel or not.
This just shows that rulers of this time had a certain standard and Caligula was no more cruel than anyone else.
The passage mentions that the bad things written about Caligula were by his enemies, it never mentions people that he was cruel to.
The passage does not mention that there was a scarcity of documents.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, adds the most support for the challenge from the modem historians?
main_answers: People who have lived under someone regarded as a cruel tyrant are more likely to view that person unfavorably than favorably.
The specific outrageous acts attributed to Caligula in Roman documentation are very similar to acts attributed in earlier writings to other rulers alleged to be cruel tyrants.
There is less documentation of any sort from Caligula's reign than from the reigns of most other Roman emperors of Caligula's era.
There is ample documentation of modern tyrants being responsible for outrageous acts worse than those attributed to Caligula.
others.target_option: People who have lived under someone regarded as a cruel tyrant are more likely to view that person unfavorably than favorably.

context: The children in the second grade at a local elementary school scored lower on tests of math skills this year than the second graders did last year. The school board blames the disappointing results on the budget cuts that forced the school to consolidate several classes of second-grade students, thus depriving them of the individualized attention that they had previously enjoyed.
question: How does the fact that the test that the second graders took this year was not more difficult than the test that the second graders took last year support the explanation offered by the school board for the students' lower test scores?
answers: This undermines the board's argument by suggesting a possible alternative explanation for the decline in test performance.
This is not relevant to the argument as we are not told whether or not these other schools experienced a decline in test performance.
If true, this would exclude the only other possible explanation which is mentioned in the passage to the one suggested by the board for the difference in test performance.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, best supports the explanation offered by the school board for the students' lower test scores?
main_answers: The test that the second graders took this year was not more difficult than the test that the second graders took last year.
Students at other elementary schools in the area also scored poorly on the same test of math skills this year.
No new textbooks were purchased by the school board this year.
Other schools in the area also experienced severe budget cuts.
others.target_option: The test that the second graders took this year was not more difficult than the test that the second graders took last year.

context: Appendicitis (inflammation of the appendix) is potentially fatal; consequently, patients with symptoms strongly suggesting appendicitis almost always have their appendix removed. The appropriate surgery is low-risk but performed unnecessarily in about 20 percent of all cases. A newly developed internal scan for appendicitis is highly accurate, producing two misdiagnoses for every 98 correct diagnoses. Clearly, using this test, doctors can largely avoid unnecessary removals of the appendix without, however, performing any fewer necessary ones than before, since __.
question: Why does the fact that all of the patients who are diagnosed with this test as having appendicitis do, in fact, have appendicitis not logically complete the passage?
answers: If there are two misdiagnoses for very 98 correct diagnoses, then not all of the patients diagnosed with this test do in fact have appendicitis.

If misdiagnoses produced by this test are always instances of attributing appendicitis to someone who does not have it, then there are a few unnecessary surgeries performed but no necessary surgeries that are not performed.

Whether or not a patient has more than one of the symptoms associated with appendicitis does not tell us anything about the accuracy of the test, or the proportion of necessary to unnecessary surgeries, or whether all necessary surgeries are performed.

Symptoms in the patients who are misdiagnosed does not tell us anything about the accuracy of the test, how many unnecessary surgeries are avoided, or whether all the necessary surgeries are in fact performed.
label: A

others.main_question: Which of the following most logically completes the passage?
main_answers: all of the patients who are diagnosed with this test as having appendicitis do, in fact, have appendicitis
the misdiagnoses produced by this test are always instances of attributing appendicitis to someone who does not, in fact, have it
every patient who is diagnosed with this test as having appendicitis has more than one of the symptoms generally associated with appendicitis
the only patients who are misdiagnosed using this test are patients who lack one or more of the symptoms that are generally associated with appendicitis
others.target_option: all of the patients who are diagnosed with this test as having appendicitis do, in fact, have appendicitis

context: Columnist: Until very recently, Presorbin and Veltrex, two medications used to block excess stomach acid, were both available only with a prescription written by a doctor. In an advertisement for Presorbin, its makers argue that Presorbin is superior on the grounds that doctors have written 200 million prescriptions for Presorbin, as compared to 100 million for Veltrex. It can be argued that the number of prescriptions written is never a worthwhile criterion for comparing the merits of medicines, but that the advertisement' s argument is absurd is quite adequately revealed by observing that Presorbin was available as a prescription medicine years before Veltrex was.
question: Why does the columnist's argument not state the main conclusion in the second highlighted portion while also drawing a conclusion in defending that conclusion against an objection?
answers: The first does indeed detail the maker's claim that Presorbin is superior based on its total number of prescriptions, but the columnist's contrary argument in the second is not limited to only one possible interpretation of this claim but rather addresses its fundamental basis.
The main conclusion of the columnist's argument is in fact stated in the second case, not the first as asserted here.
The first case details the makers' conclusion that Presorbin is superior, and the second case details the columnist's conclusion that the maker's conclusion is invalid.
None of the above choices
label: B

main_answers: The first states the main conclusion of the columnist's argument; the second states a conclusion that the columnist draws in defending that conclusion against an objection.

The first identifies an assumption made in an argument that the columnist's argument is directed against; the second states the main conclusion of the columnist's argument.
others.target_option: The first states the main conclusion of the columnist's argument; the second states a conclusion that the columnist draws in defending that conclusion against an objection.

context: The book To Save the Earth is so persuasive that no one who reads it can fail to heed its environmentalist message. Members of the Earth Association have given away 2, 000 copies in the last month. Thus the Earth Association can justly claim credit for at least 2, 000 people in one month converted to the environmentalist cause.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the argument does not depend on the assumption that no other environmental organization gave away copies of To Save the Earth during the month in which the Earth Association gave away its 2,000 copies?
answers: It does not matter how many books were given out by other organizations. The Earth Association is still responsible for the conversion of the people they gave books to.
It does not matter what the book was written on. It was the words that converted people. The Earth Association can receive credit for anyone they gave the words to.
If every recipient embraces the program, then Earth Association is still credited for the people they sent the book to.

In order for the Earth Association to claim credit for a conversion, the person must have not be committed before reading the book. 2000 conversions depend on 2000 people becoming newly committed to the cause in the book.
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
main_answers: No other environmental organization gave away copies of To Save the Earth during the month in which the Earth Association gave away its 2, 000 copies.
The copies of To Save the Earth given away by members of the Earth Association were printed on recycled paper.
Every recipient of To Save the Earth will embrace the environmental program advocated by the Earth Association.
None of those who received To Save the Earth from a member of the Earth Association were already committed to the environmentalist cause when they received this book.
others.target_option: No other environmental organization gave away copies of To Save the Earth during the month in which the Earth Association gave away its 2, 000 copies.

context: Technologically, it is already possible to produce nonpolluting cars that burn hydrogen rather than gasoline. But the national system of fuel stations that would be needed to provide the hydrogen fuel for such cars does not yet exist. However, this infrastructure is likely to appear and grow rapidly. A century ago no fuel-distribution infrastructure existed for gasoline-powered vehicles, yet it quickly developed in response to consumer demand.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the argument draws the conclusion that hydrogen-powered vehicles will be similar to gasoline-powered vehicles with regard to the amount of consumer demand for their fuel-distribution infrastructure?
answers: The passage explicitly links hydrogen-powered cars to their gasoline-powered predecessors, for which infrastructure did indeed appear and grow rapidly.
The passage does assert that such cars can be produced, but as part of its premise rather than as its conclusion.
The passage makes no assertions regarding the relative levels of consumer demand for hydrogen and gasoline powered vehicles.
The passage mentions only two types of technology, and does not generalise its conclusions about them to all technologies.
label: C

context: Recently, a team of scientists digging through a tar pit unearthed a jawbone fossil. Initially, the team hypothesized that the jawbone came from a young gomphothere, a now extinct distant relative of the elephant, since the teeth were those of a juvenile. The gomphothere, however, is known for its large molars, and the teeth on the jawbone would not allow enough room for the molars of an adult gomphothere to fit. Based on this evidence, the scientists conclude that the jawbone fossil provides evidence of a distinct species closely related to the gomphothere.
question: How does the fact that in order for the molars of an adult gomphothereto emerge, several juvenile teeth are first forced out of the gums to accommodate the molars provide evidence that the conclusion is possibly flawed?
answers: This is just comparing to another animal, it does not help show the flaw of the argument.
The passage is assuming the molars would not fit, it does not guarantee a new species.
The length of the jawbone is not mentioned in the passage.
The passage is skipping an important part of teeth formation in that new ones come behind the juvenile ones.
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, would best provide evidence showing that the conclusion above is possibly flawed?
main_answers: In order for the molars of an adult gomphothereto emerge, several juvenile teeth are first forced out of the gums to accommodate the molars.
The juvenile jawbone of a species related to a gomphothere is longer than the juvenile jawbone of a gomphothere.
The manner in which teeth grow provide sufficient evidence for the accurate classification of a bygone species.
The molars of an adult mastodon, a close relative of the gomphothere, are similar in size to those of an adult gomphothere.
others.target_option: In order for the molars of an adult gomphothereto emerge, several juvenile teeth are first forced out of the gums to accommodate the molars.

context: Fossilized teeth of an extinct species of herbivorous great ape have on them phytoliths, which are microscopic petrified remains of plants. Since only phytoliths from certain species of plants are found on the teeth, the apes' diet must have consisted only of those plants.
question: What is the basis for the argument assuming that plants of every type eaten by the apes left phytoliths on their teeth?
answers: The article is only concerned with one particular species of ape.
Scientists have assumed that the apes didn't eat plants which didn't happen to show up on the petrified fossils of the apes they happened to dig up.
The article doesn't discuss whether the plant species represented by the phytoliths still exist today or not.
The article discusses which plant species were represented by the phytoliths regardless of how prevalent they were on the teeth.
label: B

others.main_question: The argument assumes which one of the following?
main_answers: Plants of every type eaten by the apes left phytoliths on their teeth.
Phytoliths have also been found on the fossilized teeth of apes of other extinct species.
None of the plant species that left phytoliths on the apes' teeth has since become extinct.
Each of the teeth examined had phytoliths of the same plant species on it as all the other teeth.
others.target_option: Plants of every type eaten by the apes left phytoliths on their teeth.

context: For centuries, mathematics seemed to exist in service to the natural sciences. Many of the great mathematical breakthroughs, like Newton' s Calculus, were spearheaded in the effort to solve scientific questions. In the nineteenth century, though, mathematicians made it clear that the primary object of mathematical study were the abstract creations of mathematics-numbers and shapes and functions and their more abstruse extensions-irrespective of whether this study has any bearing on scientific investigation. Ttherefore, mathematics is not properly one of the natural sciences.
question: What is the reasoning behind the assumption that the object of a natural science must be something tangible that can be perceived by the senses in order to support drawing the conclusion from the reasons given?
answers: Mathematics is the study of intangible ideas and functions.
Math's other applications are not relevant to the classification of math as a natural science.
Great scientists not being good at math is not relevant to math being classified as a natural science.
The conclusion presented does not rank math and science.
label: A

others.main_question: Which of the following is an assumption that supports drawing the conclusion above from the reasons given for that conclusion?
main_answers: The object of a natural science must be something tangible that can be perceived by the senses.
Some great scientists, like Einstein, by their own admission, were not very good at math.
Mathematics can also be used to serve social sciences, such as economics.
If one discipline serves another discipline, it can never rise to the same rank as the discipline it serves.
others.target_option: The object of a natural science must be something tangible that can be perceived by the senses.

context: As many as 98, 000 people die each year due to medical error. In a campaign to reduce lethal errors, thousands of hospitals introduced six key changes, including rapid-response teams, re-checks of patient medication, and new guidelines for preventing infection. The campaign estimated that, over an 18-month period, more than 100, 000 lives were saved as a direct result of the program.
question: What is the basis for inferring that, if the campaign had not been implemented, more than 100,000 people might have died during the 18-month period due to medical error?
answers: If hospitals adopt changes which reduce medical error, fewer fatal medical errors will occur, and without the medical errors, more people would have lived.
If 98, 000 people die each year, and 100,000 lives were saved by the changes, this statement is close, but not entirely accurate.
This assumes the changes saved everyone and will be used in the future, neither of which is supported.
This may or may not be true, since adjustments to the changes may occur.
label: A

others.main_question: Which of the following can be most properly inferred from the above statements?
main_answers: If the campaign had not been implemented, more than 100, 000 people might have died during the 18-month period due to medical error.
The key changes initiated by the campaign will continue to be implemented in the future.
In the future, no one will die because of medical error.
The campaign saved all of the people who otherwise would have died due to medical error in that time period.
others.target_option: If the campaign had not been implemented, more than 100, 000 people might have died during the 18-month period due to medical error.

context: A technology company plans to develop a prototype laptop that uses iris scanners that can distinguish one user from another. The inventor of this laptop claims that it will reduce insurance and security costs at offices, as only authorized users will be able to turn on the laptop, making it a less appealing target for thieves.
question: Why does the fact that insurance and security companies provide other services to companies in addition to protecting laptops not support the company's implementing its plan to develop the prototype?
answers: This does nothing to the companies claim that only the authorized user would be able to turn on and use the laptop as the iris would remain unchanged if the intended user was wearing contacts and it would still turn on and work for them.
This fact means that a thief would not be able to turn on or use the laptop because people’s irises are unique and there is a great deal of variation between the iris from one person to the next.
This information has no bearing on the company creating the laptop as it does not matter to a thief is not concerned with how many different products insurance companies protect.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most supports the company's implementing its plan to develop the prototype?
main_answers: Colored contacts allow people to change their eye color, without altering any of the other characteristics of their iris.
Insurance and security companies provide other services to companies in addition to protecting laptops.
There is considerable variation in the color and patterns present in most people's irises.
In-person security services will not suffer from technological glitches when allowing access to laptops.
others.target_option: Insurance and security companies provide other services to companies in addition to protecting laptops.

context: Teacher to a student: You agree that it is bad to break promises. But when we speak to each other we all make an implicit promise to tell the truth, and lying is the breaking of that promise. So even if you promised Jeanne that you would tell me she is home sick, you should not tell me that, if you know that she is well.
question: Explain why the teacher's argument does not depend on the assumption that breaking a promise leads to worse consequences than does telling a lie.
answers: Telling the truth is what takes precedence, so its better not to lie at all or make any implied or explicit statement that is a lie to protect a friend's best interest.
Breaking a promise is the same as lying so if anything, the consequences are the same.
Telling the truth is the overriding value, not keeping a promise.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the teacher's argument depends?
main_answers: One should never break a promise.
It is sometimes better to act in a friend's best interests than to keep a promise to that friend.
Some implicit promises are worse to break than some explicit ones.
Breaking a promise leads to worse consequences than does telling a lie.
others.target_option: Breaking a promise leads to worse consequences than does telling a lie.

context: Counselor: Those who believe that criticism should be gentle rather than harsh should consider the following: change requires a motive, and criticism that is unpleasant provides a motive. Since harsh criticism is unpleasant, harsh criticism provides a motive. Ttherefore, only harsh criticism will cause the person criticized to change.
question: Why is the counselor's argument not considered to be flawed for assuming that everyone who is motivated to change will change?
answers: If a person is truly motivated, one will see changes in their behavior over time.
Although harsh criticism does indeed work in order to cause change, it is not the only strategy that has been used to implement change in others.
Criticism is utilized to express unhappiness with the way an individual is performing, and to get them to change.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The reasoning in the counselor's argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the argument
main_answers: fails to address the possibility that in some cases the primary goal of criticism is something other than bringing about change in the person being criticized
takes for granted that everyone who is motivated to change will change
infers that something that is sufficient to provide a motive is necessary to provide a motive
confuses a motive for doing something with a motive for avoiding something
others.target_option: takes for granted that everyone who is motivated to change will change

context: The problem that environmental economics aims to remedy is the following: people making economic decisions cannot readily compare environmental factors, such as clean air and the survival of endangered species, with other costs and benefits. As environmental economists recognize, solving this problem requires assigning monetary values to environmental factors. But monetary values result from people comparing costs and benefits in order to arrive at economic decisions. Thus, environmental economics is stymied by what motivates it.
question: Why is the passage's conclusion not considered to be unsupported even though the argument is circular, taking that conclusion as one of its premises?
answers: The author is not using a circular argument that takes the conclusion as one of its premises.
The assumption that monetary values for environmental factors cannot be assigned unless people make economic decisions about these factors is supported by the author's assertions.
The passage indicates that economic decision-making does have an effect on  environmental factors
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: If the considerations advanced in its support are true, the passage's conclusion is supported
main_answers: at best weakly, because the passage fails to establish that economic decision-makers do not by and large take adequate account of environmental factors
not at all, since the argument is circular, taking that conclusion as one of its premises
strongly, on the assumption that monetary values for environmental factors cannot be assigned unless people make economic decisions about these factors
strongly, unless economic decision-making has not yet had any effect on the things categorized as environmental factors
others.target_option: not at all, since the argument is circular, taking that conclusion as one of its premises

context: All known living things are made of the same basic kinds of matter, are carbon based, and are equipped with genetic codes. So human life has the same origin as all other known life.
question: Why does the conclusion not logically follow even if it is assumed that there can never be any living thing that does not have a genetic code?
answers: If any two living things made of the same basic kinds of matter have the same origin, and all known living things are made of the same basic kinds of matter, then a living thing that is human has the same origin as any other living thing.
Whether or not there could be an unknown living thing that does not have a genetic code is irrelevant to the argument that living things that do have a genetic code share the same origin.

The conclusion that human life shares the same origin as all other life depends on characteristics shared in common with all life, but does not depend on the assumption that human life could not exist without the existence of other life forms.

If there were living beings that had genetic codes but were not carbon based, it would contradict the argument that the existence of genetic codes and being carbon based indicates a shared origin for all living things.
label: B

others.main_question: The conclusion follows logically if which one of the following is assumed?
main_answers: There can never be any living thing that does not have a genetic code.
Any two living things made of the same basic kinds of matter have the same origin.
Without the existence of other life forms, human life would never have come into existence.
There are not any living beings that have genetic codes but are not carbon based.
others.target_option: There can never be any living thing that does not have a genetic code.

context: Orthodox medicine is ineffective at both ends of the spectrum of ailments. At the more trivial end, orthodox medicine is largely ineffective in treating aches, pains, and allergies, and, at the other extreme, it has yet to produce a cure for serious, life-threatening diseases such as advanced cancer and lupus. People turn to alternative medicine when orthodox medicine fails to help them and when it produces side effects that are unacceptable to them. One of the reasons alternative medicine is free of such side effects is that it does not have any effects at all.
question: Why is it not valid to infer that orthodox medicine will eventually produce a solution for the diseases that are currently incurable from the statements given?
answers: The passage in fact argues that alternative medicine is ineffective for all illnesses, including trivial ones.
The passage makes no moral judgement on any medical practitioners, including practitioners of alternative medicine.
The passage in fact argues that orthodox medicine is currently ineffective in treating incurable diseases, and makes no mention of any future trends.
The passage asserts both that orthodox medicine is ineffective for some conditions and also that alternative medicine is ineffective for all conditions, justifying this overall conclusion.
label: C

others.main_question: If the statements above are true, which one of the following can be properly inferred from them?
main_answers: Orthodox medicine will eventually produce a solution for the diseases that are currently incurable.
There are some medical conditions for which no orthodox or alternative treatment is effective.
There are some trivial illnesses that can be treated effectively by the methods of alternative medicine.
Practitioners of alternative medicine are acting in bad faith.
others.target_option: Orthodox medicine will eventually produce a solution for the diseases that are currently incurable.

context: The widespread staff reductions in a certain region' s economy are said to be causing people who still have their jobs to cut back on new purchases as though they, too, had become economically distressed. Clearly, however, actual spending by such people is undiminished, because there has been no unusual increase in the amount of money held by those people in savings account.
question: What is the reasoning behind the argument in the passage concluding that since an expected consequence of a supposed development did not occur, that development itself did not take place?
answers: There has been no unusual increase in saving, so the change is not ambiguous.
Because savings have remained the same, this means people will jobs are saving the same, which means the supposed increased saving of people with jobs never happened.
This may or may not be true, but we have no information on the motive behind people's economic activity.
Other alternative developments may or may not exist.
label: B

others.main_question: The argument in the passage proceeds by doing which one of the following?
main_answers: concluding that since an expected consequence of a supposed development did not occur, that development itself did not take place
concluding that since the evidence concerning a supposed change is ambiguous, it is most likely that no change is actually taking place
arguing that since two alternative developments exhaust all the plausible possibilities, one of those developments occurred and the other did not
arguing that since people's economic behavior is guided by economic self-interest, only misinformation or error will cause people to engage in economic behavior that harms them economically
others.target_option: concluding that since an expected consequence of a supposed development did not occur, that development itself did not take place

context: Nuclear fusion is a process whereby the nuclei of atoms are joined, or "fused, " and in which energy is released. One of the by-products of fusion is helium-4 gas. A recent fusion experiment was conducted using "heavy" water contained in a sealed flask. The flask was, in turn, contained in an air-filled chamber designed to eliminate extraneous vibration. After the experiment, a measurable amount of helium-4 gas was found in the air of the chamber. The experimenters cited this evidence in support of their conclusion that fusion had been achieved.
question: Why does the fact that when fusion is achieved, it normally produces several by-products, including tritium and gamma rays not cast doubt on the experimenters' conclusion?
answers: It is not stated whether or not a large amount of heat was released and the by-product (or one of) of fusion was measurably obtained.
If the amount of helium-4 in the chamber's air was the same as ordinarily in the air outside of the chamber, it would seem to indicate no change and so no fusion achieved.
Helium-4 is a by-product of fusion and so the production of other byproducts or lack thereof has no bearing on whether or not fusion was achieved within the chamber.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, would cast doubt on the experimenters' conclusion?
main_answers: Helium-4 gas rapidly breaks down, forming ordinary helium gas after a few hours.
When fusion is achieved, it normally produces several by-products, including tritium and gamma rays.
Nuclear fusion reactions are characterized by the release of large amounts of heat.
The amount of helium-4 found in the chamber's air did not exceed the amount of helium-4 that is found in ordinary air.
others.target_option: When fusion is achieved, it normally produces several by-products, including tritium and gamma rays.

context: This spring, Bill, who has worked for the City of Hortonville for just over three years, plans to spend the entire three weeks of paid vacation to which he is entitled this year with his family. Anyone who has worked for the City of Hortonville from between one and four years is entitled to two weeks paid vacation each year but can apply up to half of any vacation time that remains unused at the end of the year to the next year' s vacation, as long as the unused vacation time is not more than eight weeks.
question: What evidence supports the claim that Bill had exactly two weeks of vacation left unused at the end of last year based on the statements given?
answers: If he had no unused vacation time, he would have only had two weeks of vacation time to use.
If he had used one week, he would not have three weeks this year. Also does not mention paid or unpaid and there isn't enough information regarding previous years.
If he continued to save his paid vacation each year, he could eventually get eight weeks. Also, this does not specify paid vacation.

Everyone who has worked for the City of Hortonville for between one and four years gets two weeks paid vacation each year and half of the unused can be used in the next year. If he is taking three weeks, he must have had two weeks left, half of which would be one week.
label: D

others.main_question: If the statements above are all true, which one of the following must also be true on the basis of them?
main_answers: Bill had exactly two weeks of vacation left unused at the end of last year.
Bill did not have any vacation time left and the end of his first year.
Bill will never have eight weeks of vacation time.
Bill has used one week of vacation time each year for the past two year.
others.target_option: Bill had exactly two weeks of vacation left unused at the end of last year.

context: Because of strong overall stylistic similarities, prehistoric cave paintings in El Castillo, Spain and others in Altamira, Spain, were thought to date from the same period. Recent pigment analyses, however, established the Altamira paintings as by far the older and as about the same age as a third group of paintings done in a different overall style. Nevertheless, this case does not prove that stylistic similarities cannot be a reliable indicator of closeness in age, since __.
question: Why does the statement that determining the age of a prehistoric cave painting simply by reference to the age of the pigments used in that painting substitutes technology for artistic judgment not logically complete the passage?
answers: Using artistic judgment instead of age of pigments is not a strong argument for the viability of stylistic similarities being a reliable indicator of closeness in age.
If there are certain stylistic features that the Altamira paintings share with all known paintings of their period then using stylistic features to judge the age of paintings is viable.
Experts not finding previously unnoticed stylistic similarities between the paintings is not an argument for using stylistic similarities in the future.

Even if there are experts who maintain that the results of the pigment analyses leave the similarities between the paintings unexplained that is not a good argument for the usefulness of using stylistic similarities to judge age.
label: A

others.main_question: Which of the following most logically completes the passage?
main_answers: Determining the age of a prehistoric cave painting simply by reference to the age of the pigments used in that painting substitutes technology for artistic judgment

Experts who knew the results of the pigment analyses reexamined these paintings and found no previously unnoticed stylistic similarities between the Altamira paintings and the paintings in the third group
There are experts who maintain that the results of the recent pigment analyses leave the striking stylistic similarities between the El Castillo paintings and the Altamira paintings unexplained
There are certain stylistic features that the Altamira paintings share with all known paintings of their period and do not share with the El Castillo paintings
others.target_option: Determining the age of a prehistoric cave painting simply by reference to the age of the pigments used in that painting substitutes technology for artistic judgment

context: The true scientific significance of a group of unusual fossils discovered by the paleontologist Charles Walcott is more likely to be reflected in a recent classification than it was in Walcott' s own classification. Walcott was, after all, a prominent member of the scientific establishment. His classifications are thus unlikely to have done anything but confirm what established science had already taken to be true.
question: Why does the argument not use a questionable technique of analyzing the past on the basis of social and political categories that properly apply only to the present and using the results of this analysis to support its conclusion?
answers: The argument concludes that Walcott's classification is relatively less likely to unearth true scientific significance merely due to the fact that Walcott was part of the scientific establishment, rather than based on any attributes of his classification itself.
The piece of evidence that Walcott was a prominent member of the scientific establishment is neither questionable nor unverifiable.
The only categorization used in the argument is that of the scientific establishment, but there's no apparent reason why the idea of the scientific establishment only applies to the present.
There are no contradictions in the premises of the argument.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following most accurately describes a questionable technique used in the argument?
main_answers: It analyzes the past on the basis of social and political categories that properly apply only to the present and uses the results of this analysis to support its conclusion.
It cites two pieces of evidence, each of which is both questionable and unverifiable, and uses this evidence to support its conclusions.
It draws conclusions about the merit of a position and about the content of that position from evidence about the position's source.
It bases a conclusion on two premises that contradict each other and minimizes this contradiction by the vagueness of the terms employed.
others.target_option: It analyzes the past on the basis of social and political categories that properly apply only to the present and uses the results of this analysis to support its conclusion.

context: Like airplane accidents, most accidents in medical care result from human error, particularly failures in communication, leadership, and decision making. Following the introduction of standard procedures governing these three areas, the airline industry succeeded in significantly reducing the number and severity of accidents. Since airplane flights and health care delivery both require the cooperation of groups of people with diverse knowledge and skills, the medical care community should adopt a similar set of procedures in order to reduce errors.
question: Why does the argument not use the technique of providing examples in order to show that two seemingly dissimilar situations are in fact the same?
answers: I think it was more focused on the desirable results that could be found by enacting these procedures.
The passage is stating that the airplane and healthcare industries face similar accident and that the action of one being successful could be succesful in the other.

The passage is just not comparing the two situations but showing that the skills required in one are similar to that of the other and that training could be helpful in the solutions that worked for one in the second one.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following is a technique of reasoning used in the argument?
main_answers: providing examples in order to show that two seemingly dissimilar situations are in fact the same
defending a general principle by presenting two separate successful applications of that principle
arguing for taking a course of action based on results of taking such action in an analogous situation
justifying the introduction of a set of procedures by outlining undesirable results in an analogous situation in which those procedures were not followed
others.target_option: providing examples in order to show that two seemingly dissimilar situations are in fact the same

context: Most scholars agree that King Alfred (A. D. 849-899) personally translated a number of Latin texts into Old English. One historian contends that Alfred also personally penned his own law code, arguing that the numerous differences between the language of the law code and Alfred' s translations of Latin texts are outweighed by the even more numerous similarities. Linguistic similarities, however, are what one expects in texts from the same language, the same time, and the same region. Apart from Alfred' s surviving translations and law code, there are only two other extant works from the same dialect and milieu, so it is risky to assume here that linguistic similarities point to common authorship.
question: What evidence is there that the passage does not proceed by demonstrating that the premises of another argument are mutually inconsistent?
answers: The passage identifies the assumption made by a historian that linguistic similarity implies common authorship, and questions it on the basis of there being insufficient available source material to properly test it.
The argument discussed has only a single premise, namely that King Alfred wrote his own law code.
Only two such examples are mentioned in the passage, and their relevance to the argument is not made clear.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The passage above proceeds by
main_answers: showing that the premises of another argument are mutually inconsistent
questioning the plausibility of an assumption on which another argument depends
providing examples that underscore another argument's conclusion
showing that a principle if generally applied would have anomalous consequences
others.target_option: showing that the premises of another argument are mutually inconsistent

context: If a piece of legislation is the result of negotiation and compromise between competing interest groups, it will not satisfy any of those groups. So, we can see that the recently enacted trade agreement represents a series of compromises among the various interest groups that are concerned with it, because all of those groups are clearly unhappy with it.
question: Explain why the argument does not contain a logical flaw by taking for granted that no piece of legislation can ever satisfy all competing interest groups.
answers: This particular case of a trade agreement is based on the general principle of a similar kind of case of negotiation and compromise between competing interest groups.
The assumption that no legislation can fully satisfy competing interest groups is part of the premise, and the conclusion can logically follow whether or not the assumption is factually correct.
The conclusion that interest groups in this particular case must have compromised because they are unhappy with the agreement is an example of the premise, rather than a restatement.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following most accurately describes a logical flaw in the argument?
main_answers: It takes for granted that no piece of legislation can ever satisfy all competing interest groups.
It concludes that a condition is necessary for a certain result merely from the claim that the condition leads to that result.
It draws a conclusion that is merely a disguised restatement of one of its premises.
It bases a conclusion about a particular case on a general principle that concerns a different kind of case.
others.target_option: It takes for granted that no piece of legislation can ever satisfy all competing interest groups.

context: Essayist: One of the claims of laissez-faire economics is that increasing the minimum wage reduces the total number of minimum-wage jobs available. In a recent study, however, it was found that after an increase in the minimum wage, fast-food restaurants kept on roughly the same number of minimum-wage employees as before the increase. Ttherefore, laissez-faire economics is not entirely accurate.
question: Why does the essayist's argument not depend on assuming that if laissez-faire economics makes an incorrect prediction about the minimum wage, then all the doctrines of laissez-faire economics are inaccurate?
answers: The author specifies "laissez-faire economics is not entirely accurate," which means some aspects are accurate
From the results of a fast food industry study, the author makes a claim for minimum-wage jobs across every industry
The effect of the increase on unemployment nationally is unknown and doesn't change the argument
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The essayist's argument depends on assuming which one of the following?
main_answers: If laissez-faire economics makes an incorrect prediction about the minimum wage, then all the doctrines of laissez-faire economics are inaccurate.
The national unemployment rate did not increase following the increase in the minimum wage.
Minimum-wage job availability at fast-food restaurants included in the study was representative of minimum-wage job availability in general.
No study has ever found that a business has decreased the number of its minimum-wage employees after an increase in the minimum wage.
others.target_option: If laissez-faire economics makes an incorrect prediction about the minimum wage, then all the doctrines of laissez-faire economics are inaccurate.

context: Carol Morris wants to own a majority of the shares of the city' s largest newspaper, The Daily. The only obstacle to Morris' s amassing a majority of these shares is that Azedcorp, which currently owns a majority, has steadfastly refused to sell. Industry analysts nevertheless predict that Morris will soon be the majority owner of The Daily.
question: Why does the fact that Morris already owns more shares of The Daily than anyone except Azedcorp not provide support for the industry analysts' prediction?
answers: This information is not necessarily relevant, as even if others are interested in becoming majority owner that does not mean that Morris will not fulfill the given claim.

This supports the claim that Morris will soon be the majority owner because it states that Azedcorp will soon need to sell their holdings. If Morris were to purchase them she would be the majority owner.
This information does not help or hinder the claim and is really simply basic information that has little to no bearing on the claim.
Where Morris stands in order of owning the most shares is not necessarily relevant to the claim.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, provides the most support for the industry analysts' prediction?
main_answers: Morris already owns more shares of The Daily than anyone except Azedcorp.
No one other than Morris has expressed any interest in purchasing a majority of The Daily's shares.
Azedcorp is financially so weak that bankruptcy will probably soon force the sale of its newspaper holdings.
Azedcorp does not own shares of any newspaper other than The Daily.
others.target_option: Morris already owns more shares of The Daily than anyone except Azedcorp.
