context: In Country X' s last election, the Reform Party beat its main opponent, the Conservative Party, although pollsters, employing in-person interviews shortly before the vote, had projected a Conservative Party victory. Afterwards, the pollsters determined that, unlike Conservative Party supporters, Reform Party supporters were less likely to express their party preference during in-person interviews than they were during telephone interviews. Ttherefore, using only telephone interviews instead would likely result in more accurate projections for the next election.
question: How does the statement that for each person interviewed in telephone polls before the next election, pollsters will be able to reasonably determine the likelihood of that person voting support the argument in the passage?
answers: The size of the voting base has nothing to do with the accuracy of voting projections.
What brought the projections into question to begin with was that the Conservative Party lost, so them winning would do nothing to support the argument.
In order for the party preferences of people interviewed by telephone to matter, it must be known about how many of them will actually vote.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following statements, if true, would most support the argument in the passage?
main_answers: For each person interviewed in telephone polls before the next election, pollsters will be able to reasonably determine the likelihood of that person voting.
In the next election, pollsters will be able to conduct more in-person interviews than telephone interviews.
The number of voters in Country X's next election will be significantly larger than the number of voters in the last election.
The Conservative Party will win the next election.
others.target_option: For each person interviewed in telephone polls before the next election, pollsters will be able to reasonably determine the likelihood of that person voting.

context: For Megan to get to the grocery store, she must take either the bus or the subway. The bus is not running this week, so although Megan generally does not like to take the subway, she must have used it today, since she was seen at the grocery store today.

answers: If there were additional alternatives, one could reason that Megan had gotten to the store using a mode of transportation other than the subway or the bus.

One of the weaknesses of the argument is that it doesn't try to prove that there couldn't have been any exceptions.

context: The graphical illustrations mathematics teachers use enable students to learn geometry more easily by providing them with an intuitive understanding of geometric concepts, which makes it easier to acquire the ability to manipulate symbols for the purpose of calculation. Illustrating algebraic concepts graphically would be equally effective pedagogically, even though the deepest mathematical understanding is abstract, not imagistic.
question: What evidence is provided by the statements above to support the claim that there are strategies that can be effectively employed in the teaching both of algebra and of geometry?
answers: Correct.  Mathematical concepts are argued to be abstract so those who know how to manipulate symbols might not know how or why it works.
The passage does not address the order in which graphics should be used to teach mathematical concepts or when it is should be deployed.
The passage does not argue that graphical illustrations are effective, but rather they may be used as a supplement to help teach a concept.
The passage does not focus on techniques that are useful to teaching both algebra and geometry, but rather introduces the possibility that graphics may help understand these subjects.
label: D

context: Editorial: Despite the fact that recent military success has made the prime minister personally popular, her party will lose the next election unless the economy is no longer in recession; the electorate will blame the state of the economy on her, even though she is hardly responsible for it and her policies will be beneficial in the long run.

context: Astronomer: Does a recent meteorite from Mars contain fossilized bacteria? Professor Tagar, a biologist, argues that the bacteria-like structures found in the meteorite cannot be fossilized bacteria, on the grounds that they are one-tenth of 1 percent the volume of the smallest earthly bacteria. However, Tagar' s view cannot be right. Tagar does not accept the views of biologists Swiderski and Terrada, who maintain that Martian bacteria would shrink to one-tenth of 1 percent of their normal volume when water or other nutrients were in short supply.
question: Explain why the astronomer's argument does not have a flaw as accurately described by the fact that it presumes, without providing justification, that the authorities cited have always held the views attributed to them.
answers: The argument makes no assumption about the relative validity of all expert opinions, but focuses on the views of three experts mentioned by name.
The astronomer's argument does fail to justify why Tagar's belief is incorrect while the others' is accurate.
According to the passage the views of Swiderski and Terrada are aligned on the matter.
The consistency of the authorities' views over time does not reflect on the validity of the astronomer's argument
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following most accurately describes a flaw in the reasoning in the astronomer's argument?
main_answers: The argument presumes, without providing justification, that the authorities cited have always held the views attributed to them.
The argument presumes, without providing justification, that the opinions of all experts are equally justified.
The argument appeals to views that contradict rather than support one another.
The argument provides no justification for giving preference to the views of one rather than the other of two competing sets of authorities.
others.target_option: The argument presumes, without providing justification, that the authorities cited have always held the views attributed to them.

No one reads the website so even though Trevor does something good it goes unnoticed so others don't benefit.

context: Political theorist: The chief foundations of all governments are the legal system and the police force; and as there cannot be a good legal system where the police are not well paid, it follows that where the police are well paid there will be a good legal system.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument not considered unsound even though it does not demonstrate that many governments with bad legal systems have poorly paid police forces?
answers: Whether this is true or not would not change whether or not a well-paid police force is necessary for a good legal system.
The argument refers to the quality of the legal system and how well-paid the police are, not the quality of the government in general.
The argument only submits that police being well paid is a requirement, not that that alone is sufficient.
None of the above choices
label: A

main_answers: many governments with bad legal systems have poorly paid police forces

a well-paid police force cannot be effective without a good legal system
others.target_option: many governments with bad legal systems have poorly paid police forces

answers: All the information in the passage proves the main point that Kimmy is rich and famous.
The author does not make any judgements about whether the fame is deserved or not.
The movie is only a detail that serves to  prove the main point of the passage.
The paparazzi tracking Kimmy is only used to prove the main point of the passage.

context: Philosopher: Wolves do not tolerate an attack by one wolf on another if the latter wolf demonstrates submission by baring its throat. The same is true of foxes and domesticated dogs. So it would be erroneous to deny that animals have rights on the grounds that only human beings are capable of obeying moral rules.
question: What is the reason for why the philosopher's argument does not attempt to cast doubt on the principle that being capable of obeying moral rules is a necessary condition for having rights?
answers: There is no attempt by the passage to establish a claim based on the alternative yielding a logical contradiction.
The passage does the opposite.  It makes the claim that the concept of morality is often applied too narrowly.
The passage does the opposite.  It claims by obeying moral rules the animals satisfy a necessary condition for having rights.
The passage counters the premise that only humans are capable of obeying moral rules and thus are the only ones deserving rights.
label: C

others.main_question: The philosopher's argument proceeds by attempting to
main_answers: cast doubt on the principle that being capable of obeying moral rules is a necessary condition for having rights
provide evidence suggesting that the concept of morality is often applied too broadly
provide counterexamples to refute a premise on which a particular conclusion is based
establish a claim by showing that the denial of that claim entails a logical contradiction
others.target_option: cast doubt on the principle that being capable of obeying moral rules is a necessary condition for having rights

context: Tax reformer: The proposed tax reform legislation is being criticized by political groups on the right for being too specific and by political groups on the left for being too vague. Since one and the same statement cannot be both too specific and too vague, the criticisms just go to show that the legislation is framed just as it should be.
question: Explain why the argument does not depend on the assumption that it is rare for political groups both on the right and on the left to criticize a particular tax reform proposal?
answers: Legislation can be too vague or too specific and still satisfy political groups
The legislation cannot be both overly vague and overly specific at the same time and is a product of political group machinations
The statement makes no mention or reference to how often tax reforms are criticized
The author does not say only political groups have criticized the legislation.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
main_answers: The proposed legislation has not been criticized by any group that does not identify itself with the political right or the political left.
It is rare for political groups both on the right and on the left to criticize a particular tax reform proposal.
The proposed legislation is not made up of a set of statements some of which are overly specific and some of which are overly vague.
The proposed legislation as it is framed was not meant to satisfy either political groups on the right or political groups on the left.
others.target_option: It is rare for political groups both on the right and on the left to criticize a particular tax reform proposal.

context: In the past, when there was no highway speed limit, the highway accident rate increased yearly, peaking a decade ago. At that time, the speed limit on highways was set at 90 kilometers per hour (kph) (55 miles per hour). Every year since the introduction of the highway speed limit, the highway accident rate has been at least 15 percent lower than that of its peak rate. Thus, setting the highway speed limit at 90 kph (55 mph) has reduced the highway accident rate by at least 15 percent.
question: How does the fact that drivers are better able to maintain control of their cars in dangerous situations due to changes in automobile design in the past ten years weaken the argument?
answers: Cars still would have been capable of going faster than 90 kph after the introduction of the highway speed limit.
It is possible that changes in automobile design and not the speed limit is what caused the reduced accident rate.
The argument is focused only on accidents that happened on the highway. Accidents that occurred in other places would be irrelevant.
The accident rate would not be affected by features intended to prevent harm to passengers in accidents.
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
main_answers: Thanks to changes in automobile design in the past ten years, drivers are better able to maintain control of their cars in dangerous situations.
It was not until shortly after the introduction of the highway speed limit that most cars were equipped with features such as seat belts and airbags designed to prevent harm to passengers.
In the years prior to the introduction of the highway speed limit, many cars could go faster than 90 kph (55 mph).
Ten years ago, at least 95 percent of all automobile accidents in the area occurred on roads with a speed limit of under 80 kph (50 mph).
others.target_option: Thanks to changes in automobile design in the past ten years, drivers are better able to maintain control of their cars in dangerous situations.

context: Doctor: While a few alternative medicines have dangerous side effects, some, such as many herbs, have been proven safe to consume. Thus, though there is little firm evidence of medicinal effect, advocates of these herbs as remedies for serious illnesses should always be allowed to prescribe them, since their patients will not be harmed, and might be helped, by the use of these products.
question: Explain why the fact that some patients may have allergic reactions to certain medicines that have been tolerated by other patients does not weaken the doctor's argument.
answers: If doctors are always allowed to prescribe alternative medicines that are not proven to work then patients might assume that these will help them and not take more effective conventional medicines.
If herbs do provide benefit to a patient then the fact that they derive entirely from patients' belief in the remedy is not that important.
Allergic reaction could happen with both alternative and or non-alternative medicine.
The majority of purveyors of non-alternative medicines are also likely driven as much by the profit motive as by a regard for their patients' health.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the doctor's argument?
main_answers: Some patients may have allergic reactions to certain medicines that have been tolerated by other patients.
Any pain relief or other benefits of many herbs have been proven to derive entirely from patients' belief in the remedy, rather than from its biochemical properties.
The vast majority of purveyors of alternative medicines are driven as much by the profit motive as by a regard for their patients' health.
Many practitioners and patients neglect more effective conventional medicines in favor of herbal remedies.
others.target_option: Some patients may have allergic reactions to certain medicines that have been tolerated by other patients.

context: Many scholars believe that official medieval persecutions of various minority groups were undertaken very reluctantly by medieval authorities and only in order to soothe popular unrest caused by underlying popular hostility to the groups in question. This belief is highly questionable. For one thing, there are few indications of any profound underlying popular hostility toward persecuted groups in cases where persecutions were particularly violent and sustained. For another, the most serious and widespread persecutions carried out by medieval authorities seem to have had as targets exactly those groups that most effectively disputed these authorities' right to govern.
question: Why does the argument not succeed in proving that the view is correct by referring to the large numbers of scholarly adherents of a certain view?
answers: The author argues against what the evidence of the past shows us, it does not argue about how reliable or valid that evidence is.
There is no principle being debated in the passage, only historical facts.
The argument explicitly argues against what is a popular belief, that is to say, that the popular belief is incorrect.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: The argument proceeds by
main_answers: referring to the large numbers of scholarly adherents of a certain view to support the claim that the view is correct
establishing a general principle and using the principle to justify a conclusion about a particular category of cases
citing both a lack of evidence supporting a particular explanation and further evidence that suggests an alternative explanation
providing reasons to suspect the reliability of any conclusions based on evidence concerning the distant past
others.target_option: referring to the large numbers of scholarly adherents of a certain view to support the claim that the view is correct

context: Philosopher: The eighteenth-century thesis that motion is absolute asserts that the change in an object' s position over time could be measured without reference to the position of any other object. A well-respected physicist, however, claims that this thesis is incoherent. Since a thesis that is incoherent cannot be accepted as a description of reality, motion cannot be absolute.
question: Explain why the argument does not use the technique of attempting to persuade by the mere use of technical terminology?
answers: Technical terminology is used but this is not the sole reason of the argument.
The passage mentions a specific example and mentions nothing about this bringing true in all spaces.
The passage mentions that a well respected physicist is the person that says this passage is incoherent without much of an explanation, we have to assume they are right in their assertion.
What was suggested in the passage is the direct opposite to this statement.
label: A

others.main_question: The argument uses which one of the following argumentative techniques?
main_answers: attempting to persuade by the mere use of technical terminology
inferring from what has been observed to be the case under experimental conditions to what is in principle true
generalizing from what is true in one region of space to what must be true in all regions of space
relying on the authority of an expert to support a premise
others.target_option: attempting to persuade by the mere use of technical terminology

question: What evidence is there that the argument relies on the authority of an expert to support a premise?
answers: What was suggested in the passage is the direct opposite to this statement.
The passage mentions that a well respected physicist is the person that says this passage is incoherent without much of an explanation, we have to assume they are right in their assertion.
The passage mentions a specific example and mentions nothing about this bringing true in all spaces.
Technical terminology is used but this is not the sole reason of the argument.
label: B

others.main_question: The argument uses which one of the following argumentative techniques?
main_answers: attempting to persuade by the mere use of technical terminology
inferring from what has been observed to be the case under experimental conditions to what is in principle true
generalizing from what is true in one region of space to what must be true in all regions of space
relying on the authority of an expert to support a premise
others.target_option: relying on the authority of an expert to support a premise

context: Between 1971 and 1975, the government office that monitors drug companies issued an average of 60 citations a year for serious violations of drug-promotion laws. Between 1976 and 1980, the annual average for issuance of suchs citations was only 5. This decrease indicates that the government office was, on average, considerably more lax in enforcing drug-promotion laws between 1976 and 1980 than it was between 1971 and 1975.
question: Explain why the argument does not assume that the government office should not issue more than an average of 5 citations a year to drug companies for serious violations of drug-promotion laws?
answers: The article did not differentiate between the types of violations but violations in general.
This article states that the average of 5 citations shows a lax in enforcement so it wasn't about it being only 5 citations.
The drug companies still committed the violations but the number of citations dropped which shows they became lax in enforcement.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The argument assumes which one of the following?
main_answers: The government office should not issue more than an average of 5 citations a year to drug companies for serious violations of drug-promotion laws.
Before 1971 the government office issued more than 60 citations a year to drug companies for serious violations of drug-promotion laws.
A change in enforcement of drug-promotion laws did not apply to minor violations.
The decrease in the number of citations was not caused by a decrease in drug companies' violations of drug-promotion laws.
others.target_option: The government office should not issue more than an average of 5 citations a year to drug companies for serious violations of drug-promotion laws.

context: Lydia: Each year, thousands of seabirds are injured when they become entangled in equipment owned by fishing companies. Ttherefore, the fishing companies should assume responsibility for funding veterinary treatment for the injured birds. Jonathan: Your feelings for the birds are admirable. Your proposal, however, should not be adopted because treatment of the most seriously injured birds would inhumanely prolong the lives of animals no longer able to live in the wild, as all wildlife should.
question: Explain why Jonathan's response to Lydia does not involve questioning the appropriateness of interfering with wildlife in any way, even if the goal of the interference is to help.
answers: Jonathan does not make a personal attack Lydia; indeed, he actually compliments her for her compassion towards the birds.
Jonathan mentions and praises her feelings for the birds, but also addresses her proposal with a counterargument based on anticipated consequences.
Jonathan refers only to one specific instance of helping, and does not generalize his argument to encompass all interference with wildlife.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Jonathan uses which one of the following techniques in his response to Lydia?
main_answers: He questions the appropriateness of interfering with wildlife in any way, even if the goal of the interference is to help.
He attempts to discredit her proposal by discussing its implications for only those birds that it serves least well.
He evades discussion of her proposal by raising the issue of whether her feelings about the birds are justified.
He directs a personal attack against her rather than addressing the argument she advances.
others.target_option: He questions the appropriateness of interfering with wildlife in any way, even if the goal of the interference is to help.

context: No widget factory is located in the Western Time Zone. Some widget factories are employee owned and operated, and nearly all widget factories are publicly owned. answers: The factory is a widget factory, because only widget factories employ more than one thousand employees, and this factory employs two thousand.

This is not a guarantee, because it could be in any time zone other than the Western Time Zone.

context: An undergraduate degree is necessary for appointment to the executive board. Further, no one with a felony conviction can be appointed to the board. Thus, Manu, an accountant with both a bachelor' s and a master' s degree, cannot be accepted for the position of Executive Administrator, since he has a felony conviction.
question: Why does the argument's conclusion not logically follow even if it is assumed that if Manu did not have a felony conviction, he would be accepted for the position of Executive Administrator?
answers: The argument doesn’t discuss whether Manu would have gotten the position, but states that he is ineligible for consideration because of his conviction.
Since the criteria of a bachelor’s degree and no convictions is being used for both, it can be assumed that the requirements are the same.
The stipulations are that the candidate must have no felony convictions, regardless of relevance.
The passage mentions Manu’s degrees as well as the degree requirement for an executive position, so it can be assumed that the degree was required for the Administrator.
label: A

others.main_question: The argument's conclusion follows logically if which one of the following is assumed?
main_answers: If Manu did not have a felony conviction, he would be accepted for the position of Executive Administrator.
Only candidates eligible for appointment to the executive board can be accepted for the position of Executive Administrator.
The felony charge on which Manu was convicted is relevant to the duties of the position of Executive Administrator.
An undergraduate degree is not necessary for acceptance for the position of Executive Administrator.
others.target_option: If Manu did not have a felony conviction, he would be accepted for the position of Executive Administrator.

context: Inertia affects the flow of water pumped through a closed system of pipes. When the pump is first switched on, the water, which has mass, takes time to reach full speed. When the pump is switched off, inertia causes the decrease in the water flow to be gradual. The effects of inductance in electrical circuits are similar to the effects of inertia in water pipes.
question: Why does the information not provide support for the claim that inertia in the flow of water pumped by an electrically powered pump is caused by inductance in the pump's circuits?
answers: Inertia is mentioned in relation to water flow, not electrical current.
The passage states that electrical circuits are affected by inductance.
There is no information in the passage about what electrical engineers might try to do about inductance.
The passage does not mention a specifically electrically powered pump.
label: D

others.main_question: The information above provides the most support for which one of the following?
main_answers: Inertia in the flow of water pumped by an electrically powered pump is caused by inductance in the pump's circuits.
The rate at which electrical current flows is affected by inductance.
The flow of electrical current in a circuit requires inertia.
Electrical engineers try to minimize the effects of inductance in electrical circuits.
others.target_option: Inertia in the flow of water pumped by an electrically powered pump is caused by inductance in the pump's circuits.

context: Mathematics teacher: Teaching students calculus before they attend university may significantly benefit them. Yet if students are taught calculus before they are ready for the level of abstraction involved, they may abandon the study of mathematics altogether. So if we are going to teach pre-university students calculus, we must make sure they can handle the level of abstraction involved.
question: What is the basis for not concluding that the principle that teachers who teach university-level mathematics to pre-university students should be aware that students are likely to learn effectively only when the application of mathematics to concrete problems is shown helps to justify the mathematics teacher's argument?
answers: If the motivation of those who are completing the cognitive tasks is undermined, they are unlikely to be able to complete the cognitive tasks and so this would not justify teaching any students calculus prior to university.

The level of abstraction required to complete calculus necessitates the student be able and willing to learn without the application of mathematics to concrete problems being shown as concrete and abstract are opposites of each other.

If the students are able to, without losing motivation, meet the cognitive challenges that new intellectual work involves, they are proving themselves able to handle the level of abstraction required to learn calculus prior to attending university.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following principles most helps to justify the mathematics teacher's argument?
main_answers: Teachers who teach university-level mathematics to pre-university students should be aware that students are likely to learn effectively only when the application of mathematics to concrete problems is shown.
Cognitive tasks that require exceptional effort tend to undermine the motivation of those who attempt them.
Only those who, without losing motivation, can meet the cognitive challenges that new intellectual work involves should be introduced to it.
Only those parts of university-level mathematics that are the most concrete should be taught to pre-university students.
others.target_option: Teachers who teach university-level mathematics to pre-university students should be aware that students are likely to learn effectively only when the application of mathematics to concrete problems is shown.

context: First-time computer buyers buying PXC home computers typically buy models that cost much less and have a smaller profit margin per computer than do PXC computers bought by people replacing their computers with more powerful models. Last year PXC' s profits from computer sales were substantially higher than the previous year, although about the same number of PXC computers were sold and the prices and profit margins for each computer model that PXC sells remained unchanged.
question: What evidence is there that the number of people buying PXC computers who also bought PXC computer-related products, such as printers, was larger last year than the previous year is not strongly supported by the statements?
answers: The same number of computers were sold, so there was no drop-off due to competition.
The same number of computers were sold, so the sale of computer-related products has no bearing on profits from computer sales
Production costs may or may not have changed, but even if production costs were different between the years, the margin between the computers was the same
If non-first-time buyers' computers cost more than first-time, and if profits increased while sales remained steady, then necessarily more non-first-time buyers' computers were sold
label: B

others.main_question: If the statements above are true, which of the following is most strongly supported by them?
main_answers: The number of people buying PXC computers who also bought PXC computer-related products, such as printers, was larger last year than the previous year.
PXC's production costs for its computers were lower last year than they had been the previous year.
The proportion of PXC computers bought by first-time computer buyers was smaller last year than the previous year.

Among computer buyers who bought a PXC computer to replace their existing computer, the proportion who were replacing a computer made by a competitor of PXC was greater last year than the previous year.
others.target_option: The number of people buying PXC computers who also bought PXC computer-related products, such as printers, was larger last year than the previous year.

question: What evidence does not support the claim that among computer buyers who bought a PXC computer to replace their existing computer, the proportion who were replacing a computer made by a competitor of PXC was greater last year than the previous year?
answers: The same number of computers were sold, so the sale of computer-related products has no bearing on profits from computer sales
If non-first-time buyers' computers cost more than first-time, and if profits increased while sales remained steady, then necessarily more non-first-time buyers' computers were sold
Production costs may or may not have changed, but even if production costs were different between the years, the margin between the computers was the same
The same number of computers were sold, so there was no drop-off due to competition.
label: D

others.main_question: If the statements above are true, which of the following is most strongly supported by them?
main_answers: The number of people buying PXC computers who also bought PXC computer-related products, such as printers, was larger last year than the previous year.
PXC's production costs for its computers were lower last year than they had been the previous year.
The proportion of PXC computers bought by first-time computer buyers was smaller last year than the previous year.

Among computer buyers who bought a PXC computer to replace their existing computer, the proportion who were replacing a computer made by a competitor of PXC was greater last year than the previous year.
others.target_option: Among computer buyers who bought a PXC computer to replace their existing computer, the proportion who were replacing a computer made by a competitor of PXC was greater last year than the previous year.

context: Pettengill: Bebop jazz musicians showed their distaste for jazz classics by taking great liberties with them, as though the songs could be made interesting only through radical reshaping. Romney: Only compelling, versatile songs can stand such radical reshaping. Bebop musicians recognized this, and their revolutionary approach to the jazz classics enabled them to discover previously unknown depths in the music.
question: What is the source of the disagreement between Pettengill and Romney regarding whether bebop musicians showed appreciation for jazz classics by radically reshaping them?
answers: Nowhere in the argument is the popularity of music referred to.
Pettengill and Romney both explicitly agree that bebop is radically different from classic jazz, they just disagree on what motivated bebop musicians to create such radically different music.
Pettengill makes the argument that the the bebop musicians reshaped the music because of their distaste, while Romney disputes this and says they reshaped them due to the complexity of those songs.
Neither person makes any argument as to whether the classics or bebop are better or worse.
label: C

jazz music requires musicians to adhere closely to the original version in order to be widely popular
bebop jazz was an improvement on the jazz classics that preceded it
bebop jazz was radically different from the jazz music that preceded it

context: There is a widespread belief that people can predict impending earthquakes from unusual animal behavior. Skeptics claim that this belief is based on selective coincidence: people whose dogs behaved oddly just before an earthquake will be especially likely to remember that fact. At any given time, the skeptics say, some of the world' s dogs will be behaving oddly.
question: What evidence is needed to clarify whether the sorts of behavior supposedly predictive of earthquakes are as pronounced in dogs as they are in other animals in order to evaluate the skeptics' position?
answers: Lack of knowledge about the specific behaviors of other animal species would not confirm or deny the skeptics' position.
The study of other species could also exhibit the same selective coincidence bias.
If the observed behaviors are specific to earthquakes it may be more relevant or notable.
The proportion of skeptics or believers would not shed any light on the veracity of the assertion.
label: B

others.main_question: Clarification of which one of the following issues would be most important to an evaluation of the skeptics' position?
main_answers: Are the sorts of behavior supposedly predictive of earthquakes as pronounced in dogs as they are in other animals?
Are there animals about whose behavior people know too little to be able to distinguish unusual from everyday behavior?
Which is larger, the number of skeptics or the number of people who believe that animal behavior can foreshadow earthquakes?
Is the animal behavior supposedly predictive of earthquakes specific to impending earthquakes or can it be any kind of unusual behavior?
others.target_option: Are the sorts of behavior supposedly predictive of earthquakes as pronounced in dogs as they are in other animals?

context: Herbalist: Many herbal medicines work best when they have a chance to influence the body gently over several months. However, many of these herbal medicines have toxic side effects when taken daily for such long periods. Ttherefore, at least some people who use herbal medicines daily should occasionally skip their usual dose for a day or two, to give the body a chance to recuperate.
question: What is the basis for the herbalist's argument not requiring the assumption that at least some herbal medicines work less well in achieving their desired effects if one occasionally skips one's usual dose than if one does not?
answers: The statement suggests that skipping these dose will eliminate the chance of the side effects, because the body will get to recuperate.
The skipping of the dose is meant to prevent toxicity, not help the medicine work better.
The herbalist believes that only some people who are using herbal medicine will need to skip occasionally as a precaution.
None of the above choices

context: A recently passed law requires all places of public accommodation to eliminate discrimination against persons with disabilities by removing all physical barriers to accessibility. Private schools, ttherefore, are legally obligated to make their campuses physically accessible to persons with disabilities.
question: Why does the conclusion follow logically if it is assumed that private schools, like public schools, are places of public accommodation?
answers: The passage only makes the claim that the schools need to be physically accessible to people with disabilities, not that they have to admit every person who has one.
This article makes no claim about the history of resistance of change of private schools, and this resistance would have no bearing in the face of a legal obligation anyways.
This isn't implied by the passage, only that the private schools are obligated to make the campuses barrier free regardless of funding.
If private schools weren't places of public accommodation, they wouldn't be legally obligated to become physically accessible.
label: D

main_answers: Private schools, like public schools are places of public accommodation.
Private schools have enough funds to make their campuses barrier-free.
No private school can legally deny admission to a person with a disability.
Private schools have historically been resistant to changes in government policy on discrimination.
others.target_option: Private schools, like public schools are places of public accommodation.

context: A famous artist once claimed that all great art imitates nature. If this claim is correct, then any music that is great art would imitate nature. But while some music may imitate ocean waves or the galloping of horses, for example, most great music imitates nothing at all.
question: Explain why the claim that music is inferior to the other arts does not accurately express the main point of the argument.
answers: One form of art not imitating nature does not indicate that another form does not.
If some music does not imitate the sounds of nature but is considered great than imitating art is not needed for music to be great or if it is, than music must imitate art to be great.
This is an opinion rather than a fact and is unsupported.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the main point of the argument?
main_answers: Music is inferior to the other arts.
Like some great music, some great painting and sculpture may fail to imitate nature.
Sounds that do not imitate nature are not great music.
Either the artist's claim is incorrect, or most great music is not great art.
others.target_option: Music is inferior to the other arts.

context: Vandenburg: This art museum is not adhering to its purpose. Its founders intended it to devote as much attention to contemporary art as to the art of earlier periods, but its collection of contemporary art is far smaller than its other collections. Simpson: The relatively small size of the museum' s contemporary art collection is appropriate. It' s an art museum, not an ethnographic museum designed to collect every style of every period. Its contemporary art collection is small because its curators believe that there is little high-quality contemporary art.
question: Why does the principle that the intentions of an art museum's curators should not determine what is collected by that museum not help to justify the reasoning in Simpson's response to Vandenburg?
answers: The art museum doesn't have to hold every type of art but can focus on one specific style.
An ethnographic museum is one that tries to collect an array of types of art. It is more than just one type of art.
There is nothing in the passage about the curator not determining what goes into the art museum but that the curator chooses what they deem as important to be seen.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following principles, if valid, most helps to justify the reasoning in Simpson's response to Vandenburg?
main_answers: The intentions of an art museum's curators should not determine what is collected by that museum.
An art museum's purpose need not be to collect every style of every period.
An ethnographic museum's purpose should be defined according to its curators' beliefs.
An art museum should collect only works that its curators consider to be of high artistic quality.
others.target_option: The intentions of an art museum's curators should not determine what is collected by that museum.

context: Literature professor: Critics charge that the work of C. F. Providence' s best-known follower, S. N. Sauk, lacks aesthetic merit because it employs Providence' s own uniquely potent system of symbolic motifs in the service of a political ideal that Providence -- and, significantly, some of these critics as well -- would reject. Granting that Sauk is more imitator than innovator, and that he maintained political views very different from those Providence maintained, it has yet to be shown that these facts make his writings any less subtly or powerfully crafted than those of his more esteemed mentor. So the critics' argument should be rejected.
question: What is the reason for why the literature professor's argument is not valid in claiming that the conclusion drawn by the critics has not been established due to the critics' antipathy toward Sauk's political ideas?
answers: The literature professor argues that the fact that the person was imitating another person's works is not necessarily relevant to judging the aesthetic merit of their own work.
The literature professor argues against the critics, not necessarily for the aesthetic merit of Sauk's work.
There is no information in the passage showing that the critics were motivated by any kind of antipathy towards political ideas.
None of the above choices
label: C

Granting that Sauk is more imitator than innovator, and that he maintained political views very different from those Providence maintained, it has yet to be shown that these facts make his writings any less subtly or powerfully crafted than those of his more esteemed mentor. So the critics' argument should be rejected.
question: What is the rationale for why the literature professor argues that the conclusion drawn by the critics has not really been established because the claims made in support of this conclusion have not been shown to be relevant to it?
answers: The literature professor argues that the fact that the person was imitating another person's works is not necessarily relevant to judging the aesthetic merit of their own work.
The literature professor argues against the critics, not necessarily for the aesthetic merit of Sauk's work.
There is no information in the passage showing that the critics were motivated by any kind of antipathy towards political ideas.
None of the above choices
label: A

context: All potatoes naturally contain solanine, which is poisonous in large quantities. Domesticated potatoes contain only very small amounts of solanine, but many wild potatoes contain poisonous levels of solanine. Since most of the solanine in potatoes is concentrated in the skin, however, peeling wild potatoes makes them at least as safe to eat as unpeeled domesticated potatoes of the same size.
question: Why does the assumption that wild potatoes are generally much smaller than domesticated potatoes not allow the conclusion to be properly drawn?
answers: The amount of solanine in the skin has nothing to do with the amount of solanine after the wild potato is peeled.
If there amount of solanine in a peeled wild potato and an unpeeled domesticated potato of the same size, then both are equally safe to eat.
The average size of the potato has no relevance when comparing specific potatoes of the same size.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if assumed, allows the conclusion above to be properly drawn?
main_answers: Wild potatoes are generally much smaller than domesticated potatoes.
The amount of solanine concentrated in the skin of a wild potato is large enough by itself to be poisonous.
There are no poisonous substances in domesticated potatoes other than solanine.
There is no more solanine in a peeled wild potato than in an unpeeled domesticated potato of the same size.
others.target_option: Wild potatoes are generally much smaller than domesticated potatoes.

context: Over 90 percent of the human brain currently serves no purpose, as is evident from the fact that many people with significant brain damage show no discernible adverse effects. So once humans begin to tap into this tremendous source of creativity and innovation, many problems that today seem insurmountable will be within our ability to solve.
question: What is the reason for the argument not being considered to have a flaw due to presuming, without providing justification, that the only reason that any problem remains unsolved is a lack of creativity and innovation?
answers: The argument makes no such broad sweeping statement about problems in general. It instead states certain problems can be solved if we had additional creativity and innovation.
The crux of the argument is about fully utilizing the human mind in order to solve previously unsolvable problems. It does not merely claim that problems will be within our ability to solve.
The parts of the brain that are not used may very well exist as a backup and cannot function actively. The argument does not provide any evidence or studies to prove otherwise.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following most accurately describes a flaw in the argument?
main_answers: The argument infers that certain parts of the brain do nothing merely on the basis of the assertion that we do not know what they do.
The argument presumes, without providing justification, that the only reason that any problem remains unsolved is a lack of creativity and innovation.
The argument infers that problems will be solved merely on the basis of the claim that they will be within our ability to solve.
The argument presumes, without providing justification, that the currently unused parts of the brain are a potential source of tremendous creativity and innovation.
others.target_option: The argument presumes, without providing justification, that the only reason that any problem remains unsolved is a lack of creativity and innovation.

context: Director of personnel: Ms. Tours has formally requested a salary adjustment on the grounds that she was denied merit raises to which she was entitled. Since such grounds provide a possible basis for adjustments, an official response is required. Ms. Tours presents compelling evidence that her job performance has been both excellent in itself and markedly superior to that of others in her department who were awarded merit raises. Her complaint that she was treated unfairly thus appears justified. Nevertheless, her request should be denied. To raise Ms. Tours' s salary because of her complaint would jeopardize the integrity of the firm' s merit-based reward system by sending the message that employees can get their salaries raised if they just complain enough.
question: Why is the personnel director's reasoning not considered to be flawed for disregarding the possibility that some of the people who did receive merit increases were not entitled to them?
answers: The response doesn’t make the claim that those who received increases did not earn them, but it suggests that compelling evidence, that Ms. Tours was also worthy, was presented.
The director does not consider the damage to the firm’s reputation as well as legal issues that could arise if they don’t treat Ms. Tours fairly.
The response already explains that an official response is required because it concerns a salary adjustment.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The personnel director's reasoning is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that it
main_answers: fails to consider the possibility that Ms. Tours's complaint could be handled on an unofficial basis
ignores the possibility that some of the people who did receive merit increases were not entitled to them
overlooks the implications for the integrity of the firm's merit-based reward system of denying Ms. Tours's request
sidesteps the issue of whether superior job performance is a suitable basis for awarding salary increases
others.target_option: ignores the possibility that some of the people who did receive merit increases were not entitled to them

context: Lightbox, Inc. , owns almost all of the movie theaters in Washington County and has announced plans to double the number of movie screens it has in the county within five years. Yet attendance at Lightbox' s theaters is only just large enough for profitability now and the county' s population is not expected to increase over the next ten years. Clearly, ttherefore, if there is indeed no increase in population, Lightbox' s new screens are unlikely to prove profitable.
question: Why does the fact that Lightbox's policy is to avoid movies that appeal to only a small segment of the moviegoing population not weaken the argument about Washington County?
answers: Video purchases and rental is only a small cost of a theater's running costs.
A large influx of customers would make opening more locations profitable.
This is a preexisting policy, and Lightbox is still not profitable.
How Lightbox generates its revenue has nothing to do with the argument in the passage.
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true about Washington County, most seriously weakens the argument?
main_answers: In selecting the mix of movies shown at its theaters, Lightbox's policy is to avoid those that appeal to only a small segment of the moviegoing population.
The sales of snacks and drinks in its movie theaters account for more of Lightbox's profits than ticket sales do.
Spending on video purchases, as well as spending on video rentals, is currently no longer increasing.
Though little change in the size of the population is expected, a pronounced shift toward a younger, more affluent, and more entertainment-oriented population is expected to occur.
others.target_option: In selecting the mix of movies shown at its theaters, Lightbox's policy is to avoid those that appeal to only a small segment of the moviegoing population.

context: Taxi driver: My passengers complained when, on a hot day, I turned off my cab' s air conditioner while driving up a steep hill. While the engine is powerful enough to both run the air conditioner and climb the hill without slowing, this would have decreased my fuel economy considerably. So turning off the air conditioner was the right decision.
question: Why does the principle that a taxi driver should always act in a way that is most likely to ensure customer satisfaction not support the taxi driver's reasoning?
answers: If the customer would be more satisfied with the air on rather than conserving fuel, then shutting the air off would not contribute to customer satisfaction.
The passenger was displeased with shutting the air off which the driver did anyone, prioritizing fuel economy.
The driver shut off the air based on fuel economy, not the passengers displeasure with the decision.
The taxi driver ran the air until it was necessary to shut it off to conserve fuel.
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following principles, if valid, most supports the taxi driver's reasoning?
main_answers: A taxi driver should always act in a way that is most likely to ensure customer satisfaction.
A taxi driver should run a cab's air conditioner only if doing so does not cause fuel economy to drop below normal levels.
A taxi driver should try to balance concern for fuel economy with concern for passenger comfort.
A taxi driver's turning off air-conditioning for a short period of time is acceptable only if passengers do not complain.
others.target_option: A taxi driver should always act in a way that is most likely to ensure customer satisfaction.

context: Conventional wisdom suggests vaccinating elderly people first in flu season, because they are at greatest risk of dying if they contract the virus. This year's flu virus poses particular risk to elderly people and almost none at all to younger people, particularly children. Nevertheless, health professionals are recommending vaccinating children first against the virus rather than elderly people.
question: What is the basis for not considering that the fact that children who catch one strain of the flu virus and then recover are likely to develop immunity to at least some strains with which they have not yet come in contact to be the strongest reason for the health professionals' recommendation?
answers: The passage explicitly states that children are at practically no risk to this year's virus, so their lack of exposure in the past would not be relevant as to why they should be getting this particular vaccine first.
Whether or not last year's vaccines affect this year's virus is not relevant to why a certain group of people should be first to receive this year's vaccine.
If children develop immunity to other strains of the disease after catching a virus, vaccinating them would be counterintuitive.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, provides the strongest reason for the health professionals' recommendation?
main_answers: Children who catch one strain of the flu virus and then recover are likely to develop immunity to at least some strains with which they have not yet come in contact.
Children are particularly unconcerned with hygiene and ttherefore are the group most responsible for spreading the flu virus to others.
The vaccinations received last year will confer no immunity to this year's flu virus.
Children are no more likely than adults to have immunity to a particular flu virus if they have never lived through a previous epidemic of the same virus.
others.target_option: Children who catch one strain of the flu virus and then recover are likely to develop immunity to at least some strains with which they have not yet come in contact.

context: Farm animals have certain behavioral tendencies that result from the evolutionary history of these species. By imposing on these animals a type of organization that conflicts with their behavioral tendencies, current farm-management practices cause the animals more pain and distress than do practices that more closely conform to the animals' behavioral tendencies. Because the animals tend to resist this type of organization, current practices can also be less efficient than those other farm-management practices.
question: Why is it not valid to infer that, in order to implement efficient farm-management practices, it is necessary to be familiar with the evolutionary history of farm animals from the statements given?
answers: Knowing the animals behavioral tendencies does not require familiarity with their evolutionary history.
The passage states that current practices can be less efficient but it does not state that practices causing the least amount of pain and distress are the most efficient.
Since current practices that cause more pain and distress can be less efficient, some changes that more closely conform to the animals' behavioral tendencies, could result in gains in efficiency.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: If the statements above are true, which one of the following can be properly inferred from them?
main_answers: In order to implement efficient farm-management practices, it is necessary to be familiar with the evolutionary history of farm animals.
In order to create farm-management practices that cause less pain and distress to farm animals, a significant loss of efficiency will be required.
Farm-management practices that cause the least amount of pain and distress to farm animals are also the most efficient management practices.
Some changes in farm-management practices that lessen the pain and distress experienced by farm animals can result in gains in efficiency.
others.target_option: In order to implement efficient farm-management practices, it is necessary to be familiar with the evolutionary history of farm animals.

The passage states that current practices can be less efficient but it does not state that practices causing the least amount of pain and distress are the most efficient.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: If the statements above are true, which one of the following can be properly inferred from them?
main_answers: In order to implement efficient farm-management practices, it is necessary to be familiar with the evolutionary history of farm animals.
In order to create farm-management practices that cause less pain and distress to farm animals, a significant loss of efficiency will be required.
Farm-management practices that cause the least amount of pain and distress to farm animals are also the most efficient management practices.
Some changes in farm-management practices that lessen the pain and distress experienced by farm animals can result in gains in efficiency.
others.target_option: Some changes in farm-management practices that lessen the pain and distress experienced by farm animals can result in gains in efficiency.

context: Doctor: The practice of using this therapy to treat the illness cannot be adequately supported by the claim that any therapy for treating the illness is more effective than no therapy at all. What must also be taken into account is that this therapy is expensive and complicated.
question: Why does the doctor's argument not support the claim that the therapy is more effective than other forms of treatment for the illness?
answers: Therapy's effectiveness is not compared to other treatments only to no therapy
The author states that therapy can be expensive and complicated but there is no reference to the cost or expensive of other illness treatments.
Cost and effectiveness are part of the criteria for determining if therapy should be used but not the only criteria
Therapy's other costs must be considered before enlisting the treatment as it is not cheap and not simple.

context: Forest fragmentation occurs when development severs a continuous area of forest, breaking it down into small patches. Some animals, such as white-footed mice, thrive in conditions of forest fragmentation, reaching their highest population densities in small forest patches. These mice are the main carrier of the bacteria that cause Lyme disease, a debilitating illness that is often transmitted from white-footed mice to humans by deer ticks.
question: Why is it not reasonable to conclude that the population density for most species of small animals increases when a continuous area of forest becomes fragmented based on the information given?
answers: That conclusion cannot be drawn from the passage since such mice would necessarily have to exist in unfragmented forests in order to proliferate when said forests become fragmented.
This cannot be conclusive since theoretically there could be other environments, such as zoos for example, where deer ticks have higher population densities.

According to the passage mice that cause Lyme disease in humans proliferate in fragmented forests, therefore preventing forest fragmentation would prevent the proliferation of such mice and result in less harm to the health of humans.
Such a generalized conclusion cannot be drawn by the example of just one species of small animals proliferating when forests get fragmented.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the information above?
main_answers: The population density for most species of small animals increases when a continuous area of forest becomes fragmented.
Deer ticks reach their highest population densities in small forest patches.
White-footed mice are very rarely found in unfragmented forests.
Efforts to stop the fragmentation of forests can have a beneficial effect on human health.
others.target_option: The population density for most species of small animals increases when a continuous area of forest becomes fragmented.

context: The chairperson should not have released the Election Commission' s report to the public, for the chairperson did not consult any other members of the commission about releasing the report before having it released.
question: Explain why the argument's conclusion cannot be properly inferred even if it is assumed that some members of the commission would have preferred that the report not be released to the public.
answers: If a majority consent to have their report publicized, it would have been more acceptable for the chairperson to do so.
Some could represent a small minority of total members.
If the members freely associate themselves with the report, they would likely not oppose its public release.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The argument's conclusion can be properly inferred if which one of the following is assumed?
main_answers: It would have been permissible for the chairperson to release the commission's report to the public only if most other members of the commission had first given their consent.
The chairperson would have been justified in releasing the report only if each of the commission's members would have agreed to its being released had they been consulted.
Some members of the commission would have preferred that the report not be released to the public.
All of the members of the commission had signed the report prior to its release.
others.target_option: Some members of the commission would have preferred that the report not be released to the public.

context: Electronic cigarettes should not be subject to the same regulation as other products that contain nicotine. Recent studies indicate that electronic cigarettes help people quit smoking by providing nicotine without the harmful tar and additive chemicals. Although electronic cigarettes also contain their own additives, they are much less harmful in the short-term than traditional cigarettes. People who smoke electronic cigarettes are ten times less likely to die from cancer than smokers of traditional cigarettes.
question: How does the fact that the current regulations are designed to prevent children from using nicotine weaken the argument?
answers: It's likely that if smoking electronic cigarettes instead of traditional cigarettes lowers cancer risk, it also lowers heart disease risk. The argument didn't mention heart disease.
There are no additives in electronic cigarettes that could possibly be as harmful as those found in traditional cigarettes.
There is no evidence to support the claim that the studies cited are not conclusive.

The argument is focused on the benefits of using electronic cigarettes instead of traditional cigarettes. Children aren't likely to already be smokers, so they would not benefit from using a product that is less harmful than cigarettes.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following most weakens the argument?
main_answers: The current regulations are designed to prevent children from using nicotine.
The recent studies are not conclusive.
The additives in electronic cigarettes have not been tested as thoroughly as those in traditional cigarettes.
More smokers die from heart disease than cancer.
others.target_option: The current regulations are designed to prevent children from using nicotine.

context: Near-Earth objects (NEOs) such as asteroids threaten the Earth because they have the potential to collide with it. The goal of NEO research is to develop measures to counteract a possible hit by a sizable NEO. Government funding of this research is not a waste of money. Buying home insurance makes good fiscal sense, and governments fund NEO research for the same reason that people insure their homes.
question: Why does the statement that buying home insurance makes good fiscal sense not play the role of a general principle for which the argument attempts to provide support?
answers: The argument is not attempting to provide support for home insurance making sense, it is attempting to provide support for NEO research making sense.
Home insurance making good fiscal sense is only used to support the conclusion that Government funding of NEO research is good.
The author makes an analogy between home insurance and funding for NEO research and uses this to show that the funding is as good an idea as the insurance is.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The statement that buying home insurance makes good fiscal sense plays which one of the following roles in the argument?
main_answers: It is a general principle for which the argument attempts to provide support.
It connects an analogy made in the argument to the argument's conclusion.
It is the overall conclusion of the argument.
It provides a contrast to the situation that is the main focus of the argument.
others.target_option: It is a general principle for which the argument attempts to provide support.

context: At many electronics retail stores, the consumer has the option of purchasing product warranties that extend beyond the manufacturer' s warranty. However, consumers are generally better off not buying extended warranties. Most problems with electronic goods occur within the period covered by the manufacturer' s warranty.
question: Why does the fact that retail stores sell extended warranties in part because consumers who purchase them are likely to purchase other products from the same store not strengthen the argument?
answers: An extended warranty being purchased has no bearing on when and how an item might break.
If the cost of the repairs are likely to be less than the cost of the warranty it would be more financially positive to just pay for the repair if it is needed.
Purchasing other products from a store does not effect when any one product might break.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?
main_answers: Most of those who buy extended warranties on electronic goods do so because special circumstances make their item more likely to break than is usually the case.
Retail stores sell extended warranties in part because consumers who purchase them are likely to purchase other products from the same store.
Problems with electronic goods that occur after the manufacturer's warranty expires are generally inexpensive to fix in comparison with the cost of an extended warranty.
Some extended warranties on electronic goods cover the product for the period covered by the manufacturer's warranty as well as subsequent years.
others.target_option: Retail stores sell extended warranties in part because consumers who purchase them are likely to purchase other products from the same store.

context: All social systems are based upon a division of economic roles. The values of a social system are embodied in the prestige accorded persons who fill various economic roles. It is ttherefore unsurprising that, for any social system, the introduction of labor-saving technology that makes certain economic roles obsolete will tend to undermine the values in that social system.
question: Explain why it is not reasonable to conclude that a technologically advanced society will place little value on the prestige associated with an economic role based on the information provided?
answers: By this logic if a social system does not change then technology can never enter into the equation.
The passage is saying the opposite of this, every role in an economy is valued.
The passage does not mention technology undermining the social system.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following can most reasonably be concluded on the basis of the information above?
main_answers: A technologically advanced society will place little value on the prestige associated with an economic role.
No type of technology will fail to undermine the values in a social system.
Social systems will have unchanging values if they are shielded from technological advancement.
A social system whose values are not susceptible to change would not be one in which technology can eliminate economic roles.
others.target_option: A technologically advanced society will place little value on the prestige associated with an economic role.

context: Activist: As electronic monitoring of employees grows more commonplace and invasive, we hear more and more attempted justifications of this practice by employers. Surveillance, they explain, keeps employees honest, efficient, and polite to customers. Such explanations are obviously self-serving, and so should not be taken to justify these unwarranted invasions of privacy.
question: What is the evidence that the activist's argument is not using a questionable technique of making a generalization based on a sample that there is reason to believe is biased?
answers: The argument is indeed general, but no specific sample is referred to at any point and so this cannot the called a generalisation from a sample.
The passage suggests that the employers' argument is self-serving, but offers no rebuttal of it other than to call it unwarranted.
No mention is made of any ethical standards other than those currently by applied by employers.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: A questionable technique used in the activist's argument is to
main_answers: attack employers' motives instead of addressing their arguments
attack an argument different from that actually offered by the employers
insist that modern business practices meet moral standards far higher than those accepted in the past
make a generalization based on a sample that there is reason to believe is biased
others.target_option: make a generalization based on a sample that there is reason to believe is biased

context: One' s palate is to a great extent socially determined: that is, if we notice that a lot of people enjoy consuming a certain type of food, we will eventually come to like the food as well, once we have become accustomed to the food.
question: Explain why the example of Sally finding jalapeno peppers to be too hot when she first tried them, but now she can eat them without discomfort, because her family members use them frequently in their cooking does not closely conform to the principle above.
answers: Sally has built up a tolerance to a food.  Her liking the jalapenos is not because she didn't previously not find them to be godd just too hot.
By staying with others it is common to learn to enjoy the same things that they do.
Maxine did learn to enjoy pasta just because her neighbor liked it.  Maxine just discovered a new way to eat something.
Yolanda dislikes something that she hasn't tasted.  Observation is not the same as consumption.
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following most closely conforms to the principle above?
main_answers: Sally found jalapeno peppers to be too hot when she first tried them, but now she can eat them without discomfort, because her family members use them frequently in their cooking.
Yolanda dislikes pickles because she has observed that many of her relatives wince when eating pickles.
Maxine spoke to her neighbor about the many different ways he prepared pasta, and after trying some of his recipes found out that she loves to eat pasta.
All of George's Ukrainian relatives love to eat pierogis, and by staying with them for several summers, George has become very fond of pierogis as well.
others.target_option: Sally found jalapeno peppers to be too hot when she first tried them, but now she can eat them without discomfort, because her family members use them frequently in their cooking.

context: Paperback books wear out more quickly than hardcover books do, but paperback books cost much less. Ttherefore, users of public libraries would be better served if public libraries bought only paperback books, since by so doing these libraries could increase the number of new book titles added to their collections without increasing their budgets.
question: How does the fact that library users as a group depend on their public library for access to a wide variety of up-to-date reference books that are published in hardcover only weaken the argument?
answers: This cost would defeat the purpose of buying paperback books, but it also does not address the availability of titles in paperback
There is no mention of how budget cutbacks are implemented, so a budget cutback may leave the new acquisition budget relatively unaffected.
If paperback books would increase the number of books available at public libraries and lessen the demand for book purchases
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
main_answers: People are more likely to buy for themselves a copy of a book they had previously borrowed from the public library if that book is available in paperback.
Library users as a group depend on their public library for access to a wide variety of up-to-date reference books that are published in hardcover only.
Paperback books can very inexpensively have their covers reinforced in order to make them last longer.
If a public library's overall budget is cut, the budget for new acquisitions is usually cut back more than is that for day-to-day operations.
others.target_option: Library users as a group depend on their public library for access to a wide variety of up-to-date reference books that are published in hardcover only.

context: A certain auto repair shop services a particular make of car in the downtown region of a particular city. Three years ago, 4% of all repairs at this shop were not successful --- the mechanics were not able to restore the car to a drivable state. This year, only 2% of all repairs were not successful. Clearly, the mechanics training course, given over a year ago, has considerably increased the skill of mechanics at this particular shop, so that fewer cars are beyond their ability to repair.
question: Why is the argument weakened by the statement that the manufacturer of this particular make of car recalled a few models due to defects that potentially jeopardized the engine?
answers: This weakens the argument because cars with difficult to repair defects were recalled and could result in the increase in efficiency by the station in the passage.

This would weaken the argument because older and unreliable vehicles would no longer be serviced by the station in the passage because they would have been pulled from the road and not be able to be driven.
This would in face strengthen the argument because the 2% would be based on many more servicing incidents showing that the shop really had increased their efficiency to a great degree.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: All of the following statements, if true, weaken the argument, EXCEPT:
main_answers: The manufacturer of this particular make of car recalled a few models due to defects that potentially jeopardized the engine.
The total number of cars served per year by this shop has increased by 35% over the past three years.
Three years ago, statewide smog regulations had the effect of removing the oldest and most unreliable vehicles from the road.
A new shop uptown specializes in repairing cars of this make more than six years old, and most of these older cars are taken to this shop.
others.target_option: The manufacturer of this particular make of car recalled a few models due to defects that potentially jeopardized the engine.

context: Mayor Pollister always repays his contributors by passing the laws they desire. Since Mayor Pollister recently passed the city' s first clean air act, he must have had a contributor to repay.
question: Explain why the argument does not depend on the assumption that Mayor Pollister recently gained a great deal of support from a contributor?
answers: The contributor that the mayor is repaying may not have been gained recently.
Whether or not the city will benefit from the clean air act is irrelevant to why it was passed if the mayor is passing it for reasons other than the benefit of the city.
The argument doesn't mention an election.
If the mayor passes laws for reasons other than paying back contributors, it would not be necessary for the mayor to have had a contributor to repay in order to pass the clean air act.
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
main_answers: Mayor Pollister recently gained a great deal of support from a contributor.
Mayor Pollister would not have passed the law unless he was doing so for a contributor.
Mayor Pollister needed contributions to succeed in the election.
The city will be benefited by the passage of the clean air act.
others.target_option: Mayor Pollister recently gained a great deal of support from a contributor.
