context: Sociologist: Many rural residents claim to only approve of modest lifestyles; yet, many of these same rural residents often buy magazines focused on the lives of celebrities. However, it is proven that humans are often fascinated by the very things they condemn. Ttherefore, it is predictable that these celebrity magazines would be popular with these rural residents.
question: Why is it valid to conclude that the sociologist's argument depends on the assumption that most rural residents who buy the magazines focused on celebrities do not regard the celebrity lifestyles as modest?
answers: If the celebrities lived modest lifestyles, it wouldn't be something the rural residents would condemn, and therefore they wouldn't be interested in reading about it.
If rural residents regarded modest living highly, they wouldn't condemn it, and thus wouldn't buy more celebrity magazines.
The passage only deals with rural residents buying celebrity magazines, and what wealthier or more urban people do with such magazines is beyond the scope/claim of the passage
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The sociologist's argument depends on which one of the following assumptions?
main_answers: More rural residents than before regard modest living highly.
All people who buy magazines focused on the lives of celebrities condemn such lifestyles.
Most rural residents who buy the magazines focused on celebrities do not regard the celebrity lifestyles as modest.
All rural residents who buy the magazines focused on the lives of celebrities are fascinated by the things that they condemn.
others.target_option: Most rural residents who buy the magazines focused on celebrities do not regard the celebrity lifestyles as modest.

None of the above choices
label: D

context: Leaf beetles damage willow trees by stripping away their leaves, but a combination of parasites and predators generally keeps populations of these beetles in check. Researchers have found that severe air pollution results in reduced predator populations. The parasites, by contrast, are not adversely affected by pollution; nevertheless, the researchers' discovery probably does explain why leaf beetles cause particularly severe damage to willows in areas with severe air pollution, since __.
question: What is the reasoning for concluding that, where air pollution is not especially severe, predators have much more impact on leaf-beetle populations than parasites do logically completes the passage?
answers: A leaf beetle does not have to kill a willow tree to cause severe damage.

If parasites are more prevalent in areas with severe air pollution, then leaf beetles should have caused less damage in the area, as the parasites are not as affected by pollution, and can continue keeping the leaf beetle population in check.
The absolute amount of willows has no relevance to the proportion of willow trees damaged by beetles.

If predators have a much larger impact than parasites and air pollution reduces the amount of predators, then the overall amount of predators and parasite are proportionally decreased more substantially.
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following most logically completes the passage?
main_answers: where air pollution is not especially severe, predators have much more impact on leaf-beetle populations than parasites do
the damage caused by leaf beetles is usually not enough to kill a willow tree outright
the parasites that attack leaf beetles actually tend to be more prevalent in areas with severe air pollution than they are elsewhere
willows often grow in areas where air pollution is especially severe
others.target_option: where air pollution is not especially severe, predators have much more impact on leaf-beetle populations than parasites do

context: Consumer: I would like to have the features contained in the latest upgrade to your computer software package, but I am leery of installing the upgrade because a friend has told me he had a problem with it. Company representative: We have distributed nearly 3, 000 copies of the upgrade and we have received fewer than 100 calls saying that it has caused problems. So it is very unlikely that you will experience any problems with the upgrade.
question: Why is the reasoning in the company representative's argument considered vulnerable to criticism for failing to consider the possibility that a significant number of people have experienced problems with the upgrade but have not reported them?
answers: Not everyone who experiences a problem will take the time to contact a company representative to report it.  Therefore the number of people experiencing problems may not be accurate.
Of the fewer than 100 calls it is not known what the problems were only that the customers had an issue whether it was their fault or not is not relevant.
The representative is taking into account just the numbers of complaints and not the specific causes of the complaints.
If a consumer does not update the software than a problem may not occur but the argument is relevant to only those who do chose to upgrade.
label: A

others.main_question: The reasoning in the company representative's argument is most vulnerable to criticism because it fails to consider the possibility that
main_answers: a significant number of people have experienced problems with the upgrade but have not reported them
some of the reported problems were a result of users failing to follow instructions
the consumer will experience software problems if the upgrade is not installed
some of the problems people have experienced with the upgrade have been quite serious
others.target_option: a significant number of people have experienced problems with the upgrade but have not reported them

answers: Of the fewer than 100 calls it is not known what the problems were only that the customers had an issue whether it was their fault or not is not relevant.
If a consumer does not update the software than a problem may not occur but the argument is relevant to only those who do chose to upgrade.
Not everyone who experiences a problem will take the time to contact a company representative to report it.  Therefore the number of people experiencing problems may not be accurate.
The representative is taking into account just the numbers of complaints and not the specific causes of the complaints.
label: A

others.main_question: The reasoning in the company representative's argument is most vulnerable to criticism because it fails to consider the possibility that
main_answers: a significant number of people have experienced problems with the upgrade but have not reported them
some of the reported problems were a result of users failing to follow instructions
the consumer will experience software problems if the upgrade is not installed
some of the problems people have experienced with the upgrade have been quite serious
others.target_option: some of the reported problems were a result of users failing to follow instructions

context: The attribution of the choral work Lacrimae to the composer Pescard (1400-1474) has been regarded as tentative, since it was based on a single treatise from the early 1500' s that named Pescard as the composer. Recently, several musical treatises from the late 1500' s have come to light, all of which name Pescard as the composer of Lacrimae. Unfortunately, these newly discovered treatises lend no support to the attribution of Lacrimae to Pescard, since __.
question: What is the reasoning behind the conclusion that the later treatises probably had no source for their attribution other than the earlier treatise?
answers: if the later writings were based only on the previous one, they would not lend any new or useful evidence to support the attribution
If the original treatise was found to be questionable, the additional newer ones could still lend credence to the attribution of Lacrimae to Pescard
errors in the earlier treatise do not necessarily have any bearing on the veracity of the later findings
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which of the following most logically completes the argument?
main_answers: the later treatises probably had no source for their attribution other than the earlier treatise
the author of the treatise from the early 1500's had no very strong evidence on which to base the identification of Pescard as the composer of Lacrimae
the treatise from the early 1500's misidentifies the composers of some of the musical works it considers
there are works that can conclusively be attributed to Pescard that are not even mentioned in the treatise from the early 1500's
others.target_option: the later treatises probably had no source for their attribution other than the earlier treatise

context: Sherrie: Scientists now agree that nicotine in tobacco is addictive inasmuch as smokers who try to stop smoking suffer withdrawal symptoms. For this reason alone, tobacco should be treated the same way as other dangerous drugs. Governments worldwide have a duty to restrict the manufacture and sale of tobacco. Fran: By your own admission, "addictive" is broad enough to include other commonly consumed products, such as coffee and soft drinks containing caffeine. But of course the manufacture and sale of these products should not be restricted.
question: Why does the dialogue not lend support to the claim that Sherrie and Fran disagree with each other about the statement that the manufacture and sale of all drugs should be regulated by governments?
answers: Sherrie argues that nicotine is addictive and thus should be regulated, but Fran lists addictive substances that one wouldn't need regulated
Sherrie is concerned about dangerous, addictive drugs and isn't making an argument about all drugs
Fran's argument rests on assuming Sherrie agrees coffee and soft drinks should not be regulated.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The dialogue above lends the most support to the claim that Sherrie and Fran disagree with each other about which one of the following statements?
main_answers: The manufacture and sale of all drugs should be regulated by governments.
Coffee and soft drinks that contain caffeine should not be regulated by governments.
Scientists and governments have a duty to cooperate in regulating drugs to protect the public health.
Agreement by scientists that a substance is addictive justifies government restrictions on products containing that substance.
others.target_option: The manufacture and sale of all drugs should be regulated by governments.

context: Formal performance evaluations in the professional world are conducted using realistic situations. Physicians are allowed to consult medical texts freely, attorneys may refer to law books and case records, and physicists and engineers have their manuals at hand for ready reference. Students, then, should likewise have access to their textbooks whenever they take examinations.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument questionable for failing to consider the possibility that the purposes of evaluation in the professional world and in school situations are quite dissimilar?
answers: The passage does not reference how much experience one needs to have.
What is true for a professional such as a physician or attorney can be very different than what is true for a student.
This reasoning is incorrect because it does state that students have access to their textbooks.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The reasoning in the argument is questionable because the argument
main_answers: neglects to take into account the fact that professionals were once students who also did not have access to textbooks during examinations
neglects to take into account the fact that, unlike students, professionals have devoted many years of study to one subject
cites examples that are insufficient to support the generalization that performance evaluations in the professional world are conducted in realistic situations
fails to consider the possibility that the purposes of evaluation in the professional world and in school situations are quite dissimilar
others.target_option: fails to consider the possibility that the purposes of evaluation in the professional world and in school situations are quite dissimilar

context: Researcher: Dinosaurs lack turbinates -- nasal cavity bone structures in warm-blooded species that minimize water loss during breathing. According to some paleobiologists, this implies that all dinosaurs were cold-blooded. These paleobiologists must be mistaken, however, for fossil records show that some dinosaur species lived in Australia and Alaska, where temperatures drop below freezing. Only warm-blooded animals could survive such temperatures.
question: Explain why the claim that only warm-blooded animals could survive temperatures below freezing does not play the role of counterevidence to the paleobiologists' assertion that dinosaurs lack turbinates in the researcher's argument.
answers: The premise regarding survival of those temperatures and the requirements of such are presented in support of the main conclusion.
The researcher does not argue against or for the lack or presence of turbinates.

The researcher is not providing a counterexample for their own argument, nor is it a counterexample for the implications of some paleo biologists. It is provided in support of the researcher's conclusion.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following most accurately describes the role played in the researcher's argument by the claim that only warm-blooded animals could survive temperatures below freezing?
main_answers: It is presented as counterevidence to the paleobiologists' assertion that dinosaurs lack turbinates.
It is presented as a potential counterexample to the argument's main conclusion.
It is a premise offered in support of the argument's main conclusion.
It is the argument's main conclusion.
others.target_option: It is presented as counterevidence to the paleobiologists' assertion that dinosaurs lack turbinates.

context: Economist: Our economy' s weakness is the direct result of consumers' continued reluctance to spend, which in turn is caused by factors such as high-priced goods and services. This reluctance is exacerbated by the fact that the average income is significantly lower than it was five years ago. Thus, even though it is not a perfect solution, if the government were to lower income taxes, the economy would improve.
question: What is the basis for the economist's argument not requiring the assumption that if income taxes are not lowered, consumers' wages will decline even further?
answers: The author does not make any predictions about future wages, they only argue about spending.
The economist is talking about consumer spending, and how government spending is affected is not relevant.

The author states that consumers are spending less, suggests that it is exacerbated by consumers having less disposable income, and then suggests that lower taxes will help, presumably because they'd have more disposable income and would be less reluctant.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the economist's argument?
main_answers: Lowering income taxes will have no effect on government spending.
Increasing consumer spending will cause prices for goods and services to decrease.
If income taxes are not lowered, consumers' wages will decline even further.
Consumers will be less reluctant to spend money if income taxes are lowered.
others.target_option: If income taxes are not lowered, consumers' wages will decline even further.

context: Advertisement: Clark brand-name parts are made for cars manufactured in this country. They satisfy all of our government automotive tests -- the toughest such tests in the world. With foreign-made parts, you never know which might be reliable and which are cheap look-alikes that are poorly constructed and liable to cost you hundreds of dollars in repairs. Ttherefore, be smart and insist on brand-name parts by Clark for your car.
question: What evidence is needed to show that the argument does not depend on the assumption that no foreign-made parts satisfy our government standards?
answers: The article makes the claim that domestic parts satisfy all government standards, not that foreign-made parts don't satisfy any of them
The article makes the claim that domestic parts are more suitable, not that foreign-made parts are unsuitable.
Since the domestic parts pass the government standards, it is implied they're more well constructed than foreign ones since quality usually increases the odds of passing the tests.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The argument requires the assumption that
main_answers: foreign-made parts are not suitable for cars manufactured in this country
no foreign-made parts satisfy our government standards
if parts are made for cars manufactured in our country, they are not poorly constructed
parts that satisfy our government standards are not as poorly constructed as cheap foreign-made parts
others.target_option: no foreign-made parts satisfy our government standards

context: Researcher: It is commonly believed that species belonging to the same biological order, such as rodents, descended from a single common ancestor. However, I compared the genetic pattern in 3 rodent species -- guinea pigs, rats, and mice -- as well as in 13 nonrodent mammals, and found that while rats and mice are genetically quite similar, the genetic differences between guinea pigs and mice are as great as those between mice and some nonrodent species. Thus, despite their similar physical form, guinea pigs stem from a separate ancestor.
question: How does the fact that some pairs of species not having a common ancestor are genetically more similar to each other than are some pairs that do have a common ancestor seriously undermine the researcher's reasoning?
answers: The epoch that a common ancestor dates from is not related the the argument of genetic similarity.
Peculiarities of body structure are not related to the argument of genetic similarity.
Even if the researcher selected nonrodent species that have specific cell structures this would not undermine their argument which is based on genetic differences.
Genetic similarity does not determine common ancestors therefore genetic differences between guinea pigs and mice do not prove that they stem from a separate ancestor.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously undermines the researcher's reasoning?
main_answers: Some pairs of species not having a common ancestor are genetically more similar to each other than are some pairs that do have a common ancestor.
For some genuine biological orders, the most recent common ancestor dates from later epochs than does the most recent common ancestor of other biological orders.
Peculiarities of body structure, such as distinctive teeth and olfactory structures, are shared by all rodents, including guinea pigs.
The researcher selected nonrodent species that have the specific cell structures she wanted to analyze genetically, though many nonrodent mammals lack these cell structures.
others.target_option: Some pairs of species not having a common ancestor are genetically more similar to each other than are some pairs that do have a common ancestor.

context: Historian: The revolutionary party has been accused of having many overambitious goals and of having caused great suffering. However, most of the party' s goals were quickly achieved and the party did not have enough power to cause the suffering the critics claim it caused. So it is clear that the party was not overambitious and caused no suffering.
question: What is the rationale for why the historian's argument is considered flawed for failing to establish that the revolutionary party caused no suffering?
answers: It only implies that they minimized suffering via being quick and thorough, but doesn't establish that there was no suffering at all.
The passage actually makes the claim that the revolutionary party's critics overestimated the party's power.
Being quick and being less powerful than assumed are not mutually inconsistent states.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The reasoning in the historian's argument is flawed because the argument
main_answers: fails to establish that the revolutionary party caused no suffering
provides no evidence that the revolutionary party's goals were not overambitious
fails to establish that any of the revolutionary party's critics underestimated the party's power
gives mutually inconsistent responses to the two criticisms
others.target_option: fails to establish that the revolutionary party caused no suffering

It only implies that they minimized suffering via being quick and thorough, but doesn't establish that there was no suffering at all.
Being quick and being less powerful than assumed are not mutually inconsistent states.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: The reasoning in the historian's argument is flawed because the argument
main_answers: fails to establish that the revolutionary party caused no suffering
provides no evidence that the revolutionary party's goals were not overambitious
fails to establish that any of the revolutionary party's critics underestimated the party's power
gives mutually inconsistent responses to the two criticisms
others.target_option: gives mutually inconsistent responses to the two criticisms

context: Principle: A government should reduce taxes on imports if doing so would financially benefit many consumers in its domestic economy. There is a notable exception, however: it should never reduce import taxes if one or more of its domestic industries would be significantly harmed by the added competition. Conclusion: The government should not reduce taxes on textile imports.
question: Explain why the conclusion cannot be properly drawn from the statement that the domestic textile industry faces significant competition in many of its export markets using the principle.
answers: The export market is not mentioned, solely the import market and its competition (or lack thereof).
No other measures are discussed as a means to benefit the domestic textile industry so there is not enough information to form a conclusion based off of this statement.

If the decrease of taxes on imported textile goods created too much competition for the domestic textile industry by making it impossible for a profit to be made, this would indeed create sound reasoning for not reducing the taxes.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following is a statement from which the conclusion can be properly drawn using the principle?
main_answers: The domestic textile industry faces significant competition in many of its export markets.
Reducing taxes on textile imports would financially benefit some consumers in the domestic economy but would not benefit the domestic textile industry.
The added competition produced by any reduction of taxes on imports would significantly harm the domestic textile industry.
The domestic textile industry and consumers in the domestic economy would benefit less from reductions in taxes on textile imports than they would from other measures.
others.target_option: The domestic textile industry faces significant competition in many of its export markets.

context: In the nation of Partoria, large trucks currently have a much higher rate of traffic accidents per mile driven than other vehicles do. However, the very largest trucks-those with three trailers-had less than a third of the accident rate of single- and double-trailer trucks. Clearly, ttherefore, one way for Partoria to reduce the number of traffic accidents would be to require shippers to increase their use of triple-trailer trucks.
question: Explain why the fact that the safety record of the trucking industry as a whole has improved slightly over the past ten years in Partoria does not seriously weaken the argument.
answers: Increase of one type of truck does not necessarily mean another type is being used less.
If triple trailer trucks are safest then using them more would result in less accidents.
If the safety has improved for all trucks it does not indicate a difference in safety between different types of trucks rather than a difference that effects all trucks.

Smaller roads does not necessarily have anything to do with safety of the actual trucks since all kinds of trucks (presumable some that would drive on smaller roads and some bigger) have seen reduced accidents.
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
main_answers: In Partoria, the safety record of the trucking industry as a whole has improved slightly over the past ten years.
No matter what changes Partoria makes in the regulation of trucking, it will have to keep some smaller roads off-limits to all large trucks.
Increased use of triple-trailer trucks would mean that large trucks would account for a smaller proportion of all miles driven on Partoria's roads than they currently do.
Partorian trucking companies currently use triple-trailer trucks only for long trips using major highways, which is the safest kind of trip for large trucks.
others.target_option: In Partoria, the safety record of the trucking industry as a whole has improved slightly over the past ten years.

context: Julia joined Michael Scott Paperless Company, a small New York based tech startup company, last month. Michael Scott Paperless recently received a valuation of ten million dollars. Julia is clearly the reason for the valuation.
question: Explain why the fact that Julia only started working two weeks before the valuation does not weaken the argument.
answers: A hugely popular app would make a company more valuable in today’s market and Julia might have made no difference.
Julia being an expert in the field would lend credibility to the statement that the improved valuation was because of her.
Whether the valuation is valid or not would have no bearing on why the company was being valued so high.
The argument is based on the fact that Julia’s association with the company helped bolster their worth, and not how long she had been working with them.
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following statements, if true, most weakens the argument?
main_answers: Julia only started working two weeks before the valuation.
Julia is an expert in her field.
Michael Scott Paperless Company released an extremely popular mobile application shortly before hiring Julia.
Michael Scott Paperless Company is wildly overvalued.
others.target_option: Julia only started working two weeks before the valuation.

context: Police statistics have shown that automobile antitheft devices reduce the risk of car theft, but a statistical study of automobile theft by the automobile insurance industry claims that cars equipped with antitheft devices are, paradoxically, more likely to be stolen than cars that are not so equipped.
question: Why does the fact that most automobile thefts are the work of professional thieves against whose efforts antitheft devices offer scant protection not resolve the apparent paradox?
answers: This seems like this would make the anti theft devices more effective because of how sensitive they are.
This correlation would make a lot of sense and if the overall percentage of cars getting stolen is higher the ones with anti theft devices are likely the most sought after cars.
It is not mentioned how much protection is offered from anti theft devices, only that a car with this device maybe is one that is more valuable thus, more likely to be stolen.
This would not change the crime statistics given in the passage.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, does the most to resolve the apparent paradox?
main_answers: Most automobile thefts are the work of professional thieves against whose efforts antitheft devices offer scant protection.
The most common automobile antitheft devices are audible alarms, which typically produce ten false alarms for every actual attempted theft.
Automobile owners who have particularly theft-prone cars and live in areas of greatest incidence of car theft are those who are most likely to have antitheft devices installed.
Owners of stolen cars almost invariably report the theft immediately to the police but tend to delay notifying their insurance company, in the hope that the vehicle will be recovered.
others.target_option: Most automobile thefts are the work of professional thieves against whose efforts antitheft devices offer scant protection.

context: In 1995, ecologists started to reintroduce the wolf into Yellowstone Park, where the wolf had been eliminated intentionally half a century earlier. Rangers expected a rise in the number of wolf would place limits on the elk population and on the populations of many mid-size mammals. One unexpected consequence was a dramatic rise in the population of foxes, which in turn helped to control many rodent populations.
question: What evidence is there that the fact that foxes choose very different breeding areas than do wolves does not help explain the dramatic rise in the fox population?
answers: If the wolves are reintroduced to the area and prety on coyotes who are foxes predators than the foxes would have more of a chance of survival thus increasing their population.
The populations rose in an area that was inhabitated previously by the wolf population.  Therefore the foxes and wolves choose similiar breeding areas.
The passage does not reference any counties outside of Yellowstone only the Yellowstone park itself.
In the passage there is no mention of the hunting of elk or foxes only that the fox population increased but the passage does not state the status of the elk population.
label: B

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most helps explain the dramatic rise in the fox population?
main_answers: Foxes choose very different breeding area than do wolves
Elk hunting is more popular, and more widely marketable, than is fox hunting
The main predators of the fox were coyotes, on which the wolf preys.
In the agricultural counties surrounding Yellowstone, there are significantly lower wolf and fox populations.
others.target_option: Foxes choose very different breeding area than do wolves

context: Guideline: It is improper for public officials to influence the award of contracts or to perform other acts related to their office in a way that benefits themselves. Even the appearance of such impropriety should be avoided. Application: Greenville' s mayor acted improperly in urging the award of the city' s street maintenance contract to a company owned and operated by one of the mayor' s relatives, whose business would have been in serious financial trouble had it not been awarded the contract.
question: Why does the principle that creating the appearance of impropriety is as blameworthy as acting improperly not help in justifying the application of the guideline?
answers: The amount of risk in a contract has no relevance to the guidelines.
Awarding based on cost and reliability are not always free from benefiting the office of a public official.
The maintenance contract was awarded to a relative, and benefits to friends and family are likely to also benefit one's self.
Recommending that the appearance of impropriety be avoided is not the same as believing it is improper.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following principles most helps in justifying the application of the guideline?
main_answers: Creating the appearance of impropriety is as blameworthy as acting improperly.
Awarding a contract to a financially troubled business should be regarded as taking excessive risk.
Publicly funded contracts should be awarded based primarily on cost and the reliability of the contractor.
Benefiting one's family or friends should be regarded as benefiting oneself.
others.target_option: Creating the appearance of impropriety is as blameworthy as acting improperly.

context: Guideline: It is improper for public officials to influence the award of contracts or to perform other acts related to their office in a way that benefits themselves. Even the appearance of such impropriety should be avoided. Application: Greenville' s mayor acted improperly in urging the award of the city' s street maintenance contract to a company owned and operated by one of the mayor' s relatives, whose business would have been in serious financial trouble had it not been awarded the contract.
question: How does the principle that benefiting one's family or friends should be regarded as benefiting oneself help in justifying the application of the guideline?
answers: Recommending that the appearance of impropriety be avoided is not the same as believing it is improper.
Awarding based on cost and reliability are not always free from benefiting the office of a public official.
The maintenance contract was awarded to a relative, and benefits to friends and family are likely to also benefit one's self.
The amount of risk in a contract has no relevance to the guidelines.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following principles most helps in justifying the application of the guideline?
main_answers: Creating the appearance of impropriety is as blameworthy as acting improperly.
Awarding a contract to a financially troubled business should be regarded as taking excessive risk.
Publicly funded contracts should be awarded based primarily on cost and the reliability of the contractor.
Benefiting one's family or friends should be regarded as benefiting oneself.
others.target_option: Benefiting one's family or friends should be regarded as benefiting oneself.

context: Though ice cream is an excellent source of calcium, dairy farmers report that during the past ten years there has been a sharp decline in ice cream sales. And during the same period, sales of cheddar cheese have nearly doubled. Ttherefore, more and more people must be choosing to increase their intake of calcium by eating cheddar cheese rather than ice cream.
question: Why is the reasoning flawed for failing to consider alternative explanations of the decline in sales of ice cream?
answers: Only presumes that people are eating cheese instead of ice cream to get calcium, not that it is a better source.
Sales are reported, not testimony of customers.
There are many reasons such why ice cream sales might drop that have nothing to do with calcium content.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: The reasoning above is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that it
main_answers: fails to produce statistical evidence supporting the dairy farmers' claims
presumes, without providing justification, that ice cream is a better source of calcium than is cheddar cheese
fails to consider alternative explanations of the decline in sales of ice cream
relies solely on the testimony of individuals who are likely to be biased
others.target_option: fails to consider alternative explanations of the decline in sales of ice cream

context: When old-growth forests are cleared of tall trees, more sunlight reaches the forest floor. This results in a sharp increase in the population of leafy shrubs on which the mule deer depend for food. Yet mule deer herds that inhabit cleared forests are less well-nourished than are herds living in old-growth forests.
question: How does the fact that insect parasites, such as certain species of ticks, that feed primarily on mule deer often dwell in trees, from which they drop onto passing deer, not help to resolve the apparent paradox?
answers: Higher degree of sunlight is assumed to be beneficial, but increased sunlight could negatively affect a plant's chemistry.
Ticks don't make a deer less well-nourished.
Offspring doesn't effect the nourishment of the deer.
If mule deer could eat more plants than other deer, they are more likely to be well-nourished.
label: B

main_answers: Insect parasites, such as certain species of ticks, that feed primarily on mule deer often dwell in trees, from which they drop onto passing deer.

context: In jurisdictions where use of headlights is optional when visibility is good, drivers who use headlights at all times are less likely to be involved in a collision than are drivers who use headlights only when visibility is poor. Yet Highway Safety Department records show that making use of headlights mandatory at all times does nothing to reduce the overall number of collisions.
question: What is the reason for the fact that the information that in jurisdictions where use of headlights is optional when visibility is good, one driver in four uses headlights for daytime driving in good weather does not help to resolve the apparent discrepancy?
answers: This would explain both phenomenons. If a driver who is safe is more likely to use headlights all the time then it would not matter if they use them or not, they  are just a better driver.
The passage mentions nothing about the percentage of people that use headlights during the day when the weather is good.
The level of enforcement was not mentioned and it has to be assumed that people would abide by this rule if no other info is given.
None of the above choices
label: B

context: Letter to the editor: Recently, the city council passed an ordinance that prohibits loitering at the local shopping mall. The council' s declared goal was to eliminate overcrowding and alleviate pedestrian congestion, thereby improving the mall' s business and restoring its family-oriented image. But despite these claims, reducing overcrowding and congestion cannot be the actual goals of this measure, because even when fully implemented, the ordinance would not accomplish them.
question: Explain why the argument does not contain a flaw in its reasoning by taking for granted that an action that does not accomplish its stated goals will not have any beneficial effects.
answers: The argument does not address any other potential effects of the ordinance beyond those stated to be its goal.
The argument mentions no conditions necessary to achieve the goal of congestion reduction, it merely claims that the goal is impossible to achieve.
The argument claims that overcrowding and congestion cannot be reduced, and therefore that congestion reduction cannot be the goal of the ordinance.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following most accurately describes a flaw in the argument's reasoning?
main_answers: The argument takes for granted that something cannot be the goal of an action performed unless the action will in fact achieve that goal.
The argument takes for granted that an action that does not accomplish its stated goals will not have any beneficial effects.
The argument treats a condition that is necessary for achieving an action's stated goals as if this condition were sufficient for achieving these goals.
The argument dismisses a claim because of its source rather than because of its content.
others.target_option: The argument takes for granted that an action that does not accomplish its stated goals will not have any beneficial effects.

context: Biologists studying plant life in the prehistoric rainforest by utilizing samples of ancient ice and fossilized evidence of biological processes found that most of the plants removed an astonishingly small amount of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. One biologist found that a certain tree currently found in the rainforest absorbs carbon dioxide from the atmosphere at a greater rate than any tree on the planet. The biologist hypothesized that the prevalence of this tree in the prehistoric rainforest accounts for the other plants' failure to remove larger amounts of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.
question: Explain why the fact that the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has remained steady since prehistoric times does not seriously undermine the biologist's hypothesis.
answers: The hypothesis makes no mention of the adverse effects of carbon dioxide on prehistoric humans.
There is no explanation what chlorophyll is or what it does.
The tree would not have existed in the prehistoric rainforest.
The hypothesis makes no mention of a change in carbon dioxide levels.
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, would most seriously undermine the biologist's hypothesis?
main_answers: The amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has remained steady since prehistoric times.
The trees currently found in the rainforest are largely hybrids and a product of crossbreeding that occurred in the late twentieth century.
The plant life in the prehistoric rainforest also contained larger amounts of chlorophyll than modern day plants.
The prehistoric humans did not seem to be adversely affected by the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.
others.target_option: The amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has remained steady since prehistoric times.

context: In an experiment, Dr. Farouk studied houseplants that had flourished for years. Over a three-day period he spoke to the plants encouragingly. He then transplanted them outside into a garden and stopped talking to them. Although he continued watering and fertilizing the plants, they soon wilted. When they had not recovered after two days, Dr. Farouk became so concerned that he started talking to them every hour; the next day they began to recover.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the information provided strongly supports the claim that watering plants too much is as hazardous to their well-being as not watering them enough?
answers: Given that the only two variables mentioned are their setting and the speech, and the plants thrived without the latter for years while they started wilting when they changed settings, the conditions of the environment they're in are likely what affected the plants.
What might be true for these particular houseplants doesn't necessarily need to hold true for all plants.
No mention is made of watering the plants more or less, it's only stated that they were being watered in both cases.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the information above?
main_answers: Watering plants too much is as hazardous to their well-being as not watering them enough.
Talking to plants enhances their health.
Changes in growing conditions can affect the flourishing of plants.
Plants always need at least two days to adjust to transplantation.
others.target_option: Watering plants too much is as hazardous to their well-being as not watering them enough.

context: To protect certain fledgling industries, the government of country Z banned imports of the types of products those industries were starting to make. As a direct result, the cost of those products to the buyers, several export-dependent industries in Z, went up, sharply limiting the ability of those industries to compete effectively in their export markets.
question: Why is it not valid to infer that those products had become more and more expensive to import, which resulted in a foreign trade deficit just before the ban from the passage about the products whose importation was banned?
answers: Whether or not the products were imported from the same countries that country Z's exports went to was not mentioned.
Whether or not country Z wanted to export those products or produce them only for domestic use was not mentioned.
There is no evidence that there was a foreign trade deficit.

label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following can be most properly inferred from the passage about the products whose importation was banned?
main_answers: Those products had become more and more expensive to import, which resulted in a foreign trade deficit just before the ban.
Those products were the ones that country Z was hoping to export in its turn, once the fledgling industries matured.
Those products had been cheaper to import than they were to make within country Z's fledgling industries.

context: Atrens: An early entomologist observed ants carrying particles to neighboring ant colonies and inferred that the ants were bringing food to their neighbors. Further research, however, revealed that the ants were emptying their own colony' s dumping site. Thus, the early entomologist was wrong.
question: Why does Atrens's conclusion not follow logically even if it is assumed that the entomologist cited retracted his conclusion when it was determined that the particles the ants carried came from their dumping site?
answers: How ants a d how humans interact is not the subject at hand here.

others.main_question: Atrens's conclusion follows logically if which one of the following is assumed?

context: If you know a lot about history, it will be easy for you to impress people who are intellectuals. But unfortunately, you will not know much about history if you have not, for example, read a large number of history books. Ttherefore, if you are not well versed in history due to a lack of reading, it will not be easy for you to impress people who are intellectuals.
question: Why is the argument's reasoning not considered to be invalid due to its failure to take into account the possibility that many intellectuals are not widely read in history?
answers: We know intellectuals are impressed with history knowledge, but it is unknown and irrelevant what their own knowledge may be.
Intellectuals are impressed with history knowledge, but this fact doesn't exclude other areas that can be impressive
The value of impressing intellectuals is a given

context: Pediatrician: Swollen tonsils give rise to breathing problems during sleep, and the surgical removal of children' s swollen tonsils has been shown to alleviate sleep disturbances. So removing children' s tonsils before swelling even occurs will ensure that the children do not experience any breathing problems during sleep.
question: Why is the pediatrician's argument not considered to be flawed for not taking into account the possibility that there may be other medical reasons for surgically removing a child's tonsils?
answers: Given this is true, it would only serve to strengthen the pediatrician's opinion that tonsils should be removed early.

context: Safety inspector: The number of laboratory samples of rabies virus sent through the university delivery service has recently grown dangerously high. We need to limit this use of the service. Biologist: There is no need for a limit. The university delivery service has been handling rabies virus samples for 20 years with no accidents.
question: Why is the biologist's reasoning as a rebuttal of the safety inspector's claim not considered to be flawed for not explaining why the number of samples sent through the service has increased?
answers: The biologist's argument is centered around the courier service's safety record not why the samples need to be sent in the first place.
The increased rate of rabies virus samples sent may increase the risk of harm even if the delivery service has a good track record.
No information is provided to suggest that the samples themselves have become more dangerous, only that the number of samples being sent has grown.
None of the above choices

context: The five senses have traditionally been viewed as distinct yet complementary. Each sense is thought to have its own range of stimuli that are incapable of stimulating the other senses. However, recent research has discovered that some people taste a banana and claim that they are tasting blue, or see a color and say that it has a specific smell. This shows that such people, called synesthesiacs, have senses that do not respect the usual boundaries between the five recognized senses.
question: Explain why the fact that recent evidence strongly suggests that there are other senses besides sight, touch, smell, hearing, and taste does not weaken the argument.
answers: If the particular ways in which the sensory experiences overlap in Synesthesiacs follow a definite pattern, this does not take away from the fact that they experience these sensory differences.
The discovery of other senses beyond currently recognized ones would not indicate Synesthesiacs do not have senses that do not respect the usual boundaries between the five recognized senses.

If Synesthesiacs demonstrate a general, systematic impairment in their ability to use and understand words it may be that they are just unable to understand or adequately describe what they are experiencing and so do not actually mean they are tasting colors or similar.
Whether they can temporarily rid themselves of their synesthetic experience or not does not take away from their normal state of experience.
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following statements, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
main_answers: Recent evidence strongly suggests that there are other senses besides sight, touch, smell, hearing, and taste.
Synesthesiacs can be temporarily rid of their synesthetic experiences by the use of drugs.
The particular ways in which sensory experiences overlap in synesthesiacs follow a definite pattern.
Synesthesiacs demonstrate a general, systematic impairment in their ability to use and understand words.
others.target_option: Recent evidence strongly suggests that there are other senses besides sight, touch, smell, hearing, and taste.

context: The most successful economies have been, and will continue to be, those that train as many people as possible in the human skills required to research, to develop, and to apply new technology. Japan is a model for this sort of training effort. Europe as a whole is in a weaker position: there is a shortage of skilled labor trained to use the new technologies, and there are not enough scientists able to develop and apply the technology. However, even in Japan there is a shortage of technically qualified people, and, like most European countries, Japan has far too many workers qualified to perform only menial tasks.
question: What is the basis for inferring that, to be economically more successful, Europe needs to train more people in the new technologies from the passage?
answers: It is explicitly stated that Japan is a model for such training and so one could infer they are a good country against which to measure a country's success, despite the claims towards the end regarding where Japan could also improve.

If there is a shortage of skilled labor trained to use the new technologies and of scientists able to develop and apply them, it can be inferred more people need to be trained in these new technologies in order for Europe to become more successful.
No assertions are made regarding Japan's dependency on an uncommonly narrow base of highly skilled labor.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following can be properly inferred from the passage?
main_answers: To be economically more successful, Europe needs to train more people in the new technologies.
Japan's successful economy depends upon an uncommonly narrow base of highly skilled labor.
Japan is not the best country against which to measure a country's economic success.
European countries have economies that are more successful than those of most other countries.
others.target_option: To be economically more successful, Europe needs to train more people in the new technologies.

context: Quality control investigator: Upon testing samples of products from our supplier that were sent by our field inspectors from various manufacturing locations, our laboratory discovered that over 20 percent of the samples were defective. Since our supplier is contractually required to limit the rate of defects among items it manufactures for us to below 5 percent, it has violated its contract with us.
question: Why is the reasoning in the quality control investigator's argument not considered to be invalid due to the argument's failure to provide evidence that the field inspectors were just as likely to choose a defective item for testing as they were to choose a nondefective item?
answers: The author makes no assumption about the likelihood of choosing a defective versus nondefective item, only that the samples exceeded the allowable rate of defects
If inspectors tend to choose likely defective items then the samples would indeed have a higher defective rate than the overall product average
How often the inspectors visited each site is not relevant to the author's argument
No minimum required sample size is stated, nor was the actual sample size used, so it is not relevant as it pertains to the main assertion of the passage
label: A

others.main_question: The reasoning in the quality control investigator's argument is flawed in that the argument
main_answers: presumes, without providing justification, that the field inspectors were just as likely to choose a defective item for testing as they were to choose a nondefective item
presumes, without providing justification, that the field inspectors made an equal number of visits to each of the various manufacturing sites of the supplier
overlooks the possibility that the field inspectors tend to choose items for testing that they suspect are defective
bases its conclusion on too small a sample of items tested by the laboratory
others.target_option: presumes, without providing justification, that the field inspectors were just as likely to choose a defective item for testing as they were to choose a nondefective item

context: A new machine for harvesting corn will allow rows to be planted only fifteen inches apart, instead of the usual thirty inches. Corn planted this closely will produce lower yields per plant. Nevertheless, the new machine will allow corn growers to double their profits per acre because __.
question: What is the reason for not concluding that, with the larger number of plants growing per acre, more fertilizer will be required in order to logically complete the argument?
answers: Increased frequency of fallow years would reduce profits, not raise them.
Corn growing taller takes more time, reducing harvest frequency and thus lowering profits within a given time frame.
More fertilizer being required would lower profits, not raise them.
Reduction in weed control and irrigation would both reduce costs, leading to increased profit.
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following most logically completes the argument?
main_answers: with the larger number of plants growing per acre, more fertilizer will be required

with the closer spacing of the rows, the acreage on which corn is planted will be utilized much more intensively than it was before, requiring more frequent fallow years in which corn fields are left unplanted
with the closer spacing of the rows, the growing corn plants will quickly form a dense canopy of leaves, which will, by shading the ground, minimize the need for costly weed control and irrigation
with the closer spacing of the rows, corn plants will be forced to grow taller because of increased competition for sunlight from neighboring corn plants
others.target_option: with the larger number of plants growing per acre, more fertilizer will be required

context: The Ergonomic Society conducted a study that indicated that many people develop severe back problems during adulthood, and that virtually all such people who received chiropractic treatment showed great improvement. Ttherefore, in order to minimize the proportion of the population that suffers from back pain, the Ergonomic Society recommended that chiropractic treatment be directed toward those adults who suffer from severe back problems.
question: Explain why the argument does not depend on the assumption that severe back pain and other problems often cause individuals to miss workdays.
answers: This study only mentions that people that have back pain are benefited by treatment. This would assume that people who get treatment without cause are not going to avoid back pain.
The passage does not mention that these people are missing work.
The passage never mentions the frequency of treatment.
Other forms of treatment was not mentioned in this passage and it cannot be assumed that other treatments would work.
label: B

others.main_question: Which of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
main_answers: Severe back pain and other problems often cause individuals to miss workdays.
Chiropractic treatment is more effective in treating severe back problems when utilized over a long period of time, as opposed to sporadically.
Individuals who receive chiropractic or other treatment prior to developing severe back problems are not less likely to develop back pain than those who do not.
Any person who receives chiropractic treatment for back pain may also benefit from other forms of treatment.
others.target_option: Severe back pain and other problems often cause individuals to miss workdays.

context: "Multiple use" refers to the utilization of natural resources in combinations that will best meet the present and future needs of the public. Designating land as a wilderness area does not necessarily violate the multiple-use philosophy, for even when such use does not provide the greatest dollar return, it can provide the greatest overall benefit from that site.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the argument requires the assumption that the multiple-use philosophy takes into account some nonfinancial needs of the public?
answers: The article doesn’t make any recommendations as to how the resources should be used, but focuses on what fits the multiple use theory.
A person could violate whatever protections are in place, so the resources could still be harmed.
Since the passage specifies that the multiple use theory isn’t violated if it doesn’t provide a great financial return, the theory must include benefits that aren’t of a monetary nature.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument?
main_answers: The multiple-use philosophy takes into account some nonfinancial needs of the public.
Natural resources should be used in combinations that will most greatly benefit present and future generations.
The present and future needs of the public would best be met by designating greater numbers of wilderness areas.
Designating a wilderness area prevents any exploitation of natural resources in that area.
others.target_option: The multiple-use philosophy takes into account some nonfinancial needs of the public.

context: The Rienzi, a passenger ship, sank as a result of a hole in its hull, possibly caused by sabotage. Normally, when a holed ship sinks as rapidly as the Rienzi did, water does not enter the ship quickly enough for the ship to be fully flooded when it reaches the ocean floor. Full flooding can be achieved, however, by sabotage. Any ship that sinks deep into the ocean when not fully flooded will implode. Deep-sea photographs, taken of the sunken Rienzi where it rests on the ocean floor, reveal that the Rienzi did not implode.
question: Explain why it is not valid to conclude that, if the Rienzi had sunk more slowly, it would have imploded on the basis of the information given?
answers: Nowhere in the passage are we given information concerning the construction of the ship.
Speed of sinking is not correlated with implosion anywhere in the passage.
The passage does not state that implosion takes place before or after the ship reaches the ocean floor.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following must be true on the basis of the information above?
main_answers: If the Rienzi was not sunk by sabotage, water flooded into it unusually fast.
The Rienzi was so strongly constructed as to resist imploding under deep-sea pressure.
If the Rienzi had sunk more slowly, it would have imploded.
If the Rienzi became fully flooded, it did so only after it reached the ocean floor.
others.target_option: If the Rienzi had sunk more slowly, it would have imploded.

context: When butterfat was considered nutritious and healthful, a law was enacted requiring that manufacturers use the term "imitation butter" to indicate butter whose butterfat content had been diminished through the addition of water. Today, it is known that the high cholesterol content of butterfat makes it harmful to human health. Since the public should be encouraged to eat foods with lower rather than higher butterfat content and since the term "imitation" with its connotations of falsity deters many people from purchasing products so designated, manufacturers who wish to give reduced-butterfat butter the more appealing name of "lite butter" should be allowed to do so.
question: Why does the fact that some individuals who need to reduce their intake of cholesterol are not deterred from using the reduced-butterfat product by the negative connotations of the term "imitation" not seriously undermine the argument?
answers: Changing the composition to contain more water should not disallow them from changing the name to lite butter.
Regardless of their motivation, they are changing to lite instead of imitation, to appeal more to customers and should be allowed to.
The fact that some individuals are not deterred, does not change the fact that many are deterred by the term.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously undermines the argument?
main_answers: Most people deterred from eating "imitation butter" because of its name choose alternatives with a lower butterfat content than this product has.
Some individuals who need to reduce their intake of cholesterol are not deterred from using the reduced-butterfat product by the negative connotations of the term "imitation. "
The manufacturers who wish to call their product "lite butter" plan to change the composition of the product so that it contains more water than it now does.
The manufacturers who prefer to use the word "lite" instead of "imitation" are motivated principally by the financial interest of their stockholders.
others.target_option: Some individuals who need to reduce their intake of cholesterol are not deterred from using the reduced-butterfat product by the negative connotations of the term "imitation. "

context: The workers at Bell Manufacturing will shortly go on strike unless the management increases their wages. As Bell' s president is well aware, however, in order to increase the workers' wages, Bell would have to sell off some of its subsidiaries. So, some of Bell' s subsidiaries will be sold.
question: Why does the conclusion not properly follow even if it is assumed that Bell's workers will not accept a package of improved benefits in place of their desired wage increase?
answers: Losses may or may not increase in the future, but for now, selling subsidiaries allows the company to pay higher wages and no real loss has occurred.
Bell's workers may or may not accept a package of improved benefits, but we don't know if this was offered
If workers will strike without higher wages, and they receive higher wages, there is no reason to strike.
Bell's management would not sell subsidiaries to pay higher wages if it refused to pay higher wages
label: B

others.main_question: The conclusion above is properly drawn if which one of the following is assumed?
main_answers: Bell's workers will not accept a package of improved benefits in place of their desired wage increase.
The workers at Bell Manufacturing will not be going on strike.
Bell's management will refuse to increase its workers' wages.
Bell Manufacturing will begin to suffer increased losses.
others.target_option: Bell's workers will not accept a package of improved benefits in place of their desired wage increase.

context: Politician: The mandatory jail sentences that became law two years ago for certain crimes have enhanced the integrity of our system of justice, for no longer are there two kinds of justice, the kind dispensed by lenient judges and the kind dispensed by severe ones. Public advocate: But with judges stripped of discretionary powers, there can be no leniency even where it would be appropriate. So juries now sometimes acquit a given defendant solely because the jurors feel that the mandatory sentence would be too harsh. Those juries, then, do not return an accurate verdict on the defendant' s guilt. This is why it is imperative that the legislation instituting mandatory jail sentences be repealed.
question: What is the basis for the public advocate not responding to the politician's argument by arguing that leniency is not a trait of individuals but that, rather, it is a property of certain kinds of decisions?
answers: The severity of any problem is not referred to by the advocate.
Whether leniency is a property of decisions or individuals is not relevant to the advocate's main point that a lack of room for leniency is a barrier to accuracy.

The politician argues about how the legislation helped enhance the integrity of the system, while the advocate argues that the integrity of the system is harmed in another way when looking at the consequences more deeply.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The public advocate responds to the politician's argument by doing which one of the following?
main_answers: arguing that leniency is not a trait of individuals but that, rather, it is a property of certain kinds of decisions
charging that the politician exaggerated the severity of a problem in order to justify a sweeping solution
claiming that the politician's evidence, properly analyzed, has no bearing on the conclusion the politician derives from it
arguing that an analysis of the consequences of certain legislation undermines the politician's conclusion
others.target_option: arguing that leniency is not a trait of individuals but that, rather, it is a property of certain kinds of decisions

context: Five years ago, as part of a plan to encourage citizens of Levaska to increase the amount of money they put into savings, Levaska' s government introduced special savings accounts in which up to $3, 000 a year can be saved with no tax due on the interest unless money is withdrawn before the account holder reaches the age of sixty-five. Millions of dollars have accumulated in the special accounts, so the government' s plan is obviously working.
question: Explain why the fact that the rate at which interest earned on money deposited in regular savings accounts is taxed depends on the income bracket of the account holder does not significantly weaken the argument.
answers: The limit is a hard 3,000, so it wouldn't matter how much the holder earns as long as they can save that amount.
If they withdrew money from the accounts, they would be taxed, which directly contradicts the author's claim that many Lavaskans are utilizing the account as intended.
Criticism wouldn't affect the results from which the author bases their argument.
If the Lavaskans already had the cash on hand, it would be incredibly easy for them to take advantage of the tax free accounts.
label: A

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
main_answers: The rate at which interest earned on money deposited in regular savings accounts is taxed depends on the income bracket of the account holder.
Many Levaskans who already had long-term savings have steadily been transferring those savings into the special accounts.
Many of the economists who now claim that the government's plan has been successful criticized it when it was introduced.
A substantial number of Levaskans have withdrawn at least some of the money they had invested in the special accounts.
others.target_option: The rate at which interest earned on money deposited in regular savings accounts is taxed depends on the income bracket of the account holder.

context: Numerous books describe the rules of etiquette. Usually the authors of such books merely codify standards of behavior by classifying various behaviors as polite or rude. However, this suggests that there is a single, objective standard of politeness. Clearly, standards of politeness vary from culture to culture, so it is absurd to label any one set of behaviors as correct and others as incorrect.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument considered vulnerable to criticism for overlooking the possibility that authors of etiquette books are purporting to state what is correct behavior for one particular culture only?
answers: This passage does generalize these books but it does not say how many book or by how many authors.
The passage does not mention the influence of these rules, just that they need to be adjusted for different cultures.
The passage is saying that what is right for one situation might not be right in another depending on culture. Nothing about how they ought to behave.
It is not mentioned in the passage of what books are specifically being talked about so there is no way to know if the books are about any one culture.
label: D

others.main_question: The reasoning in the argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the argument
main_answers: overlooks the possibility that authors of etiquette books are purporting to state what is correct behavior for one particular culture only
reaches a conclusion about how people actually behave on the basis of assertions regarding how they ought to behave
fails to justify its presumption regarding the influence of rules of etiquette on individual behavior
bases a generalization about all books of etiquette on the actions of a few authors
others.target_option: overlooks the possibility that authors of etiquette books are purporting to state what is correct behavior for one particular culture only

context: In constructing a self-driving robotic car, engineers face the challenge of designing a car that avoids common traffic problems like crashes and congestion. These problems can also affect fish traveling together in schools. However, the principles fish use to navigate in schools ensure that these problems are much less common within schools of fish than among cars on the road. Hence, __.
question: Why does the fact that the best drivers use the same navigational principles that fish use in schools not logically complete the argument?
answers: Since the problems faced are similar, and fish surmount them more  successfully, it makes sense for the engineers to study the principles that allow the fish to be more successful than the drivers.
It is suggested that this expertise could be helpful, not that it is mandatory.
If this were the case, the fish would encounter the same rate of problems as the drivers did.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following most logically completes the argument?
main_answers: the best drivers use the same navigational principles that fish use in schools
a self-driving robotic car using the navigational principles that fish use in schools would be better than a human-driven car at avoiding crashes and congestion
studying the principles fish use to navigate in schools could help engineers to design a self-driving robotic car that avoids common traffic problems
constructing a self-driving robotic car requires expertise in fish biology
others.target_option: the best drivers use the same navigational principles that fish use in schools

context: Data froma recent biodiversity study of the Ukuluku river estuary in Tritonia showed that last year the pollution rate of this environmentally sensitive region was significantly lower than in previous years. The Tritonian government, which spent millions of dollars last year to enforce laws against dumping waste into the river, is claiming that the study data indicate that its increased efforts to halt the pollution are proving effective.
question: Explain why the fact that government agents had to issue fines totaling over $27 million to 650 violators of the river dumping regulations does not seriously undermine the government's claim.
answers: The author mentions that the government has spent millions specifically on enforcing anti pollution laws.
This provides an alternate reason for the pollution levels going down that has nothing to do with the government's efforts.
Fines would decrease the amount of pollution in the river, so this statement supports their claim.
The heightened response from factory owners is indicative that the laws were effective.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously undermines the government's claim?
main_answers: Government agents had to issue fines totaling over $27 million to 650 violators of the river dumping regulations.
Much of the money that was designated last year for estuary preservation has been spent on research and not enforcement.
Factory owner opposition to the government's anti-pollution efforts grew more violent last year in response to the increased enforcement.
The largest known polluter on the Ukuluku river relocated to another part of Tritonia, closer to the airport, so as to decrease its shipping costs.
others.target_option: Government agents had to issue fines totaling over $27 million to 650 violators of the river dumping regulations.

context: Acme' s bank loan must be immediately repaid in full if Acme' s earnings fall below $1 million per year. If Acme has to repay the entire loan immediately, it will have to declare bankruptcy. Acme had seemed safe from bankruptcy, having reported annual earnings of well over $1 million in each year it has had the bank loan. However, Acme has now admitted overstating its earnings for last year, so it will have to declare bankruptcy.
question: What evidence is needed to support the assumption that Acme would be able to avoid bankruptcy if it did not have to repay the bank loan in order for the argument to be valid?
answers: Other debts are not relevant if Acme's cannot even repay it's bank loan.
It's possible for Acme to have more debt than assets to repay without having repaid the bank loan.
If Acme's earnings for last year were above $1 million even without the overstatement, they would still not have to repay the bank loan in full.
Even if Acme overstated it's earnings for more than last year, it would still have to declare bankruptcy as earnings are counted per year.
label: B

others.main_question: The argument requires the assumption that
main_answers: Acme would be able to avoid bankruptcy if it did not have to repay the bank loan
Acme has other debts besides the bank loan
last year is not the only year for which Acme overstated earnings
Acme's earnings for last year, when accurately stated, are below $1 million
others.target_option: Acme would be able to avoid bankruptcy if it did not have to repay the bank loan

context: At Tromen University this semester, some students taking French Literature 205 are also taking Biology 218. Every student taking Biology 218 at Tromen is a biology major. Ttherefore, some of the students taking French Literature 205 are not French-literature majors.
question: Why does the conclusion drawn above follow logically if it is assumed that it is not possible to major in both biology and French literature at Tromen University?
answers: This may or may not be true, but the amount of majors has no bearing on the argument.
We know that "Every student taking Biology 218 at Tromen is a biology major," but we don't know if this is due to a regulation or coincidence.
If it was possible to major in both biology and French literature, the author could not draw any conclusions about the majors of the students in French Literature 205.
It may or may not be true that French Literature 205 is a required course for French-literature majors, but that wouldn't change the fact that non-majors are also attending the class.
label: C

others.main_question: The conclusion drawn above follows logically if which one of the following is assumed to be true at Tromen University?
main_answers: It is not possible to major in both biology and French literature.
There are more biology majors than there are French-literature majors.
French Literature 205 is a required course for French-literature majors.
Only biology majors are allowed to take Biology 218.
others.target_option: It is not possible to major in both biology and French literature.

context: Film Director: It is true that certain characters and plot twists in my newly released film The Big Heist are similar to characters and plot twists in Thieves, a movie that came out last year. Pointing to these similarities, the film studio that produced Thieves is now accusing me of taking ideas from that film. The accusation is clearly without merit. All production work on The Big Heist was actually completed months before Thieves was released.
question: What evidence does not support the directors position that production work on Thieves began before production work on The B/g Heist was started?
answers: If the script for Thieves had been circulating for several years prior to production, this would have given more time for the ideas to be seen and stolen.
If the director of Thieves worked on other projects with the director of The Big Heist, it would be more likely not less that ideas were taken and used in the movie.
If production work on Thieves began before production work on the Big Heist, it would still be possible for the director to have stolen ideas from the film regardless of which was released first.

If the allegedly stolen characters and plot twists are similar to many films belonging to the same genre, it could be generic plot lines, rather than theft of ideas as not all the films could have stolen ideas and/or it could be argued then that the director of Thieves stole from these earlier films as well.
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, provides the strongest support for the directors position?
main_answers: Production work on Thieves began before production work on The B/g Heist was started
The director of Thieves worked with the director of The Big Heist on several earlier projects
Before Thieves began production, its script had been circulating for several years among various film studios, including the studio that produced The Big Heist.
The characters and plot twists that are most similar in the two films have close parallels in many earlier films of the same genre.
others.target_option: Production work on Thieves began before production work on The B/g Heist was started
