context: Researchers studying athletes found that those who played mainly for the love of their sport actually had sharper vision during athletic competitions than those whose main goal was winning a trophy or championship. The vision of the first group of athletes was sharper because the concentration necessary for acute vision during an activity is typically possessed to a greater degree by those whose attention is focused on the activity itself.
question: Explain why the statements above do not strongly support the claim that winning a trophy or championship is not important to athletes who play mainly for the love of their sport.
answers: The passage makes no claim concerning whether or not athletes are incapable of concentrating on multiple things, but rather deals with what they're likely concentrating on the most.
The passage makes no claim about desire to win negatively impacting concentration, but rather that love of sport aids it.
The passage makes no claim concerning winning not being important to people who love playing their sport.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the statements above?
main_answers: Winning a trophy or championship is not important to athletes who play mainly for the love of their sport.
Athletes who play mainly for the love of their sport concentrate more on the sport itself during athletic competitions than do athletes whose main goal is winning a trophy or championship.
If an athlete's main goal during an athletic competition is winning a trophy or championship, that athlete will lack the concentration necessary for adequate vision during that competition .
It is impossible for an athlete to concentrate on more than one thing at a time during an athletic competition.
others.target_option: Winning a trophy or championship is not important to athletes who play mainly for the love of their sport.

context: Productivity is average output per worker per unit of time. High productivity cannot be achieved without adequate training of workers. So high productivity does not depend on having high-tech equipment.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument considered vulnerable to criticism for ignoring the possibility that having high-tech equipment is required for adequate training of workers?
answers: Correct.  The passage does not define what is adequate training so high tech equipment might be needed or required.
The passage is not about the desirability of productivity but rather what is required to train workers to be productive.
The passage does not focus on education as a necessary input to productivity, but rather high tech equipment.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The reasoning in the argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the argument
main_answers: ignores the possibility that having high-tech equipment is required for adequate training of workers
overlooks the fact that increases in productivity may not be desirable in some circumstances
confuses a stated requirement for having high- tech equipment with a sufficient condition for having high-tech equipment
presumes without giving justification that educating workers always results in an increase in their productivity
others.target_option: ignores the possibility that having high-tech equipment is required for adequate training of workers

context: When glass products are made from recycled glass, the resulting products can be equal in quality to glass products made from quartz sand, the usual raw material. When plastics are recycled, however, the result is inevitably a plastic of a lower grade than the plastic from which it is derived. Moreover, no applications have been found for grades of plastic that are lower than the currently lowest commercial grade.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that glass products made from recycled glass are less expensive than comparable products made from quartz sand based on the statements above?
answers: Recycled glass products are of equal quality to first-run glass products
The quality can be compared, but we don't have any information on cost
If recycled plastic ends up a lower grade that the original plastic, then recycling the lowest commercial grade would yield a plastic with with no commercial grade and therefore no application
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following is a conclusion that can be properly drawn from the statements above?
main_answers: Glass products made from recycled glass are less expensive than comparable products made from quartz sand.
Products cannot presently be made out of plastic recycled entirely from the currently lowest commercial grade.
It is impossible to make glass products from recycled glass that are equal in quality to the best glass products made from the usual raw material.
The difference in quality between different grades of glass is not as great as that between different grades of plastic.
others.target_option: Glass products made from recycled glass are less expensive than comparable products made from quartz sand.

context: Although the pesticide TDX has been widely used by fruit growers since the early 1960' s, a regulation in force since 1960 has prohibited sale of fruit on which any TDX residue can be detected. That regulation is about to be replaced by one that allows sale of fruit on which trace amounts of TDX residue are detected. In fact, however, the change will not allow more TDX on fruit than was allowed in the 1960' s, because __.
question: What is the reasoning behind the conclusion that pre-1970 techniques for detecting TDX residue could detect it only when it was present on fruit in more than the trace amounts allowed by the new regulations logically completes the argument?
answers: This only affects what happens post-purchase, after the decision on whether the fruit is acceptable for sale has already been made.
The passage makes no claims concerning what amount of TDX residue is considered harmful.
The threshold at which the post-1970 techniques can detect the TDX residue is lower than the threshold at which the substance was allowed to be on fruit pre 1970.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following most logically completes the argument?
main_answers: pre-1970 techniques for detecting TDX residue could detect it only when it was present on fruit in more than the trace amounts allowed by the new regulations
at least a small fraction of the fruit sold each year since the early 1960's has had on it greater levels of TDX than the regulation allows
many more people today than in the 1960's habitually purchase and eat fruit without making an effort to clean residues off the fruit
the presence of TDX on fruit in greater than trace amounts has not been shown to cause any harm even to children who eat large amounts of fruit
others.target_option: pre-1970 techniques for detecting TDX residue could detect it only when it was present on fruit in more than the trace amounts allowed by the new regulations

context: Columnist: Video games are not works of art. No matter how rich the aesthetic experience produced by a video game might be, it is interactive: players make choices that affect the outcome of the game. For something to be a work of art, it must produce an aesthetic experience that is controlled by the artist or artists who created the work.
question: Why does the conclusion of the columnist's argument not follow properly even if it is assumed that most video game creators do not intend their video games to be works of art?
answers: They may not be the creators, but they can still influence the outcome of video games.
If the players have the ability to affect the expression of the game, it is not art.
A medium can be perceived differently than what its creators intended.
Being an interactive medium takes the control away from the creator of it, so it can't be art.
label: C

others.main_question: The conclusion of the columnist's argument can be properly drawn if which one of the following is assumed?
main_answers: Players' choices that have no effect on the outcome of a video game are irrelevant to the aesthetic experience produced by that game.
An aesthetic experience cannot be both interactive and controlled by the artist or artists who created the work.
Most video game creators do not intend their video games to be works of art.
Typically, video game players do not themselves create video games.
others.target_option: Most video game creators do not intend their video games to be works of art.

context: If the price it pays for coffee beans continues to increase, the Coffee Shoppe will have to increase its prices. In that case, either the Coffee Shoppe will begin selling noncoffee products or its coffee sales will decrease. But selling noncoffee products will decrease the Coffee Shoppe' s overall profitability. Moreover, the Coffee Shoppe can avoid a decrease in overall profitability only if its coffee sales do not decrease.
question: Explain why it is not valid to conclude that, if the Coffee Shoppe's overall profitability decreases, the price it pays for coffee beans will have continued to increase based on the statements above?
answers: As stated by the argument, having higher costs will cause the Coffee Shop to be less profitable.
The Coffee Shoppe's sales are independent of the factors discussed by the argument.
There are other factors that could cause the Coffee Shoppe's profitability to decrease.
If the price the Coffee Shoppe pays for coffee beans decreases, their profitability would likely increase because their costs would be lower.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following statements follows logically from the statements above?
main_answers: If the Coffee Shoppe's overall profitability decreases, the price it pays for coffee beans will have continued to increase.
The price it pays for coffee beans cannot decrease without the Coffee Shoppe's overall profitability also decreasing.
The Coffee Shoppe's overall profitability will decrease if the price it pays for coffee beans continues to increase.
Either the price it pays for coffee beans will continue to increase or the Coffee Shoppe's coffee sales will increase.
others.target_option: If the Coffee Shoppe's overall profitability decreases, the price it pays for coffee beans will have continued to increase.

context: The term "sex" and "gender" are often used interchangeably. But "sex" more properly refers to biological differences of male and female, while "gender" refers to society' s construction of a system that identifies what is masculine and feminine. Unlike the set of characteristics defining biological sex, the set of traits that are associated with gender does not sort people into two nonoverlapping groups. The traits characterize people in a complex way, so that a person may have both "masculine" and "feminine" traits.
question: What is the basis for concluding that the statement that the terms "sex" and "gender" are not properly interchangeable expresses a main point of the argument?
answers: Although this passage does kind of say this by saying that people can have both masculine and feminine traits it is not the main point.
The passage touches on this claim but it is not the main point of the passage.
The passage explains how these two things are different and it sums up the passage nicely.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following statements best expresses a main point of the argument?
main_answers: Distinctions based on gender are frequently arbitrary.
Society rather than the individual decides what is considered proper behavior.
The terms "sex" and "gender" are not properly interchangeable.
Gender traits are not determined at birth.
others.target_option: The terms "sex" and "gender" are not properly interchangeable.

context: In a recent study, each member of two groups of people, Group A (composed of persons sixty-five to seventy-five years old) and Group B (composed of college students), was required to make a telephone call to a certain number at a specified time. The time when each call was initiated was recorded electronically. Group A proved far better at remembering to make a telephone call precisely at a specified time than did Group B. There were fourteen lapses in Group B but only one lapse in Group A. Clearly, at least one type of memory does not suffer as a person ages.
question: Explain why the fact that the same group of researchers answered the calls made by the callers in both study groups is not helpful in establishing that the conclusion is properly drawn.
answers: If one group received instructions much longer before they were expected to make the calls, they may be more likely to forget to do so.
Who answered the calls does little to explain any difference in results between Group A and B.
The number of people in each group being even would be a necessary condition for being able to make accurate inferences about the results.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if all of them are true, is LEAST helpful in establishing that the conclusion above is properly drawn?
main_answers: The members of the two groups received their instructions approximately the same amount of time before they were to make their telephone calls.
The same group of researchers answered the calls made by the callers in both study groups.
Both groups had unrestricted access to telephones for making the required calls.
There was the same number of people in each group.
others.target_option: The same group of researchers answered the calls made by the callers in both study groups.

context: Biologist: Marine animals known as box jellyfish have eyes with well-formed lenses capable of producing sharp images that reveal fine detail. But the box jellyfish' s retinas are too far forward to receive a clear image, so these jellyfish can receive only a blurry image that reveals prominent features of objects but not fine detail. This example shows that eyes are adapted only to an animal' s needs rather than to some abstract sense of how a good eye would be designed.
question: Why is it not necessary to assume that box jellyfish developed from jellyfish whose retinas received clear images in order for the argument to be valid?
answers: This assumes that the box jellyfish has a need for only features and not fine details from its sight, which supports the argument that eyes are adapted to an animal's needs.
Whether they would benefit from eyes that focus more sharply is unimportant  because the argument is only about needs not benefits.
What the box jellyfish developed from is not a necessary assumption for the argument.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: The argument requires assuming which one of the following?
main_answers: Box jellyfish developed from jellyfish whose retinas received clear images.
Box jellyfish have a need to detect prominent features of objects but not fine details.
Box jellyfish would benefit from having retinas that allowed their eyes to focus more sharply.
Box jellyfish use vision as their main means of detecting prey.
others.target_option: Box jellyfish developed from jellyfish whose retinas received clear images.

context: Therapist: The ability to trust other people is essential to happiness, for without trust there can be no meaningful emotional connection to another human being, and without meaningful emotional connections to others we feel isolated.
question: Why does the conclusion of the therapist's argument not follow logically even if it is assumed that to avoid feeling isolated, it is essential to trust other people?
answers: The passage says one cannot have a meaningful emotional connection without trust, but doesn’t imply that one will definitely have such a connection if one has trust.
The article is more concerned with what is necessary for happiness rather than what is possible.
The necessity of trust is explicitly stated in the text and is not an assumption.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if assumed, allows the conclusion of the therapist's argument to be properly inferred?
main_answers: Anyone who is able to trust other people has a meaningful emotional connection to at least one other human being.
To avoid feeling isolated, it is essential to trust other people.
No one who is feeling isolated can feel happy.
Anyone who has a meaningful emotional connection to another human being can be happy.
others.target_option: To avoid feeling isolated, it is essential to trust other people.

context: Astronauts who experience weightlessness frequently get motion sickness. The astronauts see their own motion relative to passing objects, but while the astronauts are weightless their inner ears indicate that their bodies are not moving. The astronauts' experience is best explained by the hypothesis that conflicting information received by the brain about the body' s motion causes motion sickness.
question: How does the fact that during rough voyages ship passengers in cabins providing a view of the water are less likely to get motion sickness than are passengers in cabins providing no view provide the strongest additional support for the hypotheses above?
answers: This is counter evidence to the hypothesis put forward in the passage.
This would support that being able to visualize your movement helps with motion sickness.
The passage does not indicate that there is only one cause of motion sickness
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, provides the strongest additional support for the hypotheses above?
main_answers: During rough voyages ship passengers in cabins providing a view of the water are less likely to get motion sickness than are passengers in cabins providing no view.
Some automobile passengers whose inner ears indicate that they are moving and who have a clear view of the objects they are passing get motion sickness.
Many people who are experienced airplane passengers occasionally get motion sickness.
People who have aisle seats in trains or airplanes are as likely to get motion sickness as are people who have window seats.
others.target_option: During rough voyages ship passengers in cabins providing a view of the water are less likely to get motion sickness than are passengers in cabins providing no view.

context: Sportfishers introduced the Zander, a type of perch, to Britain' s rivers and canals in the 1970s. Because zander eat large numbers of smaller fish, they have had a devastating effect on native fish populations. To protect the native fish, a government program removed a significant proportion of the zander from Britain' s waterways last year. Surprisingly, this year the loss of native fish to zander has been greater than before.
question: How does the fact that most of the zander removed were fully grown, and fully grown zander eat large numbers of smaller zander help to explain the greater effect of zander on the native fish population?
answers: Even if every year a large number of zander are caught this does not explain why more native fish were lost this year.
When the fully grown Zander that eat smaller Zander were removed this allowed more of the smaller Zander to survive and prey on native fish.
The climate in Britain being similar to the climate in regions to which zander are native does not explain why more native fish were lost after the Zander removal.

context: Garnet and RenCo each provide health care for their employees. Garnet pays for both testing of its employees' cholesterol levels and treatment of high cholesterol. context: There is evidence to suggest that our cave-dwelling ancestors polished many of their flints to a degree far surpassing what was necessary for hunting purposes. It seems, ttherefore, that early humans possessed an aesthetic sense.

context: On the nights immediately following the mysterious Tunguska event, which destroyed a tract of Siberian wilderness in 1908, eyewitnesses reported seeing noctilucent clouds -- brilliant night-visible clouds made up of ice particles that form rarely and only at very high altitudes. Recently, noctilucent clouds have been observed on the nights following launches of rockets that release large amounts of water vapor into the upper atmosphere. This shows that it was a comet impact and not the impact of an asteroid that caused the destruction in Siberia.
question: Why does the argument not depend on assuming that comets collide with Earth more frequently than asteroids do?
answers: The argument does not rely on the frequency with which comets or asteroids collide with the Earth.
It doesn't matter how long the noctilucent clouds were visible, only that they were reported as having been seen.
The timing of the discovery that noctilucent clouds were made of ice particles is not relevant to the argument.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The argument depends on assuming which one of the following?
main_answers: Comets but not asteroids release large amounts of water vapor into the upper atmosphere when they collide with Earth.
The fact that noctilucent clouds are made of ice particles in the upper atmosphere was only recently discovered.
Comets collide with Earth more frequently than asteroids do.
Noctilucent clouds are visible for many consecutive nights following the release of water vapor into the upper atmosphere.
others.target_option: Comets collide with Earth more frequently than asteroids do.

context: A development company has proposed building an airport near the city of Dalton. If the majority of Dalton' s residents favor the proposal, the airport will be built. Thus, it is unlikely that the airport will be built.

context: There is no mystery as to why figurative painting revived in the late 1970s. People want to look at recognizable images. Sorting out art theories reflected in abstract paintings is no substitute for the sense of empathy that comes from looking at a realistic painting of a figure in a landscape. Perhaps members of the art-viewing public resented abstract art because they felt that its lack of realistic subject matter was a rejection of the viewers and their world.
question: Explain why the claim that abstract paintings often include shapes or forms that are suggestive of real objects or emotions does not accurately express the main point of the passage?
answers: There is no mention of the specific treatment of the subject matter, only that they began to prefer representational subjects.
The public grew tired of abstract art and became drawn towards representations of their world again.
There is no mention in the passage of the specific forms in abstract painting.
The passage argues that the general public did not feel empathy and relate to the abstract paintings, not that they didn’t understand them.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the main point of the passage?
main_answers: Abstract paintings often include shapes or forms that are suggestive of real objects or emotions.
The general public is unable to understand the theories on which abstract painting is based.
The artistic preferences of the art-viewing public stimulated the revival.
The art-viewing public wished to see traditional subjects treated in a nontraditional manner.
others.target_option: Abstract paintings often include shapes or forms that are suggestive of real objects or emotions.

context: Very powerful volcanic eruptions send large amounts of ash high into the atmosphere, blocking sunlight and causing abnormally cold temperatures for a year or more after the eruption. In 44 B. C. there was a powerful eruption of Mount Etna in Sicily. In the following year, Chinese historians recorded summer frosts and dimmed sunlight in China, thousands of miles east of Sicily. If these phenomena were caused by volcanic ash in the atmosphere, then the ash sent into the atmosphere by Mount Etna' s eruption must have spread over great distances.
question: Why is it important to determine whether there were any volcanic eruptions near China around the time of Mount Etna's eruption when evaluating the support given for the conclusion advanced in the last sentence of the passage?
answers: These subsequent eruptions would have no bearing on the Chinese weather the following year unless they occurred immediately following (or within a short time after) the initial eruption.
If there were eruptions closer to China it's likely they could have been the cause of the changes in China.
The length of time would have no bearing on whether Etna was the cause or not, but rather the time period it occurred.
Modern equipment would only be effective at tracking current ash clouds, not ones from 2000 years ago.
label: B

others.main_question: In evaluating the support given for the conclusion advanced in the last sentence of the passage, it would be most important to determine whether
main_answers: there were any volcanic eruptions near China around the time of Mount Etna's eruption
modern monitoring equipment can detect the precise path of volcanic ash in the atmosphere
the abnormal weather in China lasted for a full year or longer
subsequent eruptions of Mount Etna were as powerful as the one in 44 B. C.
others.target_option: there were any volcanic eruptions near China around the time of Mount Etna's eruption

context: John' s literature professor believes that the ability to judge the greatness of literary works accurately can be acquired only after years of specialized training. Such training is, in fact, what is required to become a literature professor. She is also well aware that the vast majority of the reading public does not have access to this specialized training.
question: Explain why it is not necessary to accept that literature professors do not belong to the reading public in order for what John's literature professor believes to be true?
answers: Literature professors are among the reading public, they simply have greater skills than their counterparts.
One can receive training similar to a literature professor yet not be one.
Lack of specialized training would be a likely reason that the majority of readers can't judge literary works accurately.

context: Researchers working in Western Australia have discovered the oldest fragments of the Earth' s early crust that have yet been identified: microdiamonds. These microscopic crystals measure only 50 microns across and were formed 4. 2 billion years ago. This discovery sheds light on how long it took for the Earth' s crust to form, since this date is only 300 million years after the formation of the Earth itself.
question: Why is it not necessary to accept that all naturally occurring microdiamonds were formed at the time the Earth's crust was being formed in order for the statement to be true?
answers: Just because microdiamonds are the oldest fragments of the Earth' s early crust that have yet to be identified, does not mean that all natural microdiamonds were formed at that period.
The fact that these fragments were found in Western Australia does not prove that this is where the Earth's crust first formed.
The statements show that some of the Earth's crust was formed within 300 million years and it taking billions of years to form would not be likely or supported by the statements.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: If the statements above are true, which one of the following must also be true?
main_answers: The Earth's crust first formed in the area that is now Western Australia.
The Earth's crust took no longer than 300 million years to start to form.
All naturally occurring microdiamonds were formed at the time the Earth's crust was being formed.
The Earth's crust took billions of years to form.
others.target_option: All naturally occurring microdiamonds were formed at the time the Earth's crust was being formed.

" in a crowded theatre, and the harm done as investors and lenders rush madly to get their money out before everyone else does can be just as real as the harm resulting from a stampede in a theatre.
question: What is the reasoning behind the argument attempting to show that a set of principles is limited in a specific way by using an analogy to a similar principle that is limited in a similar way?
answers: There is no attempt to reach a conclusion from a generalization in the passage.
The passage uses the analogy between a theatre fire and a bank panic, both of which are similarly limited in how they can be dealt with.
There is no attempt by the passage to draw a conclusion about a phenomenon based upon an individual instance of it.
There are no references to experimental results in the passage.

context: People widely believed that the controlled use of fire originated 200, 000 years ago with the human species Homo sapiens. However, a site containing a deposit, estimated to be nearly 500, 000 years old, consisting of charcoal, burned animal bones, and charred rocks, has recently been found. Although homo sapiens did not exist at that time, this discovery provides no basis to the claim that the controlled use of fire preceded the Homo sapiens, since __.
question: Why does the fact that it is possible that fire was used much earlier than 500,000 years ago not logically complete the passage?
answers: Due to the sample found being nearly 500,000 years old, it could be possible for it to be from a lightening strike or other natural occurrence of fire rather than from controlled use of fire.
The use of fire originating independently in several parts of the world would make it more difficult to dispute its controlled use predating Homo sapiens.
If it is possible that fire was used much earlier than 500,000 years ago, it would strengthen the claim of controlled use of fire preceding the Homo sapiens.
Fire created and used for protection or heat are still controlled uses of fire.
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following most logically completes the passage?
main_answers: It is possible that fire was used much earlier than 500, 000 years ago
The use of fire might have originated independently in several different parts of the world
It is impossible to determine whether a charred deposit dating from so long ago resulted from a fire caused by lightening or from the purposeful use of fire
Animal bones could have been discarded in a fire used for purposes such as protection or heat rather than for cooking
others.target_option: It is possible that fire was used much earlier than 500, 000 years ago

context: In some places, iceberg lilies are the mainstay of grizzly bears' summer diets. The bears forage meadows for the lilies, uprooting them and eating their bulbs. Although the bears annually destroy a large percentage of the lilies, scientists have determined that the bears' feeding habits actually promote the survival of iceberg lilies.
question: Explain why the fact that the geographic regions in which iceberg lilies are most prevalent are those regions populated by grizzly bears does not help to resolve the apparent discrepancy in the statements above.
answers: While this would certainly be of interest to the bears, this would have no effect on the subsequent results of the bears actions which are the focus of the passage.
This would reduce the overall survival rate of lilies, not increase them.
The bears routinely culling iceberg lilly populations would result in them not depleting the resources at a rate to harm their overall survival rate.
None of the above choices
label: D

context: If the magazine' s circulation continues to rise as it has over the last ten years, in another ten years it will be the largest-selling martial arts magazine in the world. Unfortunately, it has now become clear that the magazine' s publisher will not allow the managing editor to make the changes she has proposed, and without these changes, the magazine' s circulation will not rise as quickly over the next ten years as it has over the last ten. So the magazine will not be the largest-selling martial arts magazine ten years from now.
question: Why is the argument's reasoning not considered to be invalid due to its mistake of equating a reduction in the rate at which the magazine's circulation is increasing with a decline in the magazine's circulation?
answers: Only one change is taken into consideration, which is the editor's suggestions. It is not said that no other changes are needed, but rather assumes this is the only change that will ensure the magazine reaches largest-selling martial arts magazine ten years from now.
A reduction in the rate at which the magazine is circulating would indicate a decline in the overall circulation and would support the argument.

The occurrence of the editor's suggestions being used or ignored does not necessarily mean it will not still become the largest-selling martial arts magazine ten years from now as other factors could lead to this result as well.
It is not a re-statement of previous claims. It is the conclusion reached due to the logic following those claims.
label: B

others.main_question: The argument's reasoning is flawed because the argument
main_answers: equates a reduction in the rate at which the magazine's circulation is increasing with a decline in the magazine's circulation
treats an occurrence that will ensure a certain outcome as something that is required for that outcome
identifies some changes required for the magazine's circulation to continue its rapid increase and concludes from this that no other changes are needed
draws a conclusion that simply restates a claim that is presented in support of that conclusion
others.target_option: equates a reduction in the rate at which the magazine's circulation is increasing with a decline in the magazine's circulation

context: Conservative Politician: Social welfare programs are destroying our country. These programs are not only adding to the annual deficit, which increases the national debt, but they also discourage hard work. Our country must continue producing leaders who bootstrap their way to the top. None of our country' s citizens truly need assistance from the government; rather, the assistance just makes things easier. Liberal Politician: Our great country is founded on the principle of hope. The country is built on the backs of immigrants who came here with nothing, except for the hope of a better life. Our country is too wealthy not to provide basic necessities for the less fortunate. Recent immigrants, single mothers, historically disenfranchised, disabled persons, and the elderly all require an ample safety net.
question: Why does the main point of dispute between the politicians not involve the claim that all of the country's leaders have bootstrapped their way to the top?
answers: Social welfare programs cost money, so this is not a disputed point
This is an agreed point, and the dispute is if this reliance has good or bad long-term effects.
Each argues that people are either harmed or helped by social welfare programs.
One argues that some leaders have bootstrapped themselves to the top, but not all, and the point isn't disputed by the other
label: D

others.main_question: What is the main point of dispute between the politicians?
main_answers: All of the country 's leaders have bootstrapped their way to the top.
Certain classes of people rely on social welfare programs to meet their basic needs.
Certain classes of people would be irreparably harmed if the country failed to provide a social welfare program.
Spending on social welfare programs increases the national debt.
others.target_option: All of the country 's leaders have bootstrapped their way to the top.

context: Carl is clearly an incompetent detective. He has solved a smaller percentage of the cases assigned to him in the last 3 years -- only 1 out of 25 -- than any other detective on the police force.
question: Why does the fact that before he became a detective, Carl was a neighborhood police officer and was highly respected by the residents of the neighborhood he patrolled not weaken the argument?
answers: If Carl is receiving the hardest cases with the lower likelihood of being solved, it would explain why those other detectives have a greater completion ratio than him.
If Carl was also struggling as a detective in another jurisdiction, it would help strengthen the argument that he was not very good at his job.
The promotions of Carl’s fellow officers have no bearing on his skills as a detective.
Carl’s success as a patrol officer would not necessarily translate to success as a detective.

context: The use of growth-promoting antibiotics in hog farming can weaken their effectiveness in treating humans because such use can spread resistance to those antibiotics among microorganisms. But now the Smee Company, one of the largest pork marketers, may stop buying pork raised on feed containing these antibiotics. Smee has 60 percent of the pork market, and farmers who sell to Smee would certainly stop using antibiotics in order to avoid jeopardizing their sales. So if Smee makes this change, it will probably significantly slow the decline in antibiotics' effectiveness for humans.
question: Explain why the fact that a phaseout of use of antibiotics for hogs in one country reduced usage by over 50 percent over five years does not strengthen the argument.
answers: Because Smee is such a large pork producer, it forces the pork marketers to buy pork that is not treated with antibiotics.
The dosage never mentions whether the authorities are promoting this behavior.
This passage never compares this system to another country, making this argument irrelevant.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, would most strengthen the argument above?
main_answers: A phaseout of use of antibiotics for hogs in one country reduced usage by over 50 percent over five years.
Other major pork marketers will probably stop buying pork raised on feed containing growth-promoting antibiotics if Smee no longer buys such pork.
Authorities are promoting the use of antibiotics to which microorganisms have not yet developed resistance.
The decline in hog growth due to discontinuation of antibiotics can be offset by improved hygiene.
others.target_option: A phaseout of use of antibiotics for hogs in one country reduced usage by over 50 percent over five years.

context: When expert witnesses give testimony, jurors often do not understand the technical information and thereby are in no position to evaluate such testimony. Although expert witnesses on opposite sides often make conflicting claims, the expert witnesses on both sides frequently seem competent, leaving the jury unable to assess the reliability of their testimonies.
question: What is the basis for not considering the statements to strongly support the claim that jurors who understand the technical information presented in a case can usually assess its legal implications accurately?
answers: Most jurors cannot understand technical information
Any amount of technical information is difficult or impossible for a jury to process
The problem is two experts may disagree, leaving the jury confused
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The statements above, if true, most strongly support which one of the following?
main_answers: Jurors who understand the technical information presented in a case can usually assess its legal implications accurately.
There should be limits placed on how much technical information can be considered by both sides in preparing a legal case.
Jury decisions in cases involving expert witness testimonies are not always determined by the reliability of those testimonies.
Expert witnesses who testify on opposite sides in legal cases are likely to agree in their evaluations of technical claims.
others.target_option: Jurors who understand the technical information presented in a case can usually assess its legal implications accurately.

context: When trying to identify new technologies that promise to transform the marketplace, market researchers survey the managers of those companies that are developing new technologies. Such managers have an enormous stake in succeeding, so they invariably overstate the potential of their new technologies. Surprisingly, however, market researchers typically do not survey a new technology' s potential buyers, even though it is the buyers-not the producers-who will ultimately determine a technology' s commercial success.
question: What is the reason for why the potential buyers for not-yet-available technologies can seldom be reliably identified accounting for the typical survey practices among market researchers?
answers: If developers and consumers are equally knowledgeable, this doesn't explain why survey practices focus on developers
Consumers can't know if they want a product before it is developed, so identifying those who do want the product is challenging, if not impossible.
Developers' attitudes toward old technologies doesn't explain why research focuses on developers.
Managers are often over-optimistic about their new technologies
label: B

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, best accounts for the typical survey practices among market researchers?
main_answers: The developers of a new technology are generally no better positioned than its potential buyers to gauge how rapidly the new technology can be efficiently mass-produced.
The potential buyers for not-yet-available technologies can seldom be reliably identified.
People who promote the virtues of a new technology typically fail to consider that the old technology that is currently in use continues to be improved, often substantially.
Investors are unlikely to invest substantial amounts of capital in a company whose own managers are skeptical about the commercial prospects of a new technology they are developing.
others.target_option: The potential buyers for not-yet-available technologies can seldom be reliably identified.

context: Cultural anthropological theory tends to fall into two camps. One focuses on everyday social behavior as a system that has developed in response to human needs in a given environment. The other rejects this approach, focusing on the systems of meanings by which thoughts, rituals, and mythology in a society are structured. Cultural anthropologists, however, should employ both approaches, and also attend to a third, often neglected dimension: the view of a community as a set of individuals whose actions constitute the actual stuff of everyday life.
question: What evidence from the information above supports the claim that disagreement among cultural anthropological theorists does not necessarily imply that their approaches are incompatible?
answers: While focusing on the meaning of the rituals and thoughts, anthropologists are considering attributes that make us human.
Focusing on the environment is just one of the anthropological approaches championed by the article.
The article does state that the notion of community is often neglected, but it does not say it is excluded.
The article advocates for making use of all the approaches when studying civilizations.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following statements is most strongly supported by the information above?
main_answers: Disagreement among cultural anthropological theorists does not necessarily imply that their approaches are incompatible.
Cultural anthropological theorists who focus on issues of meaning overlook the humanity of their individual subjects.
Cultural anthropologists too often rely on a conception of human needs that excludes the notion of community.
Systems of behavior can be understood only by experiencing the environments to which they respond.
others.target_option: Disagreement among cultural anthropological theorists does not necessarily imply that their approaches are incompatible.

context: The human brain and its associated mental capacities evolved to assist self-preservation. Thus, the capacity of make aesthetic judgments is an adaptation to past environments in which humans lived. So an individual' s aesthetic judgments must be evaluated in terms of the extent to which they promote the survival of that individual.
question: Why does the principle that all human adaptations to past environments were based on the human brain and its associated mental capacities not provide the strongest justification for the reasoning above?
answers: If a capability is to judged primarily on how well it serves its intended purpose, then the reasoning of the passage is sound.
The reasoning suggests that aesthetic judgments should be judged on their ability to promote survival, so being unable to evaluate preference judgments would not promote this line thinking.
The argument is about how capacities are judged, not whether they should or shouldn't be.
How many past human adaptations were based around the brain does not serve to strengthen the reasoning presented.

context: Tissue biopsies taken on patients who have undergone throat surgery show that those who snored frequently were significantly more likely to have serious abnormalities in their throat muscles than those who snored rarely or not at all. The passage did not compare the rate of snoring between people that have had throat surgery and those that haven't.

context: There is little point in looking to artists for insights into political issues. Most of them hold political views that are less insightful than those of any reasonably well-educated person who is not an artist. Indeed, when taken as a whole, the statements made by artists, including those considered to be great, indicate that artistic talent and political insight are rarely found together.
question: Why is it not valid to infer from the passage that every reasonably well-educated person who is not an artist has more insight into political issues than any artist?
answers: This conclusion cannot be rightly drawn from the passage because while it claims that artists rarely have political insight it does not claim that the reverse is also true. Politicians could be more well-rounded than artists and display artistic talent as hobbyists. Hitler and Churchill come to mind.
The passage contrasts artists to reasonably well educated people, so this conclusion can not be derived from it.
That line in the passage claims "most" not "every". Big difference.
This conclusion is easily drawn from the use of the word "most" in the passage, which by definition leaves room for "some" exceptions to its rule.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following can be inferred from the passage?
main_answers: Every reasonably well-educated person who is not an artist has more insight into political issues than any artist.
Politicians rarely have any artistic talent.
Some artists are no less politically insightful than some reasonably well-educated persons who are not artists.
A thorough education in art makes a person reasonably well educated.
others.target_option: Every reasonably well-educated person who is not an artist has more insight into political issues than any artist.

context: Henry: Some scientists explain the dance of honeybees as the means by which honeybees communicate the location of whatever food source they have just visited to other members of the hive. But honeybees do not need so complicated a mechanism to communicate that information. Forager honeybees returning to their hive simply leave a scent trail from the food source they have just visited. There must ttherefore be some other explanation for the honeybees' dance. Winifred: Not necessarily. Most animals have several ways of accomplishing critical tasks. Bees of some species can navigate using either the position of the Sun or the memory of landmarks. Similarly, for honeybees, scent trails are a supplementary not an exclusive means of communicating.
question: What evidence is there to suggest that there is not more than one valid explanation for the dance of the honeybees?
answers: The two are in disagreement about the reason for a specific honeybee behavior, not whether broader theories can be established from a single species.
The ability of other bee species to convey navigational information to each other is not in question.
The point of contention is not whether there may be more than one reason that honeybees dance, but whether the dance communicates the location of food sources.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: The point at issue between Henry and Winifred is whether
main_answers: there is more than one valid explanation for the dance of the honeybees
the honeybee is the only species of bee that is capable of communicating navigational information to other hive members
honeybees communicate the location of food sources through their dance
theories of animal behavior can be established on the basis of evidence about only one species of animal
others.target_option: there is more than one valid explanation for the dance of the honeybees

context: James: Community colleges, by their very nature, work to meet the educational needs of the communities they are in. The same is not true of universities, whose primary goals differ from those of community colleges. Margaret: A primary goal of any university is to serve the needs of the community where it is located. The main reason people have for attending a university is the same as that for attending a community college: preparing oneself for a career.
question: What is the basis for concluding that James's and Margaret's statements provide support for the claim that they disagree over the truth of the statement that a primary goal of any university is to serve the educational needs of its community?
answers: The educational needs of a community are to provide education, some students are not necessarily seeking careers yet or ever.
Universities provide education and while many students seek this for employment reasons, the focus of the university is to provide the education.
Colleges provide education to students.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: James's and Margaret's statements provide the most support for the claim that they disagree over the truth of which one of the following?
main_answers: The main reason people have for attending a university is to prepare themselves for a career.
A primary goal of any university is to serve the educational needs of its community.
In a typical community, the primary educational need is to prepare community residents for careers.
Most universities adequately serve the educational needs of the communities in which they are located.
others.target_option: A primary goal of any university is to serve the educational needs of its community.

context: On a short trip a driver is more likely to have an accident if there is a passenger in the car, presumably because passengers distract drivers. However, on a long trip a driver is more likely to have an accident if the driver is alone.
question: What evidence is there that the fact that good drivers tend to take more long trips than bad drivers does not help to explain the facts described above?
answers: If more short trips were taken, that would skew the number of accidents to make it look like the conclusions given above are a result of data error.
The perceived skill of the driver has no relation to the ideas presented in the passage.
Given this is true, it is a sound explanation behind why longer car trips may be safer.
None of the above choices

context: Energy analyst: During this record-breaking heat wave, air conditioner use has overloaded the region' s electrical power grid, resulting in frequent power blackouts throughout the region. For this reason, residents have been asked to cut back voluntarily on air conditioner use in their homes. But even if this request is heeded, blackouts will probably occur unless the heat wave abates.
question: How does the fact that most air-conditioning in the region is used to cool businesses and factories help to resolve the apparent discrepancy in the information above?
answers: Knowing when the heat wave is expected to end does not provide a solution to the current blackout issue.
The passage addresses only air conditioning and not other sources of stress on the electrical system.
If residential cooling only represents a small fraction of total energy use, its reduction may not be enough to prevent blackouts.
Potential design modifications to existing systems would not resolve the apparent discrepancy.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to resolve the apparent discrepancy in the information above?
main_answers: Most air-conditioning in the region is used to cool businesses and factories.
Most air-conditioning systems could be made more energy efficient by implementing simple design modifications.
The heat wave is expected to abate in the near future.
Air-conditioning is not the only significant drain on the electrical system in the area.
others.target_option: Most air-conditioning in the region is used to cool businesses and factories.

context: Roland: The alarming fact is that 90 percent of the people in this country now report that they know someone who is unemployed. Sharon: But a normal, moderate level of unemployment is 5 percent, with 1 out of 20 workers unemployed. So at any given time if a person knows approximately 50 workers, one or more will very likely be unemployed.
question: Explain why Sharon's argument does not lead to the conclusion that the current level of unemployment is not moderate?
answers: There is no evidence in the article that states that it is moderate but that it is normal to have some unemployment.
If it is given as a certain percent then the number is known and wouldn't be greater but at a moderate level.
Many people in the country will of course know someone who is unemployed because 1 in 20 are unemployed at any given time.
There is no way of knowing who he is talking about because there are not facts or stats cited.
label: A

others.main_question: Sharon's argument is structured to lead to which of the following as a conclusion?
main_answers: The current level of unemployment is not moderate.
The fact that 90% of the people know someone who is unemployed is not an indication that unemployment is abnormally high.
It is unlikely that the people whose statements Roland cites are giving accurate reports.
If an unemployment figure is given as a certain percent, the actual percentage of those without jobs is even higher.
others.target_option: The current level of unemployment is not moderate.

context: One should always capitalize the main words and the first and last words of a title. But one should never capitalize articles, or prepositions and conjunctions with fewer than five letters, when they occur in the middle of a title.
question: Why is it not valid to infer that, if a word that is a preposition or conjunction should be capitalized, then it is the first or last word of the title based on the statements above?
answers: Correct, since the rule would be adhered to in this case.
A preposition or conjunction could occur in the first or last word, but they are not main words so they should not be capitalized
False, since the rule would state that these words would not be capitalized if they appeared in the middle.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following can be properly inferred from the statements above?
main_answers: If a word that is a preposition or conjunction should be capitalized, then it is the first or last word of the title.
Prepositions and conjunctions with five or more letters should be capitalized in any text.

context: Modern science is built on the process of posing hypotheses and testing them against observations -- in essence, attempting to show that the hypotheses are incorrect. Nothing brings more recognition than overthrowing conventional wisdom. It is accordingly unsurprising that some scientists are skeptical of the widely accepted predictions of global warming. What is instead remarkable is that with hundreds of researchers striving to make breakthroughs in climatology, very few find evidence that global warming is unlikely.
question: What is the basis for concluding that the information provided supports the statement that most researchers in climatology have substantial motive to find evidence that would discredit the global warming hypothesis?
answers: The author only speaks about where recognition comes from, not whether recognition is the primary motivating factor it is for scientists.
The passage does not refer to any  specific evidence for or against the hypothesis, only what researchers are doing.

Because the author argues recognition comes from overthrowing conventional wisdom, and because the global warming hypothesis is conventional wisdom, it would stand to reason that most scientists have substantial motive to disprove it.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: The information above provides the most support for which one of the following statements?
main_answers: Research in global warming is primarily driven by a desire for recognition in the scientific community.
Most researchers in climatology have substantial motive to find evidence that would discredit the global warming hypothesis.
There is evidence that conclusively shows that the global warming hypothesis is true.
Scientists who are skeptical about global warming have not offered any alternative hypotheses to explain climatological data.
others.target_option: Most researchers in climatology have substantial motive to find evidence that would discredit the global warming hypothesis.

context: Attorneys for a criminal defendant charged that the government, in a cover-up, had destroyed evidence that would have supported the defendant in a case. The government replied that there is no evidence that would even tend to support the defendant in the case.
question: Why is it not correct to conclude that, if true, the government's reply effectively disproves the charge made on behalf of the defendant?
answers: Saying that there "is no evidence" would be true whether it had never existed or if it had been destroyed.
If the evidence really doesn't exist, it wouldn't have been found whether or not the government searched for it.
The government's response does not prove or even insinuate that the attorneys didn't know whether their charge was true or not.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following is the most accurate evaluation of the government' s reply?
main_answers: If true, it effectively disproves the charge made on behalf of the defendant.
It leaves open the question of whether the government had destroyed such evidence.
It shows that the attorneys did not know whether their charge was true.
It demonstrates the government's failure to search for evidence in its files.
others.target_option: If true, it effectively disproves the charge made on behalf of the defendant.

context: The average hourly wage of television assemblers in Vernland has long been significantly lower than that in neighboring Borodia. Since Borodia dropped all tariffs on Vernlandian televisions three years ago, the number of televisions sold annually in Borodia has not changed. However, recent statistics show a drop in the number of television assemblers in Borodia. Ttherefore, updated trade statistics will probably indicate that the number of televisions Borodia imports annually from Vernland has increased.
question: Why does the argument not depend on the assumption that televisions assembled in Vernland have features that televisions assembled in Borodia do not have?
answers: Whether or not the hourly wage of television assemblers goes up or down in the future would not affect the sale of televisions currently.
The argument implies that the sales of televisions from Vernland has gone up not because they are more desirable, but because they are less expensive due to low labor costs.

Vernland would not necessarily need to increase its number of television assemblers in order to sell more televisions to Borodia, as they may instead be importing fewer televisions to other countries, selling fewer domestically, or selling stock that would not otherwise have sold.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
main_answers: Televisions assembled in Vernland have features that televisions assembled in Borodia do not have
The average number of hours it takes a Borodian television assembler to assemble a television has not decreased significantly during the past three years
The number of television assemblers in Vernland has increased by at least as much as the number of television assemblers in Borodia has decreased
The difference between the hourly wage of television assemblers in Vernland and the hourly wage of television assemblers in Borodia is likely to decrease in the next few years
others.target_option: Televisions assembled in Vernland have features that televisions assembled in Borodia do not have

context: The use of radar detectors in commercial vehicles was banned because commercial truck and bus drivers were using these devices to drive faster than the posted speed limit without fear of arrest. Since drivers of noncommercial vehicles also use radar detectors and since speeding decreases safety for any vehicle, use of radar detectors should also be banned in noncommercial vehicles to increase safety.
question: Why does the fact that traffic accidents involving a truck or bus generally pose a greater threat of injury or death than do other accidents not strongly support the argument?
answers: This supports banking radar detectors in noncommercial vehicles because it suggests it effectively reduces speeding.
This information supports the argument that commercial vehicles should not be allowed to use radar detectors, but does not suggest support towards radar being banned in noncommercial vehicles.

This is not necessary information to the passage towards supporting a ban or not supporting a radar ban.   It would only mean that people using a radar detector would have their detector go off for no reason.
This would not support a ban on radar detectors as they would not be worthwhile anyway if airplanes and helicopters were utilized.
label: B

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most strongly supports the argument above?
main_answers: Traffic accidents involving a truck or bus generally pose a greater threat of injury or death than do other accidents.
Radar detectors are sometimes set off by devices other than the law enforcement devices that the radar detectors were built to detect.
In many places airplanes or helicopters are used rather than radar to locate vehicles traveling faster than the posted speed limit.
The ban on radar detectors in commercial vehicles has been effective in deterring them from speeding.

context: Last year the rate of inflation was 1. 2 percent, but during the current year it has been 4 percent. We can conclude that inflation is on an upward trend and the rate will be still higher next year.
question: Explain why the fact that the inflation figures were computed on the basis of a representative sample of economic data rather than all the available data does not seriously weaken the conclusion.
answers: Changing the sample size wouldn't necessarily refute the claim that inflation will go up next year.
Having identified a cause behind the rise in inflation serves to support the author's argument.
If the cause is truly temporary, the inflation rate may not be as high next year.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the conclusion above?
main_answers: The 1. 2 percent rate of inflation last year represented a 10-year low.
The inflation figures were computed on the basis of a representative sample of economic data rather than all the available data.
Increases in the pay of some workers are tied to the level of inflation, and at an inflation rate of 4 percent or above, these pay raises constitute a force causing further inflation.
Last year a dip in oil prices brought inflation temporarily below its recent stable annual level of 4 percent.
others.target_option: The inflation figures were computed on the basis of a representative sample of economic data rather than all the available data.

context: A group of 5, 000 undergraduate students was randomly selected from three universities in a large state and asked the question, "Do you plan to attain your master' s degree eventually? " More than 82 percent answered "Yes. " This shows that the overwhelming majority of students want to attain their master' s degree, and that if the national number of students earning a master' s degree is low, it cannot be due to a lack of desire on the part of the students.
question: Why is the reasoning of the argument not considered questionable even though it contradicts itself by admitting that there might be a low number of students earning master's degrees, while claiming that most students want to acquire such a degree?
answers: 82 percent being an overwhelming majority is a reasonable statement that requires no justification.

The fact that there is low number of students earning master's degrees even though most students want to acquire such a degree is not a contradiction in the author's argument, only a contradiction in the situation the author is describing.
The passage only gives the responses from students in one state and uses that to make a argument for national sentiment.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The reasoning of the argument above is questionable because it
main_answers: contradicts itself by admitting that there might be a low number of students earning master's degrees, while claiming that most students want to acquire such a degree
overlooks the possibility that there might, in fact, be a majority of students who will eventually earn a master's degree
treats university students from a particular state as if they are representative of university students nationwide
fails to justify its presumption that 82 percent is an overwhelming majority
others.target_option: contradicts itself by admitting that there might be a low number of students earning master's degrees, while claiming that most students want to acquire such a degree

answers: 82 percent being an overwhelming majority is a reasonable statement that requires no justification.

The fact that there is low number of students earning master's degrees even though most students want to acquire such a degree is not a contradiction in the author's argument, only a contradiction in the situation the author is describing.
The passage only gives the responses from students in one state and uses that to make a argument for national sentiment.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The reasoning of the argument above is questionable because it
main_answers: contradicts itself by admitting that there might be a low number of students earning master's degrees, while claiming that most students want to acquire such a degree
overlooks the possibility that there might, in fact, be a majority of students who will eventually earn a master's degree
treats university students from a particular state as if they are representative of university students nationwide
fails to justify its presumption that 82 percent is an overwhelming majority
others.target_option: fails to justify its presumption that 82 percent is an overwhelming majority

context: The United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) regulates the introduction of new therapeutic agents into the marketplace. Consequently, it plays a critical role in improving health care in the United States. While it is those in the academic and government research communities who engage in the long process of initial discovery and clinical testing of new therapeutic agents, it is the FDA' s role and responsibility to facilitate the transfer of new discoveries from the laboratory to the marketplace. Only after the transfer can important new therapies help patients.
question: What is the evidence in the passage that allows for the inference that before new therapeutic agents reach the marketplace they do not help patients?
answers: The author states that researchers are the ones engaged in clinical testing, it does not claim that the FDA should be involved in ensuring quality.
The passage does not say that testing periods are excessively long, or any longer than they need to be.
The passage states that new discoveries which are transferred to the marketplace may help patients, not that they definitely will.
The passage states that new therapies help patients only after transfer to the marketplace.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following statements can be inferred from the passage?
main_answers: Before new therapeutic agents reach the marketplace they do not help patients.
The FDA should work more closely with researchers to ensure that the quality of therapeutic agents is maintained.
If a new medical discovery has been transferred from the laboratory to the marketplace, it will help patients.
The research community is responsible for the excessively long testing period for new drugs, not the FDA.
others.target_option: Before new therapeutic agents reach the marketplace they do not help patients.

context: Aristophanes' play The Clouds, which was written when the philosopher Socrates was in his mid-forties, portrays Socrates as an atheistic philosopher primarily concerned with issues in natural science. The only other surviving portrayals of Socrates were written after Socrates' death at age 70. They portrayed Socrates as having a religious dimension and a strong focus on ethical issues.
question: How does the fact that Socrates' philosophical views and interests changed sometime after his mid-forties help to resolve the apparent discrepancy between Aristophanes' portrayal of Socrates and the other surviving portrayals?
answers: If the later philosophers were interested in the natural sciences, then their portrayals of Socrates would have shown this slant rather than a religious one.
Whether the atheistic view of Socrates or the philosophical view is more flattering is a subjective issue which depends on the reader’s world view.
Those who were familiar with Socrates nearer the end of his life would have seen him after he experienced a philosophical shift.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, would most help to resolve the apparent discrepancy between Aristophanes' portrayal of Socrates and the other surviving portrayals?
main_answers: Socrates had an influence on many subsequent philosophers who were primarily concerned with natural science.
Socrates was a much more controversial figure in the years before his death than he was in his mid-forties.
Socrates' philosophical views and interests changed sometime after his mid-forties.
Aristophanes' portrayal of Socrates in The Clouds was unflattering, whereas the other portrayals were very flattering.
others.target_option: Socrates' philosophical views and interests changed sometime after his mid-forties.

context: Roger Bacon, the thirteenth-century scientist, is said to have made important discoveries in optics. He was an early advocate of hands-on experimentation, and as a teacher warned his students against relying uncritically on the opinions of authorities. Nevertheless, this did not stop Bacon himself from appealing to authority when it was expedient for his own argumentation. Thus, Bacon' s work on optics should be generally disregarded, in view of the contradiction between his statements and his own behavior.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument considered flawed for criticizing Bacon's character in order to question his scientific findings?
answers: The argument does not criticize any of Bacon's opinions so much as it criticizes him for being a hypocrite.
The character of a scientist is immaterial to whether or not their work is valid.
Whether or not 13th century science generally holds up has no bearing on whether or not the work of one scientist is valid.
In most cases it is acceptable to take the remarks of a person as evidence of their opinions, since there is no other way of knowing their opinions.
label: B

others.main_question: The reasoning in the argument is flawed because the argument
main_answers: criticizes Bacon's character in order to question his scientific findings
uses Bacon's remarks to his students as evidence of his opinions
ignores the fact that thirteenth-century science may not hold up well today
attacks Bacon's uncritical reliance on authority opinion
others.target_option: criticizes Bacon's character in order to question his scientific findings

context: Programmer: We computer programmers at Mytheco are demanding raises to make our average salary comparable with that of the technical writers here who receive, on average, 20 percent more in salary and benefits than we do. This pay difference is unfair and intolerable. Mytheco executive: But many of the technical writers have worked for Mytheco longer than have many of the programmers. Since salary and benefits at Mytheco are directly tied to seniority, the 20 percent pay difference you mention is perfectly acceptable.
question: Why is it not necessary to clarify how the Mytheco executive's salary compares with that of the programmers in order to evaluate the adequacy of the executive's response?
answers: A change is job within the company is not relevant to the salary that one is given.
The focus is on whether or not the salary of programmers are fair in comparisson to that of writers not overall benefit packages.
Since the executive is stating that the salary is based off of senority and not job title than comparing two workers that have similar senority should be getting similar wages.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Evaluating the adequacy of the Mytheco executive's response requires a clarification of which one of the following?
main_answers: how the Mytheco executive's salary compares with that of the programmers
how the average seniority of programmers compares with the average seniority of technical writers
whether any of the technical writers at Mytheco once worked as programmers at the company
whether the sorts of benefits an employee of Mytheco receives are tied to the salary of that employee
others.target_option: how the Mytheco executive's salary compares with that of the programmers

context: The makers of Activite, a natural dietary supplement, claim that it promotes energy and mental alertness. To back up their claim, they offer a month' s supply of Activite free to new customers. Clearly, Activite must be effective, since otherwise it would not be in the company' s interest to make such an offer.
question: Explain why the fact that a dietary supplement contains only natural ingredients does not weaken the argument.
answers: Even if there are less expensive dietary supplements on the market that are just as effective as Activite that does not mean that Activite is not effective.
The handling fee is a source of revenue for the company whether the customer finds the product effective or not.
The natural ingredients or potential harmful side effects are not part of the argument about the free month' s supply showing that the product is effective.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?
main_answers: The makers of Activite charge a handling fee that is considerably more than what it costs them to pack and ship their product.
The mere fact that a dietary supplement contains only natural ingredients does not insure that it has no harmful side effects.
The nutrients in Activite can all be obtained from a sufficiently varied and well-balanced diet.
There are less expensive dietary supplements on the market that are just as effective as Activite.
others.target_option: The mere fact that a dietary supplement contains only natural ingredients does not insure that it has no harmful side effects.

context: Despite increasing international efforts to protect the natural habitats of endangered species of animals, the rate at which these species are becoming extinct continues to rise. It is clear that these efforts are wasted.
question: How does the fact that species that would have become extinct have been saved due to the establishment of animal refuges weaken the argument?
answers: The ease of preserving habitats has no bearing on the argument made in the passage.
The passage talks about internation efforts increasing.
Despite a number of animals going extinct, a large number remain only through the efforts made to protect them.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?
main_answers: Many countries do not recognize the increased economic benefit of tourism associated with preserved natural habitats.
Species that would have become extinct have been saved due to the establishment of animal refuges.
Scientists are better able to preserve the habitats of endangered species now than ever before.
Scientists estimate that at least 2000 species become extinct every year.
others.target_option: Species that would have become extinct have been saved due to the establishment of animal refuges.
