context: Principle: When none of the fully qualified candidates for a new position at Arvue Corporation currently works for that company, it should hire the candidate who would be most productive in that position. Application: Arvue should not hire Krall for the new position, because Delacruz is a candidate and is fully qualified.
question: Why does the fact that Krall works for Arvue but Delacruz is the candidate who would be most productive in the new position not justify the application of the principle?
answers: If Krall works for Arvue, Krall would have gotten the job as the principle applies only when none of the candidates for the new position currently work for the company.

If the company should hire the candidate who would be most productive in the new position in the absence of a candidate who currently works for the company, this indicates Delacruz is the candidate who would be most productive in the new position as well as that there are no candidates currently employed by the organization.
If several candidates currently work for Arvue and Krall and Delacruz do not, neither would be considered for the new position.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, justifies the above application of the principle?
main_answers: None of the candidates already works for Arvue, and Delacruz is the candidate who would be most productive in the new position.
Of all the candidates who do not already work for Arvue, Delacruz would be the most productive in the new position.
Krall works for Arvue, but Delacruz is the candidate who would be most productive in the new position.
Several candidates currently work for Arvue, but Krall and Delacruz do not.
others.target_option: Krall works for Arvue, but Delacruz is the candidate who would be most productive in the new position.

context: Famous personalities found guilty of many types of crimes in well-publicized trials are increasingly sentenced to the performance of community service, though unknown defendants convicted of similar crimes almost always serve prison sentences. However, the principle of equality before the law rules out using fame and publicity as relevant considerations in the sentencing of convicted criminals.
question: What is the basis for concluding that the statements above strongly support the conclusion that the sentencing of celebrities to community service instead of prison constitutes a violation of the principle of equality before the law in many cases?
answers: There is no consideration given to the type of crimes by certain people. All people are considered the same in the law being applied.
By considering a persons station in life it violates the principle of equality. The law rules out using fame and publicity as relevant considerations in the sentencing of convicted criminals.
The principle of equality before the law is that fame or any other circumstance cannot override the law.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The statements above, if true, most strongly support which one of the following conclusions?
main_answers: The principle of equality before the law can properly be overridden by other principles in some cases.
The sentencing of celebrities to community service instead of prison constitutes a violation of the principle of equality before the law in many cases.
The principle of equality before the law is rigorously applied in only a few types of criminal trials.
The number of convicted celebrities sentenced to community service should equal the number of convicted unknown defendants sentenced to community service.
others.target_option: The sentencing of celebrities to community service instead of prison constitutes a violation of the principle of equality before the law in many cases.

context: Jackson City has outgrown its current fire station. The existing station cannot be expanded to fit the city' s needs because of building code restrictions. Real estate in the area of the existing station is far more expensive than building space on the west side of the city. Since the price of a building is a considerable portion of the total cost, it would be more economical to move the fire station to the west side of the city.
question: Explain why the fact that city residents have expressed approval of the plan to move the city's fire station to the west side of the city does not seriously undermine the argument's conclusion.
answers: If the insurance costs reach a certain threshold, any savings earned from changing locations would be lost.
The nuisance of noise pollution for the residents wouldn’t affect the cost of the project.
If there is ample water supply on the west side, that would help the case because they wouldn’t incur the costs of running new water lines.
If the residents approve of the plan, it would help strengthen the argument because the developers wouldn’t have costly delays.
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most seriously undermines the argument's conclusion?
main_answers: City residents have expressed approval of the plan to move the city's fire station to the west side of the city.
If the fire station is moved to the west side of the city, insurance rates will skyrocket because the west side of the city has higher arson and vandalism rates.
If the fire station is moved to the west side of the city, residents there will have to contend with increased noise and traffic.
There is already an ample water supply to support the fire station on the west side of the city.
others.target_option: City residents have expressed approval of the plan to move the city's fire station to the west side of the city.

Real estate in the area of the existing station is far more expensive than building space on the west side of the city. Since the price of a building is a considerable portion of the total cost, it would be more economical to move the fire station to the west side of the city.
question: Why does the fact that there is already an ample water supply to support the fire station on the west side of the city not seriously undermine the argument's conclusion?
answers: If there is ample water supply on the west side, that would help the case because they wouldn’t incur the costs of running new water lines.
If the insurance costs reach a certain threshold, any savings earned from changing locations would be lost.
The nuisance of noise pollution for the residents wouldn’t affect the cost of the project.
If the residents approve of the plan, it would help strengthen the argument because the developers wouldn’t have costly delays.
label: A

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most seriously undermines the argument's conclusion?
main_answers: City residents have expressed approval of the plan to move the city's fire station to the west side of the city.
If the fire station is moved to the west side of the city, insurance rates will skyrocket because the west side of the city has higher arson and vandalism rates.
If the fire station is moved to the west side of the city, residents there will have to contend with increased noise and traffic.
There is already an ample water supply to support the fire station on the west side of the city.
others.target_option: There is already an ample water supply to support the fire station on the west side of the city.

context: Citizen: Each year since 1970, a new record has been set for the number of murders committed in this city. In fact, the number of murder victims per 100 people has actually fallen slightly in the city since 1970.
question: Explain why the fact that the incidence of fraud has greatly increased in the city since 1970 does not strongly counter the city official's response?
answers: This would make the numbers the city official provided more accurate.
The demographics of murder victims would not change, that murder has gone down overall.
Fraud and murder are not comparable as crimes.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, would most strongly counter the city official's response?
main_answers: If the health care received by assault victims last year had been of the same quality as it was in 1970, the murder rate in the city last year would have turned out to be several times what it actually was.
The incidence of fraud has greatly increased in the city since 1970.

context: Pieces of music consist of sounds and silences presented to the listener in a temporal order. A painting, in contrast, is not presented one part at a time to the viewer; there is thus no particular path that the viewer' s eye must follow in order to "read" the painting. Ttherefore, an essential distinction between the experiences of hearing music and of viewing paintings is that hearing music has a temporal dimension but viewing a painting has none.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument not considered to be invalid due to its reliance on the metaphor of "reading" to characterize how a painting is viewed, which presupposes the correctness of the conclusion to be drawn on the basis of that characterization?
answers: Viewing a painting is taking in sensory perceptions through the eyes which is bound by time like all sensory phenomena, while experiencing without consciousness of the passage of time is a delusion or hallucination of the mind.
People are free to watch a painting in their own individual ways but they will still focus on one part at a time, so the temporal dimension still exists.
This argument is assuming the exact opposite of what the passage actually posits, which is that "reading" is akin to listening but not to viewing a painting.
The point of the argument is not seeking commonalities between music and painting but differences between them.
label: C

others.main_question: The reasoning in the argument is flawed because
main_answers: relying on the metaphor of "reading" to characterize how a painting is viewed presupposes the correctness of the conclusion to be drawn on the basis of that characterization
the argument does not allow for the possibility of being immersed in experiencing a painting without being conscious of the passage of time
the absence of a particular path that the eye must follow does not entail that the eye follows no path
the argument fails to bring out the aspects of music and painting that are common to both as forms of artistic expression
others.target_option: relying on the metaphor of "reading" to characterize how a painting is viewed presupposes the correctness of the conclusion to be drawn on the basis of that characterization

context: Electrical engineers have repeatedly demonstrated that the best solid-state amplifiers are indistinguishable from the best vacuum-tube amplifiers with respect to the characteristics commonly measured in evaluating the quality of an amplifier' s musical reproduction. Ttherefore, those music lovers who insist that recorded music sounds better when played with the best vacuum-tube amplifier than when played with the best solid-state amplifier must be imagining the difference in quality that they claim to hear.
question: Explain why the fact that many people cannot tell from listening to it whether a recording is being played with a very good solid-state amplifier or a very good vacuum-tube amplifier does not seriously weaken the argument.
answers: The range of variation doesn't matter, because what is being compared is the best vacuum-tube amplifiers and the best solid-state amplifiers.
Whether or not many people can tell whether a recording is being played with a solid-state amplifier or a vacuum-tube amplifier is not relevant to the argument.

It doesn't matter if some vacuum-tube amplifiers are superior to some solid-state amplifiers, because what is being argued is that the best vacuum-tube amplifiers and the best solid-state amplifiers are equal in sound quality.
None of the above choices
label: B

Some of the characteristics that are important in determining how music sounds to a listener cannot be measured.
The range of variation with respect to the quality of musical reproduction is greater for vacuum-tube amplifiers than for solid-state amplifiers.

Some vacuum-tube amplifiers are clearly superior to some sold-state amplifiers with respect to the characteristics commonly measured in the laboratory to evaluate the quality of an amplifier's musical reproduction.

context: When volcanic lava solidifies, it becomes uniformly magnetized in the direction in which the Earth' s magnetic field points. There are significant differences in the direction of magnetization among solidified lava flows from different volcanoes that erupted at different times over the past several million years. Ttherefore, it must be that the direction of the Earth' s magnetic field has changed over time. Since lava flows differing by thousands of years in age often have very similar directions of magnetization, the change in the direction of the Earth' s magnetic field must take place very gradually over hundreds of thousands of years.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the argument that the direction of the Earth's magnetic field has changed over time requires the assumption that not all solidified lava has changed the direction of its magnetization unpredictably?
answers: Carbon dating can be used to identify rocks of non-lava origin to see if magnetic direction changed over time.
If lava flows maintain their direction of magnetization over time and are not affected by other factors after the fact, then the argument for a periodic magnetic change could be supported
Lava consistency would have to be able to impact magnetic direction, but evidence indicates that regardless of lava type, magnetic direction is consistent across time periods.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The argument that the direction of the Earth's magnetic field has changed over time requires the assumption that
main_answers: not all solidified lava has changed the direction of its magnetization unpredictably
only lava can be used to measure the direction of the Earth's magnetic field as it existed in the distant past
as lava flows down the side of a volcano, it picks up magnetized rocks
a single volcano can produce lava of differing consistencies during different eruptions
others.target_option: not all solidified lava has changed the direction of its magnetization unpredictably

context: Like a genetic profile, a functional magnetic-resonance image (fMRI) of the brain can contain information that a patient wishes to keep private. An fMRI of a brain also contains enough information about a patient' s skull to create a recognizable image of that patient' s face. A genetic profile can be linked to a patient only by referring to labels or records.
question: Why does the evidence not strongly support the claim that patients are more concerned about threats to privacy posed by fMRIs than they are about those posed by genetic profiles?
answers: There is no mention in the passage of the patients being concerned about privacy or even being aware of the privacy concerns.
Like all medical records, a patient could be reasonably sure that his or her details wouldn’t be shared without permission.
There is no mention of labeling in association with the fFMRI, only with the genetic profile.
Since the fMRI can even be used to accurately reconstruct a patient’s face, it can more easily compromise them than a collection of genetic data.
label: A

others.main_question: The statements above, if true, most strongly support which one of the following?
main_answers: Patients are more concerned about threats to privacy posed by fMRIs than they are about those posed by genetic profiles.
In most cases patients cannot be reasonably sure that the information in a genetic profile will be kept private.
It is not important that medical providers apply labels to fMRIs of patients' brains.
An fMRI has the potential to compromise patient privacy in circumstances in which a genetic profile would not.
others.target_option: Patients are more concerned about threats to privacy posed by fMRIs than they are about those posed by genetic profiles.

context: Quillium is the most popular blood pressure regulating prescription drug on the market. Giant Pharma, Inc. , the largest prescription drug manufacturer in the country, owns the patent on Quillium. Giant Pharma stock is hitting unprecedented high valuations. As a result, Quillium is by far the most effective drug available in treating irregular blood pressure.
question: Explain why the fact that Giant Pharma gouges its customers on Quillium's price does not weaken the argument.
answers: Quillium's uses in other areas of treatment are not discussed nor relevant to its efficacy as a blood pressure regulating medication.

While Quillium may be the most popular and lucrative, it does not necessarily mean it is the most effective. Other lesser known prescription drugs could be more effective just less well-known and so less popular and lucrative.

Other patent acquisitions are not mentioned nor would they be considered when determining the efficacy of Quillium. Its popularity is another factor considered as well, not just the high stock valuations.
If Giant Pharma gouged its customers on Quillium's price, it is unlikely it would be the most popular blood pressure regulating prescription drug on the market.
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?
main_answers: Giant Pharma gouges its customers on Quillium's price.
Quillium has numerous alternate applications.
The most lucrative and popular pharmaceuticals are not always the most effective.
Giant Pharma's high stock prices are attributable to recent patent acquisitions other than Quillium.
others.target_option: Giant Pharma gouges its customers on Quillium's price.

context: Although Damon had ample time earlier in the month to complete the paper he is scheduled to present at a professional conference tomorrow morning, he repeatedly put off doing it. Damon could still get the paper ready in time, but only if he works on it all evening without interruption. However, his seven-year-old daughter' s tap-dance recital takes place this evening, and Damon had promised both to attend and to take his daughter and her friends out for ice cream afterward. Thus, because of his procrastination, Damon will be forced to choose between his professional and his family responsibilities.
question: Why does the argument not proceed by demonstrating that two situations are similar in order to justify the claim that someone with certain responsibilities in the first situation has similar responsibilities in the second situation?
answers: It is not clear from the passage what harm will result from the person's actions.
Completing the paper is not a similar situation to attending the recital.
The passage shows that time must either be spent getting the paper ready or attending the recital and spending time on one of those is incompatible with spending time on the other.
The passage does not seek to invoke sympathy but is critical of the mistakes made by the person.
label: B

others.main_question: The argument proceeds by
main_answers: showing that two situations are similar in order to justify the claim that someone with certain responsibilities in the first situation has similar responsibilities in the second situation
invoking sympathy for someone who finds himself in a dilemma in order to excuse that person's failure to meet all of his responsibilities
making clear the extent to which someone's actions resulted in harm to others in order to support the claim that those actions were irresponsible
demonstrating that two situations cannot both occur by showing that something necessary for one of those situations is incompatible with something necessary for the other situation
others.target_option: showing that two situations are similar in order to justify the claim that someone with certain responsibilities in the first situation has similar responsibilities in the second situation

context: Although Damon had ample time earlier in the month to complete the paper he is scheduled to present at a professional conference tomorrow morning, he repeatedly put off doing it. Damon could still get the paper ready in time, but only if he works on it all evening without interruption. However, his seven-year-old daughter' s tap-dance recital takes place this evening, and Damon had promised both to attend and to take his daughter and her friends out for ice cream afterward. Thus, because of his procrastination, Damon will be forced to choose between his professional and his family responsibilities.
question: Why does the argument not proceed by making clear the extent to which someone's actions resulted in harm to others in order to support the claim that those actions were irresponsible?
answers: The passage shows that time must either be spent getting the paper ready or attending the recital and spending time on one of those is incompatible with spending time on the other.
The passage does not seek to invoke sympathy but is critical of the mistakes made by the person.
It is not clear from the passage what harm will result from the person's actions.
Completing the paper is not a similar situation to attending the recital.

context: Between 1980 and 2000 the sea otter population of the Aleutian Islands declined precipitously. There were no signs of disease or malnutrition, so there was probably an increase in the number of otters being eaten by predators. Orcas will eat otters when seals, their normal prey, are unavailable, and the Aleutian Islands seal population declined dramatically in the 1980s. Ttherefore, orcas were most likely the immediate cause of the otter population decline.
question: Why does the fact that the population of orcas in the Aleutian Islands has declined since the 1980s not strengthen the argument?
answers: If seals don't eat or compete with sea otters, their population numbers wouldn't be related to the sea otter populations based on those two factors.
Whether or not the prey of sea otters has grown in population would have no relevance to whether or not orcas are the main cause of declining sea otter populations.
If the population of orcas declined, it wouldn't be a good argument as to why orcas were the main cause of such an increase in sea otters being eaten.
If a disproportionate amount of sea otters are able to survive in an area inaccessible to orcas, this would add further evidence that orcas are the factor towards dwindling sea otter populations.
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?
main_answers: The population of orcas in the Aleutian Islands has declined since the 1980s.
Seals do not eat sea otters, nor do they compete with sea otters for food.
Most of the surviving sea otters live in a bay that is inaccessible to orcas.
The population of sea urchins, the main food of sea otters, has increased since the sea otter population declined.
others.target_option: The population of orcas in the Aleutian Islands has declined since the 1980s.

context: In a certain wildlife park, park rangers are able to track the movements of many rhinoceroses because those animals wear radio collars. When, as often happens, a collar slips off, it is put back on. Putting a collar on a rhinoceros involves immobilizing the animal by shooting it with a tranquilizer dart. Female rhinoceroses that have been frequently recollared have significantly lower fertility rates than uncollared females. Probably, ttherefore, some substance in the tranquilizer inhibits fertility.
question: Why is it not necessary to determine whether male rhinoceroses in the wildlife park lose their collars any more often than the park's female rhinoceroses do in order to evaluate the argument?
answers: Male rhinos do not give birth, so this information would not be relevant as there is no fertility rate to be measured.
How many female rhinos are collared does not help to determine the cause of the lower fertility rates.
The effectiveness of other tracking methods has no bearing on determining whether recollaring affects fertility rates.
This information would help to determine whether the tranquilizer itself, or some other part of the recollaring process has a detrimental effect on fertility rates.
label: A

others.main_question: In evaluating the argument, it would be most useful to determine which of the following?
main_answers: Whether male rhinoceroses in the wildlife park lose their collars any more often than the park's female rhinoceroses do
Whether radio collars are the only practical means that park rangers have for tracking the movements of rhinoceroses in the park
How often park rangers need to use tranquilizer darts to immobilize rhinoceroses for reasons other than attaching radio collars
Whether there are more collared female rhinoceroses than uncollared female rhinoceroses in the park
others.target_option: Whether male rhinoceroses in the wildlife park lose their collars any more often than the park's female rhinoceroses do

context: Social media websites rely on user engagement. Increasing the number of users and those users' activity means more advertising revenue. Most social media websites offer the service at no cost in order to attract more users, relying exclusively on advertising revenue to make a profit. The most popular articles shared on social media websites involve sensationalized stories of dubious value, including misleading titles and incorrect factual information. However, many users will stop using a social media website when the sensational stories become too overwhelming. As a result, social media companies would be best served by. . .
question: Explain why the argument does not require the claim that lying to advertisers about their user engagement completes it?
answers: The use of sensatinalized articles helps to generate more views when used in a good ratio of factual stories.

Since social media websites rely on advertising to make a profit and users will frequent the site less if there are too many sensationalized stories vs factual articles montoring the ratio of stories will help ensure that people continue to visit the site thus generating profit.
If advertisers are lied to they may not what to advertise on the website which would lead to less profits.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following best completes the argument?
main_answers: lying to advertisers about their user engagement.
surveying their users to determine what type of content they most prefer.
monitoring the ratio of sensationalized and factual articles.
prohibiting sensationalized articles.
others.target_option: lying to advertisers about their user engagement.

context: The mathematics of the scientific theory known as "complexity" describes those phenomena that are not quite stable and not quite chaotic. For example, the mathematics of complexity can be used to describe sand dunes: although sand dunes generally retain their shape, the addition of a tiny amount of sand can cause a sandslide. Certain scientists have concluded that there is good evidence that complexity is correct. After entering complexity-based mathematical models of real-world phenomena in computers, they found that the computerized mathematical models evolve much like the real-world phenomena actually evolve.
question: Why does the fact that computers verify that there are mathematical errors in the calculations of scientists not justify the scientists' conclusion based on the principle that if computers verify that there are mathematical errors in the calculations of scientists, then the theories of those scientists are probably incorrect?
answers: Being neither purely stable or unpredictable in a computer program that is designed with intention does not prove that computers are chaotic.
Duplicating results give merit to the results.
Being able to recreate a phenomenon by computer does not mean it does not exist naturally.
A mathematical error does not prove a theory incorrect.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following principles, if valid, most justifies the scientists' conclusion?
main_answers: If actual phenomena can be pictured as computerized models, computers themselves will eventually discover the mathematics of the correct theory explaining those phenomena.
If computers verify that there are mathematical errors in the calculations of scientists, then the theories of those scientists are probably incorrect.
If computerized models based on a theory behave like their real-world counterparts behave, then that theory is probably correct.
If they evolve exactly like real-world phenomena, computer models are neither purely stable nor purely chaotic, which is what complexity predicts.
others.target_option: If computers verify that there are mathematical errors in the calculations of scientists, then the theories of those scientists are probably incorrect.

context: Jamal: It' s incorrect to maintain that current data suggest a weakness in the economy. Stocks are paying higher dividends than ever and corporations' profits are very high. Yet you criticize corporations on the basis of wage data, which are the only data showing a decline. Jennifer: You' re right that only wage data show a decline, but those data are important because they show a shift of income from companies' workers to their shareholders. The statistics you cite mean little to the expanding numbers of workers finding it increasingly difficult to make a living.
question: What evidence from Jamal's and Jennifer's statements leads to the conclusion that they agree about the truth of the claim that corporations are currently making considerable profits?
answers: While Jennifer may believe that the decline in wages is a worrisome economic trend there is no evidence that Jamal agrees with this.
There is no information in the passage regarding biases of compilers.
Jamal states that corporations' profits are very high and Jennifer says that income is shifting to companies' shareholders which shows that they both think corporations are making profits.
While Jennifer may feel that the priorities of many corporations are misplaced there is no evidence that Jamal agrees with this.
label: C

others.main_question: Jamal's and Jennifer's statements provide the most support for holding that they agree about the truth of which one of the following?
main_answers: Corporations are currently making considerable profits.
The current priorities of many corporations are misplaced.
Statistical information tends to reflect the biases of its compilers.
The decline in wages is a worrisome economic trend.
others.target_option: Corporations are currently making considerable profits.

context: Dobson: Some historians claim that the people who built a ring of stones thousands of years ago in Britain were knowledgeable about celestial events. The ground for this claim is that two of the stones determine a line pointing directly to the position of the sun at sunrise at the spring equinox. There are many stones in the ring, however, so the chance that one pair will point in a celestially significant direction is large. Ttherefore, the people who built the ring were not knowledgeable about celestial events .
question: Why does Dobson's argument not contain an error of reasoning due to the conclusion logically contradicting some of the evidence presented in support of it?
answers: His conclusion is based on the vast number of stones and probability, which does not contradict the evidence.
No statements absolutely establish his conclusion but some are treated as if they do.
The opinions of the historians that are mentioned are not treated as if subject to verification, but merely claimed to be in possible error.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an error of reasoning in Dobson's argument?
main_answers: Statements that absolutely establish Dobson's conclusion are treated as if they merely give some support to that conclusion.
The failure of cited evidence to establish a statement is taken as evidence that statement is false.
Something that is merely a matter of opinion is treated as if it were subject to verification as a matter of fact.
Dobson's conclusion logically contradicts some of the evidence presented in support of it.
others.target_option: Dobson's conclusion logically contradicts some of the evidence presented in support of it.

context: Parents who consistently laud their children for every attempt to accomplish something, whether successful or not, actually erode the youngsters' sense of self-esteem. Children require commendation for their achievements, but if uniformly praised for both what they have accomplished and what they have merely attempted, they will eventually discount all words of commendation. In effect, such children never hear any praise at all.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the overall conclusion of the argument is that children will develop low self-esteem if their parents do not praise them when they succeed?
answers: The author does not make a judgement about whether the praise is deserved or not.
The main point of the argument has to do with too much praise, not too little.
The author gives solid reasons for why a parent should give praise only when appropriate.
The main point of the passage is about praising children too much not about praising children for their achievements.
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the overall conclusion of the argument?
main_answers: Children will develop low self-esteem if their parents do not praise them when they succeed.
Children's self-esteem will suffer if their parents uniformly praise their attempts to accomplish things regardless of their success or failure.
Parents should praise their children for their achievements.
Children whose actions are praised undeservedly eventually learn to discount all words of praise.
others.target_option: Children will develop low self-esteem if their parents do not praise them when they succeed.

context: Astronomer: Astronomical observations in many areas have become useless because light from nearby cities obscures the stars Many people argue that since streetlights are needed for safety, such interference from lights is inevitable. Here in Sandsville, however, the local observatory' s view remains relatively clear, since the city has restricted unnecessary lighting and installed special street lamps that direct all their light downward. It is ttherefore possible to have both well-lighted streets and relatively dark skies.
question: What is the rationale for the astronomer's argument proceeding by offering a counter example to a general claim?
answers: Specially made street lights are more than a simple distinction from traditional ones that pollute the night sky with light.
The astronomer asserts that, despite people's idea that inference from streetlights is inevitable, specially made lights can co-exist with dark skies.
Human made streetlights are not a natural phenomenon.
There is no mention of any scientific authority in the passage.
label: B

others.main_question: The astronomer's argument proceeds by
main_answers: offering a counter example to a general claim
proposing an alternative scientific explanation for a natural phenomenon
appealing to a scientific authority to challenge a widely held belief
making a distinction between terms
others.target_option: offering a counter example to a general claim

context: Benford's Law states that most phenomena in nature begin with '1's and '2' s. The law has been shown to apply very accurately to the amount of money listed on people's income statements. Investigators have used this fact when investigating financial fraud, and can often determine when people have fabricated numbers, since the perpetrators will choose varying amounts so that the first number in each of those amounts is distributed evenly from '1' to '9'. Proponents of Benford's Law, ttherefore, argue that as the technique of applying Benford's law becomes even more refined, an expert's ability to determine whether a plaintiff has engaged in financial fraud will become as accurate in determining guilt as a fingerprint is today.
question: Why does the fact that the use of fingerprinting is highly sophisticated since it has had over a century to evolve as a technology not cast doubt on the conclusion drawn by proponents of Benford's Law?
answers: It is irrelevant to the argument if there are other methods of detecting financial fraud so long as Benford's Law is effective in preventing financial fraud.
If people who commit financial fraud know about Benford's Law, they will use Benford's Law to choose amounts that will not cause suspicion.
The amount of time it took for fingerprinting to evolve is independent of the amount of time it will take Benford's Law to develop as a means of discovering financial fraud.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, casts the most doubt on the conclusion drawn by proponents of Benford's Law?
main_answers: In one financial fraud case, the numbers in which the amount was stated was not distributed evenly across '1's and '9's.
In the last year, several instances of financial fraud were discovered using other means besides Benford's Law.
Benford's Law, after being used in several notable cases, has become highly publicized and intimately known to many likely to commit such crimes.
The use of fingerprinting is highly sophisticated since it has had over a century to evolve as a technology.
others.target_option: The use of fingerprinting is highly sophisticated since it has had over a century to evolve as a technology.

context: In social science research, "highest education level attained" would refer to the most advanced grade or degree achieved by an individual-for some individuals, it may be a grade in grade school, and for other individuals, it may be a Bachelor' s Degree, a Master' s Degree, or Ph. D. (which is considered the highest education level). A recent study has shown a strong correlation between highest education level attained and proficiency in chess. Another result, studied at many points throughout the 20th century, shows a marked positive correlation between highest education level attained and income level.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that, if Jane has a Ph. D. , and Chris has not finished his undergraduate degree, then Jane will usually beat Chris in chess based on the statements above?
answers: Hard work and dedication are also important and a job and income can not be solely based on the person's degree.
Just because Jane has a higher degree than Chris whether or not each plays chess is important to the conclusion.  A degree along does not allow you to draw the conclusion.
Not everyone that plays chess has a formal education.  This assumes that all people who play chess have a formal education
A person that is proficient in chess does not necessarily correlate to the type of job or income level that one acquire's.  Many people of all degrees and income levels play chess.
label: B

others.main_question: Assuming the statements above are true, what conclusion can be drawn?
main_answers: An individual's proficiency at chess rises consistently during that individual's years of school, and levels off once that individual has finished her years of formal education.
If Jane has a Ph. D. , and Chris has not finished his undergraduate degree, then Jane will usually beat Chris in chess.
It is possible that a person who has attained only a sixth grade level of education could earn more than a person who has a Ph. D.
If one practices chess enough to raise one's proficiency, one has a good chance of raising one's income level.
others.target_option: If Jane has a Ph. D. , and Chris has not finished his undergraduate degree, then Jane will usually beat Chris in chess.

context: If something would have been justifiably regretted if it had occurred, then it is something that one should not have desired in the first place. It follows that many forgone pleasures should not have been desired in the first place.
question: Why does the conclusion follow logically if it is assumed that many forgone pleasures would have been justifiably regretted?
answers: The passage argues the opposite.  It is the desire for a certain pleasure that sometimes leads to regret.
Correct.  If you can foresee the desires that will lead to regret, you would not seek the pleasure from them.
Pleasures sometimes lead to regret and is unavoidable. Those are the ones that should not have been desirable in the first place
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The conclusion above follows logically if which one of the following is assumed?
main_answers: Everything that one desires and then regrets not having is a forgone pleasure.
One should never regret one's pleasures.
Many forgone pleasures would have been justifiably regretted.
Forgone pleasures that were not desired would not have been justifiably regretted.
others.target_option: Many forgone pleasures would have been justifiably regretted.

context: Industrialist: Environmentalists contend that emissions from our factory pose a health risk to those living downwind. The only testimony presented in support of this contention comes from residents of the communities surrounding the factory. But only a trained scientist can determine whether or not these emissions are dangerous, and none of the residents are scientists. Hence our factory' s emissions present no health risk.
question: Why is the industrialist's argument not considered to be invalid due to its lack of discussion of the benefits of the factory to the surrounding community?
answers: The term "health risk" is used the same way through the passage.
Emissions from other sources in the area have nothing to do with whether the factory is a health risk.
The benefits to the community have nothing to do with the possible health risks coming from it.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: The reasoning in the industrialist's argument is flawed because the argument
main_answers: equivocates between two different notions of the term "health risk"
presents no testimony from scientists that the emissions are safe
fails to discuss the benefits of the factory to the surrounding community
does not consider the safety of emissions from other sources in the area
others.target_option: fails to discuss the benefits of the factory to the surrounding community

context: The Canadian elk has traditionally been limited in its geographic range by the presence of elderberries, its primary source of food, which only grow up until a certain point in the tundra. A recent rise in temperatures, however, has seen a spread in the growth of elderberries northwards into the tundra. Ttherefore, the overall range of the Canadian elk can be expected to increase.
question: Explain why the fact that the grizzly bear, the Canadian elk's primary predator, has also started moving north into the tundra does not cast doubt on the argument.
answers: This does not mean the range will increase or decrease as it states it is unlikely and not impossible.
Why the elk are hunted has no bearing upon whether or not their overall range will increase.
The passage does not state anything about the grizzly bear in relation to the elderberries. If the grizzly bears are moving north it would in fact support the argument as they prey on the elk.
This would not lead to an increase in the overall range of the elk as they would simply move to a new area which would not increase their range.
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, best casts doubt on the argument?
main_answers: The grizzly bear, the Canadian elk's primary predator, has also started moving north into the tundra.
During the summer months, many Canadian elk are hunted both for sport and for their meat.
The permafrost, the region above the tundra, in which the temperatures never reach above freezing, will unlikely see elderberry growth.
Increasing temperatures have created conditions too warm for elderberry growth in the southern half of the Canadian elk's traditional territory.
others.target_option: The grizzly bear, the Canadian elk's primary predator, has also started moving north into the tundra.

context: Louis: People' s intentions cannot be, on the whole, more bad than good. Were we to believe otherwise, we would inevitably cease to trust each other, and no society can survive without mutual trust among its members.
question: Explain why the argument is not vulnerable to the criticism that it mistakenly assumes that if two claims cannot at the same time both be true, then they cannot at the same time both be false.
answers: The statement is actually advocating for a more positive outlook, not a negative one.
The statement makes the assumption that if bad consequences occur from holding a belief, then the belief must have been wrong in the first place.
There is no reference made in the article to multiple claims being either true or false.
The motives of those who made the claim of people being more bad than good, are not called into question, only the validity of their claims.
label: C

others.main_question: The argument is most vulnerable to which one of the following criticisms?
main_answers: It mistakenly assumes that if two claims cannot at the same time both be true, then they cannot at the same time both be false.
It assumes without warrant that in any situation with two possible outcomes, the most negative one will inevitably occur.
It challenges the truth of a claim merely by calling into question the motives of those who profess that they believe it to be true.
It fails to rule out the possibility that a true belief can have deleterious consequences.
others.target_option: It mistakenly assumes that if two claims cannot at the same time both be true, then they cannot at the same time both be false.

context: There are about 75 brands of microwave popcorn on the market; altogether, they account for a little over half of the money from sales of microwave food products. It takes three minutes to pop corn in the microwave, compared to seven minutes to pop corn conventionally. Yet by weight, microwave popcorn typically costs over five times as much as conventional popcorn. Judging by the popularity of microwave popcorn, many people are willing to pay a high price for just a little additional convenience.
question: What evidence supports the claim that more money is spent on microwave food products that take three minutes or less to cook than on microwave food products that take longer to cook?
answers: Three minute popcorn costs more and sells more than foods with longer cooking times, so it follows that more money is spent
Microwave popcorn as a whole is considered, and it is not necessarily true or relevant that one brand is more popular than another
Microwave popcorn as a whole sells more than any other microwave food, which is true if there are 2 microwave popcorn companies or 200.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: If the statements in the passage are true, which one of the following must also be true?
main_answers: More money is spent on microwave food products that take three minutes or less to cook than on microwave food products that take longer to cook.
No single brand of microwave popcorn accounts for a large share of microwave food product sales.
There are more brands of microwave popcorn on the market than there are of any other microwave food product.
Of the total number of microwave food products on the market, most are microwave popcorn products.
others.target_option: More money is spent on microwave food products that take three minutes or less to cook than on microwave food products that take longer to cook.

The evidence that technological improvements increase labor productivity is not inconsistent with any other evidence presented.
There are many possible causes for Parland's labor productivity being higher than Vergia's and no one cause can be assumed to be the clear reason.

context: Mammals cannot digest cellulose and ttherefore cannot directly obtain glucose from wood. Mushrooms can, however; and some mushrooms use cellulose to make highly branched polymers, the branches of which are a form of glucose called beta-glucans. Beta-glucan extracts from various types of mushrooms slow, reverse, or prevent the growth of cancerous tumors in mammals, and the antitumor activity of beta-glucans increases as the degree of branching increases. These extracts prevent tumor growth not by killing cancer cells directly but by increasing immune-cell activity.

The passage asserts that the beta-glucans are what triggers a positive immune response so it can be inferred that more beta-glucans will cause greater immune-cell activity.
The efficacy of a mushroom in fighting cancerous growth has no bearing on it ability to utilize cellulose.
The passage only pertains to mushrooms, not other species or organisms.

context: Forty miles to the west of Tucson, a developer attempted to develop an "oasis" glade in the Sonoran Desert. He created a glade that, the developer claims, is as lush and plant-filled as the ambient 35 degree C temperatures allow. In particular, the developer planted several native fruit-bearing plants, such as prickly-pear cactus. Once the glade was established, a number of desert birds and mammals would regularly inhabit the glade, often eating most of the fruit that falls from the plants.
question: What considerations are given that serve as part of an argument that the presence of the desert animals in the glade does not serve as evidence against the claim of the developer?
answers: Just because the desert animals are attracted to the glade, does not mean that they would have perished without it.
There is no mention that the fruit was intended to be sold or that there was a need to cover the cost of development.
The presence of desert animals serves as evidence that the glade is lush and plant filled
There is no mention of a reduction in temperature or that the plants that were planted were the kind that produce much shade.
label: C

others.main_question: The considerations given best serve as part of an argument that:
main_answers: the presence of the desert animals in the glade do not serve as evidence against the claim of the developer.
most of these desert animals in the glade would have perished if the glade had not been created in that location.
the shade from all the plants in the glade measurably reduces the ambient temperature within the glade.
enclosing the fruit -- bearing plants in wire cages to prevent consumption by desert animals would allow for fruit sales to cover the cost of the glade's development.
others.target_option: the presence of the desert animals in the glade do not serve as evidence against the claim of the developer.

context: Psychologists have claimed that many people are more susceptible to psychological problems in the winter than in the summer; the psychologists call this condition seasonal affective disorder. Their claim is based on the results of surveys in which people were asked to recall how they felt at various times in the past. However, it is not clear that people are able to report accurately on their past psychological states. Ttherefore, these survey results do not justify the psychologists' claim that there is any such condition as seasonal affective disorder.
question: What is the reason for not accepting the author's criticism of the psychologists' claim by offering an alternative explanation of the variation in the occurrence of psychological problems across seasons?
answers: The author's criticism questions the accuracy of respondents' reporting rather than offering any alternative explanation.
The author attacks the psychologists' assumption that respondents can accurately report their past mental states in order to discredit the existence of seasonal affective disorder.
The author's criticism relies on an assertion of unreliable respondent recall, not the number of people that may suffer from the disorder.
The sample population representation is not called into question.
label: A

others.main_question: The author criticizes the psychologists' claim by
main_answers: offering an alternative explanation of the variation in the occurrence of psychological problems across seasons
demonstrating that fewer people actually suffer from seasonal affective disorder than psychologists had previously thought
questioning the representativeness of the population sample surveyed by the psychologists
questioning an assumption that the author attributes to the psychologists
others.target_option: offering an alternative explanation of the variation in the occurrence of psychological problems across seasons

context: A philosophical paradox is a particularly baffling sort of argument. Your intuitions tell you that the conclusion of a philosophical paradox is false, but they also tell you that its conclusion follows logically from true premises. Solving a philosophical paradox requires accepting any one of three things: that its conclusion is true, that at least one of its premises is not true, or that its conclusion does not really follow logically from its premises.
question: Explain why it is not necessary for the statement that philosophical paradoxes with one or two premises are more baffling than those with several premises to also be true.
answers: The passage does not mention how a paradox with more or less premises would be any less confusing.
You only need one of the qualifying things to be true according to the passage in this case if you accept that one conclusion is not true than you can solve a paradox.
Because a paradox is self contradicting, it would be the case that in order to accept a paradox that you would need to accept a contradiction.
A paradoxes premises can all be true and they can contradict one another, making it a paradox.
label: A

others.main_question: If the statements above are true, which one of the following must also be true?
main_answers: Philosophical paradoxes with one or two premises are more baffling than those with several premises.
Solving a philosophical paradox requires accepting something that intuitively seems to be incorrect.
The conclusion of a philosophical paradox cannot be false if all the paradox's premises are true.
If it is not possible to accept that the conclusion of a particular philosophical paradox is true, then it is not possible to solve that paradox.
others.target_option: Philosophical paradoxes with one or two premises are more baffling than those with several premises.

context: Nature constantly adjusts the atmospheric carbon level. An increase in the level causes the atmosphere to hold more heat, which causes more water to evaporate from the oceans, which causes increased rain. Rain washes some carbon from the air into the oceans, where it eventually becomes part of the seabed. A decrease in atmospheric carbon causes the atmosphere to hold less heat, which causes decreased evaporation from the oceans, which causes less rain, and thus less carbon is washed into the oceans. Yet some environmentalists worry that burning fossil fuels may raise atmospheric carbon to a dangerous level. It is true that a sustained increase would threaten human life. But the environmentalists should relax -- nature will continually adjust the carbon level.
question: What is the rationale for why a decrease in the level of carbon in the atmosphere does not cause decreased evaporation of ocean water, which can be inferred from the information in the passage?
answers: Decrease in the level of carbon in the atmosphere leads to a decrease of the level of atmospheric heat, not the other way around.
Rain washes some carbon from the air into the oceans, where it eventually becomes part of the seabed. When the level of atmospheric heat decreases, less carbon is washed into the oceans.
When the atmosphere holds more heat, more water evaporates from the oceans, which causes increased rain.
A decrease in atmospheric carbon causes the atmosphere to hold less heat, which causes decreased evaporation from the oceans.
label: D

main_answers: A decrease in the level of carbon in the atmosphere causes decreased evaporation of ocean water.
A decrease in the level of atmospheric heat causes a decrease in the level of carbon in the atmosphere.
An increase in the level of atmospheric heat causes increased rainfall.
A decrease in the level of atmospheric heat causes a decrease in the amount of carbon that rain washes into the oceans from the air.
others.target_option: A decrease in the level of carbon in the atmosphere causes decreased evaporation of ocean water.

context: Economist: Some critics of the media have contended that negative news reports on the state of the economy can actually harm the economy because such reports damage people' s confidence in it, and this lack of confidence in turn adversely affects people' s willingness to spend money. But studies show that spending trends correlate very closely with people' s confidence in their own immediate economic situations. Thus these media critics are mistaken.
question: Why is the economist's argument not considered to be invalid due to its failure to take into account the possibility that news reports about the state of the economy are not always accurate?
answers: The degree to which people are surprised by changes in the economy would not prove the argument false.
If people that see the economy in a negative light are also more likely to view their individual situation in a pessimistic way, it would invalidate the argument that they aren't related.
Even if news reports were inaccurate, they could still affect consumer confidence.
People that don't pay any attention to economic news would be irrelevant in proving whether people's views of the overall economy and their individual situations are related.
label: C

others.main_question: The economist's argument is flawed in that it fails to consider the possibility that
main_answers: news reports about the state of the economy are not always accurate
people who have little confidence in the overall economy generally take a pessimistic view concerning their own immediate economic situations
an economic slowdown usually has a greater impact on the economic situations of individuals if it takes people by surprise than if people are forewarned
people who pay no attention to economic reports in the media always judge accurately whether their own economic situation is likely to deteriorate or improve
others.target_option: news reports about the state of the economy are not always accurate

context: Yorco and Zortech are two corporations that employ large numbers of full-time workers who are paid by the hour. answers: This would have no impact on the wage rate already calculated for Yorco.
This supports the fact that other pay factors such as overtime are not skewing the hourly wage data in favor of a higher rate at Yorco.

context: Due to the profitable but unlawful practice of selling elephant tusks, elephants have been hunted to near extinction by unlicensed poachers. Ttherefore, an efficient way to prevent the hunting of elephants would be to file down the tusks from time to time, thus removing any incentive for hunting elephants.
question: What is the reasoning that justifies the conclusion that the argument requires the assumption that elephants are only valued by poachers for their tusks?
answers: The passage does not delve into elephants defending themselves against the poachers or the importance of their ability to do so.
The passage states that filing the tusks would remove any incentive for hunting elephants, which means that the tusks are the only reason elephants are valued by poachers.
The passage does not discuss the demand and typically the demand increases with scarcity.
The passage does not state anything about poachers stealing baby elephants and only mentions the value poachers place upon the tusks.
label: B

others.main_question: Which of the following is an assumption required by the argument?
main_answers: Elephants are only valued by poachers for their tusks.
Poachers often steal baby elephants to raise in captivity and later sell them for a profit.
Elephants whose tusks have been trimmed will be unable to defend themselves against poachers.
The demand for elephant tusks will decrease as supply dwindles.

The passage does not delve into elephants defending themselves against the poachers or the importance of their ability to do so.
label: A

others.main_question: Which of the following is an assumption required by the argument?
main_answers: Elephants are only valued by poachers for their tusks.
Poachers often steal baby elephants to raise in captivity and later sell them for a profit.
Elephants whose tusks have been trimmed will be unable to defend themselves against poachers.
The demand for elephant tusks will decrease as supply dwindles.
others.target_option: The demand for elephant tusks will decrease as supply dwindles.

context: Conservationist: The risk to airplane passengers from collisions between airplanes using the airport and birds from the wildlife refuge is negligible. In the 10 years since the refuge was established, only 20 planes have been damaged in collisions with birds, and no passenger has been injured as a result of such a collision. The wildlife refuge ttherefore poses no safety risk. Pilot: You neglect to mention that 17 of those 20 collisions occurred within the past 2 years, and that the number of birds in the refuge is rapidly increasing. As the number of collisions between birds and airplanes increases, so does the likelihood that at least one such collision will result in passenger injuries.
question: What evidence does the pilot provide to refute the conservationist's argument that is not based on the accuracy of the figures cited?
answers: The pilot doesn't dispute the figures, but does point out the missing context of the figures
The conservationist suggests that the bird population is constant, which isn't true and a significant piece of information
The pilot is referencing a specific situation and isn't making a universal statement about all situations
The pilot discredits the figures, but doesn't address any moral principle, which in any case they may or may not share
label: A

others.main_question: The pilot counters the conservationist by
main_answers: disputing the accuracy of the figures cited by the conservationist
discrediting the moral principle on which the conservationist's argument is based
attempting to show that the conservationist's description of the facts is misleading
asserting that dangerous situations inevitably become more dangerous with the passage of time
others.target_option: disputing the accuracy of the figures cited by the conservationist

context: Sasha: Handwriting analysis should be banned in court as evidence of a person' s character: handwriting analysts called as witnesses habitually exaggerate the reliability of their analyses. Gregory: You are right that the current use of handwriting analysis as evidence is problematic. But this problem exists only because there is no licensing board to set professional standards and thus deter irresponsible analysts from making exaggerated claims. When such a board is established, however, handwriting analysis by licensed practitioners will be a legitimate courtroom tool for character assessment.
question: What is the basis for Gregory's defense of a principle by restricting the class to which it is to be applied in response to Sasha's argument?
answers: Gregory does not use any evidence in his claim, just assumptions.
Gregory is agreeing with Sasha and provides a situation where this analysis could be trusted.
Gregory states that if there was some quality control that this method of analysis could be trusted.
None of the above choices
label: C

He identifies a self-contradictory statement in Sasha's argument.
He abstracts a general principle from specific evidence.

context: Some educators have had remarkable success with an unusual approach to science education. For example, a physics lesson on the properties of waves might begin by plucking guitar strings. After observing the strings vibrate, students would begin to apply names to the phenomena they had witnessed, such as frequency and amplitude. Only after fully understanding these real-life concepts would they begin to apply abstract terms and equations to the phenomena.
question: How does the example illustrate the principle that familiarity with phenomena facilitates the learning of more formal treatments of these phenomena?
answers: Learning abstract concepts and then observing phenomena related to the concept forms a building block for full understanding.
Students can learn without observation, but it is through observation that they better understand the application of the terms.
Students learn best when teachers appeal to the interests of their students in the service of demonstrating the application of an abstract concept, otherwise its merely amusement.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following principles is best illustrated by the example above?
main_answers: Familiarity with phenomena facilitates the learning of more formal treatments of these phenomena.
Students are unable to form abstract concepts concerning phenomena until they become familiar with these phenomena.
Students will understand abstract terms only if they are applicable to phenomena they have observed.
Students learn best when teachers appeal to the interests of their students.
others.target_option: Familiarity with phenomena facilitates the learning of more formal treatments of these phenomena.

context: Environmentalist: The United Kingdom recently instituted a law requiring that foods containing genetically altered ingredients be labeled accordingly. Food producers, fearing that consumers would understand the labels as warnings and thus avoid their products, rushed to rid those products of genetically altered ingredients. Other countries contemplating such labeling should ttherefore refrain, because many crops are genetically altered to be pest resistant; loss of demand for these genetically altered crops would necessitate production alternatives, all of which are dangerous and pesticide intensive.
question: What is the basis for the environmentalist's argument not depending on the assumption that countries that institute new food labeling regulations often experience a change in consumer eating habits?
answers: The argument made not claims about consumers eating habits.
The argument claims that manufactures were concerned about consumers misunderstanding labels, but does not say if it supports it.
The argument makes no claims on if the products were actually consumed less due to the warnings.
The argument uses the actions of United Kingdom food producers to warn against law changes in other countries.
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the environmentalist's argument depends?
main_answers: Countries that institute new food labeling regulations often experience a change in consumer eating habits.

The reactions of food producers in other countries to laws requiring labeling of foods containing genetically altered ingredients are likely to be similar to the reactions of food producers in the United Kingdom.
Warning labels on food products have proven to be effective in reducing consumption of those products.
In general, people interpret labels stating that some food ingredients are genetically altered as warnings.
others.target_option: Countries that institute new food labeling regulations often experience a change in consumer eating habits.

context: At the end of the year, Wilson' s Department Store awards free merchandise to its top salespeople. When presented with the fact that the number of salespeople receiving these awards has declined markedly over the past fifteen years, the newly appointed president of the company responded, "In that case, since our award criterion at present is membership in the top third of our sales force, we can also say that the number of salespeople passed over for these awards has similarly declined. "
question: Why does the company president's conclusion not require the assumption that Wilson's calculates its salespeople's sales figures in the same way as it did fifteen years ago?
answers: Since the award recipients have been on decline for 15 years it must necessarily follow that for the author's conclusion to be reached the criterion for selection must be the same as well over that time period.
Hiring policy and the number of employees does not directly relate to how many of those employees could have earned an award.
The passage references the top third of the sales force as a population and this does not rely on how their sales figures are derived, merely how many qualify for an award.
Since the number of salespeople passed over for the award has decreased it would not make logical sense that more salespeople are available to earn the award.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption that would allow the company president's conclusion to be properly drawn?
main_answers: Wilson's calculates its salespeople's sales figures in the same way as it did fifteen years ago.
Policies at Wilson's with regard to hiring salespeople have not become more lax over the past fifteen years.
The number of salespeople at Wilson's has increased over the past fifteen years.
The criterion used by Wilson's for selecting its award recipients has remained the same for the past fifteen years.
others.target_option: Wilson's calculates its salespeople's sales figures in the same way as it did fifteen years ago.

context: Jane: According to an article in this newsmagazine, children' s hand-eye coordination suffers when they spend a great amount of time watching television. Ttherefore, we must restrict the amount of time Jacqueline and Mildred are allowed to watch television. Alan: Rubbish! The article says that only children under three are affected in that way. Jacqueline is ten and Mildred is eight. Ttherefore, we need not restrict their television viewing.
question: Explain why Alan's argument against Jane's conclusion does not make the error of relying on the same source that Jane cited in support of her conclusion.
answers: The article is more concerned with the perception of the risk, rather than how much risk was actually occurring.
Alan only shows that Jane's conclusion is flawed, which does not necessarily prove his to be correct.
The source of Alan's argument may be the same without nullifying its veracity.
People can still worry a lot about taking a particular risk, even if they believe the actual chances of something bad happening are very low.
label: C

others.main_question: Alan's argument against Jane's conclusion makes which one of the following errors in reasoning?
main_answers: It relies on the same source that Jane cited in support of her conclusion.
It confuses undermining an argument in support of a given conclusion with showing that the conclusion itself is false.
It fails to distinguish the consequences of a certain practice from the causes of the practice.
It makes an irrelevant appeal to an authority.
others.target_option: It relies on the same source that Jane cited in support of her conclusion.

context: In Malsenia sales of classical records are soaring. The buyers responsible for this boom are quite new to classical music and were drawn to it either by classical scores from television commercials or by theme tunes introducing major sports events on television. Audiences at classical concerts, however, are continually shrinking in Malsenia. It can be concluded from this that the new Malsenian converts to classical music, having initially experienced this music as recorded music, are most comfortable with classical music as recorded music and really have no desire to hear live performances.
question: Why does the argument not assume that the classical records available in Malsenia are, for the most part, not recordings of actual public concerts?
answers: The argument is concerned only with the existence of life (intelligent or otherwise) beyond the Earth, not on the existence of intelligence per se.
The argument is founded on the absence of evidence of ANY life, with no definition of that concept being given.
The passage makes no suggestion about where the classical records were recorded.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: The argument assumes which one of the following?
main_answers: Classical concerts in Malsenia are not limited to music that is readily available on recordings.
The classical records available in Malsenia are, for the most part, not recordings of actual public concerts.
To sell well in Malsenia, a classical record must include at least one piece familiar from television.
The number of classical concerts performed in Malsenia has not decreased in response to smaller audiences.
others.target_option: The classical records available in Malsenia are, for the most part, not recordings of actual public concerts.

context: A recent study of perfect pitch -- the ability to identify the pitch of an isolated musical note -- found that a high percentage of people who have perfect pitch are related to someone else who has it. Among those without perfect pitch, the percentage was much lower. This shows that having perfect pitch is a consequence of genetic factors.
question: How does the fact that people who have relatives with perfect pitch generally receive no more musical training than do others strengthen the argument?
answers: The passage only talks about people's tendency to have perfect pitch if they are related to someone else that does, nothing about choosing it as a career.
The passage does not mention anything about the researchers having perfect pitch.

The passage alludes to the fact that if you are related to someone with perfect pitch you are more likely to have it already, meaning that you would have to train less to accomplish the same as with someone without perfect pitch.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?
main_answers: People who have relatives with perfect pitch generally receive no more musical training than do others.
All of the researchers conducting the study had perfect pitch.
People with perfect pitch are more likely than others to choose music as a career.
People with perfect pitch are more likely than others to make sure that their children receive musical training.
others.target_option: People who have relatives with perfect pitch generally receive no more musical training than do others.

context: Advertisement: Anyone who thinks moisturizers are not important for beautiful skin should consider what happens to the earth, the skin of the world, in time of drought. Without regular infusions of moisture the ground becomes lined and cracked and its lush liveliness fades away. Thus your skin, too, should be protected from the ravages caused by lack of moisture; give it the protection provided by regular infusions of Dewyfresh, the drought-defying moisturizer.
question: What is the basis for concluding that the Dewyfresh advertisement exhibits an error of reasoning by relying on an analogy between two things that are insufficiently alike in the respects in which they would have to be alike for the conclusion to be supported?
answers: Both the process of infusion and the product of the process achieve the similar effect of moisturizing the ground or skin.
The earth's crust being lined and cracked does not occur at the same time a human's skin would be.
The Earth's crust is insufficiently alike to the skin of a human being in respects to requiring moisture to draw any conclusions.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: The Dewyfresh advertisement exhibits which one of the following errors of reasoning?
main_answers: It relies on an analogy between two things that are insufficiently alike in the respects in which they would have to be alike for the conclusion to be supported.
It treats something that is necessary for bringing about a state of affairs as something that is sufficient to bring about that state of affairs.
It treats the fact that two things regularly occur together as proof that there is a single thing that its the cause of them both.
It relies on the ambiguity of the term "infusion, "which can designate either a process or the product of that process.
others.target_option: It relies on an analogy between two things that are insufficiently alike in the respects in which they would have to be alike for the conclusion to be supported.

context: Salesperson: When a salesperson is successful, it is certain that that person has been in sales for at least three years. This is because to succeed as a salesperson, one must first establish a strong client base, and studies have shown that anyone who spends at least three years developing a client base can eventually make a comfortable living in sales.
question: Why is the reasoning in the salesperson's argument not considered to be flawed for not taking into account the possibility that a salesperson who has not spent three years developing a client base may not succeed in sales?
answers: Taking longer than three years to develop a strong client base does not disagree with the author, as the claim is anyone spending three or more years developing a client base.
If a sales person who hasn't been developing a client base for three years yet does not succeed, this would support the author's argument instead of criticizing it.
If there are people who don't require three years to develop a strong client base it would contradict the claim that anyone succeeding in sales requires at least three years developing a client base.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The reasoning in the salesperson's argument is vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that it fails to consider the possibility that
main_answers: it takes longer than three years for a salesperson to develop a strong client base
a salesperson who has not spent three years developing a client base may not succeed in sales
some salespeople require fewer than three years in which to develop a strong client base
salespeople who have spent three years developing a client base might not yet be successful in sales
others.target_option: a salesperson who has not spent three years developing a client base may not succeed in sales
